webTitle: Brady in court for right to end life

fields.headline: Brady in court for right to end life
fields.standfirst: Hindley 'tried to join police' after first killing
fields.trailText: The Moors murderer Ian Brady will launch a landmark high court battle today for the right to starve himself to death. He claims Ashworth hospital has no legal right to force-feed him by tube and foil the hunger strike he began 152 days ago.
fields.body:
The Moors murderer Ian Brady will launch a landmark high court battle today for the right to starve himself to death. He claims Ashworth hospital has no legal right to force-feed him by tube and foil the hunger strike he began 152 days ago.

Brady, 61, is expected to attend part of the four-day hearing, which will be held in private amid strict security at the Queen Elizabeth II court complex in Liverpool.

He will be brought under heavy police escort for his first court appearance since he was convicted of killing three children at Chester assizes in 1966. In 1987 he confessed to the murders of two other youngsters.

The case raises complex legal and medical issues about the right of doctors to force-feed adults against their will. The normal rule under English law is that an adult who is competent - mentally capable - of understanding the consequences and weighing up the factors involved, may refuse any treatment, including force-feeding.

The House of Lords confirmed in the case of the Hillsborough survivor Tony Bland that artificial feeding is a form of medical treatment.

Being mentally ill, as Brady is, does not deprive an individual of the right to take treatment decisions. The question is whether he is capable of taking that particular decision at that time.

In the past, the high court held that a paranoid schizophrenic in Broadmoor, with delusions that he was a famous surgeon, was competent to decide he did not want his leg amputated and banned doctors from operating without his consent. The court of appeal ruled in 1994 that a woman compulsorily detained in a psychiatric hospital under the mental health act could be force-fed even though she was competent to refuse. But the court made it clear that this finding was limited to patients detained under that specific act and noted that force-feeding a competent adult would not be lawful in common law.

The decision in Brady's case, which will be heard by Mr Justice Kay, is likely to come down to evidence by psychiatrists about whether or not he fully understands the nature and effects of his decision to refuse food. Brady began his hunger strike last September in protest at being moved from a relatively relaxed ward at Ashworth to a tougher one.

Robin Makin, Brady's solicitor, said: "We are content to have finally reached a court hearing which will deal with the very difficult issues regarding the force-feeding. Mr Justice Maurice Kay will deliver his judgment in a case which involves complex legal, medical and moral issues."

The court will also hear a second application by Brady, challenging the right of Ashworth to open letters between him and his solicitors.

A spokeswoman for Ashworth said: "The details of Mr Brady's case against Ashworth are confidential. Mr Brady's counsel have requested he be allowed to attend but I am unable to say whether he will be present throughout."

Brady was convicted with Myra Hindley of murdering Lesley-Anne Downey, 10, and Edward Evans, 17, and alone of murdering John Kilbridge, 12. In 1987 he and Hindley also confessed to killing two other children, Pauline Reade, 16, and Keith Bennett, 12.

Merseyside police will set up a security operation to protect Brady when he travels the 10 miles from Ashworth to the court in Liverpool city centre. A spokeswoman said: "Merseyside police have carefully planned, with Ashworth hospital, to ensure the safety of the public, the hospital staff and the patient himself."

webTitle: Hindley 'tried to join police' after first killing

fields.headline: Hindley 'tried to join police' after first killing
fields.standfirst: Brady in court for right to end life
fields.trailText: Myra Hindley applied to join the police after the first of the Moors Murders and was considered suitable for training at a preliminary interview, she has claimed in a series of letters describing her life and involvement in the killings.
fields.body:
Myra Hindley applied to join the police after the first of the Moors Murders and was considered suitable for training at a preliminary interview, she has claimed in a series of letters describing her life and involvement in the killings.

The letters, which run to well over 100,000 words, form the basis of a BBC documentary to be shown on Wednesday which is to examine her case for freedom. Last week she appealed to the House of Lords over the right of the home secretary, Jack Straw, to decide that she should die behind bars.

In her letters, which were written without payment and on the understanding that she would have no editorial control over their use, Hindley says she applied to join the police after she fell in love with a policeman called Norman.

She says the affair, lasting several months, was an attempt to end her relationship with her accomplice in the murders, Ian Brady.

Hindley claims to have met Norman when he called at her home offering to buy the van that had been used to abduct Pauline Reade, 16.

"Outside was one of the tallest, most good-looking men I'd ever seen. He said he'd come to talk to me about the van and could he come in for a few minutes?" she wrote in one of the letters.

She and Norman used to meet while she was supposed to be attending night school.

"If we'd met before Ian and I did, I knew that the love that had grown between us would have blossomed. I would have had no hesitation in marrying and having children with him."

In her letters Hindley says she wanted to leave Brady. As they worked in the same office this meant that she would have to get a new job. She visited the police training centre.

"I went to Mill Street for an interview, and was considered suitable for training, and given forms to fill in; a formal application to join the police and a list of questions to answer.

"When I told Ian what I had done he thought it was hilarious. Then he said 'join the force, you'll pick up a lot of useful information'. That made me change my mind."

As Hindley never completed her formal application to join the force, there is no written record. An officer who worked at Gorton station in Manchester in the 1960s has confirmed she was supplied with literature on a career in the police.

"She was given a number of brochures which outlined the opportunities open to a woman officer. That much is certain but it's impossible to confirm whether or not she actually went for interview."

Former Detective Chief Superintendent Geoff Knupfer, who worked on the Moors Murders inquiry in the 1980s, assessed Hindley's letters for the documentary. He said applying to join the police would not have been out of character.

"It would not be surprising had she tried something like this. She did, after all, try to join the army in an attempt to get away at an earlier stage of their relationship."

Ian Brady's former psychiatrist Malcolm MacCulloch, who has examined the letters, says they help form a real understanding of the murders.

"Examining material of this kind is extremely valuable to professionals such as myself and to society in general, because it helps us to come to an understanding of the processes which allow people to do these dreadful things."

But he said Hindley's letters must be assessed as a whole.

"The letters are, of course, only what Myra Hindley wants to write and therefore have to be approached with considerable caution. One has to look at what is there and what is missing."

Hindley was sentenced to life in 1966 for the murder of John Kilbride, 10, and Lesley Ann Downey, 12. She was also found guilty of being an accessory in the killing of Edward Evans, 17.

In 1987 she confessed that she and Brady had also abducted and murdered Pauline Reade and 10-year-old Keith Bennett.

 Modern Times: Myra Hindley is on BBC2 this Wednesday at 9pm.

webTitle: Customs faces arms-to-Iraq shame in court

fields.headline: Customs faces arms-to-Iraq shame in court
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Customs officials knew months before it prosecuted a businessman for trying to export so-called nuclear triggers to Iraq that the charges were flawed, according to hitherto secret Whitehall documents.
fields.body:
Customs officials knew months before it prosecuted a businessman for trying to export so-called nuclear triggers to Iraq that the charges were flawed, according to hitherto secret Whitehall documents.

The documents have been disclosed to Ali Daghir, of dual Iraqi-British nationality, who is suing for malicious prosecution in a lawsuit presenting customs with the prospect of renewed embarrassment over the arms-to-Iraq scandal.

They were referred to in a public hearing at the high court last week when Mr Daghir was allowed to have his case tried by a jury despite strong objections by customs lawyers.

Mr Daghir, manager of Euromac, an import-export trading company, was convicted in 1991 after a 19-month sting operation by US customs. His conviction was overturned on appeal in 1994 on the grounds that the trial judge misdirected the jury.

Customs relied on the claim that the electrical capacitors - devices which store and release electrical energy - were specially designed for use in nuclear weapons. But the trial judge told the jury they could convict if they found the equipment had any military use.

Peter Irvin, counsel for Mr Daghir, told the hearing last week that foreign office and department of trade and industry documents showed that the capacitors were, indeed, suitable for "general military use" and not, as customs told the jury, designed specifically for use in nuclear weapons.

Subsequent evidence from a UN inspection team in Iraq showed that the "triggers" had no part in Baghdad's nuclear weapons programme. The Daghir trial followed the collapse of a customs prosecution of two other businessmen allegedly involved in selling parts for the Iraqi supergun project after evidence emerged that the men had alerted Whitehall about their own suspicions which were then ignored.

Mr Irvin said that customs was "very anxious to avoid the fact that the evidence suggested the capacitors had other uses". He said: "There was pressure [on customs] to gain a prestigious conviction after the wave of publicity with prominent stories about nuclear triggers."

Margaret Thatcher had responded to Mr Daghir's arrest by writing a personal letter of congratulations to Sir Brian Unwin, then head of customs.

It is also known that when he was first arrested in early 1990, Whitehall suggested deporting Mr Daghir to Iraq, not realising he had the right to stay in Britain.

Lawrence Kormornick, his lawyer, said: "The recent disclosure of documents by the foreign office is a breakthrough. It has taken 18 months to obtain them."

He was disappointed that customs was not prepared to settle the claim through mediation. The case has already cost an estimated £400,000.

Mr Daghir, 60, said: "This case is not just about money. I want to clear my name."

Mr Kormornick is also seeking compensation for Paul Grecian, a director of Ordtec, a military engineering company, whose conviction for selling military equipment to Iraq via Jordan was quashed.

Customs, which has always denied any wrongdoing, argued against a jury trial in the Daghir case saying that the issue was no longer a matter of public importance.

fields.headline: Meet Victoria Harwood
fields.trailText: Are newspapers over? At this moment in media history, they have never been more pressed to define themselves, or done a worse job. All over the information spectrum, media audiences are fragmented, drawn to the timeliness, convenience and immediacy of cable news, and the net and the web.
fields.body:
* Jon Katz (who last week provoked a big online debate with an article on the future of the press. An extract is published at) www.slashdot.org

Are newspapers over? At this moment in media history, they have never been more pressed to define themselves, or done a worse job. All over the information spectrum, media audiences are fragmented, drawn to the timeliness, convenience and immediacy of cable news, and the net and the web.

The challenge for newspapers isn't technological. It's creative. They don't tell us things we don't know. They don't offer us good writing or strong opinion. They don't even have good comics any more. And their coverage of technology generally sucks. And profoundly so. They still don't recognise that the net is not a sex story or a business story but the biggest story of our time.

In recent years, newspapers have remained graphically impaired. They seem oblivious to the graphic revolution that has swept magazines and is spreading through the web. Papers continue to cover new media technologies and popular culture poorly, alienating young and future audiences. They have ceded good writing to magazines, publishing and websites.

Papers seem seem almost stupefyingly oblivious to the fact that they aren't in the breaking news business anymore. As the net and web spawn ferocious and idiosyncratic commentary, democratising opinion all over the country, newspapers cling to stuffy and elitist op-ed pages, where opinion is generally confined to a "left" and "right" and voice usually given to elite cliques of pundits, academics, authors and chief executives.

Technology is spawning a host of significant issues of relevance to almost everyone. How many of these stories make their way to the front pages of newspapers? Few, and then rarely. Newspapers are the scolds of the Digital Age, shrieking and clucking about a changing world (the net, the web, movies, TV shows, rap, hip-hop, kids today) like Temperance Ladies wandering into a bar.

Newspapers are also struggling to evolve definitions of culture, leisure time, recreation and amusement. Opera, classical music, hard cover books, art museums are one kind of culture. But there are new kinds - elaborate and creative gaming and video cultures, creative coding, the booming business of web architecture and design, proliferating weblogs , vast messaging systems and services like AIM and ICQ, collaborative global information-and-software sharing movements like Linux.

Few newspaper readers have even heard about these new kinds of culture. No wonder kids- especially geek and nerd kids - have abandoned papers in droves.

webTitle: Relief for battered CDU in local poll

fields.headline: Relief for battered CDU in local poll
fields.standfirst: German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Germany's conservatives last night emerged from their first trial by ballot since the start of their illegal-funding crisis in better shape than they had any reason to hope.
fields.body:
Germany's conservatives last night emerged from their first trial by ballot since the start of their illegal-funding crisis in better shape than they had any reason to hope.

Exit polls and first results from an election in the northern region of Schleswig-Holstein indicated that, in the midst of the worst crisis in its history, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) had been abandoned by less than 1% of the electorate there.

The forecast gave a big boost to the CDU's candidate, Volker Rühe, who is also one of two frontrunners for the unenviable job of leading the party out of the mire. Since the results suggested that the Social Democrats would continue in office locally, Mr Rühe - the choice of the CDU's more traditional wing - will be free to pursue the leadership without the distraction of having to form a regional administration.

Though predominantly rural, Schleswig-Holstein is not typical of Germany as a whole, and yesterday's results could encourage the CDU to start counter-attacking its critics on the grounds that the public cares less about sleaze than the media or its political rivals.

The party has been steeped in trouble since last November when it emerged that its former leader, the ex-chancellor Helmut Kohl, ran a network of slush funds to finance its operations.

Yesterday's showing by the CDU was a long way short of the 10% lead it was showing locally in opinion polls before the scandal broke. It was also fractionally below the target set by Mr Rühe who, perhaps rashly, confided to party colleagues that he hoped to equal the CDU's tally of four years earlier.

A calculation based on exit polling and initial counts gave the Christian Democrats 36.5% of the vote - 0.7% less than in 1996 and 6% less than the Social Democrats.

But it was still a convincing performance under the circumstances. Beaming at the television cameras, Mr Rühe refused to confirm that he was an aspirant for the party leadership, but said that he would certainly not have been if support for the CDU had slipped into the low 30s.

"Clearly we have lost but we have averted a collapse and stabilised the vote," he said.

Mr Rühe was the party's general secretary during the period in which much of the cash was laundered, but he has denied knowledge of the illegal financing and nothing has emerged to contradict this.

His main rival for the leadership is the party's general secretary, Angela Merkel, who has attracted support from those who want a radical break with the past. But her liberal views on abortion and other social issues are unpopular. "Volker Rühe did a fantastic job," she said last night. "The CDU is coming out of the trough."

webTitle: Autumn bill planned to curb arms trade

fields.headline: Autumn bill planned to curb arms trade
fields.standfirst: Arms trade faces curbsLabour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to clamp down on British arms traffickers and brokers as part of far-reaching reforms aimed at cleaning up the murkiest parts of the weapons trade.
fields.body:
The government is to clamp down on British arms traffickers and brokers as part of far-reaching reforms aimed at cleaning up the murkiest parts of the weapons trade.

In the biggest change to the arms trade envisaged by any government since the second world war, a bill is to be introduced in the Queen's speech in the autumn to bring unregulated traders within the law for the first time.

And in a separate but potentially more fundamental reform, the notorious government body that subsidises the arms trade, the export credit guarantee department (ECGD), is to be completely overhauled. "This is where the real filth in the arms trade is to be found," a ministerial source said.

The changes could reduce the string of dubious arms deals that have embarrassed the government, including recent sales to Indonesia, Pakistan and Zimbabwe.

Arms trafficking and brokering is currently unregulated. Anyone can set up an office and broker deals that would see weapons from eastern Europe heading to the war-torn countries of Africa and Asia.

Figures for the number of companies operating in Britain at present are estimated at between 150 and 200.

The source said: "This is the unacceptable face of the arms industry and at last we are moving to ban these activities."

Two reviews were launched last year by the department of trade and industry. A white paper on the arms trade was published and submissions were invited. A fundamental review of the "mission and status" of the ECGD was also ordered.

The results of both reviews will not be published until the spring but the Guardian has learned that sweeping changes have been agreed.

The key proposals are:

 A bill to license arms trafficking and brokering, making it a criminal offence to operate without such a licence. The legislation will apply to UK citizens operating overseas as well as at home.

 The bill will implement the recommendations of Lord Scott, who carried out the inquiry into the arms to Iraq scandal. He advocated tighter control of arms exports, claiming that the existing legislation, which dated back to 1939, was wholly inadequate.

 The ECGD, which comes under the wing of the department of trade and industry, is to be shaken up. At present, between a quarter and a half of its £3bn budget goes to arms companies. Under the proposed changes, the arms element will be diluted, switching the emphasis to civilian development projects, such as building electricity and water supplies.

 Instead of three or four big defence and aerospace companies winning the bulk of ECGD money, most will go to smaller and medium-sized companies, especially those in the regions.

 The ECGD's advisory committee, which is dominated by businessmen, is to be scrapped because of fears of a conflict of interest.

 Environmental screening criteria are to be built into its mission statement. The ECGD is at present involved in controversy for providing guarantees to a British company involved in the Ilisu dam project in Turkey.

webTitle: If your newsroom plans don't include multi-media, you may as well go ahead and take an axe to them

fields.headline: If your newsroom plans don't include multi-media, you may as well go ahead and take an axe to them
fields.standfirst: Mono-media is dead, says  Nora Paul  and any attempt to ignore that fact is tantamount to journalistic malpractice. What are you going to do about it?
fields.trailText: Think about this for a moment. As leaders of your news organisations there are three areas in which you have to provide the vision, the support, and the enthusiasm for change. Are you achieving that? New technologies, new resources, new products, and a new customer base are changing so many aspects of journalists' work. Keeping an eye on and preparing for the new while building on the well-honed traditions of journalistic practice are the challenges for newsroom leaders.
fields.body:
Think about this for a moment. As leaders of your news organisations there are three areas in which you have to provide the vision, the support, and the enthusiasm for change. Are you achieving that? New technologies, new resources, new products, and a new customer base are changing so many aspects of journalists' work. Keeping an eye on and preparing for the new while building on the well-honed traditions of journalistic practice are the challenges for newsroom leaders.

The three areas of news media most affected by new media are:

*News-gathering and reporting.

*New products.

*News customers.

As Dan Bradley, the vice-president of WFLA-TV in Tampa, Florida, says: "Stop thinking of yourself as a broadcast journalist. In the uncertain digital world we are entering, your platform of distribution . . . will have little relevance."

When the big story breaks, how is your team prepared to tap into online resources to get the background it needs? When covering an on-going story, how is your team able to see what others are saying, to find new angles and perspectives? When doing enterprise, how is your team finding new and fresh ideas, covering the uncovered? When bringing "voice" to the story, how is your team locating people with expertise and those with experience?

If the resources of the web are not part of the answer to those questions it borders on journalistic malpractice. The internet is where stories are breaking, where background is provided, where experts are located.

Computer-assisted reporting techniques are under-used in television newsrooms. Using spreadsheets to compile and analyse data, developing databases to track trends, and working with mapping programs that can reveal concentrations of occurrences provide powerful new storytelling techniques. They have the potential to uncover untold stories, to wrest away the power of interpretation of data from the officials, to bust popular perceptions, or to confirm anecdotal evidence.

What kind of journalism are you doing in your newsroom - reactive or investigative?

Think of it in terms of four key opportunities:

*There is now a more level playing field - anyone anywhere has the same access to resources.

*There is cheaper access to resources which only well-funded newsrooms had in the past.

*Take the lead, don't just follow others' coverage - using news alerts, mining sites for new stories, doing original data analysis.

*Keep talented and energised journalists by providing them with resources.

And six key questions:

*What access do reporters/producers have to the internet? Is it a resource at their desktops or is access limited to a few stations in the newsroom?

*What kind of training have reporters/producers received?

*What resources are available to help them find good sites (an intranet, a researcher)?

*What techniques are used to facilitate news finding (filters or personalised news services)? Are all the advanced techniques of research and personalised services understood and being used?

*What is the budget line for accounts to "for-fee" information services? Not everything is free on the web. How will subscription services be managed?

*How are successes promoted? Are examples of innovative research and enterprise rewarded?

To put it simply, mono-media is dead. The creative product of your newsroom is going out via multiple platforms. The packaging of the news product has to be multipurpose - for broadcast, the web, the cell phone, the bathroom mirror. Soon the potential of high definition television (HDTV) [providing pictures with higher resolution and more information] delivery of news will bring new opportunities and issues.

*How are you preparing your staff to anticipate and embrace the potential of multi-platform delivery of the news?

*What is your own attitude toward these new technologies? HDTV has been referred to, disparagingly, as high deficit TV. How might the development of plans for HDTV go if your team thinks of it as hot damn TV. While developing plans with a sense of reality is critical, don't stymie creative R&D in the early stages when enthusiasm and idea generation is essential.

Some more issues:

*Audience can get the news they want when they want it in the form they want.

*Create the product line that people use, rely on.

*Provide more depth, additional material, "give-me-more" features to customers.

*Re-engineer the newsroom to think of information in multiple forms, prepare for the future (which is now).

*Realise that there is a potential for collaboration of content, specialise in local audio/video stock.

And more questions:

Training: do your journalists know how to create multimedia, interactive, non-linear news pack ages? What skill sets will be required to think in a 3D information space?

Collaboration/integration: how is the "new products" unit operating - as part of the news team, as a separate unit with little interaction with the news team? How is this helping or hindering efforts to re-engineer the newsroom?

Digital asset management: as things go digital, are you archiving for re-use? How can you tap into resources of the past to make up the current news package? How do you control and manage various media resources?

Staffing: What kind of reporters/ researchers will you need to create the elements of the multiple media/interactive news product? What will the positions in the multiple media newsroom be?

The "Us to Them" model of television producers and viewers is dying. New news consumers will expect to have control on many aspects of the newscast: when they watch it, from what angle, the depth of the coverage, the type of news they want to see. Time-shifting, multicasting, camera vantage point selection - all will provide the viewer with more power over the product. News consumers will have new means of communicating with you about the news, and will expect a response.

If you look at the top 50 websites in terms of traffic you will find out a lot about what people want to do online. They want to communicate with each other. They want to create their own pages. They want to play games, buy things, find things. How are the products you are creating helping them do those things? The primary mission, being a credible and reliable source of news and information, has not changed, but it does need to be augmented to satisfy the expectations of the new news customer.

There are a thousand opportunities out there:

*Get a better sense of the news consumers' appetites and reactions.

*Track actual use of the news consumers' behaviour.

*Create a dialogue with the news consumer.

And a thousand questions:

*Do your reporters all have email addresses?

*Is there a public forum area on the website? Do you offer interactive features on the website?

*Are users of your site able to customise to meeet their needs and interests?

*How easily can people find things on your site? Do you facilitate learning or frustrate it?

Think about it, the future is now.

webTitle: Sharif defence lawyers quit over threat of reporting ban

fields.headline: Sharif defence lawyers quit over threat of reporting ban
fields.standfirst: Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: Two of the lawyers representing Pakistan's deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, at his trial stepped down from the case yesterday, complaining about decisions made by the judge.
fields.body:
Two of the lawyers representing Pakistan's deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, at his trial stepped down from the case yesterday, complaining about decisions made by the judge.

Ijaz Batalvi and Khwaja Sultan, the two leading lawyers for the defence, criticised a decision by the judge presiding over the anti-terrorist court to consider imposing a reporting ban when Mr Sharif gives evidence.

"The whole world for the last two months heard the prosecution malign and scandalise Mian Nawaz Sharif and now when it was his turn to tell the truth he has been asked to shut up," said Mr Batalvi. "To say the least, this is not justice. We have decided to withdraw from the case."

Mr Sharif was overthrown in a military coup on October 12 and is now on trial at the court in Karachi together with his brother Shahbaz and five former senior government officials.

They have pleaded not guilty to charges of hijacking, kidnapping, attempted murder and terrorism and face the death penalty if convicted.

Mr Sharif was due to give evidence this week at the start of the defence case but prosecutors argued that the hearing should be held in private, saying the former prime minister's evidence could breach national security.

Judge Rehmat Hussain Jafri ruled on Friday that he would decide which parts of Mr Sharif's testimony could be reported after the former prime minister had spoken in open court and handed in written statements.

Mr Batalvi, one of Pakistan's most senior lawyers, said he believed the judge had stepped beyond the law in making his decision but said the defence was unable to appeal against the ruling under the terms of the anti-terrorism court. "The law has not given him any such authority nor has the law fixed any parameters by which the statement of the accused can be scissored by the judge," he said.

Mr Batalvi represented the prosecution in another trial of a former Pakistani prime minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was sentenced to death and hanged in April 1979 under the dictatorship of General Zia ul-Haq.

Mr Sharif was detained immediately after the October coup but a series of setbacks for Pakistan's new military regime has delayed his trial.

A high court judge refused to hear the case in January, complaining about the presence of intelligence agents in the court room, and later that month all the country's senior judges were ordered to swear new oaths of loyalty to the military regime.

There are still seven lawyers working in the defence team.

fields.headline: Dethroning the market
fields.trailText: A tax base on the move. Growing resistance by the rich. A need to educate the electorate. Your leader (February 25) was an excellent start. But why are you so coy?
fields.body:
A tax base on the move. Growing resistance by the rich. A need to educate the electorate. Your leader (February 25) was an excellent start. But why are you so coy? I want the Guardian to be out in front in the coming economic rethink now the free market ideology that has prevailed for 20 years is being knocked from its pedestal. I have just finished former Bishop of Durham, David Jenkins's book, Market Whys & Human Wherefores, which devastatingly exposes the false promises of market assumptions and describes the nightmare threatening us if the required radical rethink isn't under way soon.

Yes, we're going to need higher taxes. But the needed debate is more far reaching. As Jenkins puts it: "The central task is to develop a second wealth-creating system which will recapture trading and productivity as a humane activity for all human beings and as a sustaining activity for the future of the world."
Revd Nicholas Bradbury
Rector of Horfield, Bristol
Nicbradbry@aol.com

 Tony Blair still doesn't understand, does he? The flagship of the Tory years was their implementation of a grossly unfair tax system - the shifting of the burden from the well-off to the not-so-well-off. New Labour, after three years, has done nothing to move towards a more progressive and fairer tax system. Even removing the ceiling from NI payments would be a move in the right direction.
Terry Middleton
Barnsley

 You miss one way of combining the objectives you cite, without threat from global competition. The cap on the council tax banding was a disgraceful piece of Tory gerrymandering to maintain the reverse distributive function of the poll tax for the richer Tory voters. Under a Labour government it is even more absurd that Sandringham or Longleat are in the same tax band as a semi in a moderately prosperous part of London. It is reasonable to reintroduce some measure of progressive taxation on the wealthiest, who are now sheltered by the tax and NI system. Even the prospect of the addition of, say, two new bands would cool the housing market, and draw some additional contribution from resident foreigners.

This should be coupled with a "quick and dirty" rateable value revaluation, based on postcodes and current bands, to tide over until a full re-rating is completed.
George Sudbury
Winchester
geosud@compuserve.com

 Sadly, you are probably right that increasing taxation on share deals here would simply drive more dealing offshore. One partial way around the problems is the Tobin tax, levying perhaps one quarter of 1% on currency speculation - raising enough to meet the UN's estimate of the costs of ending poverty in the developing world. Such a tax would need to be applied globally, though, and the chancellor who made so much of his commitment to debt relief seems little interested in pushing for such a solution.
James Mackenzie
Edinburgh

 You claim that craven fear of revenue targets - "where failure can mean a reduced pay packet" - might be one reason why customs officers were hell bent on ruining the small business economy (War stories, February 25). What tosh! The performance pay system has no effect on the judgment of our members in carrying out the law. In a highly competitive world the efforts of the VAT inspector may be all that is between most small businesses and the wall; ask any dry cleaner who is being undercut by a non-tax paying competitor.
Frank McLaughlin
Public & Commercial Services Union

fields.headline: Liberals led the way
fields.trailText: You maintain that "it surely would have been the Liberals who had to leave the stage" (Leader, February 26). I think this assumes too much. It is the idea, the policy, which persuades the public to support the party and therefore "makes" the party, and not the reverse.
fields.body:
You maintain that "it surely would have been the Liberals who had to leave the stage" (Leader, February 26). I think this assumes too much. It is the idea, the policy, which persuades the public to support the party and therefore "makes" the party, and not the reverse. Hence until the Labour party adopted "liberal" policies it was likely to stay in semi-permanent opposition: by "liberal" policies I mean those which retain the support of the broad centre.

The tragedy of the century is that the long obsession with clause four meant that billions were spent and years wasted on nationalising elements of our infrastructure which were then denationalised by the Tories. The Tories, whose general policy was to do nothing, and do it very well, understood English conservatism, and retained broad support.

The Liberal party's non-doctrinaire and pragmatic approach as a progressive party would not have wasted so much time and money. It would have carried out most of the measures you mention to Labour's credit - do not ignore the radical nature of those measures carried out by the 1906 government. We would have been in Europe years earlier and have the euro by now and not be dithering over freedom of information, jury trial and what Mr Murdoch thinks. But then it is all about "if", isn't it?
SG Richards
Much Wenlock, Shropshire

Hence until the Labour party adopted "liberal" policies it was likely to stay in semi-permanent opposition: by "liberal" policies I mean those which retain the support of the broad centre. The tragedy of the century is that the long obsession with clause four meant that billions were spent and years wasted on nationalising elements of our infrastructure which were then denationalised by the Tories. The Tories, whose general policy was to do nothing, and do it very well, understood English conservatism, and retained broad support. The Liberal party's non-doctrinaire and pragmatic approach as a progressive party would not have wasted so much time and money. It would have carried out most of the measures you mention to Labour's credit - do not ignore the radical nature of those measures carried out by the 1906 government. We would have been in Europe years earlier and have the euro by now and not be dithering over freedom of information, jury trial and what Mr Murdoch thinks. But then it is all about "if", isn't it? SG Richards Much Wenlock, Shropshire

fields.headline: Labour's two parties
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour party has a peculiar relationship with its history. It is both drawn by its symbolism but repelled by its significance; keen to establish an emotional link with its past but reluctant to admit any structural relationship with it. New Labour is still defined not so much by what it actually is, but by what it has abandoned.
fields.body:
Junior minister Stephen Timms rose to address the Labour party faithful in Norwich on Saturday framed by history and proclamation. To his right a banner for the Amalgamated Engineering Union announcing "Unity is Strength"; to his left a display of the early labour movement in Norfolk presenting a "rousing speech" made during a strike at Grout's silk works in Great Yarmouth; behind him a banner for the Norwich Labour party stating simply "Forward with Socialism".

With talk of building a society which is "modern and decent" through a "dynamic enterprise economy", by balancing "prosperity and fairness", Timms, treasury financial secretary, reassured many but inspired few. Then the crowd of around 60 members went off into different rooms, clutching brown envelopes, to discuss the policy documents sent by Millbank.

It is the eve of Labour's 100th birthday. The keynote speaker has wound up to polite applause. Nobody has mentioned the trade unions which set the party up or uttered the word "socialism". There will be discussions in small groups behind closed doors, and there has been no open, public debate.

The Labour party has a peculiar relationship with its history. It is both drawn by its symbolism but repelled by its significance; keen to establish an emotional link with its past but reluctant to admit any structural relationship with it. New Labour - that mixture of PR jingle and political construct - is still defined not so much by what it actually is, but by what it has abandoned.

The fact that the party has changed is, of course, both welcome and inevitable. It started the last century with two MPs and ended with the largest majority in its parliamentary history. All that has come between, from the birth, life and death of the Soviet Union to the globalisation of capital, via feminism, the ozone layer and the end of empire, has had a profound and fundamental effect on society that must be reflected in a party that wishes to lead it.

But for the best part of the century the fundamental tensions within the party have remained consistent. On the one hand there have been those who wanted to use the party's base among the working class as a vehicle for radical, social change; on the other those who wished to extend its appeal so that it could use its parliamentary presence to gradually negotiate reforms. In a sense it has been a phoney war. The two camps have not always been in conflict, have shared many basic values and in the broader scheme of things have always had more in common than divides them. But at times of crisis or opportunity the representatives of either side - be it Bevan and Gaitskell, Healey and Benn or Livingstone and Dobson - will square up for a conflict which threatens to split the party asunder.

"In other parts of Europe these two traditions have been the basis, broadly speaking, for two separate parties; social democratic and communist," wrote Hilary Wainwright in her book, Labour: A Tale of Two Parties. "In Britain, by contrast, the Labour party has united the majority of each tradition in one party."

For the most part these traditions have expressed themselves not so much as a battle of policies but of axioms. There is no point in having power unless you are going to use it to improve the livelihoods of those who support you, say one camp; you cannot do anything for those who support you unless you are in power, say the other. The arbitrator between these two truisms has traditionally been the membership which, through internal democracy, has always made its voice clear about how much its thirst for change might be quenched by the chance to taste power. Failure to hear this voice has been punished with low turnouts and a sharp decline in envelope stuffers, door- knockers and telephone canvassers as people who feel their support has been taken for granted or ignored stay at home. The result can be electoral defeat.

"Obedient ministers who tramp through lobbies strange to all they have ever said may preserve themselves from the prime minister's sacking," said Lena Jeger MP back in 1968. "But they do not protect themselves from a sacking in their constituencies, a sacking which may well not be deliberate but may come just because nobody turns up to drive the loudspeaker van."

Back at Norwich Labour club, the local trades council are showing a video about the Burston village school strike. In 1914 Annie Higdon, a teacher, and her husband Tom, her assistant, took on the local Norfolk clergy and squierarchy after their school was closed down by the authorities. The two socialists defied the law and opened up a strike school nearby which became a cause célèbre for the entire labour and trade union movement.

Through the grainy stills and personal accounts of pensioners who were pupils at the school emerges the glue that keeps these competing currents within the labour movement together - struggle. The arguing, campaigning and organising which forces progressive change - however modest - in favour of the many and challenges the power structure which serves the interests of the privileged few. "The Labour party is a moral crusade or it is nothing," said Harold Wilson in 1962.

With one foot in and one foot out of parliament the Labour party has, for the past century, provided an imperfect but constant conduit for the struggles taking place outside to be translated into legislative reform within it. Sometimes, as with the repeal of the poll tax or the miners strike of 1974, it was action on the streets that made the crucial difference. For the introduction of the NHS and the welfare state, the parliamentary route proved most effective. Although the two strategies have often appeared contradictory and antagonistic they have most often been complementary and symbiotic.

Or at least they were. For in this key sense Blairism does represent a break from the past. By distancing himself from the unions and sidelining internal democracy he leaves a vacuum between himself and the rest of the movement. What you are left with is not a campaigning party underpinned by the experience of struggle but an electoral machine driven by crude, majoritarian impulses. He represents not the architect of a social democratic party on the European model but of an American-style Democratic party. The resignation of Peter Kilfoyle and the breadth of support for Livingstone's independent candidacy suggest that concern over this goes beyond the traditional left.

And while none of this should detract from Blair's considerable achievements (like the minimum wage and devolution) or excuse his mistakes (like the harsh asylum regulations and his failure to deliver on freedom of information) it does present him with a vital problem which he needs to address within the next 18 months. His desire to broaden his support outside the party is eating away at his base within it; he risks becoming the head of a government without a body of activists to support him.

fields.headline: In support of the indefensible
fields.standfirst:
The block vote is a necessary evil. All we can do is make it as democratic as possible and hope no one makes a fuss.

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The block vote is a necessary evil. All we can do is make it as democratic as possible and hope no one makes a fuss.
fields.body:
There is very little that you can teach me about Labour party democracy. And my knowledge has been gained from hard experience.

In the 1983 leadership election, it was the 12-man national executive of what was then the Amalgamated Engineering Union which decided how the AEU should cast its million votes. Abandon all suspicion that my implied criticism springs from resentment at rejection. The AEU voted for me. At the time, I was touring the country demanding "one member, one vote". So my gratitude was tinged with embarrassment.

I have known, at least since 1954, that the union block vote is indefensible. That was the year of Labour's German rearmament debate. A conference resolution - which now seems even more absurd than it did at the time - sought to prohibit Germany from raising an army and joining Nato.

The nonsense was defeated by 200,000 votes after the Woodworkers Union was persuaded to change its mind, break its mandate and support the leadership. I decided then and there that manipulating the block vote was hard to defend even in a good cause - hard to defend but essential.

A block vote of some sort is inevitable - at least as long as Labour maintains the trade union links which were forged a hundred years ago. Polling individual trade unionists would be unacceptably complicated and expensive. Some trade unions are not sure who their members are and thousands of trade unionists do not realise that they are counted among the legions of Labour. Yet somehow the trade union voice has to be heard. All that the party can do is make the process as democratic as possible and hope that nobody makes a fuss about its manifold injustices.

Over the last year, trade unions - first the Transport and General in Wales and then the Engineers and Electricians in London - have gone out of their way to expose the system's innate inadequacy. If the Welsh T&G had wanted to undermine Alun Michael's position in the Welsh assembly, it would have behaved exactly as it did in the mistaken belief that imposing him on a resentful rank and file would guarantee his acceptance as Wales' first secretary.

And if Ken Livingstone decides to run as "independent" candidate for mayor of London, he will pretend that his apostasy is justified by the AEEU's refusal to consult their members before they supported Frank Dobson. Livingstone will then be elevated to the status of saint and martyr - a selfless socialist, broken on the authoritarian wheel of the party machine. In consequence, Labour's reputation will be desperately damaged. The credit for the mayhem will go to the "loyalist" fixers of the AEEU.

The image - a facet of Labour on which the party leadership spends so much time and trouble - has not been improved by clumsy attempts to tell the world that John Smith's one-member-one-vote reforms (nobly supported by John Prescott) have been implemented in both letter and spirit.

The constituency parties have improved their ways. In 1983 Sparkbrook (not surprisingly) voted to support me. But the minority who wanted Neil Kinnock were counted amongst the thousand votes which were added to my total. Credit where it is due. In London last week each member's vote was allocated individually to the preferred candidate.

Paradoxically, that im provement has added to the public relations disaster. Because most individual party members chose Livingstone, it is popularly (and reasonably) assumed that, given the chance, trade unionists would have done the same. So the impression of a fix was intensified.

Perhaps more damaging still, grassroots Labour was left to ponder another question. Were the people who launched the stop Livingstone campaign too stupid to realise the catastrophe which their machinations would cause? Or were they too arrogant to care about the opinions of Labour's rank and file?

None of the nonsense of the past few months begins to justify Ken Livingstone's typically self-indulgent conduct. But the pleasure he so obviously takes in exploiting the stupidity of Labour's leadership does more than confirm his unsuitability to lead London. It illustrates the folly of playing into his hands.

If, as I hope and believe, Frank Dobson becomes mayor in May, Millbank must learn the lesson of what they will be tempted to regard as a successful operation. No triumphalism. No suggestion that the manipulations were justified. Only the determination never to behave like that again.

webTitle: History points the way to another crash landing

fields.headline: History points the way to another crash landing
fields.trailText: Common to every bubble is the ingrained belief that this time it will be different, that the rise in the price of an asset is rooted in sound common sense rather than on recklessness, stupidity and greed.
fields.body:
In the spring of 1720, when all of London was clamouring for shares in the South Sea company, Sir Isaac Newton was asked what he thought about the market. "I can calculate the motions of the heavenly bodies, but not the madness of the market," the scientist and master of the mint is supposed to have replied.

Newton should have heeded his own wise words. Having sold his £7,000 of stock in the company, he later bought back in at the top of the boom and went down for £20,000. Like all the other mug punters in every bout of speculative fever, Newton was cleaned out when the crash came.

Little has changed in the intervening 280 years. Common to every bubble is the ingrained belief that this time it will be different, that the rise in the price of an asset is rooted in sound common sense rather than on recklessness, stupidity and greed.

Take the crash of 1929, for example. In his excellent book charting the sad history of bubbles, Edward Chancellor* records how Wall Street's elite convinced themselves that the rules of economics had been rewritten and that the market could support ever-higher share prices. John Moody, the founder of the credit agency intoned in 1927 that "no one can examine the panorama of business and finance in America during the past half-dozen years without realising that we are living in a new era".

A new economy

Yale economist Irving Fisher declared a few weeks before the October crash that stock prices had reached a "permanently high plateau". Why was this? Simple. The creation of the Federal Reserve in 1913 had abolished the business cycle, while technological breakthroughs had created a "new economy" that was much more profitable than the old.

As share prices continued their heady rise, traditional methods of stock market valuations were abandoned. It did not matter that many of the start-up companies of the late 1920s were not making any money; what counted was that some day they surely would. So share prices were justified by discounted future earnings.

Investors mortgaged themselves up to the hilt to buy stocks in exotic companies from broking houses, the number of which proliferated in the 1920s. One analyst warned that "factories will shut ... men will be thrown out of work ... the vicious circle will get into full swing and the result will be a serious business depression". He was ridiculed, naturally.

Sound familiar? It should, because the gravity defying performance of stocks in London and New York is eerily redolent of 1929. Those of us who have been warning for some time that the whole stock market edifice is built on sand have so far been proved wrong.

It is possible that we will continue to be wrong and that this time the rules really have been rewritten. It may be that Alan Greenspan has abolished the business cycle, that Goldman Sachs' contented equity guru Abby Joseph Cohen is wiser than Irving Fisher, that Amazon.com is in a different league from RCA (the go-go stock of the 1920s). Maybe.

However, there are plenty of warnings there for those prepared to heed them. One is what is happening in the markets themselves. More and more money is being concentrated in a handful of stocks in the technology sector, while shares in "old industry" fall. An analysis by Peter Oppenheimer, of HSBC, showed that the price-earnings gap in London between the new economy stocks and the old economy stocks is the largest for any market ever.

An analysis of the balance sheet of Amazon.com by Tim Congdon of Lombard Street showed that liabilities were covered more than four times by holdings of cash and securities in early 1999. However, by the end of the year high investment and trading losses meant that liabilities were higher than cash and securities. He believes that the rise in the Nasdaq index is being underpinned by firms borrowing money to buy each other's shares - the equivalent of taking in each other's washing.

Amazon.com's results, he says, give "a fascinating and alarming insight into the cost of building an internet brand. Arguably, they also demonstrate that the hi-tech element in the American stock market is now gripped by a speculative madness of a kind never before seen in the organised financial markets of a significant industrial country."

In the US, the economist Robert Gordon, has started to unpick the American productivity data in an attempt to put the "new paradigm" into historical perspective. "I believe that the inventions of the late 19th century and early 20th century were more fundamental creators of productivity than the electronic-internet era of today," he said.

Oppenheimer, at HSBC, estimates that share prices in the new economy imply growth rates that are unlikely to be achieved and that collectively they are overvalued by 40%.

Survey's warning

Sushil Wadhwani, a member of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, quoted a survey last week showing that 133 internet companies that have gone public since 1995 would need on average to expand their revenues by 80% a year for the next five years. Microsoft, which has had a virtual monopoly, has managed 53% a year; Dell 66%.

It is no wonder that Greenspan is doing his level best to massage share prices down. He knows that the alternative could be a full-scale panic. But even on the assumption that there is no re peat of 1929, there are certain conclusions to be drawn.

First, the euro looks considerably undervalued against the US dollar. European exchanges have performed strongly in recent months. Equity investors seem to have cottoned on to the recovery in the European economy, but foreign exchange dealers - perhaps recalling how they were too long on euros around its launch - have not.

Second, the real medium-term danger for the global economy will be deflation rather than inflation. A stroll down any high street shows that downward pressure on prices is strong; it would not take much to tip western economies from disinflation into deflation and even though policymakers believe that they have scope to ease monetary and fiscal policy, the experience of Japan in the 1990s suggests that such action may be more difficult than they think.

A crash would have more profound implications, not least the rediscovery of the virtues of social democracy and the need for some curbs on the global money machine. A meltdown on Wall Street would be seen, rightly, as the crescendo of a period of financial turbulence that started a decade ago.

Those who today are insistent that we are all Americans now would say that the US was just another Thailand waiting to happen. After all, the US has all the ingredients - a rising trade deficit, a consumer credit binge and wasteful investment in non-performing assets.

At this point, it is traditional to say that a crash is to be avoided at all costs. Actually, it would be no bad thing. A shake-out would not mean that the benefits associated with the new technologies would be lost, any more than the end of the railway boom in the 19th century put an end to railways.

But crashes do have the effect of cleansing the stables, and boy do these stables need cleansing. In the aftermath of the 1929 crash the policies of laissez-faire were cast aside in favour of controls on speculation and the financial system in general. Sadly, those lessons have been forgotten, with the result that we live in a state of perpetual financial instability and allow money idolatry to hollow out societies from the inside.

 Devil Take the Hindmost; Macmillan.

Survey's warning Sushil Wadhwani, a member of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, quoted a survey last week showing that 133 internet companies that have gone public since 1995 would need on average to expand their revenues by 80% a year for the next five years. Microsoft, which has had a virtual monopoly, has managed 53% a year; Dell 66%. It is no wonder that Greenspan is doing his level best to massage share prices down. He knows that the alternative could be a full-scale panic. But even on the assumption that there is no re peat of 1929, there are certain conclusions to be drawn. First, the euro looks considerably undervalued against the US dollar. European exchanges have performed strongly in recent months. Equity investors seem to have cottoned on to the recovery in the European economy, but foreign exchange dealers - perhaps recalling how they were too long on euros around its launch - have not. Second, the real medium-term danger for the global economy will be deflation rather than inflation. A stroll down any high street shows that downward pressure on prices is strong; it would not take much to tip western economies from disinflation into deflation and even though policymakers believe that they have scope to ease monetary and fiscal policy, the experience of Japan in the 1990s suggests that such action may be more difficult than they think. A crash would have more profound implications, not least the rediscovery of the virtues of social democracy and the need for some curbs on the global money machine. A meltdown on Wall Street would be seen, rightly, as the crescendo of a period of financial turbulence that started a decade ago. Those who today are insistent that we are all Americans now would say that the US was just another Thailand waiting to happen. After all, the US has all the ingredients - a rising trade deficit, a consumer credit binge and wasteful investment in non-performing assets. At this point, it is traditional to say that a crash is to be avoided at all costs. Actually, it would be no bad thing. A shake-out would not mean that the benefits associated with the new technologies would be lost, any more than the end of the railway boom in the 19th century put an end to railways. But crashes do have the effect of cleansing the stables, and boy do these stables need cleansing. In the aftermath of the 1929 crash the policies of laissez-faire were cast aside in favour of controls on speculation and the financial system in general. Sadly, those lessons have been forgotten, with the result that we live in a state of perpetual financial instability and allow money idolatry to hollow out societies from the inside.  Devil Take the Hindmost; Macmillan. larry.elliott@theguardian.com

fields.headline: No Mars bar on debate
fields.trailText: According to George Monbiot (Beware the appliance of science, February 24), we scientists act as if we live on another planet. Apparently, a new generation of scientists "obliged to take modules in humanities" would tell the world that "nuclear power is inherently dangerous", because humans are needed to manage it.
fields.body:
According to George Monbiot (Beware the appliance of science, February 24), we scientists act as if we live on another planet. Apparently, a new generation of scientists "obliged to take modules in humanities" would tell the world that "nuclear power is inherently dangerous", because humans are needed to manage it. How does he know that? Presumably because Martian scientists have told him so.

He is right that such debate is essential if the earth is not to fall apart. A prerequisite for mature discussion, however, is to lay to rest the distinction between "the laity" and "science graduates". A Martian nuclear physicist (say) is very much an earthling when it comes to GM food. We are all laity with specialisms in particular areas. Let's bring back the exiles from Mars and together work for a better, safer world.
Prof WCK Poon
Dept of physics and astronomy, University of Edinburgh

 It is the content of a course that matters not its title. Any modern science course should equip students to participate in debates about wisdom of exploiting a scientific concept.
Dr Richard Firn
University of York

 As the union representing scientists in BSE and GMO research, we agree with George Monbiot. We have argued that while stringent science must be based on dispassionate and systematic analysis, standards must also be sensitive to public values and based on continuous public consultation and involvement.
Paul Noon
General secretary, IPMS

webTitle: Commission will take Coops into the 21st century

fields.headline: Commission will take Coops into the 21st century
fields.trailText: I was surprised to read the letter from Barbara Rogers (February 26) suggest that the new independent Cooperative Commission established last Thursday and endorsed by the prime minister is planning to "by-pass the democratic structures of the independent societies and the Cooperative Union".
fields.body:
I was surprised to read the letter from Barbara Rogers (February 26) suggest that the new independent Cooperative Commission established last Thursday and endorsed by the prime minister is planning to "by-pass the democratic structures of the independent societies and the Cooperative Union". The Cooperative Commission, chaired by John Monks of the TUC, is an initiative supported by the chairman of the UK Cooperative Council, the chief executive and general secretary of the Cooperative Union as well as the chairman and chief executive of the CWS.

It was their joint letter to the prime minister of January 14 requesting his endorsement for the work of the commission, which led to the launch on February 24. Furthermore, the commission will be represented at this years Cooperative Congress, and the final recommendations will be presented to the 2001 congress. Let me make it clear from the outset that the terms of reference of the commission contain nothing that could lead to a recommendation in favour of demutualisation.

The only aim of the Cooperative Commission is to see the successful application of the principles of cooperation in a 21st-century context. Any member can send evidence or ideas to the commission at the above address or via the commission's website www.co-opcommission.org.uk.
Alan Donnelly
Cooperative Commission

 I am not prepared to dismiss the CRS/CWS merger proposal out of hand. It has many attractions. The retail trade dealt is dominated by the big four retailers - Asda, Tesco Sainsbury and Safeway. The cooperative movement has to stand up to such fierce competition and be able to demonstrate the time of mutuality has come.

At the recent CRS board meeting to pursue the possible merger, Barbara Rogers was the only member to oppose the proposal and took the honourable course and resigned. Unfortunately, according to her, the remaining 11 board members in supporting the recommendation to merge were all out of step.

The merger of CRS and CWS and the setting up of the commission give cooperators the opportunity to demonstrate that cooperation has a viable future and that commerce and community can prosper hand in hand. We also need a cooperative act of parliament to ensure that cooperatives are not disadvantaged.
James Nicholl
Taunton, Somerset

 We fully support the proposed merger with CWS. Ms Rogers does not advance a mode of UK food retailing, cooperation between cooperatives, or the development of mutualism, and cooperative education. Graham Melmoth is not just a manager, but a former president of the International Cooperative Alliance. He, and others, have given an impetus to cooperative development that is long overdue.

We now require the promised and long overdue cooperatives act from government and a cooperative review board.
Hilda and David Smith
Newport, Gwent

fields.headline: Paper tiger
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee (Stabbed in the back, February 25) is right. The government's proposed regulations to protect part-timers are a paper tiger. Trade unionists, who negotiated the directive, and women should feel outraged.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee (Stabbed in the back, February 25) is right. The government's proposed regulations to protect part-timers are a paper tiger. Trade unionists, who negotiated the directive, and women should feel outraged. The EU's part-time work directive was the fruit of nine months of delicate negotiations between employers and unions, including the CBI and TUC. The agreement aimed to develop a flexible labour market while ensuring "security for workers". The use of "worker" rather than the more restrictive "employee" was agreed by both sides. "Worker", which includes the increasing number of part-timers on non-standard contracts, is used throughout directive.

It should also be the definition used in our domestic regulations. It is not open to the government to reinterpret the agreement. Furthermore the government is under an obligation to set up mechanisms that enable part-time workers to compare themselves with full-time colleagues. The government proposals mean that 99% of part-timers won't actually be able to use the new law.
John Monks
TUC general secrtetary

fields.headline: We still want mayors
fields.trailText: Despite the difficulties over the London mayoral race, the public continues to be enthusiastic for this reform in towns and cities across Britain.
fields.body:
Despite the difficulties over the London mayoral race, the public continues to be enthusiastic for this reform in towns and cities across Britain.

The survey commissioned by the new local government network (Livingstone urged to fight from within, February 26) demonstrates that 59% of the public support the idea of an elected mayor for their area and that 49% of people would be more likely to vote in local elections. Given the declining turnout levels in local government, this can only be a positive development for local democracy. Elected mayors will be an important tool for providing strong, accountable and visible leadership. The London mayoral race should be the catalyst for others to follow.
 Cllr Albert Bore, Leader, Birmingham council; Cllr Vince Muspratt, Leader, Watford council; Cllr Dave Sullivan, Leader, Lewisham council; Cllr Gideon Ben-Tovim, Labour leader, Liverpool council; Cllr Del Herod, Labour leader, Bath & NE Somerset council

fields.headline: The gloves come off
fields.standfirst:
But Labour may regret its electoral fixing

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: He knew it would get dirty, but even he must have been stunned by yesterday's Sunday Telegraph. "Revealed: Livingstone's African love child," screamed the masthead, offering full details on page 3. Inside he will have discovered that the Livingstone the paper had in mind was Dr David, the explorer, rather than Mr Ken, the would-be mayor of London.
fields.body:
He knew it would get dirty, but even he must have been stunned by yesterday's Sunday Telegraph. "Revealed: Livingstone's African love child," screamed the masthead, offering full details on page 3. Inside he will have discovered that the Livingstone the paper had in mind was Dr David, the explorer, rather than Mr Ken, the would-be mayor of London. But the relief would have been shortlived. For, just as Mr Livingstone predicted, the onslaught designed to stop him running as an independent for the London mayoralty is underway. At its most civilized, it is a campaign of political pressure, with Labour's biggest names - John Prescott and James Callaghan yesterday - called in to guilt-trip the former GLC leader into staying within the "family". At its most crude, the effort is already sliding into the gloves-off viciousness that Mr Livingstone says he and his loved ones fear most. The Mail on Sunday offered a near-perfect example of self-fulfilling prophecy yesterday. At the top of the page: "I fear Labour smears, says Livingstone." Just below: "Ken said he needed sex morning and night - but he'd stop to watch News at Ten."

The first, polite half of the effort will intensify today, when the wannabe candidate will meet Mr Prescott. The deputy prime minister might offer a compromise on private investment in public transport, the issue which officially separates Ken from New Labour. Whether it will be enough we doubt; but that will be a matter finally for Mr Livingstone himself. In the meantime there is a dispute with the Labour high command in which everyone has a stake - at least everyone who believes in democracy. Tomorrow the Lords will again be asked to approve the arrangements for May 4's mayoral election, which currently rules out the free mailshot for candidates that is a standard part of every major British election. The government's defence, hilariously, is that the contest for London mayor is a local election - admittedly a very big one, but a local election all the same. Never mind that London includes more voters than Scotland and Wales combined, the capital city is to be treated as a humble ward of a local parish council. This is pretty clearly just another ruse to block Ken - making it costly for him to spread his message. But it is also a shoddy piece of election tampering. The peer who said that "fix and fiddle" risks becoming to Labour what sleaze was to the Tories spoke good sense. Labour should listen to it.

fields.headline: Bonnie King... Arthur?
fields.standfirst:
Charles should bet on Camelot

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles, it is increasingly suggested, may never become King Charles III, preferring to call himself George VII. This notion is ascribed by some to his apprehensiveness about the fate of Charles I, whom his country got rid of; but it could equally well reflect his family's name-switching traditions. His great-uncle, hitherto David, reigned as Edward VIII, and his grandfather, known until then as Bertie, became George VI.
fields.body:
Prince Charles, it is increasingly suggested, may never become King Charles III, preferring to call himself George VII. This notion is ascribed by some to his apprehensiveness about the fate of Charles I, whom his country got rid of; but it could equally well reflect his family's name-switching traditions. His great-uncle, hitherto David, reigned as Edward VIII, and his grandfather, known until then as Bertie, became George VI.

It would seem on the face of it rather odd if superstition were to dissuade the prince from ruling as Charles. Charles I may have been deposed and executed, but Charles II died of natural causes (a fit of apoplexy, to be specific, after dinner with his mistress). Had he been that superstitious, the prince would hardly have named his eldest son William, since this is the royal forename with the least auspicious record, especially for Williams on horseback: the first three were all killed in circumstances equestrian.

Prince Charles himself was christened Charles Philip Arthur George, thus making him potentially the first British king to share his initials with the Child Poverty Action Group. This gives him the chance, should he wish to take it, of rejecting both Charles and George and settling instead for Arthur, a name which has been somewhat neglected ever since Camelot. The first Arthur died (assuming he lived: some scholars think him a fiction) as long ago as the 6th century. There is enough of the Camelot-ish in Charles's outlook, from his dreamy spirituality to the reputed shape of his private life, to suggest that this designation might suit him well. One can easily imagine him traversing the country on horseback, sword in hand, accompanied by appropriate knights and minstrels and paying obeisance at suitable shrines. There is even, come to think of it, a close relative handy, in the shape of his cousin, Viscount Linley, a kind of upmarket carpenter by profession, to knock him up a nifty round table at a suitable discount.
