fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst: Should lawyers be taken to task over romantic liaisons with their clients, as is being suggested in the US?
fields.trailText: Should lawyers be taken to task over romantic liaisons with their clients, as is being suggested in the US? Personally speaking,  Marcel Berlins  would rather they weren't
fields.body:
When I was a young lawyer I had a short, lovely affair with one of my clients. I was handling her divorce.

It was a simple enough case of her husband's obvious adultery, but this was another country, before the days of quickie divorces, and it was necessary for lawyer and client to meet often, though the law didn't require quite as many rendezvous as I contrived, nor that so many of them should take place away from the office. It seemed natural to offer her my more personal sympathies as well as my tiny legal skills.

We were never found out, although we were stupid enough to show occasional signs of affection in public, once in the café across the road from the court where she was to get her decree. Had we been spotted, say, by her husband or his lawyers, the whole divorce might have been thrown into doubt. She had sworn to the court that she was guiltless of any adultery.

At the time, and looking back now, the experience was wholly delightful. I did not believe that I was taking advantage of her; indeed, the alacrity with which I was dumped soon after her final decree suggests the opposite. I certainly don't believe that what we did in any way changed the course of her case. Justice was done. I don't remember feeling any professional guilt. And I didn't charge her for the extra, legally unnecessary, meetings.

Was sleeping with a client against professional rules? Would I have been in big trouble had our liaison been discovered? I honestly don't know; I never bothered to find out. This was a long time ago, but the circumstances are universal and timeless.

As watchers of the much lamented series LA Law will remember, divorce attorney Arnold Becker appeared to consider it compulsory to bed his (always willing) clients. This fictional storyline must have had some factual basis - not long afterwards, the California bar passed a strong rule virtually forbidding lawyer-client sex.

A few other state bars have followed, with outright bans or stringent restrictions. But now the American Bar Association is considering making it a professional offence nationwide for a lawyer to have sexual relations with his or her client (unless they were already having consensual sex beforehand). Provided, that is, the ABA's Ethics 2000 committee can agree on a definition of sexual. Everyone used to know what that meant, but now - following Bill Clinton's difficulty in categorising what he did with Monica - it may have to be spelled out in detail.

The impetus arose from two high-profile cases. Lowell Halverson, a prominent Seattle family lawyer, admitted to sleeping with six women for whom he was acting.

In the affair that made the news, he failed to tell his client-lover that, if they were found out, he would have to resign as her lawyer and that could prejudice her attempt to get custody of her daughter. The sexual bond had blinded him to his duty to give independent advice, to her detriment, the disciplinary board against him ruled. Halverson strongly, though unsuccessfully, contested the finding, claiming that he had broken no specific rule of conduct.

The same defence was used, more flamboyantly, by Chicago attorney Richard Rinella, whose case was not helped when a client with whom he'd denied having sex produced a photo she'd taken of him naked.

Allegations that he'd pestered clients to have sex with him in return for legal services resulted in his suspension for three years; his attempt to get the Supreme Court to rule that his sexual advances were protected by the first amendment - free speech - was treated with derision. His main point, though, was that there was no professional code forbidding what he'd done.

The American national body clearly wants to put the issue beyond doubt by a firm no-sex rule. By contrast, the Law Society of England and Wales is far more relaxed.

They don't see it as much of a problem. No one denies that it goes on. Anecdotally, there's a lot of it about. Most of the alarmist stories follow the formula of a distressed woman in a bad marriage seeking the help and advice of a lawyer and finding herself taken advantage of by the scheming professional (similar tales are told with vicars or doctors playing the baddie). But it's also clear that many affairs are fully consensual.

Few cases reach the press. One of them involved a former solicitor to the Princess of Wales, Paul Butner. Another well-known matrimonial solicitor began a seven-year affair with his client which led to her husband complaining to the solicitors' complaints bureau. He was cleared of any misconduct - he had stopped being her solicitor when the relationship deepened.

The official Law Society view is that it would be overkill to impose a total ban. "If sleeping with clients was a disciplinary offence, the ranks of solicitors would be decimated," a top QC once commented drily to a judge who was angry at discovering that the solicitor in the case had slept with his client, a rock star's wife.

Lawyer-client sex is mentioned twice in the solicitors' rules of conduct. Under the heading Conflicts of Interest, "a solicitor who becomes involved in a sexual relationship with a client must consider whether this may place his or her interests in conflict with those of the client, or otherwise impair the solicitor's ability to act in the best interests of the client."

Elsewhere, the rules warn that "while it would not necessarily be so, it may be an abuse of the solicitor-client fiduciary relationship for a solicitor to enter into a sexual relationship with a client."

The code of practice for members of the specialist Solicitors' Family Law Association says only this: "You should make sure that you are objective and do not allow your own emotions or personal opinions to influence your advice." In other words, it's all left to the good sense of the solicitor. If he (it's rarely she, it seems) finds himself entertaining sexual feelings towards his client, he should hand the case over to another lawyer, and play no further part in the proceedings.

Most family lawyers I spoke to are convinced that a sexual and a professional relationship should not co-exist. "It's not like a commercial case, where you're out to win and that's all that matters," says Helen Ward, a highly respected divorce solicitor with the London firm Manches. "In family cases you've got a duty to try to get the best results for the children, for the family. You can't look at it through a narrow telescope, thinking only of your client's interests. You've got to be totally objective about the steps that need to be taken to secure an acceptable solution, and you've got to be able to see the other side's point of view. If you're sexually or emotionally involved, it impedes your ability to be objective, and you give rubbish advice."

Ray Tooth, an equally well-known matrimonial lawyer, is not so sure. A few years ago, he had an affair with a client, which had begun after her divorce had gone through. He doesn't see why lawyer-client relationships are necessarily professionally wrong. "It all depends on how much she's involved, how much he's involved. You can't assume that it's the lawyer who's made all the running. Of course if the lawyer's been overbearing, taking advantage, that's different."

He's not even convinced that a lawyer who starts a relationship with a client should automatically have to hand over the case to someone else. "It all depends. Is it love or lust? If it's true love, then perhaps he should; if it's just a fling, I don't think it matters much."

In America, critics of the proposed wholesale ban argue that, at the very least, there should be a distinction between family lawyers and the rest.

The lawyer involved with a woman who comes for a divorce takes on her anger, her bad feelings towards her husband, perhaps her bitterness and desire for revenge. He starts taking her side, not as a dispassionate adviser, but as a party to the emotional turmoil. Feelings are enhanced if there's a dispute over children.

The lawyer in a commercial case, by contrast, it's said, doesn't develop personal emotions towards the large corporation or insurance company he's suing. The advice he dishes out can be dispassionate, because it's based on hard law, not people's behaviour.

But is there such a difference? The lawyer in lust or love - in whatever field of law - will surely be tempted to make rash promises, to put the most favourable gloss on her case so as not to disappoint her, to convince himself that she has a good case when she hasn't; perhaps even to cut legal corners. In the end, the result is the same as in anguished family cases: the client doesn't get the best advice.

Lawyers, it's often argued, ought to be put on the same ethical professional footing as doctors. Ray Tooth recalls a joke his lawyer uncle told him about the difference between the two professions. "A doctor can touch his patient's body but not her money; a lawyer can lay his hands on his client's money but not her body."

Or, as a senior Law Society official put it, "People say that lawyers should be treated the same as doctors. But they're not comparable. For one thing, lawyers don't have any reason for asking their clients to undress."
fields.bodyText: When I was a young lawyer I had a short, lovely affair with one of my clients. I was handling her divorce. It was a simple enough case of her husband's obvious adultery, but this was another country, before the days of quickie divorces, and it was necessary for lawyer and client to meet often, though the law didn't require quite as many rendezvous as I contrived, nor that so many of them should take place away from the office. It seemed natural to offer her my more personal sympathies as well as my tiny legal skills. We were never found out, although we were stupid enough to show occasional signs of affection in public, once in the café across the road from the court where she was to get her decree. Had we been spotted, say, by her husband or his lawyers, the whole divorce might have been thrown into doubt. She had sworn to the court that she was guiltless of any adultery. At the time, and looking back now, the experience was wholly delightful. I did not believe that I was taking advantage of her; indeed, the alacrity with which I was dumped soon after her final decree suggests the opposite. I certainly don't believe that what we did in any way changed the course of her case. Justice was done. I don't remember feeling any professional guilt. And I didn't charge her for the extra, legally unnecessary, meetings. Was sleeping with a client against professional rules? Would I have been in big trouble had our liaison been discovered? I honestly don't know; I never bothered to find out. This was a long time ago, but the circumstances are universal and timeless. As watchers of the much lamented series LA Law will remember, divorce attorney Arnold Becker appeared to consider it compulsory to bed his (always willing) clients. This fictional storyline must have had some factual basis - not long afterwards, the California bar passed a strong rule virtually forbidding lawyer-client sex. A few other state bars have followed, with outright bans or stringent restrictions. But now the American Bar Association is considering making it a professional offence nationwide for a lawyer to have sexual relations with his or her client (unless they were already having consensual sex beforehand). Provided, that is, the ABA's Ethics 2000 committee can agree on a definition of sexual. Everyone used to know what that meant, but now - following Bill Clinton's difficulty in categorising what he did with Monica - it may have to be spelled out in detail. The impetus arose from two high-profile cases. Lowell Halverson, a prominent Seattle family lawyer, admitted to sleeping with six women for whom he was acting. In the affair that made the news, he failed to tell his client-lover that, if they were found out, he would have to resign as her lawyer and that could prejudice her attempt to get custody of her daughter. The sexual bond had blinded him to his duty to give independent advice, to her detriment, the disciplinary board against him ruled. Halverson strongly, though unsuccessfully, contested the finding, claiming that he had broken no specific rule of conduct. The same defence was used, more flamboyantly, by Chicago attorney Richard Rinella, whose case was not helped when a client with whom he'd denied having sex produced a photo she'd taken of him naked. Allegations that he'd pestered clients to have sex with him in return for legal services resulted in his suspension for three years; his attempt to get the Supreme Court to rule that his sexual advances were protected by the first amendment - free speech - was treated with derision. His main point, though, was that there was no professional code forbidding what he'd done. The American national body clearly wants to put the issue beyond doubt by a firm no-sex rule. By contrast, the Law Society of England and Wales is far more relaxed. They don't see it as much of a problem. No one denies that it goes on. Anecdotally, there's a lot of it about. Most of the alarmist stories follow the formula of a distressed woman in a bad marriage seeking the help and advice of a lawyer and finding herself taken advantage of by the scheming professional (similar tales are told with vicars or doctors playing the baddie). But it's also clear that many affairs are fully consensual. Few cases reach the press. One of them involved a former solicitor to the Princess of Wales, Paul Butner. Another well-known matrimonial solicitor began a seven-year affair with his client which led to her husband complaining to the solicitors' complaints bureau. He was cleared of any misconduct - he had stopped being her solicitor when the relationship deepened. The official Law Society view is that it would be overkill to impose a total ban. "If sleeping with clients was a disciplinary offence, the ranks of solicitors would be decimated," a top QC once commented drily to a judge who was angry at discovering that the solicitor in the case had slept with his client, a rock star's wife. Lawyer-client sex is mentioned twice in the solicitors' rules of conduct. Under the heading Conflicts of Interest, "a solicitor who becomes involved in a sexual relationship with a client must consider whether this may place his or her interests in conflict with those of the client, or otherwise impair the solicitor's ability to act in the best interests of the client." Elsewhere, the rules warn that "while it would not necessarily be so, it may be an abuse of the solicitor-client fiduciary relationship for a solicitor to enter into a sexual relationship with a client." The code of practice for members of the specialist Solicitors' Family Law Association says only this: "You should make sure that you are objective and do not allow your own emotions or personal opinions to influence your advice." In other words, it's all left to the good sense of the solicitor. If he (it's rarely she, it seems) finds himself entertaining sexual feelings towards his client, he should hand the case over to another lawyer, and play no further part in the proceedings. Most family lawyers I spoke to are convinced that a sexual and a professional relationship should not co-exist. "It's not like a commercial case, where you're out to win and that's all that matters," says Helen Ward, a highly respected divorce solicitor with the London firm Manches. "In family cases you've got a duty to try to get the best results for the children, for the family. You can't look at it through a narrow telescope, thinking only of your client's interests. You've got to be totally objective about the steps that need to be taken to secure an acceptable solution, and you've got to be able to see the other side's point of view. If you're sexually or emotionally involved, it impedes your ability to be objective, and you give rubbish advice." Ray Tooth, an equally well-known matrimonial lawyer, is not so sure. A few years ago, he had an affair with a client, which had begun after her divorce had gone through. He doesn't see why lawyer-client relationships are necessarily professionally wrong. "It all depends on how much she's involved, how much he's involved. You can't assume that it's the lawyer who's made all the running. Of course if the lawyer's been overbearing, taking advantage, that's different." He's not even convinced that a lawyer who starts a relationship with a client should automatically have to hand over the case to someone else. "It all depends. Is it love or lust? If it's true love, then perhaps he should; if it's just a fling, I don't think it matters much." In America, critics of the proposed wholesale ban argue that, at the very least, there should be a distinction between family lawyers and the rest. The lawyer involved with a woman who comes for a divorce takes on her anger, her bad feelings towards her husband, perhaps her bitterness and desire for revenge. He starts taking her side, not as a dispassionate adviser, but as a party to the emotional turmoil. Feelings are enhanced if there's a dispute over children. The lawyer in a commercial case, by contrast, it's said, doesn't develop personal emotions towards the large corporation or insurance company he's suing. The advice he dishes out can be dispassionate, because it's based on hard law, not people's behaviour. But is there such a difference? The lawyer in lust or love - in whatever field of law - will surely be tempted to make rash promises, to put the most favourable gloss on her case so as not to disappoint her, to convince himself that she has a good case when she hasn't; perhaps even to cut legal corners. For one thing, lawyers don't have any reason for asking their clients to undress."

fields.headline: Case of the week:  The 'shiner'
fields.trailText: On August 19 1997, a 15-year-old boy sat next to a 13-year-old girl on the Harrow bus, and asked her several times for "a shiner". She refused. The legal effects of this were to occupy three magistrates and eight senior judges, including two lord chancellors, and cost the taxpayer a six-figure sum before it reached its conclusion last week in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
On August 19 1997, a 15-year-old boy sat next to a 13-year-old girl on the Harrow bus, and asked her several times for "a shiner". She refused. The legal effects of this were to occupy three magistrates and eight senior judges, including two lord chancellors, and cost the taxpayer a six-figure sum before it reached its conclusion last week in the House of Lords.

A shiner, "in the language of today's gilded youth, apparently means, not a black eye, but an act of oral sex", explained Mr Justice Rougier in the high court. The boy was prosecuted under the Indecency with Children Act 1960, for inciting a child under 14 to commit an act of gross indecency, a charge carrying a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. It was a new offence, brought in after two cases in which paedophiles who induced children to perform sexual acts on them were found not guilty of any offence.

The boy said he thought the girl was over 14. But was this a defence? Parliament, when it passed the act, was silent on the question. Did that mean it was a "strict liability" offence, where the perpetrator was guilty regardless of what he thought?

The boy's lawyers argued that his belief that the girl was over 14 was a defence. But the magis trates said no. He pleaded guilty and was sentenced to an 18-month supervision order. He appealed to the high court, where three judges upheld the magistrates' ruling. Lord Justice Brooke noted the court spent "a day and a half at the taxpayer's expense exploring the highways and byways of our laws on sexual offences" because parliament had not made its intentions clear.

The taxpayer had to fork out more money when the boy appealed to the Lords. There, five judges heard the appeal and unanimously came to the opposite conclusion. The judges said parliament had not expressly stated that the defendant's belief was no defence, nor could the implication that that was its intention be drawn from looking at other offences.

The result is that adult paedophiles may now get off by claiming they thought the child was over 14. It will be for the prosecution to prove otherwise. As Lord Nicholls said: "If parliament considers that the position should be otherwise regarding this serious social problem, parliament must itself confront the difficulties and express its will in clear terms."

fields.headline: Nudge the judge
fields.trailText: So judges are now going to be entitled to use public funds to sue for defamation. The rest of the populace, of course, is denied such state help.
fields.body:
So judges are now going to be entitled to use public funds to sue for defamation. The rest of the populace, of course, is denied such state help.

The judges are getting this to put them in line with other public servants - senior civil servants, for instance - who, it's thought, should not be denied the right to sue if they've been libelled over something that arises from their job. I don't expect an avalanche of claimants, but it's not unprecedented for a judge to bring legal proceedings for libel.

A few years ago, a court report in a Reading newspaper asserted that a high court judge, Mr Justice Popplewell, now retired, had fallen asleep during a trial. The sleeping judge is a traditional staple of the cartoonist and satirist; but this particular one had bucked the image and was, in fact, fully awake and concentrating. But the allegation that he was slumbering would, he believed, tend to lower his reputation.

"That's Popplewell, the kipping judge," people would mutter as they crossed the road to avoid him. "Bit of a snoozer, you know; can't be up to much as a judge." He sued; the paper conceded it was wrong. Unusually, the issue of how much to award in compensation went to an arbitrator, Gareth Williams QC, now none other than Lord Williams of Mostyn, the Attorney General. Popplewell was awarded £7,500, which wasn't much. But would a jury have given more, given the public's lack of, how shall I say, overwhelming enthusiasm for the judiciary?

There'll be real problems if judges start suing for libel. For them to request trial by a judge alone, without a jury, would be seen as an attempted stitch- up between colleagues. But if they have a normal jury trial, they run the strong risk that a hostile jury will find against them, whatever the real merits. Unless, of course, the judges sue the tabloids, in which case the jury would be in the wonderful position of having to decide between two of their least favourite institutions.

Was the exclusion of David Beckham from the Manchester United team last weekend a breach of the European Convention on Human Rights? He'd missed training because he was looking after his sick child. The Convention (part of English law from next October) guarantees the right to family life. Becks was penalised for exercising that right.

Ergo, in dropping him, Sir Alex Ferguson was in breach. Nonsense, of course, though not quite as far-fetched as you might think. An excellent conference I attended at the Centre for Public Law at Cambridge University included a discussion on this question: was Glenn Hoddle's dismissal as the England coach last year contrary to the Convention?

He was sacked because he made offensive remarks about disabled people having done something wrong in their previous lives. He was expressing a belief that was part of his faith. And that's precisely what is protected by Article 9 - freedom of religion and beliefs and the right to "manifest" them.

The issue would be, according to high court judge Sir Patrick Elias, whether what he'd said infringed other people's rights. The remarks may have been offensive to the disabled and others, but is that enough to deny Hoddle's right to make them? There's no certain answer, and I can't see Hoddle as a human rights martyr, but I'm all in favour of mixing football and human rights. I'm currently looking into grave breaches of the Convention committed against my Aston Villa over many years.

I 've been leafing through the newly published Oxford Companion to Crime and Mystery Writing, and I realise that I've done a disservice to at least two authors.

You know how I go on and on about the lack of English lawyers writing good crime fiction set in the English legal world?

Inexplicably, I've failed to mention, and recommend, the works of former solicitor Michael Gilbert, now in his late eighties, his latest novel published only two years ago. He's written dozens of books, with Smallbones Deceased a minor classic and nearly all of them written and plotted with wit, style and authentic legal atmosphere.

The other is Martin Edwards, a Liverpool solicitor whose amiable hero, Harry Devlin, is a Liverpool solicitor who is, however, far more down at heel, unsuccessful and prone to drink than his creator.

webTitle: Jospin's comments in Middle East drive wedge between PM and president

fields.headline: Jospin's comments in Middle East drive wedge between PM and president
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, was yesterday left licking literal and metaphorical wounds after a three-day Middle East visit that saw him stoned by angry Palestinian students and publicly reprimanded by President Jacques Chirac for his apparently pro-Israeli stance.
fields.body:
The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, was yesterday left licking literal and metaphorical wounds after a three-day Middle East visit that saw him stoned by angry Palestinian students and publicly reprimanded by President Jacques Chirac for his apparently pro-Israeli stance.

Mr Jospin, who flew back to France - and straight into a big domestic row - earlier than planned on Saturday night, upset Arab leaders and provoked furious protests from West Bank students on Thursday by describing Hizbullah attacks on Israeli occupation soldiers in south Lebanon as "terrorist acts".

Mr Chirac's office said yesterday that the president - who by longstanding French tradition enjoys primacy in foreign policy matters - had telephoned Mr Jospin immediately after his return, forcefully reminding him of France's delicate "equilibrium" in its dealings with Israel and the Arab world.

Mr Chirac "reaffirmed the consistancy of French foreign policy and the equilibrium that drives our interaction in the Middle East, an interaction that remains unchanged. Putting this impartiality in question would strike a blow to the credibility of our foreign policy and France's capacity to work toward peace," his office said in a statement.

Mr Jospin later toned down, but did not withdraw, his comments, referring to Hizbullah's "acts of war". But that was not enough to pacify angry Palestinian students at Bir Zeit university, who on Saturday pelted him with stones and jumped on his bullet-proof Mercedes.

French opinion is divided over whether the prime minister meant what he said.

The leftwing newspaper Libération criticised him for a "blunder" that had caused "considerable damage", while the populist Le Parisien said it was a bad mistake that would unbalance the "cohabitation" - the delicate power-sharing relationship between a con servative president and a Socialist prime minister.

But many commentators thought Mr Jospin's remarks were far from a slip of the tongue.

The authoritative Le Monde said the prime minister fully intended to criticise Syria's efforts to block the peace process in Lebanon and was "expressing truths that may not please everyone, but are a mark of his character and determination".

Conservative opponents accused Mr Jospin of compromising France's relations in a particularly sensitive region of the world by trying to score domestic political points against the president in the run-up to the two leaders' likely battle for the French presidency in 2002.

"As the elections approach, the prime minister will want to be more and more present on the international scene," said Pascal Boniface, the head of the Institute for International and Strategic Relations. "The tone will get even tougher."

webTitle: Albanian gunmen stir trouble in Serbia

fields.headline: Albanian gunmen stir trouble in Serbia
fields.standfirst:
Their own community denounces KLA fighters seeking to provoke a Nato intervention across the border

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Armed clashes between ethnic Albanian fighters and Yugoslav forces in the border region between Serbia proper and the province of Kosovo threatens to turn into a new flashpoint and raises the possibility of Nato troops operating inside Serbia.
fields.body:
Armed clashes between ethnic Albanian fighters and Yugoslav forces in the border region between Serbia proper and the province of Kosovo threatens to turn into a new flashpoint and raises the possibility of Nato troops operating inside Serbia.

The new trouble spot is the south-western corner of Serbia which is largely populated by Albanians. Former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army have started to operate in the border villages, carrying guns, wearing paramilitary uniforms and attacking Serb police in an apparent bid to provoke a Serb reaction and Nato help.

A Serb policeman died and three others were wounded on Saturday night when Albanian gunmen ambushed a patrol on the main road between Gnjilane and Bujanovac. The attack with automatic rifles and grenades occurred about six kilometres inside Serbia near the village of Konsulj. The police returned fire, killing an Albanian, according to the state-owned news agency, Tanjug. The incident followed explosions in Bujanovac the previous night.

Although General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander in Europe, has warned Albanians that Nato does not want to see fighting, United States forces are taking no chances. They have started to build a mini-base right on the border line between Kosovo and Serbia proper, close to the village of Dobrosin, from where tanks and troops in an observation tower look down on the increasingly brazen street forays by guerrillas in broad daylight.

Albanian leaders in the Kosovo's main city, Pristina, as well as ordinary people in the region, say they are against cross-border violence for fear of reprisals against the 70,000 Albanians who live in southern Serbia and a new round of ethnic cleansing by Serb security forces. But evidence on the ground suggests that embittered and now demobilised guerrillas of the Kosovo Liberation Army have started armed patrols and military training for local people.

In their first interview with journalists at the weekend, local gunmen described what they called "the little army in uniform which arose among people to defend ourselves".

There was a strange sense of deja vu as we made the encounter, just like two years ago when the world first became aware of the Kosovo Liberation Army itself - the whispered contacts, the trail on muddy roads behind a car, the walk on snow-covered fields and through coppices of dwarf oak, and finally the meeting in a village house with a group of half a dozen men with AK-47 Kalashnikov assault rifles.

The difference this time was that instead of the red-and-gold shoulder badge with the Albanian eagle and the letters UCK (the Albanian initials for the KLA), they now wear badges saying UCPMB, the initials of Presevo, Medveda, and Bujenovac. These are three towns in southern Serbia, in the area the guerrillas call "eastern Kosovo".

Speaking the Swiss dialect of French, their leader, dressed in civilian clothes, said: "Our soldiers have not come from somewhere else. They are from this village and region. It was part of Kosovo originally, but the borders were changed after the second world war. People here must have the right to decide how and where they want to live."

The UCPMB was formed on January 26, he said, after Serb police entered the village of Dobrosin and killed Isa Saqipi, 31, and his brother Shaip, 35. They were innocently cutting wood, he insisted. "There have always been incidents but after that January event people began to reflect and organise," he said.

He acknowledged that half of Dobrosin's 2,500 inhabitants had fled across the border to Kosovo. The two broth ers' graves, a mere 200 yards from the barrels of the American tanks on the hill, are covered with wreaths.

Dobrosin lies just inside the five-kilometre-deep "Ground Safety Zone", which the Yugoslav forces accepted when they signed the agreement which ended Nato's bombing last June and authorised the international peacekeeping force in Kosovo (K-For). Local Serb police are allowed to operate in the zone, but Yugoslav army troops and special police with heavy weapons are forbidden.

Although US forces who control Kosovo's eastern sector send low-flying helicopters along the border line, they respect Serbia's sovereignty by not penetrating the buffer zone. But the ceasefire agreement has a major loophole. Negotiated in a rush as part of the package which put Kosovo under United Nations administration, it said any violation "would be subject to K-For military action" but did not specify what exactly might trigger a K-For response.

"If atrocities occur in the area, we will go in and take action. We're working on what the definition of an atrocity is," Major Michael Boehme, information officer Camp Monteith, the US base in Gnjilane, told the Guardian yesterday.

The K-For commander, General Klaus Reinhardt, along with Dr Bernard Kouchner, the top UN administrator and the American general in command of the eastern sector, were preparing detailed guidelines, he said.Gary Carrell, an American policeman who commands the UN police in the area, said his staff had held "preliminary meetings" with the Serbian police on the border in the last few weeks.

Albanians cross the border freely and the main aim was to prevent people involved in assassinations of Serbs from slipping away. "We're pretty sure the suspects in the killing of three Serbs in Kosovo last month were from Presevo," he said. But the plan for further meetings with the Serb police was vetoed by Jock Covey, the American who is deputy head of the UN administration. The Serb police, known as the MUP, won a fearful reputation among Albanians during last year's expulsions and killings.

It is hard to gauge what support the UCPMB has. Hundreds of people from the region have fled to Kosovo in recent weeks because of stepped-up Serb police action and alleged intimidation.

fields.headline: Big boys don't cry
fields.standfirst: When a man claimed his son had been raped by an older woman, why would no one listen?
fields.trailText: Neither God nor his ministers helped Jamie Phillips' father help his son. When devout Methodist Anthony Phillips discovered his 15-year-old son had a sexual relationship, then a child, with a 34-year-old neighbour, he bought an axe and beheaded her. He was, he thought, relieving the world of a child abuser and a rapist.
fields.body:
Neither God nor his ministers helped Jamie Phillips' father help his son. When devout Methodist Anthony Phillips discovered his 15-year-old son had a sexual relationship, then a child, with a 34-year-old neighbour, he bought an axe and beheaded her. He was, he thought, relieving the world of a child abuser and a rapist.

The case, concluded last week, poignantly exposes our collective difficulty with adults' sexual interest in children and children's authority over their lives. Jamie Phillips may have been bigger than the woman but the law, his parents, his school and society still regard him as a child.

Propaganda about masculine sexual prowess is predicated on lack of control on the one hand, dominion on the other. Masculinity is always swinging somewhere between martyrdom and mastery, and so boys can't be victims because masculinity's cultural history can't cope with a notion of victimisation that might echo the experience of girls.

Not so, of course, with girls. We expect them to be dominated, humiliated, overwhelmed. Until the Women's Liberation generation tried to challenge and change transactions between the genders, this destiny was attributed to a force of nature. An entire sexual literature was constructed after the Enlightenment around the conceit of woman as enigma, an empty space to be filled, an inert violin to be played. A man, by contrast, was designated instinctively domineering. The ideology that valorised masculine agency could not assimilate the effects of abuse. Thus boys' own accounts of their experience are dissembled.

There is a fascinating scent of the problem in Britain's most comprehensive study of abuse among young people, published in 1991 by the North London University Child and Woman Abuse Studies Unit. If boys understood an adult's behaviour towards them as abusive or inappropriate, they nonetheless could not see themselves as abused or as victims, but re-interpreted the experience as initiation. This, of course, fits an ideology that represents masculinity always as power. It simultaneously erases boys' unease or unhappiness, especially when the sexual predator is a woman.

By this measure, victimisation is unthinkable. That's what happens to females - except when boys are subjected to sexual dominion by a man. The "men are beasts" theory of gender renders men's abusiveness predictable, but leaves boys' experience of abuse without words.

The meaning of Jamie Phillips' experience remains muddled. When his father asked his church minister for advice about his son, he was told "it is every boy's dream to have an older woman". Patriarchal attitudes traduce a mature woman's "initiation" of a boy as her death sentence - and his as good luck.

fields.headline: Whatever happened to the housewife?
fields.standfirst: It started 40 years ago, when a letter to this paper led to a register of all those bored women stuck at home in suburbia. And now?
fields.trailText: It started 40 years ago, when a letter to this paper led to a register of all those bored women stuck at home in suburbia. And now?
fields.body:
It was with sharp frustration and a dollop of sympathy that Guardian journalist Betty Jerman wrote about surburbia 40 years ago. The open space and fresh air, she said, made it a good place to bring up children, but she feared these advantages were outweighed by the brain-numbing atmosphere.

"Surburbia is an incredibly dull place to live in and I blame the women," she wrote. "They stay here all day. They set the tone. Many of them look back with regret to the days when they worked in an office. Their work kept them alert. Home and childminding can have a blunting effect on a woman's mind. But only she can sharpen it."

Jerman's observations struck a chord with reader Maureen Nicol. She wrote to the paper suggesting that "housebound wives with liberal interests and a desire to remain individuals could form a national register, so that whenever one moves, one can contact like-minded friends".

An avalanche of letters was sent to the paper from desperate women all over the country who felt they were floundering in what society expected of them as wives and mothers. Women who had been educated but, like their mothers before them, found themselves trapped in the domestic sphere, often having to up sticks because of their husband's job, even if they'd found a kindred spirit nearby.

Local groups formed and a few years later acquired the name the National Housewives' Register. In the absence of a personal income, early members admit fiddling the housekeeping to raise the small membership fee. Today most groups meet every other week to discuss everything except the domestic, with debates on current affairs, book groups and speakers invited from every public sphere.

Year on year membership grew until, in 1980, it peaked at 24,000. This enthusiasm proved Virginia Woolf right when, in A Room Of One's Own, she wrote: "Women have sat indoors all these millions of years, so that by this time the very walls are permeated by their creative force, which has, indeed, so overcharged the capacity of bricks and mortar that it must needs harness itself to pens and brushes and business and politics." Numbers have been falling since the 80s; today 8,000 women are members of what has been known since 1987 as the National Women's Register.

The change of title raises the question of the organisation's future. The oldest member is 92 and though there are members in their late 20s, this generation of women is by no means rushing to join. NWR may be celebrating its ruby anniversary but will an organisation born to alleviate the lot of the housewife survive to drink to its golden when, politically and personally, she is apparently dead and buried? Imagine the outcry if Tony Blair made an example of the housewife's foresight in the way Margaret Thatcher once did. The title has been banished to the social history archives and now rears its head only in the unreconstructed genres of TV quiz shows and market research questionnaires.

The spic 'n' span 50s feather duster image of the British housewife went out with Hilda Ogden and Ken Dodd. Instead, the debate about women and domesticity has evolved into an anxiety not about keeping house but about bringing up children. So whereas it was better for "him" for a woman to stay at home, the argument now is it's best for the kids. The observation Jerman made about the mental "pay-off' a housewife makes still has echoes. What's best for the children may not be what's best for the modern woman. The lack of status implied by the prefix "just" a housewife has not died with the term but now attaches itself to the word mother.

"Working mother" now rolls off the tongue with the ease with which "housewife" once did. These women no longer go into voluntary exile if they marry or have children but, argues Mary Dodkins, NWR's marketing co-ordinator, there is still a need for a space where you are not someone's wife or mother, a place where you can be opinionated without fear of the consequences. Today, most members work, so the rules have been extended - no discussion about the domestic still stands but their jobs are now an out-of-bounds subject.

"The purpose of the meetings is still to stimulate the grey cells," Dodkins says. "Many women feel limited by their job and position. It is not a place where they feel their real thoughts can be said, so the more controversial the discussions are, the better."

For Kathryn de Motte, at 37 the youngest area organiser of a 30-strong NWR group in Nottingham, the emphasis on speaking your mind is crucial. She works as a secretary and finds herself having opinions she says she wouldn't articulate anywhere else."We all have different hats," she explains. "I'm a mother, I'm a wife and I work, and there's never a space to be me. We get together not to exercise or diet but to open our minds."

De Motte speaks enthusiastically about the subjects to which the speakers and discussions have introduced her: badgers, local history and learning how to juggle at the lighter end; Kafka, fox-hunting and infant mortality rates at the more serious.

But as women juggle the domestic with work, is there a need for the NWR? "It's still important to be with like-minded women," de Motte says. "Women still have more pressures than men. In my husband's life, his strongest role is in his job, but I have that and the role of wife and mother. We need a space to be just us - without the children." Time at home, alone, without chores, is still often felt as shirking responsibility. De Motte, for example, won't attend NWR meetings if her husband is away because employing a babysitter would "leave me guilt-ridden".

So although most women can now define themselves by a paid job, it is often a definition in addition to, not instead of, domestic labour. Pauline Reymond, long-time NWR member and regional organiser in Worthing, joined the group when she was 29 and her child started school. Now 64, she notes that members have "partners" as well as husbands and many are divorced, widowed or remarried. Her life goes some way to explaining how, just as the term "housewife" has been made redundant by social forces, so it was also created by them. Reymond had to give up her job as a secretary at Royal Exchange Insurance because the company did not employ married women. "It was the way things were," she says.

Though Reymond would not have to leave her job today, some things haven't changed: no matter what we call them, it is still women who do most of the housework. The last Office of National Statistics figures showed that, at £739bn, unpaid housework was worth more than the value of the formal economy. And domesticity is still hard work. The best outcome to hope for, as far as the NWR goes, is that it will continue to fall victim to its own success.

fields.headline: Eurocrats dodge car fines
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: European commissioners and senior Brussels bureaucrats have used diplomatic immunity protection to escape prosecution for traffic offences in the past five years, the commission's vice-president Neil Kinnock admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
European commissioners and senior Brussels bureaucrats have used diplomatic immunity protection to escape prosecution for traffic offences in the past five years, the commission's vice-president Neil Kinnock admitted yesterday.

The former Labour leader, who is leading the radical reform of the working practices of the Brussels-based bureaucracy, has vowed to end the practice to avoid another scandal following allegations last year of widespread fraud, mismanagement and nepotism by the commission led by Jacques Santer.

Under commission rules, all eurocrats and former commission officials enjoy protection from legal proceedings "in respect of acts performed by them in their official capacity, including their words spoken or written". But, following last year's revelations of corruption in the commission, there is growing concern in Brussels that the privilege is being used as a licence to speed and to ignore parking fines.

Commissioners, directors-general - the most senior EU civil servants - and their chauffeurs have all been able to use the immunity rules to avoid penalties, Mr Kinnock admitted in a letter to Welsh MEP Eluned Morgan.

The revelations have called into question the entire immunity system for EU officials, which treats motoring offences as privileged acts "car ried out in the execution of their duties". In his letter to the Labour MEP, Mr Kinnock revealed that immunity waivers have been granted in 10 cases involving 26 commission staff in the past five years.

He added: "In just under 100 cases in the last five years, immunity has been claimed in relation to traffic offences alleged to have been committed by commissioners, directors-general and their chauffeurs.

"I have reviewed this arrangement and am inclined to the view that it should be ended."

Mrs Morgan said: "I am delighted that Neil is taking swift action to end the unjustifiable use of immunity by commissioners and top officials to escape prosecution."

fields.headline: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: The dog has reached puberty. It has raging hormones and is in love with my leg. I have replaced one teenager with another. Now that Daughter has grown up and become charming, studious and tidy, the dog is wrecking our home, up all night wanting to party and obsessed with sex.
fields.body:
The dog has reached puberty. It has raging hormones and is in love with my leg. I have replaced one teenager with another. Now that Daughter has grown up and become charming, studious and tidy, the dog is wrecking our home, up all night wanting to party and obsessed with sex.

In fact, the dog is a teenager and baby all in one. It cannot feed itself or tell us what hurts when it feels poorly. I now have an everlasting baby to flap over. And it has medical problems. Its mutant jaw looks like Dracula inverted and hampers chewing and breathing.

"Bloody breeders!" shouts the vet. "You cannot breed from this dog."

"Rubbish," shouts the breeder, "What does that vet know?"

Who am I to believe? I choose the vet. But should I have another dog? Yes, say the Daughter and the Gardener. No, says my Mother. "Are you raving mad?"

But the dog needs a friend. Another boxer with a tail. Yes, says the vet. Docking is illegal. No it isn't, say the breeders. Get a rescue dog, say the dog walkers with rescue dogs. Get a bitch. No, don't. Two bitches will be bitchy, says half the Heath. Get a dog. No, don't, says the other half. The dog will want to protect the bitch.

These advisers are no help. Hoping for guidance, I turn, naturally, to my friend Rosemary. "For goodness' sake," she shouts. "You're too old to change!"

I think this is rather a harsh criticism. And ageist. No wonder I have turned to dogs. But I am not too old to learn and I have learned that the thing to do with advisers, regarding teenagers or dogs, is to pick the ones who agree with you and do as they say. So are there any boxer dogs with tails out there? RSVP.

webTitle: Opposition grows to new sport of total fighting

fields.headline: Opposition grows to new sport of total fighting
fields.trailText: In a Milton Keynes leisure centre, Lee Hasdell, a 16-stone martial arts champion, is flinging his weaker opponent to the floor. His colossal body slides over his rival's chest; his meaty thighs lock around his neck. Fists rise, primed to pummel. "Basically," he later explained, "it's all about beating the hell out of each other."
fields.body:
In a Milton Keynes leisure centre, Lee Hasdell, a 16-stone martial arts champion, is flinging his weaker opponent to the floor. His colossal body slides over his rival's chest; his meaty thighs lock around his neck. Fists rise, primed to pummel. "Basically," he later explained, "it's all about beating the hell out of each other."

This is total fighting - a new combat sport which has only recently infiltrated the UK but is already garnering thousands of supporters. Dubbed the human equivalent of cockfighting, it is an extreme form of fighting in which participants kick and punch as well as choke and wrestle each other into submission.

Anything goes - bar eye gouging, biting, striking to the groin or throat, or bending back the fingers.

To its fans - 2,000 of whom will on March 12 flock to Milton Keynes to watch eight of Britain's 30 professional total fighters, and many of whom will attend a similar contest in Sunderland in April - this is the most sophisticated and challenging form of fighting, incorporating techniques taken from kick-boxing, boxing, wrestling, judo and jujitsu. But to its opponents, including the British Medical Association and the boxing fraternity, total fighting - known as extreme fighting in the US - is nothing more than a glamorised form of brawling.

"It's just a street fight in a ring," says the boxing promoter, Frank Warren. "Basically, it's just about them punching the crap out of each other."

The sport originated in Japan, where millions follow it on TV, and some 50,000 spectators fill the arena.

Dereck Wade, a consultant neurosurgeon at the Rivermead rehabilitation centre in Oxford, said: "My guess is there will be a far higher rate of deaths and severe injuries from this than from boxing, which is regulated and doesn't have the additional threat of strangling."

But Lee Hasdell, a 6ft 1in, shaven-headed man, discounts such anxieties by pointing to the fact that a doctor and paramedics have been at the ringside of each of the five contests he has held so far, with an ambulance waiting on hand. "We have an amazing safety record. In 80 matches, not one person's had to spend a night in hospital."

But the BMA is concerned that the sport has not been independently monitored, and that the safety regulations have been thrashed out between the local authority licensing the fights, Milton Keynes, and Mr Hasdell, the organiser and promoter.

Bill O'Neill, the BMA's science and ethics adviser, said: "We are calling for a complete ban unless it can be demonstrated there's no significant risk of brain damage or eye damage, and until some independent expert rules and regulations are laid down."

The association's anxieties have been mirrored by the Labour MP for Dartford and practising GP, Howard Stoate, who is to put down an early day motion to galvanise opposition to the sport.

The former British heavyweight boxing champion, Sir Henry Cooper, said: "If you were the sensitive type, you'd call this barbaric. With this, unlike boxing, there's no discipline, and that's why a lot of these guys have gone into it. They can't take it - in their lives or their fighting."

The lack of independent medical testing could also be a recipe for disaster, according to Brendan Ingle, a promoter and trainer in Sheffield. "If you are a professional boxer in Britain, you have to have a brain scan and a full medical every year, you have to go through checks and counter checks and you can still get seriously injured.

"You don't have to have that with total fighting... It's out-and-out violence. It's absolutely vicious."

Mr Hasdell says the controversial sport is safer than boxing because the head is not the sole target. But even he admits the success of his "mission" to ensure total fighting replaces boxing in the popularity stakes depends on gaining some sort of external regulation which might bestow respectability.

fields.headline: Grand design
fields.standfirst: Culture palace boasts biggest stage outside London
fields.trailText: The Lowry, the shimmering stainless-steel culture palace nearing completion on a peninsula jutting into the Manchester ship canal, will boast the largest stage in England outside London.
fields.body:
The Lowry, the shimmering stainless-steel culture palace nearing completion on a peninsula jutting into the Manchester ship canal, will boast the largest stage in England outside London.

But it is still not quite big enough for the sets of Rudolph Nureyev's version of La Bayadére which the Paris Opera Ballet is bringing to Salford to open the centre's 1,730-seat Lyric theatre in May.

So having been transported from France in 15 huge trucks, the sets will spill over into the back-stage scene dock to leave plenty of dance space for the company which is making its first visit to Britain for 15 years.

It is stopping for just five performances before packing all the scenery back into the trucks and heading south down the M6 to the channel.

There should be no crowding problems in the enormous pit, which will be filled with the Hallé Orchestra in an unusual accompanying role.

Ticket prices will range from £48 ("There won't be a better view of any stage anywhere than from the two seats at the centre of the front row of the dress circle," boasted Robert Robson, the Lowry's theatres director) to £12 in an upper circle which will be close enough to the action to make opera glasses redundant.

While the French dancers leap next door, the Royal National Theatre will perform its new production of Ted Hughes's version of the Oresteia by Aeschylus in the smaller Quays theatre (466 seats). The style of the Quays is a blend of the Cottesloe at the National and the Swan at Stratford.

The Lowry project, costing £96.4m and including a spectacular footbridge which will link it to the Imperial War Museum North across the ship canal, also provides space for 350 works by the Salford artist in whose honour it is named.

Within weeks, Lowry's paintings and drawings will be moved from their present home near Salford university to new galleries running alongside the two auditoria and a Lowry study centre will be established in a tall drum tower.

The rest of the building will be given over to restaurants, bars, shops, wide public spaces and Artworks, a unique gallery area which sets out to encourage creativity in adults and children.

The Lowry, the national landmark millennium project for the arts, attracted a unique package of huge grants from the arts council, the millennium commission and the heritage lottery fund.

Its significance in the region is the equivalent of the Covent Garden redevelopment in London.

It has already been dubbed Salford's Guggenheim and will be closely watched after its big glass doors officially open on April 28 to see if it can succeed in pulling in the crowds from Salford and beyond.

The Royal Shakespeare Company will make a visit early in 2001.

webTitle: Fugitive MI5 agent denies breaching secrecy code

fields.headline: Fugitive MI5 agent denies breaching secrecy code
fields.trailText: David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, will today formally reject government claims that he broke his duty of confidence by disclosing information about the activities of the security and intelligence services, insisting that he spoke out in the public interest.
fields.body:
David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, will today formally reject government claims that he broke his duty of confidence by disclosing information about the activities of the security and intelligence services, insisting that he spoke out in the public interest.

John Wadham, his lawyer and director of Liberty, the civil rights group, will deliver his defence to the treasury solicitor's office in London.

The Guardian exclusively revealed on Saturday that after failing to get him extradited from France to face a criminal trial under the official secrets act, the government is suing Mr Shayler in the civil courts, claiming breaches of confidence and contract, and of infringing crown copyright.

Mr Shayler's lawyers deny he breached any obligations or that his disclosures caused "injury to the national interest". They say he is protected by article 10 of the European convention on human rights, guaranteeing freedom of expression.

Mr Shayler yesterday named two serving MI6 officers whom he says were involved in a plot to assassinate Colonel Muammar Gadafy, the Libyan leader, in 1996, according the Observer newspaper.

Mr Shayler last night said he had named them - and others - in a letter to Jack Straw, the home secretary, last November. The Observer said it did not publish the names for legal reasons.

Mr Shayler said: "The government realises I can survive abroad and that I can continue to cause embarrassment. It continues to ignore crimes that have been exposed and instead has decided to sue me because I am the enemy."

The foreign office commented: "We have never denied knowledge of coup attempts against Colonel Gadafy. We have always described allegations of involvement as fantasy. We have nothing to add or subtract."

webTitle: Mobile phones necessity of modern life, say users

fields.headline: Mobile phones necessity of modern life, say users
fields.trailText: Britons rate their mobile phones as a necessity of modern life - whether they are on the street, in bed or even on the toilet, a survey revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Britons rate their mobile phones as a necessity of modern life - whether they are on the street, in bed or even on the toilet, a survey revealed yesterday.

Mobiles, once identified as the ultimate "yuppie" accessory, are no longer seen as a luxury by most of Britain's 24m owners, with 62% seeing them as an essential part of life.

The survey of more than 1,000 adults, commissioned by Philips Consumer Communications, found that eight out of 10 mobile owners said they would never throw their phone away, while 15% use their mobiles more than their home phones.

Despite widespread public antipathy, 68% of owners are not embarrassed to use a mobile phone in public. More than 2.5m people answered their phone on the toilet and nearly 250,000 responded to calls while having sex.

While almost half of all mobiles were initially purchased for use in emergencies such as a car breakdown, two-thirds of calls are social and a third are work-related.

The survey also found that, regardless of the range of hi-tech features, reception quality and price remain the most important considerations for buyers, while text messaging was important to 20% of 16- to 24-year-olds, but had little appeal for the over-45s.

webTitle: Police check on fresh child abuse allegations

fields.headline: Police check on fresh child abuse allegations
fields.standfirst: Inquiry covers 20,000 children who stayed in council homes
fields.trailText: Police in the west country have launched an investigation into what could turn out to be one of the country's biggest child abuse scandals involving as many as 20,000 children in council care.
fields.body:
Police in the west country have launched an investigation into what could turn out to be one of the country's biggest child abuse scandals involving as many as 20,000 children in council care.

Avon and Somerset police have set up incident rooms in Bristol and Taunton to investigate allegations of institutional abuse during the 1960s, 70s and 80s at residential homes. More than 30 officers have been assigned to the inquiry, which could take up to five years.

The investigation has so far focused on three homes: the Olands observation and assessment centre in Milverton, near Taunton, Somerset, the Kingswood assessment centre and the Kingswood secure unit, both in Bristol.

More than 20,000 boys passed through the two Bristol centres before they were demolished in the 1980s, and several hundred boys and girls passed through Milverton before it closed in 1993.

The inquiry was launched after several former residents came forward following the recent Bryn Alyn care home scandal in north Wales.

Several arrests have already been made but senior detectives are said to be overwhelmed by the scale of the abuse they have uncovered.

The inquiry started after allegations of abuse from former residents of the Forde Park approved school in Newton Abbott, Devon.

Officers found a disturbing pattern of abuse at the Bristol homes and the investigation was expanded. Many of the suspected victims were boys and girls who passed through the homes before moving back home, to foster homes or another institution.

Steve Pilkington, chief constable of Avon and Somerset, said: "This should put out a strong message to those people who prey on the vulnerable."

A force spokesman confirmed a 50-year-old man arrested in connection with the Taunton inquiry had been released on police bail. A 55-year-old man who worked in the Milverton home was bailed pending further inquiries.

A Somerset social services spokesman said: "We are co-operating fully with the police and will do all we can to assist them in their inquiries."

News of the investigation comes two weeks after the publication of Lost in Care, the report of the Waterhouse inquiry into abuse in north Wales children's homes.

Sir Ronald Waterhouse recommended a massive overhaul of the care system after uncovering a paedophile ring that targeted hundreds of young people in care in the 70s and 80s.

The report condemned social workers, children's home staff, police and local councils and made more than 70 recommendations to protect the 4,000 children cared for by local authorities in Wales.

In another inquiry, the Metropolitan police are investigating claims that 200 children in the south London borough of Lambeth may have been sexually and physically abused between 1974 and 1994.

The Operation Middleton investigation, which began last year after police in Merseyside arrested a former council worker, gained momentum after five more victims contacted police after the Waterhouse report.

The allegations cover more than 20 homes run by Lambeth.

The inquiry, which centres on Lambeth council's social services department, has led to seven arrests and the suspension of 10 staff employed by the borough.

fields.headline: Two-tier airspace mooted
fields.standfirst:
More about the privatisation of air traffic control
Air traffic control explained
fields.trailText: Plans to offer a fast-track service in the skies for airlines that pay extra for the privilege are being discussed by the national air traffic service with air traffic control staff.
fields.body:
Plans to offer a fast-track service in the skies for airlines that pay extra for the privilege are being discussed by the national air traffic service with air traffic control staff.

British Airways and Lufthansa, the German airline, have expressed interest in the idea, although air traffic controllers are worried about the threat to safety.

Under the plan, airlines such as BA would be guaranteed a take-off and landing time by air traffic control in return for a bigger payment to the national air traffic service (Nats). If Nats did not meet its target, the airline would not have to pay the extra money.

The plan was last night described by Nats as "hypothetical". A spokesman agreed that it had been presented to staff, but said there would need to be a European-wide agreement among air traffic control services before it could be implemented.

The department of transport said the transport secretary, John Prescott, was opposed to the idea.

The plan has alarmed air traffic controllers in the run-up to the sale of the service, legislation for which is going through parliament. The sell-off is being strongly opposed by staff.

Paul Noon, the general secretary of the air traffic controller's union, said: "This confirms our many fears about privatisation." He said controllers needed to concentrate on getting planes safely up and down. "Expecting them to assess whether those planes are first- or second-class customers is an unnecessary and potentially dangerous distraction."

BA said: "We and a number of airlines are interested in a first-track service in airspace - 25% of our flights are late and we are examining ways of improving them."

Nats claimed that the proposals would not threaten safety. "Separation standards between aircraft would remain, and aircraft would not be treated differently in the air. But if you have a very exclusive service for premium passengers, you would want your aircraft to arrive bang on time."

fields.headline: Primary school pupils 'starved of PE'
fields.trailText: The government's back-to-basics curriculum in primary schools is starving children of physical education, according to a report, which ministers tried to suppress, from Sport England.
fields.body:
The government's back-to-basics curriculum in primary schools is starving children of physical education, according to a report, which ministers tried to suppress, from Sport England.

Trevor Brooking, the sport funding agency's chairman, said in the report, published today, that the squeeze on PE was misguided and likely to cause permanent damage to pupils' sporting talent.

The agency's first comprehensive survey of sport and PE in England's primary schools since 1994 found a "disturbing" cut in the number of six- to eight-year-olds getting the recommended two hours a week of PE.

This fell from 32% in 1994 to 11% last year. For nine- to 11-year-olds, the proportion getting two hours PE fell from 46% to 21% over the same period.

Mr Brooking, a former West Ham and England player, said: "Unless youngsters get into PE and sport at primary school age, you've lost them.

"If children aren't shown how to kick a ball, catch, or hold a racquet at that stage, it's very difficult for them to pick it up later in life."

Sources at Sport England said ministers tried to delay publication of the report to avoid embarrassing the government before it publishes its strategy for sport.

A draft Sport England press release criticising pressures on the curriculum had been toned down after political pressure.

The British Heart Foundation said it was "deeply concerned" by the survey.

Dr Vivienne Press, assistant medical director, said: "Learning at an early age that sport and physical activity are not only beneficial to health, but also enjoyable, is important in establishing good exercise patterns for life."

The department for education said: "We are committed to improving the quality of teaching and learning of PE in schools and the provision of sporting opportunities."

fields.headline: U-turn by Blair on GM food
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday embarked on the biggest u-turn of his premiership when he admitted for the first time that genetically modified foods could pose a health risk.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, Nick Watt  and  David Hencke
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday embarked on the biggest u-turn of his premiership when he admitted for the first time that genetically modified foods could pose a health risk.

In a move which was welcomed by environmentalists, Mr Blair said he understood the "legitimate public concern" which he had dismissed as over-reaction only last year.

The change in attitude came as it emerged that the biotechnology industry is unable to find enough British farmers willing to grow GM crops during trials due to start on Wednesday.

Mr Blair made it clear that he had radically altered his opinion when he said: "There's no doubt that there is potential for harm, both in terms of human safety and in the diversity of our environment, from GM foods and crops."

In an article in the Independent on Sunday, the prime minister said he understood the "cause for legitimate public concern", adding that the government was proceeding "very cautiously indeed" because of the potential ill effects.

Downing Street insisted that policy had not changed. A source said that Mr Blair was still committed to scientific research, and that it was too soon to reach a definitive position on GM foods.

However, there is no doubt that Mr Blair's remarks represent a significant shift in his position, which will be seen as another attempt to reach out to Labour's traditional supporters. There is disquiet in the party over the issue. There was a feeling last year that Mr Blair appeared to be over-zealous in defending the interests of GM producers.

Given the Tories' unease over GM foods, the government is likely to have calculated that there is more political capital on going cool on the issue, at least in the run up to the general election.

The attempts to play down the prime minister's remarks also cut little ice with environmental groups, who remember how Mr Blair told the House of Commons last year how he was eating genetically modified food.

Charles Secrett, executive director of Friends of the Earth, said: "At long last Mr Blair is listening to the public who have made it perfectly clear that they don't want GM food on their plates, or GM crops in their fields. Now it is essential that this approach is backed with action."

The prime minister will today be provided with a reminder of his earlier enthusiasm when the Guardian discloses that Britain agreed to help the United States sell GM food to Europe in 1998, after intense pressure from President Bill Clinton.

Documents obtained under the US freedom of information act show that Mr Clinton lobbied Mr Blair to open up Britain and Europe during private talks in Downing Street in 1998. A day after the meeting Britain set in motion changes to make it easier for more GM food to be sold in Britain and Europe.

The meeting came as the prime minister was insisting that scientific research should be allowed to continue into GM foods because it could be the technology of the future.

Yesterday's sea-change in his attitude came on the eve of a three-day conference in Edinburgh at which the critics of the industry are expected to lambast the government.

The government also faces another embarrassment because the backlash against GM crops has been so great that the biotech industry is unable to find enough British farmers willing to grow them during trials due to start on March 1.

An emergency meeting of the industry committee on February 8 was held because they could not find enough farmers to provide 75 fields for the four years of trials needed to prove that GM crops are not harmful to the environment. Another meeting is to be held on March 10 to decide what to do.

Planting should start in 25 fields on Wednesday but not enough farmers can be found to take part. The trials are a cornerstone of government's tests to see if the environment is harmed by the growing of these crops.

English Nature and an independent body of scientists were to spend four years examining the evidence and advising the government. The industry had agreed to hold off commercial sales until the study is complete. With his new doubts about the technology it is hard to see how Mr Blair could allow the crops to be planted without first reassuring the green lobby with independent scientific evidence that they were safe.

Yesterday a ship carrying GM soya from the United States turned back after a two day occupation by five Greenpeace volunteers. They were arrested after chaining themselves inside the anchor room but later released without charge.

webTitle: From gung-ho to acceptance of 'legitimate concerns'

fields.headline: From gung-ho to acceptance of 'legitimate concerns'
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair came into office gung-ho about genetic engineering and the great benefits it would bring.
fields.body:
Tony Blair came into office gung-ho about genetic engineering and the great benefits it would bring.

His premiership was marked from the start by his wish to be close to big business and partnership with the bio-tech companies was part of this.

Genetically modified soya was already on supermarket shelves in many prepared foods and the invasion of GM grains into the whole food chain seemed inevitable.

The American government and companies like Monsanto had made sure GM soya and maize were mixed at harvest and Europe was told it was no longer possible to separate them.

All that was before the European consumer backlash, the size and speed of which took everyone by surprise. The full horror of the BSE scandal, and the effects of tampering with food for increased profit, has left a deep mark.

Successive food scares led to Europe-wide demands for clear labelling and the consumers' right to choose.

The British firm Iceland, out of the conviction of its owner Martin Walker, banned GM food from own-label products and found a steady increase in sales.

Gradually the supermarket giants followed suit as it was clear that many consumers were not prepared to buy GM foods at all. Products containing GM tomatoes that were selling well when Mr Blair came to power disappeared from the shelves.

Scientifically and politically things were changing too, although listening to Mr Blair, it seemed nothing had. His closest allies, Peter Mandelson and Jack Cunningham, first at the ministry of agriculture and then fixer in charge of the cabinet office, were still just as enthusiastic about the new technology.

They stood firm with the prime minister that this was a great opportunity for British science to lead the world and cash in on patents.

A year ago Mr Blair said: "Standing in front of a stampede is never a nice business. But occasionally it has to be done. Parts of the media, and the Conservatives, have conducted such an extraordinary campaign of distortion about the great GM food saga that it's hard to know where to begin.

"There is no scientific evidence on which to justify a ban on GM foods and crops... we should resist the tyranny of pressure groups."

In September the government was embarrassed by stories about Lord Sainsbury, the science minister. Although he had put his affairs in Diatech into a blind trust it was clear that he had a large financial stake in genetic patents. Mr Blair was unmoved and Lord Sainsbury remains in post but it did not improve the atmosphere.

The government was largely saved by Michael Meacher, the environment minister, after the European Union and the government had granted permission for bio-tech companies to begin farm-scale plantings.

Mr Meacher got a four-year voluntary agreement from the industry to hold off on commercial plantings while English Nature and scientists do field tests to see if the wider countryside is affected by the growing of GM crops.

The growing band of organic farmers also feared that their products would lose their status if tainted by GM pollen.

Scientific evidence has begun to mount that these crops could harm wildlife. In the US caterpillars of the Monarch butterfly died when they ate GM pollen. In the UK the life of ladybirds was shortened when they fed on aphids which live on GM crops.

In the debate about free trade and biotechnology the EU won a victory in January. New rules covering the import of GM seeds were written into the biodiversity convention, allowing countries to refuse to accept them.

On the eve of the three-day conference in Edinburgh beginning today to examine the whole GM debate, Mr Blair finally did a u-turn and acknowledged "legitimate public concern".

He now understands these "anxieties". These will soon, no doubt, be reflected in more cautious policies, some of which may be spelt out in Edinburgh by Mo Mowlam, the cabinet office minister, who has always had doubts about the GM dreams of the PM.
