fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Man charged with killings
A man was remanded in custody yesterday charged with the murders of Andrew Robb, 19, and David McIlwaine, 18, both from Portadown in Co Armagh, whose bodies were discovered on a roadside near Tandragee, last Sunday morning. Steven Leslie Revels, 19, a process operator from Tandragee, Co Armagh, appeared before Armagh magistrates court.
fields.body:
Man charged with killings
A man was remanded in custody yesterday charged with the murders of Andrew Robb, 19, and David McIlwaine, 18, both from Portadown in Co Armagh, whose bodies were discovered on a roadside near Tandragee, last Sunday morning. Steven Leslie Revels, 19, a process operator from Tandragee, Co Armagh, appeared before Armagh magistrates court.

10th successive sell-out at Dome
The Millennium Dome recorded its 10th successive sell-out yesterday with more than 250,000 visitors over half-term. A spokesman said: "We've had families coming, and tourism has been picking up."

Beckham stalker detained
A woman who has been stalking David Beckham, the Manchester United and England player, was detained yesterday under the mental health act. Chinyela Obue, 36, had bombarded him with mail and broke into his flat in Alderley Edge, Cheshire.

Library hunts for lost voices
The British Library yesterday mounted a hunt for "lost" recordings of the voices of writers such as George Orwell, Thomas Hardy and DH Lawrence, which are missing from the National Sound Archive.

It wants to include interviews and readings in Chapter & Verse - 1,000 Years of English Literature. "We hope that people who made amateur recordings will trawl through their attics," said Toby Oakes, curator of literature and drama.

Boy, 11, survives 600ft cliff fall
An 11-year-old boy survived with back injuries and concussion yesterday after he was blown 600ft down Boulby cliff on the North Yorkshire and Cleveland border.

The boy, from Ormesby, Middlesbrough, who was not named, had been out walking with his parents and their dog in a force eight gale. The boy's father, who was walking ahead, did not realise his son was missing until the dog returned, police said.
Linus Gregoriadis

3 share £6.7m
Three tickets shared the £6.7m National Lottery jackpot with numbers 3, 5, 6, 8, 16, and 45. The bonus ball was 1. One ticket won the top £250,000 prize in the Thunderball draw with numbers 3, 11, 21, 26, 30 and Thunderball 12.

fields.headline: Cynics not welcome
fields.standfirst: Tony BlairNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: An extract from the text of the prime minister's anniversary speech at the Old Vic theatre in London yesterday.
fields.body:
This is an extract from the text of the prime minister's anniversary speech at the Old Vic theatre in London yesterday:

We can be immensely proud of our record in 33 months of this government. Any Tory government with that record on the economy alone, would be lauded from the skies.

Instead, the focus is almost entirely not on what we've done; but on what we've yet to do. Why? Because of expectations.

Take the NHS. We set out to transform the NHS. We always said it would take time. And it will. That does not mean we have failed. It means it is difficult. But we will turn it round. There is massive change and reform and investment now going into the NHS.

Rebuilding it is crucial to rebuilding trust in politics, to showing people that political action can make a difference. That is why I will do it and am content to be judged by it.

What I will not do is what the rightwing press and Tory party want: to say that the NHS is hopeless and that the only response is to force people to take out private medical insurance. We will never go down that road. It isn't true and it would not work.

But the NHS is just an example of expectations. When we take power, no matter what we do, our rightwing opponents attack us for failing the country. Of course they do - they think it's their job.

But it is the fate of progressive parties, however, that parts of their own side join in. Their motivation is different. Their desired outcome - a more leftist Labour government - is the opposite of the right. But unwittingly they help spread the seeds of disillusion which the right can harvest.

And all this is nothing new. Every Labour government has faced the same: from the revolt against the 1924 government on unemployment benefit; to the 1949 resignations over health charges; to the crippling disputes over public spending in the 1960s; to the winter of discontent in the 1970s.

One hundred years on, we are older and wiser. We are stronger, more ideologically united, more strategically capable. So are we destined to repeat history this time? No, not if we learn from its lessons.

First, in government, it is vital in part just to get things right, to govern well. We don't take economic risks, we don't swerve off course because of a few newspaper headlines. We have learnt there's nothing radical about incompetent economic management.

If we believe, as we do, we have the best economic and public-service policies for Britain, the challenge is not to change them, but to carry them through.

Second, we must remain the party of progress, of the future. Our values matter. Believe in them. But the means of realising them is not a question of ideology, but of what works. Seeing the world in these terms, allows us always to move forward, not be hidebound by doctrine or dogma.

Third, political parties require unity and leadership. That can be hard because progressives are all members of the awkward squad.

None of this means the absence of dissent between leaders and members, merely the presence of mutual understanding.

What leaders do, especially when it is difficult or unpopular, they do because they genuinely believe it to be the right thing to do. We do it out of conviction as to what is best for country and party.

We may not always be right. But the motive is sincere and it is not to betray the party's goals but to fulfil them. Of course, leaders must listen. And we do. But remember, there's only one thing the public dislikes more than a leader in control of his party, and that is a leader not in control of his party.

Fourth, the whole party has to be engaged in telling the story of the government, not just the ones at the top. The press is still mainly hostile. It always will be. We have to get out there with that big picture. Tell people what we've done. Be proud of it. Confident in it.

And never let anyone tell you that because we have not done everything, that means we have done nothing.

We are part of a wonderful tradition for which people have made great sacrifices, taken great risks but who have been sustained by moral and social values which are as valid today as they were when those 129 delegates gathered in that conference in London on February 27 1900.

Let the Labour party that was the civilising force of the 20th century, be the transforming force of British politics for the 21st century.

webTitle: Prince Charles gets a crown of feathers

fields.headline: Prince Charles gets a crown of feathers
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles was made an honorary village chief by the Amerindian natives of Guyana yesterday, and toasted his new status with a heavy local brew made from jungle root.
fields.body:
Prince Charles was made an honorary village chief by the Amerindian natives of Guyana yesterday, and toasted his new status with a heavy local brew made from jungle root.

The prince was presented with a Surama tribe head-dress fashioned from eagle feathers before a group of local girls serenaded him with a song in praise of eco-tourism.

Members of the Surama tribe - one of nine tribes scattered throughout the remote rainforest hinterland of Guyana - demonstrated how to make an alcoholic drink called pacari.

He took a sip - although his reaction was out of earshot.

The prince took a private walk into the heart of the rainforest, accompanied by Dr David Cassells, who is director general of the UN-funded conservation project in the area.

Dr Cassells said: "We would very much like a high-profile champion for our forest."

It appears that the prince was willing to oblige. After emerging from the undergrowth, he said: "It is very peaceful - the sheer size of the trees is amazing."

The 50,000 Amerindians are among the poorest of Guyana's 1m citizens.

They struggle to fend for themselves through traditional industries such as hunting and fishing, while the arrival of forestry and mining developments have imposed modern tensions.

In an attempt to protect the native population, the UN is funding an aid programme for the rain forest region, for which the prince voiced his support yesterday.

The prince is well-known for his interest in the environment. He may have felt at home in an area where experts have recorded 206 species of fish, and 120 of snakes, lizards and frogs.

They believe there may be up to 2,000 plant varieties and 450 types of bird.

Later, Prince Charles visited one of Guyana's secret marvels: the falls at Kaieteur.

Five times the height of Niagara, these waterfalls support a delicate eco-system including 100 species of orchid.

To view the Potaro river cascading 741ft down the world's longest unbroken waterfall is a privilege accorded only to a few. Tourism barely figures in the economy of Guyana.

According to Amerindian legend, the Patamona tribal chief, Kaie, paddled over the falls, sacrificing himself to the spirits to save his tribe and appease the gods.

The future of the monarchy may be uncertain, and Prince Charles's aides took no chances.

He was kept at a safe distance, one third of a mile away.

fields.headline: Prescott's grassroots warning
fields.standfirst: As Blair marks Labour centenary, deputy admits concern about losing support in party's heartlandsNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott yesterday lifted the lid on the government's biggest internal row when he admitted that ministers were failing to inspire grassroots activists who claim that Downing Street has abandoned the Labour heartlands.
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday lifted the lid on the government's biggest internal row when he admitted that ministers were failing to inspire grassroots activists who claim that Downing Street has abandoned the Labour heartlands.

Speaking hours before Tony Blair's keynote speech to mark Labour's centenary, the deputy prime minister warned of the catastrophic dangers of a party "losing heart".

In a sign of his own dissatisfaction, Mr Prescott said that Labour had undermined itself by holding elections in Scotland and Wales under proportional representation. He also gave a strong hint that he was still in favour of higher taxes.

Mr Prescott's intervention came as Mr Blair attempted to reach out to party activists by saying that he was determined to turn Labour into the "natural party of progress".

In his centenary speech at the Old Vic theatre in south London, the prime minister set out "five great goals" for the next century. They include the abolition of child poverty, full employment, creating the world's best health service and achieving educational excellence for all.

"We do not exist simply to govern," he said. "We are there to transform. It is not enough for us to be the natural party of government. We must be the natural party of progress."

But Mr Blair's attempt to reach out to the grassroots was overshadowed by Mr Prescott, who admitted in public what ministers have long complained of in private: that activists remain wary of New Labour.

Speaking on BBC1's On the Record, the deputy prime minister said that many supporters did not know what the gov ernment was doing "largely because we are not getting our message out to many of our own people".

Mr Prescott said the prime minister's reforms of the party, which were designed to encourage new members to involve themselves in Labour activities, were proving a success. But he agreed that Labour was having difficulties in bringing out its core voters.

"If you don't keep contact with your activists you will reap the kind of problems the Tories had," he said. "They begin to walk away and then the government doesn't have any support in the country. The party must have a heart to want to go out and fight."

The deputy prime minister made it clear that he understood the concerns of activists when he said taxes "could be more progressive" and he attacked the prime minister's de cision to introduce proportional representation for the elections to the devolved bodies in Scotland and Wales.

"The other thing, to be honest, I think that's undermined us a bit is that when we had this whole PR in elections, where the party [has seen its strength go down]... we've seen PR, perhaps we've had enough of it," Mr Prescott said.

The deputy prime minister tempered his remarks by say ing the government had made remarkable progress in meeting the concerns of activists, through the introduction of the minimum wage and the working families tax credit.

This message was reinforced by the prime minister in his centenary speech, when he cast himself as a "crusader" who wanted to right injustices.

But Mr Blair also issued a warning that Labour must win the support of all communities or risk losing power if it retreats back to a "narrow base" as it did in the early 1980s.

"When we have won we have won a broad coalition of support, from all walks of life, all parts of the country," the prime minister said. "When we have lost we have retreated to a narrow base."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Splash! | Shivers | Marvin's Room | For Richer Or Poorer
fields.body:
Splash!
(Ron Howard, 1984)
7pm, Disney

True love never swims smooth in this fishy little tale. Daryl Hannah is a cute mermaid, swapping fins for legs and a jaunt on terra firma with Tom Hanks's smitten human - well, as human as Hanks gets. It's romance as pure as salt spray, with swells of laughter, director Howard deftly handling the comedy: Hannah's way with a lobster in a posh restaurant is a treat. Eugene Levy is the mad scientist calling in the army (or is it Navy Seals?) to net the fair maid.

Shivers
(David Cronenberg, 1975)
10.30pm, UK Arena

Cronenberg's low-budget debut film has batty scientist Fred Doederlein infecting promiscuous Cathy Graham with an aphrodisiac parasite, so that all-and-sundry who come into contact with her shag themselves into zombiedom. What a way to go. Aside from the gruesome comic-erotic horrors, lovingly crafted by make-up man Joe Blasco, it's thought to presage the Aids era.

Marvin's Room
(Jerry Zaks, 1996)
4am, Sky Premier

A moving study of family life and love, beautifully acted by a starry ensemble. Diane Keaton's devoted middle-aged Bessie is caring for her dying father (Hume Cronyn) and elderly aunt (Gwen Verdon); but when doc Robert De Niro tells Bessie she's ill too, she needs the help of her estranged sister Meryl Streep and rebellious nephew Leonardo DiCaprio to cope. Adapted by Scott McPherson - who died young of Aids - from his own play, it may sound maudlin, but it's not.

For Richer Or Poorer
(Bryan Spicer, 1997)
8pm, Sky MovieMax

Broad feelgood farce with Kirstie Alley and Tim Allen as a couple of spoilt, rich New Yorkers who, on the lam from the IRS, hide out in an Amish community by impersonating the locals (Allen's character having seen the film Witness once). Not as crude as the Farrelly brothers' similar Kingpin - the Amish teach them the importance of simple values, they offer fashion advice - it ends surprisingly satisfyingly, though you'd like to see more of Seinfeld's Wayne Knight and mad cop Larry Miller.

fields.headline: Too much information
fields.standfirst: This week, a new Channel 4 series exposes the sordid private lives of the thirtysomething generation. Again. But why, wonders  Mark Lawson, is dirty laundry always such a turn-on for the viewers?
fields.trailText: This week, a new Channel 4 series exposes the sordid private lives of the thirtysomething generation. Again. But why is dirty laundry always such a turn-on for the viewers?
fields.body:
In the history of theatre there are many shows which lasted for only one performance: in 19th-century Europe because of riots by puritans and in 20th-century America because of poor reviews and bad box-office takings.

But for a television show (apart from an unscreened pilot) to close after a single night is a rare event. Yet last week Who Wants To Marry A Millionaire? - a planned Fox series, in which 50 women compete on air to marry a very rich bachelor - joined the television singles club when it was revealed that the prize guy in episode one was a broke hoaxer with an alleged history of domestic violence. No further programmes will be consummated.

Two points of general relevance to television are made by this fiasco: the risk posed to the medium by exhibitionists, and the fact that, in an age of general moral tolerance about sexual behaviour, relationships have become one of the most important territories for broadcasting to explore. Both of these lessons are demonstrated by The Ex-Files (Wednesday, 10.30pm, Channel 4), a new series in which people revisit old lovers in an attempt to find a pattern in their past relationships.

It's standard now to describe the accumulated influence of previous partners as "baggage". The Ex-Files is a kind of baggage search although, unlike at airports, you can conduct the check yourself. In episode one, Becky - whom viewers are told is a 35-year-old with 15 previous relationships, uncertain whether to commit to her current lover, Carl - goes back to re-open her two most important previous pieces of baggage. Guy was her first love, an older man. She deliberately ended their affair by openly snogging Luke in front of him at a party. Guy is now married with three children and running a hotel. Supposedly - it is always wise to say supposedly with television these days - he had not seen her since he found her skewered on Luke's tongue. He waited on the residents' lawn with a bottle of wine. You hoped the producers hadn't calculated that, if a spark happened still to be there, there were numerous bedrooms nearby in which it might be ignited.

When they meet on the lawn, they exchange the great social lie that neither has changed to look at, although you possibly sense a mutual relief not to be seeing that on a pillow. Speaking to the camera as she drove to meet him, Becky expressed fears that she had hurt him and claimed to be seeking "forgiveness". But, during their chat, she seems peeved that she was not given instructions to a hut somewhere in which Guy The Hermit was staring at her picture. "You got over me pretty quickly then", she chides him as he describes his emotional recovery.

There is a low-key truth to this encounter: two old lovers coolly sipping drinks and wondering if they perhaps imagined the thrashing bodies of the past. But the series, if it is to work, needs pain and hatred and, in Becky's second rendez-vous, we get it. Luke - now 30 and single and living in Denmark - meets her in Hampton Court, a site of former happy moments and therefore a promisingly dangerous place for a reunion. You get the sense that Becky sees herself as a leaver, but Luke left her.

As soon as they meet, it's like the moment in a restaurant when a domestic at one table kills all other conversation as people listen to what they hope may be a contrast but fear may be a preview. Luke, playing to a stereotype of laddish insensivity as many of the boys on Blind Date do, says that he has "spent no time thinking about my ex-girlfriends". The screen crackles with antagonism. If there were such a profession as emotional baggage-handlers, they would have walked out on strike here, demanding overtime. As they disagree over all key details of what happened, Luke says: "Am I right in thinking that it was me who ended the relationship?"

In the third section of the programme, Becky and her current luggage, Carl, walk on a Somerset beach while discussing whether they have a future and - a late-dropped detail which undermines the established tone of the show - the death of their child. Like other recent Channel 4 series - Something For The Weekend, So Graham Norton - this one seems to establish that the thirtysomething generation has no concept of emotional or sexual privacy. Television sound-men hear things that only Catholic priests in the confessional used to.

Although The Ex-Files is technically about romance, its main interest is the blood sports of the heart. Viewers are used to Blind Date. This is, with due apology to Kubrick, a kind of Eyes Wide Shut Date. Whereas someone tuning into Cilla's programme may occasionally have to sit through an encounter which went well, The Ex-Files guarantees at best wariness and at worst confrontation, although the viewer is probably most held by the possibility that a spent relationship will be recharged.

Blind Date receives most publicity when a wedding results from one of its encounters. The Ex-Files - if it works in the way that viewers and possibly producers secretly want - may be responsible for divorces. Baggage left lying around, as they warn at airports and tube stations, may be exploded.

fields.headline: Guess again
fields.trailText: The political commentator Alan Watkins observed that the long-term wisdom of any Budget usually proves the opposite of its reception in the next day's papers. Much the same is true of TV comedy, although for different reasons.
fields.body:
The political commentator Alan Watkins observed that the long-term wisdom of any Budget usually proves the opposite of its reception in the next day's papers. Chancellors cheered at the despatch box usually prove within a few years to have wrecked their party, the country or both.

Much the same is true of TV comedy, although for different reasons. Budgets are misjudged because politicians and pundits react with selfish short-termism. Critics get comedy wrong because so much humour depends on repetition of words or familiarity with characters. While thrillers need to be most expert in their opening scenes - when tension is established - comedies do their work in the final stretch: when the accumulated situations are paid off.

So, while the talent scout who turned down the Beatles has a fairly isolated infamy in the music business, any hit sit-com or sketch show - from Fawlty Towers via The Fast Show to The Royle Family - was written off by a majority of critics on the morning or the Sunday after. Experience teaches the sense of this lengthy preamble before reference to two new sketch shows starting this week, alternating in the post-Newsnight slot: Bruiser (Monday, Wednesday, 11.20pm, BBC2) and Blouse And Skirt (Tuesday, Thursday, 11.20pm, BBC2). The latter - which uses black comedians from The A Force - was unavailable for preview, but Bruiser - featuring young Footlights-type performers - was.

The clear influence on Bruiser is The League Of Gentlemen, in that five performers often appear as recurrent character types - fat toff, spivvy thirtysomething - and that familiar situations are given a sinister twist. A man coming into a shop (impossible still not to think of Python when the doorbell goes) tries to buy rat poison to kill his wife. But - as is increasingly the case with broadcast comedy - the main target is showbusiness itself. There's a spoof of TV bowls (satirically claimed to be sexy) and of countryside shows (a celebrity chooses a favourite tree against which to pee). There are several James Bond spoofs - only their edge of cruelty making them seem contemporary - and a spoof of the camerawork in Yoof shows which could have been filmed ten years ago. I was going to describe this self-reflectiveness as worrying, but the truth is we just don't know. Judging comedy is like supporting a failing football team. You have to be there next week no matter how bad it gets. Comedy is the anti-Viagra of culture, making critics impotent.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Face The Facts | Night Waves
fields.body:
Last week's acquittal of a Bahamian youth accused of killing an English tourist adds one more to the growing list of Brits whose murder abroad remains unsolved. Such crimes in Europe get widely reported - like that of the student murdered on a French train. In Face The Facts (8.0pm, Radio 4), however, John Waite discovers it's really a far wider problem, which the bereaved families claim is not treated seriously enough in Whitehall.

It's nearly six centuries since Joan of Arc was burned at the stake and 80 years since the French accorded her an annual festival after she was canonised. But La Pucelle's capacity to re-ignite the passions of the 100 Years' War seems undiminished. Luc Besson's new film, starring Milla Jovovich, with its savage portrayal of Henry VI's lumpen British soldiery running wild, is only the latest effort to blow life into the ashes. In Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) Isobel Hilton tries to separate myth and reality.

fields.headline: Boys' night in
fields.trailText: Top Ten | Monarch Of The Glen | Inside The Met: Operation Athena
fields.body:
You've worked hard all week. You've spent most of Saturday attending to a few vital chores that might just keep domestic chaos at bay. Exhausted but quietly smug, you flop out in front of the television for an evening of relaxation and jolly entertainment. And what do you get? Anguish and trauma in Casualty on BBC1, followed by the seaside follies of Sunburn. Not in the mood for formula drama? Try BBC2: documentaries about the Southall train crash, the press in China, and genealogy. Desperate for thrills, you flick to ITV: Blind Date, Family Fortunes and a Stallone movie. You're running out of options.

Things have come to a pretty pass when one's hopes for Saturday night entertainment are pinned on Channel 4, but they did their best with Top Ten, a little oasis of intelligent fun in the scheduling desert. It's a simple formula: pick a category in pop music and run through its best-selling representatives with miles of archive footage, a barbed commentary and a glamorous presenter. Saturday night's show was the best yet, and it mined a rich seam: boy bands. Paula Yates came over all fluffy during the links, but it was left to narrator Dale Winton to deliver the best jokes. Boyzone, he recalled, were regularly gobbed at during their formative years in the clubs; in this viewer's mind they will henceforth forever be "the sputum-covered quintet".

There were enough revelations to keep things juicy. Curiosity Killed The Cat appeared on Wide-Awake Club with Timmy Mallett off their heads on acid, New Kids On The Block went on Live And Kicking hopelessly drunk, East 17's Tony Mor timer became so stressed out by his party lifestyle that he got down to nine stone. Julie Burchill noted that the Bay City Rollers "looked like foetuses", and advanced the theory that teenage girls are turned on by male homosexuality. Hence, presumably, the success of Take That, a band so intensely homoerotic it's hard to believe they got out of gay clubs in one piece. "Jason and Howard were there to appeal to the older woman", claimed manager Nigel Martin-Smith. Yeah, right.

Sunday night offered an even more pronounced viewing choice. BBC1 made a blatant bid for disaffected Heartbeat fans with Monarch Of The Glen, a new drama series with lovely Scottish scenery, a handsome lead and the promise of romance to come. It also fielded a secret weapon in the shape of Richard Briers, always guaranteed to add a couple of noughts to the viewing figures. The combination of all these factors was irresistible. Granted, the story of young urbanite Archie (Alastair Mackenzie) returning to his ancestral home of Glenbogle and discovering his roots was hardly original, but it jogged along nicely, fulfilled all its promises and made you want to ring the Scottish Tourist Board.

BBC2 was having none of this escapist nonsense, and plunged gleefully into a family-size can of worms with Inside The Met: Operation Athena. What seemed certain to be a gloomy 50 minutes turned out to be bracing, inspiring television, as cameras went inside the Met's racial and violent crime task force with its director, Deputy Assistant Commissioner John Grieve. In the wake of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, Grieve was handed an unenviable brief: tackle racism within the force, step up the response to racist crimes and revisit failed investigations. In the hands of a lesser man, this might quickly have become a tale of nicely phrased excuses. Grieve, however, grasped the nettle and secured convictions in the Michael Menson case, which had hitherto been dismissed as some kind of bizarre suicide.

Grieve's methods aren't always orthodox: he took a group of young rappers to a police chiefs' conference, and interrupted policy discussions to enthuse about reggae and R&B. Home Secretary Jack Straw suggested that "he would make a good character in a series about eccentric police officers" - A Touch Of Frost with a Bob Marley soundtrack, perhaps. Reporting of racist crimes has tripled in the last two years, and the Met's commitment to Operation Athena seems, for the time being, to be rock solid. For Grieve, though, improved figures and good PR are not enough. He wants convictions in the case that will otherwise haunt the Met for ever. "I would desperately like to satisfy Neville Lawrence", he said. "That's the last job to do."

Curiosity Killed The Cat appeared on Wide-Awake Club with Timmy Mallett off their heads on acid, New Kids On The Block went on Live And Kicking hopelessly drunk, East 17's Tony Mor timer became so stressed out by his party lifestyle that he got down to nine stone. Julie Burchill noted that the Bay City Rollers "looked like foetuses", and advanced the theory that teenage girls are turned on by male homosexuality. Hence, presumably, the success of Take That, a band so intensely homoerotic it's hard to believe they got out of gay clubs in one piece. "Jason and Howard were there to appeal to the older woman", claimed manager Nigel Martin-Smith. Yeah, right. Sunday night offered an even more pronounced viewing choice. BBC1 made a blatant bid for disaffected Heartbeat fans with Monarch Of The Glen, a new drama series with lovely Scottish scenery, a handsome lead and the promise of romance to come. It also fielded a secret weapon in the shape of Richard Briers, always guaranteed to add a couple of noughts to the viewing figures. The combination of all these factors was irresistible. Granted, the story of young urbanite Archie (Alastair Mackenzie) returning to his ancestral home of Glenbogle and discovering his roots was hardly original, but it jogged along nicely, fulfilled all its promises and made you want to ring the Scottish Tourist Board. BBC2 was having none of this escapist nonsense, and plunged gleefully into a family-size can of worms with Inside The Met: Operation Athena. What seemed certain to be a gloomy 50 minutes turned out to be bracing, inspiring television, as cameras went inside the Met's racial and violent crime task force with its director, Deputy Assistant Commissioner John Grieve. In the wake of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, Grieve was handed an unenviable brief: tackle racism within the force, step up the response to racist crimes and revisit failed investigations. In the hands of a lesser man, this might quickly have become a tale of nicely phrased excuses. Grieve, however, grasped the nettle and secured convictions in the Michael Menson case, which had hitherto been dismissed as some kind of bizarre suicide. Grieve's methods aren't always orthodox: he took a group of young rappers to a police chiefs' conference, and interrupted policy discussions to enthuse about reggae and R&B. Home Secretary Jack Straw suggested that "he would make a good character in a series about eccentric police officers" - A Touch Of Frost with a Bob Marley soundtrack, perhaps. Reporting of racist crimes has tripled in the last two years, and the Met's commitment to Operation Athena seems, for the time being, to be rock solid. For Grieve, though, improved figures and good PR are not enough. He wants convictions in the case that will otherwise haunt the Met for ever. "I would desperately like to satisfy Neville Lawrence", he said. "That's the last job to do."

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous: Willem Dafoe in Streets Of Fire
fields.body:
Willem Dafoe in Streets Of Fire (Walter Hill, 1984)

Who? Angular actor perhaps more widely renowned for his (rumoured) penis size than his talent. Having played Jesus in Scorsese's 1988 Last Temptation Of Christ, and turning in a tour de force performance in David Lynch's Wild At Heart, it became apparent that despite some fine cinematic performances, his heart really lies with the theatre - particularly the NY-based avant-garde Wooster Group. He proved the point by starring in both the "erotic thriller" Body Of Evidence and Speed 2. But he's decided to take it all a bit more seriously, it seems, with upcoming roles in American Psycho and Scorsese's Gangs Of New York with Leonardo DiCaprio.

The role: Raven, the leather-clad leader of a biker gang which kidnaps rock singer Ellen Aim (Diane Lane). Although the film professes to take place in "another time, another place", its peculiarly 80s take on 50s America pretty much gives away its heritage, right down to Raven's James Dean quiff.

Best Line: To the kidnapped Ellen, as she refuses his sexual advances: "You know, you're making things really hard on yourself. You act nice, you and me fall in love for a week or two, and then I let you go. Nobody gets hurt. You see, I ain't such a bad guy. I just get excited around pretty girls."

Cringe factor: Pretty high. The reason? Black PVC fisherman's dungarees with no shirt. Enough already.

Other wannabes: Rick Moranis as Ellen's manager, and Bill Paxton as a bartender.

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin describes it as "a 50s B movie brought up to date with pulsating rock score, state-of-the-art visuals, and a refusal to take itself too seriously".

Also not starring in: Tony Scott's vampire flick The Hunger (1983) as Second Phone Booth Youth.

Streets Of Fire, Sky Cinema, Friday February 25, 11.50pm.

Lucy Barrick

webTitle: Prescott rules out deal with Livingstone

fields.headline: Prescott rules out deal with Livingstone
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone will today intensify speculation that he is on the verge of abandoning the Labour party when he makes his most confident prediction that he would be swept into office as London mayor if he stood as an independent.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone will today intensify speculation that he is on the verge of abandoning the Labour party when he makes his most confident prediction that he would be swept into office as London mayor if he stood as an independent.

As John Prescott made clear that the Labour leadership sees no grounds for a compromise deal with the former GLC leader, Mr Livingstone said that he "desperately" wanted to be mayor.

"All the polls show I can win," he will tell BBC1's Panorama tonight. "I desperately want it. Almost every aspect of my waking life is thinking about the nuts and bolts of how you would now run London."

Mr Livingstone has still not made up his mind whether to stand as an independent because of the emotional wrench of leaving the party he has supported for more than 30 years. He also knows that Labour's Millbank headquarters would do its best to destroy him. The first hints of a dirty tricks campaign came yesterday when Sunday newspapers reported on his sex life, and his support for Sinn Fein in the early 1980s, when the IRA was bombing Britain.

However, the chances of an independent campaign appeared to increase yesterday when Mr Prescott ruled out a deal with the MP for Brent East on funding for London Underground. There has been speculation that Mr Livingstone would agree to remain on board if Mr Prescott abandoned Labour's plans to fund the tube through a public-private partnership.

Mr Prescott made it clear he would not offer any concessions when the two meet today to discuss the Labour ballot. Speaking on BBC1's On the Record, the deputy prime minister said: "The public-private partnership was in our manifesto. Ken says he supports the manifesto. Ken voted for it... I can't change the manifesto any more than he can."

There was still speculation last night that Mr Prescott might adopt Mr Livingstone's idea of issuing public bonds to finance the planned £2.5bn Crossrail line through the centre of London. But it is understood that this would not be enough for Mr Livingstone.

Mr Prescott warned him against a "walk in the wilderness", saying he would go the way of Oswald Mosley, David Owen and Derek Hatton, who all failed politically after leaving the Labour party.

In a Panorama interview tonight, Mr Livingstone makes clear that an independent candidacy remains a strong possibility, by warning of a "meltdown" in Labour's vote in London if Frank Dobson stands for mayor. "I don't think Frank is electable," he says. "He's indelibly stained as the stooge of Downing Street. As we've seen in Wales, you can't escape once you've got that albatross round your neck."

Mr Livingstone adds to the theory of a "Millbank stitch-up" by telling the programme that he was told the results of Labour's ballot by an internal source within half an hour of the polls closing.

He admits that by standing as an independent he would leave himself vulnerable to attacks, because of his written assurances that he would abide by Labour's selection process. He says that breaking his word would be "probably the worst thing I've done in public life".

fields.headline: Beau Jack
fields.standfirst: World champion boxer who ended his days as a hotel shoeshine boy
fields.trailText: Beau Jack, the world lightweight boxing champion of the 1940s, who has died aged 78, fought before sellout crowds at New York's Madison Square Garden three times in one month alone. Yet, in a tragic irony typical of his profession, he ended his working life as he had begun: toiling as a shoe-shiner in the lobby of a Miami hotel, largely forgotten by all but a handful of boxing insiders and fight aficionados.
fields.body:
Beau Jack, the world lightweight boxing champion of the 1940s, who has died aged 78, fought before sellout crowds at New York's Madison Square Garden three times in one month alone. Yet, in a tragic irony typical of his profession, he ended his working life as he had begun: toiling as a shoe-shiner in the lobby of a Miami hotel, largely forgotten by all but a handful of boxing insiders and fight aficionados.

A full three decades before the legendary venue hosted the Muhammad Ali-Joe Frazier epics of the early 1970s, Jack's ring exploits had established the Garden as the most famous indoor sports centre in the world. Indeed, for an all-too-brief period during the war years, the hard-hitting boxer from Augusta, Georgia, was the most popular fighter in the United States, headlining on a record 21 occasions before an estimated 350,000 fans.

Jack packed a fierce punch in either hand; a legacy of his teenage apprenticeship in the brutal "Battle Royals," an illegal form of the sport dating back to the days of slavery in which four or five blindfolded black fighters would flail away at one another until only two remained on their feet. The surviving pair would then be allowed to remove their masks and proceed to box. This experience helped shape Jack's survival instincts and a powerhouse style which made him such a huge box office draw.

He is probably best remem bered for his 10-round victory over world champion Bob Montgomery in April 1944 in the so-called "War Bonds Fight," tickets to which were only available through the purchase of war bonds. Although Montgomery's title was not at stake, the sale of 15,822 bonds generated a record gate of $36m. Many who purchased bonds left tickets at the box office for US servicemen, and Montgomery and Jack - both privates in the US Army - declined to accept purses for the fight.

The highlight of the evening came when the lights were dimmed and a spotlight picked out a familiar-looking uniformed figure standing in the front row. Huge cheers shook the arena as "Sgt Joe Louis" was introduced to the crowd.

Jack was born Sidney Walker and, exposed to racism from an early age, honed his boxing skills in a local boys' club. He launched his professional career in 1940 in Massachusetts, where his relentless ferocity quickly established him as a leading attraction. On arrival in New York in 1942, a third-round knockout of Allie Stolz earned him a match with Tippy Larkin for the New York Boxing Association's version of the vacant world lightweight title. Jack won it on a third-round knockout. Six months later Montgomery outpointed him and, although Jack won the return over 15 rounds, Montgomery turned the tables again and Jack was never able to regain the title.

His nemesis throughout his long career was fellow Georgian Ike Williams. Williams not only ended Jack's bid to capture the world lightweight title with a sixth- round stoppage in 1948; he also sent him into retirement by knocking him out when they met for the fourth time in August 1956. Jack finished with a record of 83 wins, five draws and 24 defeats.

After retiring, he moved to Miami Beach where he trained fighters at the famous Fifth Street Gym. Financially impoverished, he became determined that future fighters would not suffer his plight and campaigned passionately for a pension plan for boxers. He was also inducted into the international boxing hall of fame.

Jack spent his final years battling Parkinson's disease. He is survived by three daughters and two sons.

Sidney Walker (Beau Jack), boxer, born April 1 1921; died February 9 2000

fields.headline: Scots parliament at risk
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland's proposed new parliament building may be scrapped because of soaring costs. The original estimate for the building at Holyrood, designed by the Catalan architect, Enric Miralles, was £40m, but latest reports put the cost at £230m and rising.
fields.body:
Scotland's proposed new parliament building may be scrapped because of soaring costs. The original estimate for the building at Holyrood, designed by the Catalan architect, Enric Miralles, was £40m, but latest reports put the cost at £230m and rising.

Yesterday, the parliament's presiding officer, Sir David Steel, MSP, admitted that the scheme was over budget, although he did not know the exact cost, and said that the Scottish parliament would have to decide on its viability.

He refused to rule out the possibility that the project may have to be axed.

First minister Donald Dewar approved the scheme while he was Scottish secretary, before devolution last year.

Critics are calling the project Donald's Dome and say that he should take personal responsibility for its problems. It was originally thought that the building would be ready in the autumn of 2001, but it is not now expected to be completed until December, 2002.

Sir David, speaking on BBC Scotland's Holyrood Live programme, said that the original cost was misleading because it had only been for the construction of the building and did not include other factors including the purchase of the site, demolition or VAT.

fields.headline: Tide of death sweeps Mozambique
fields.standfirst:
Government appeals for help as just five helicopters battle to save thousands stranded in flood

More about the floods in Mozambique
fields.trailText: Government appeals for help as just five helicopters battle to save thousands stranded in flood
fields.body:
Dozens, possibly hundreds, of people were swept to their deaths by surging flood waters in Mozambique yesterday as too few rescue helicopters battled to save survivors clinging to trees and roofs, and crammed into ever shrinking strips of high ground.

The Mozambican government appealed for more aircraft to back up five South African military helicopters which are battling to save thousands of people from surging river waters.

Up to 60,000 people were yesterday attempting to flee the town of Chokwe, where waters rose by about six feet in a few hours and were predicted to surge significantly higher with a new bout of flooding. Surrounding low-lying villages have completely disappeared.

One helicopter pilot wept as he described his desperation at being able to save just a few dozen people at a time.

"People are just disappearing. We can't get to them all in time. We see people stuck and when we fly back they've gone," he said.

One helicopter crew said they had flown over a cluster of houses with people waving for help. When they returned later, the homes had vanished into a vast lake broken only by the tips of a few tall trees and telegraph poles. The people were nowhere to be seen.

The storm waters surged yesterday as tropical cyclone Eline, which hit Mozambique last week, delivered a second blow. The cyclone had moved on to South Africa and Zimbabwe where its rains further swelled three rivers - the Limpopo, the Save and the Incomati - which flow back into Mozambique.

Wall of water

Eline's torrential winds and rain have flooded eastern and southern Zimbabwe, making an estimated 250,000 people homeless and killing at least 62. Hundreds of Zimbabwe's rural communities have been forced to flee floodwaters and for most of the weekend a single helicopter struggled to pluck people from treetops in eastern Manicaland province.

It was a wall of water travelling the length of the Limpopo which consumed Chokwe. Tens of thousands more people are trapped in the Save river valley, 600 miles north of the capital Maputo.

At least 50 were drowned as the town of Nova Mambone virtually disappeared underwater where the Save river meets the sea. Thousands of people are trapped on narrow islands of high ground in the area with no food or shelter.

Similar devastation has hit northern parts of South Africa where bridges and roads have been destroyed, and farms flooded. But Mozambique is bearing the brunt of the floods.

Ian Macleod of the UN children's fund, Unicef, said another wave of water is expected to hit southern and central Mozambique almost immediately and a third will sweep across the area on Wednesday.

"There is a dramatic urgency. Our window of opportunity is very small. A lot of people have to be moved from one area to another. The number of rescue assets, whether it be helicopters or boats or whatever, is insufficient. We need to get more in there," he said.

Britain has donated $1m (£625,000) to keep the South African helicopters flying. They have provided the backbone of rescue operations over the past fortnight but their exhausted crews have been forced to abandon their original missions to deliver food and medicines to areas hit by the ear lier floods in favour of rescuing victims of the latest crisis.

The survivors say the effects of the flooding are worse than those of Mozambique's very brutal 16-year civil war. Then they may have had to flee the rebels, but they usually returned to find their homes intact. Now, when they return, everything is destroyed.

Madeleine Mucantcho spent three days in a tree as the flood waters swept away everything she owned. Her feat was all the more remarkable because she is well in to her 70s.

"Some people swam away on the first day. There wasn't a man to help me so I just had to stay in the tree.

"After three days, some of them came back and told us they heard that there was more water coming and we will drown if we stay. I cannot swim properly so it took me hours to get to the road," she said. "I've seen different floods but not like this one."

Mrs Mucantcho comes from the village of Ngoyene, which is now a dot in the middle of a sprawling lake of flood water about 30 miles wide. Most of its villagers were eventually plucked to safety by a South African helicopter operating from a stretch of main road which has been turned into a runway just outside the town of Palmeiras.

The road used to be the main route along the north coast, through Xai-Xai and on to the port of Beira. But a few miles beyond Palmeiras the highway was swept away by a brand new river created by the floods.

Several hundred yards of road have been pummelled out of existence by the massive surge of water. On either side, the water stretches for miles over farmland that fed hundreds of families.

Mrs Mucantcho and the rest of the villagers do not now intend to return to live in Ngoyene.

"Every day I go and see how the water is. If the floods go, I will go back to plant but I can't live there," she said.

Another of the villagers, Fabiao Matchovane Lhongo, said Ngoyene's residents were now constructing a new settlement near Palmeiras.

"We are building a village here. They have told us this is our land forever. We will live here and keep our ducks and goats and then we will go back to look after our crops in our fields. It is a long walk - nearly two hours - but we will never live there again," he said.

Finding land is not as difficult as it might be elsewhere in Africa. Mozambique is not an overcrowded country and most agricultural land is still owned by the government, despite American pressure to privatise it. Many local authorities have swiftly reassigned the land for the displaced.

Where the highway abruptly ends after Palmeiras, a group of men who usually work in gold mines in South Africa were stripped to their underwear and preparing to wade through chest-deep water on their way on to find out what happened to their villages.

Worse to come

Dinis Tivane was among them. He was given six days off from the Western Area mine near Johannesburg to try and make it to Josina Machel village. He eyed two buses swept from the road by the force of water and planted into the mud as he speculated on the fate of his home.

"I haven't heard anything about my village. I don't know what happened to my family. In Johannesburg all we heard was our country was disappearing under water. I don't know what I'll find. Probably nothing," he said.

Perhaps the worst will come when the waters recede. That will expose the carcasses of thousands of animals which can only compound the problems created by a severe lack of clean drinking water. The first case of cholera has been reported, and the number of malaria cases is three times higher than normal even for the rainy season, when the disease is rampant.

 Readers who want to donate money to the relief operation can phone donations to the British Red Cross on 0870 444 3444 or send a cheque to British Red Cross, Freepost, Mid21782, Halesowen B63 3BR.

Donations will help to provide blankets, medical equipment, water tanks, tents and plastic sheeting, as well as building materials, seeds and tools.

"After three days, some of them came back and told us they heard that there was more water coming and we will drown if we stay. I cannot swim properly so it took me hours to get to the road," she said. "I've seen different floods but not like this one." Mrs Mucantcho comes from the village of Ngoyene, which is now a dot in the middle of a sprawling lake of flood water about 30 miles wide. Most of its villagers were eventually plucked to safety by a South African helicopter operating from a stretch of main road which has been turned into a runway just outside the town of Palmeiras. The road used to be the main route along the north coast, through Xai-Xai and on to the port of Beira. But a few miles beyond Palmeiras the highway was swept away by a brand new river created by the floods. Several hundred yards of road have been pummelled out of existence by the massive surge of water. On either side, the water stretches for miles over farmland that fed hundreds of families. Mrs Mucantcho and the rest of the villagers do not now intend to return to live in Ngoyene. "Every day I go and see how the water is. If the floods go, I will go back to plant but I can't live there," she said. Another of the villagers, Fabiao Matchovane Lhongo, said Ngoyene's residents were now constructing a new settlement near Palmeiras. "We are building a village here. They have told us this is our land forever. We will live here and keep our ducks and goats and then we will go back to look after our crops in our fields. It is a long walk - nearly two hours - but we will never live there again," he said. Finding land is not as difficult as it might be elsewhere in Africa. Mozambique is not an overcrowded country and most agricultural land is still owned by the government, despite American pressure to privatise it. Many local authorities have swiftly reassigned the land for the displaced. Where the highway abruptly ends after Palmeiras, a group of men who usually work in gold mines in South Africa were stripped to their underwear and preparing to wade through chest-deep water on their way on to find out what happened to their villages. Worse to come Dinis Tivane was among them. He was given six days off from the Western Area mine near Johannesburg to try and make it to Josina Machel village. He eyed two buses swept from the road by the force of water and planted into the mud as he speculated on the fate of his home. "I haven't heard anything about my village. I don't know what happened to my family. In Johannesburg all we heard was our country was disappearing under water. I don't know what I'll find. Probably nothing," he said. Perhaps the worst will come when the waters recede. That will expose the carcasses of thousands of animals which can only compound the problems created by a severe lack of clean drinking water. The first case of cholera has been reported, and the number of malaria cases is three times higher than normal even for the rainy season, when the disease is rampant.  Readers who want to donate money to the relief operation can phone donations to the British Red Cross on 0870 444 3444 or send a cheque to British Red Cross, Freepost, Mid21782, Halesowen B63 3BR. Donations will help to provide blankets, medical equipment, water tanks, tents and plastic sheeting, as well as building materials, seeds and tools.

webTitle: Grilling for chef in menu con

fields.headline: Grilling for chef in menu con
fields.trailText: A French superchef will today suffer the most ignominious fate known to his profession when the Michelin red guide strips him of his stars as punishment for the mendacity of his £75-a-head menu.
fields.body:
A French superchef will today suffer the most ignominious fate known to his profession when the Michelin red guide strips him of his stars as punishment for the mendacity of his £75-a-head menu.

Jean Bardet's celebrated two-star restaurant in the Loire valley town of Tours was found to have been passing off £1.90 bottles of plonk from the local supermarket as a superior regional vintage worthy of a price tag of £19.

Mr Bardet and his wife Sophie, whose elegant parkland establishment has a turnover of £2.2m a year, were also accused of describing their veal as "free range" when it was not; their sea bass as having been "caught with rod and line" when it had not, and their asparagus as coming from the noted asparagus-growing region of Bourgeuil when it did not.

The restaurant, which has held its two Michelin stars since 1985 and also boasts an 18 out of 20 rating in the rival Gault-Millau guide, was fined £3,000 just before Christmas after consumer protection inspectors discovered the fraud.

At an appeal court hearing last week, the public prosecutor demanded an even stiffer penalty of £4,500 apiece for Mr and Mrs Bardet and the publication of the court's judgment in two upmarket foody bibles, Le Figaro Magazine and Gault-Millau.

In his summing-up, the prosecutor, Christian Dreux, described the couple as a pair of "poets of French haute cuisine, part of our national heritage", who had "behaved like chop-house proprietors of the very lowest order".

Defending herself, Mrs Bardet said the wine appeared on the "appellation controlée" pages of the wine list because it was the only one in its category. The price, she said, was defensible in view of the "luxurious surroundings" in which it would be consumed.

As for the inaccurate origins of the veal, bass and asparagus, she said she still had the invoices for the relevant produce and that if there had been any fraud it "certainly was not her fault".

But the cheeseboard, most which was described on the menu as "farmyard", when in fact the cheeses came from big industrial dairies, was a problem, she admitted. "I'm afraid we were a bit confused about the terms 'farmyard cheese' and 'dairy cheese'. We didn't know there was a difference."

The case follows a number of attacks in France and Britain on the famous Michelin Guide, which is accused of failing to move with the times. Last month a one-star Loire valley restaurant, La Chancelière, announced that it was renouncing its rosette and reverting to a cheap bistro.

fields.headline: International news in brief
fields.trailText: Bombs kill 12
fields.body:
Bombs kill 12

Twelve people were killed in explosions across India yesterday, according to police and local news agencies. A state minister was among 11 killed in a vehicle explosion in Assam and one man died in a bombing in northern India. Eight people were injured by a bomb in New Delhi. Agencies, New Delhi

Winds hit Cairns

The tropical cyclone Steve, with winds up to 106mph, hit the northern Australian resort town of Cairns yesterday, uprooting trees and bringing down power lines. Rains have left two-thirds of Queensland under water. Reuters, Sydney

Ankara gun haul

A weapons cache belonging to a Kurdish Islamic group, Hizbullah, has been found in the eastern Turkish city of Mardin, police claimed yesterday. AP, Ankara

webTitle: Hired hands stake out a corner of the boom

fields.headline: Hired hands stake out a corner of the boom
fields.standfirst: America's day labourers emerged in the 30s but only now look like gaining some rights
fields.trailText: America's day labourers emerged in the 30s but only now look like gaining some rights
fields.body:
It is 6am and on the corner of Atlantic and Pomona, and more than 100 other corners in Los Angeles, the jornaleros - day labourers - are already gathering.

"Yo, yo, llevame a mi" (Me, me, choose me), goes the cry as the first contractors arrive with their vans seeking building workers and removal men, gardeners and cleaners.

There are 24,000 day labourers in Los Angeles, according to research carried out last year, more than in any other US city. These hired hands are mainly Latinos, who wait patiently in the hope that the ripples from America's economic boom will reach as far as the dusty corners of the city.

Traditionally, they have had to take whatever money they are offered and put up with abuse from passers-by or hassle from police and immigration officials but now, as their numbers grow, they are responding through a union that is seeking to bring them recognition and rights after decades of anonymity.

In a historic move last week, the AFL-CIO union federation called for the government to repeal the law that makes it a crime to hire workers who cannot produce proper papers. Traditionally, the big unions have been hostile to cheap immigrant labour, but the AFL-CIO's traditional membership has long been in decline.

California has a long history of casual labour. In 1931, in the Depression, thousands of unemployed workers streamed westwards and Los Angeles police even put up "bum blockades" on the roads leading into the city to stop the flow of some 2,000 people a day.

Many people assumed that the days when labourers scrabbled with each other to be chosen to work ended around the time that Elia Kazan showed stevedores doing just that in his 1954 film On the Waterfront. But not so. Now the flow comes from the south, mainly from Mexico but also Guatemala, El Salvador and elsewhere in central America, as stuttering economies and unstable politics drive people north in search of work.

Carlos Bautista, 36, has been working all day on a construction site in Watts county. A former government worker from Guatemala, he arrived three years ago after being sacked from his job and blacklisted for trying to set up a union.

"I never thought that I would still be working as a jornalero," he says, over a couple of stuffed tortillas in a restaurant not far from where he shares a room with three other jornaleros. He sends money to his wife and children in Guatemala but since he has arrived he has not been able to return except "in my heart".

Mr Bautista waits on a corner in Ladera Heights, along with 40 to 70 others, seven days a week until it is clear there is no work for the day. In a good month, he will work 15 days, as everything from a hotel maintenance worker to a gardener, at rates of around $5 (£3) an hour. In a bad month, he may work only three or four days.

"Some of the employers are honest, conscientious. Some of the others do not pay and then they can say, 'What are you going to do about it?' " he says.

While around 80% of the casual workers are Latino, there are also African-Americans, a few Armenians, even "a Russian in San Pedro", but no western Europeans. There is just one corner of women jornaleras, in Beverly Hills, where they wait for domestic work.

Further north, jornaleros can be found in Seattle, Portland, and increasingly in other big cities where it suits employers not to have to pay benefits for readily available hands.

While a few of the corners date back to the 50s, others have sprung up to cater to whatever trade is nearby. Mr Bautista was introduced to his corner by a cousin and most require an introduction from a friend or relative.

Once established, says Mr Bautista, "there is a lot of solidarity, we are all united in good times and bad times". People are chosen at random, although it helps to speak English, says Mr Bautista, to look smart and clean or to be recognised by an employer from a previous job.

Until now, the big unions have not been too interested in jornaleros and, with only 10% of the private sector unionised, there are other more obvious places to recruit. However, the AFL-CIO announced a change in policy last week when it called on congress to loosen the restrictions on undocumented workers. An estimated 200,000 illegal workers enter the US annually and there are about 6m in the country, all vulnerable to poor working conditions because of their flimsy immigration status.

At the same time, an independent union, Sindicato de Jornaleros, has been formed. It already has 300 members in LA and has negotiated with local authorities and police that have tried to move the jornaleros away.

"If you don't organise, you don't have a voice," says Mayron Payes, an El Salvadorean who arrived eight years ago and is helping to get the union off the ground as part of his work with the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights of LA (Chirla). "What we want is not just wages but dignity."

Pablo Alvorado, the project's chief coordinator, says: "For us no human being is illegal. The right to work goes beyond any human law."

With the economy booming, there will always be a call for day workers, says Mr Payes. "There were jornaleros in Greek and Roman times," he says with a smile.

fields.headline: The shaming of a she-devil
fields.standfirst: With her raunchy stage show, risqué song lyrics and soft-porn modelling, Gloria Trevi outraged Catholic Mexico. Then came allegations that she procured underage girls for her manager's sexual gratification. So the two went on the run.  Duncan Campbell  on the Latin Madonna and the 'Academy of Lolitas'
fields.trailText: With her raunchy stage show, risqué song lyrics and soft-porn modelling, Gloria Trevi outraged Catholic Mexico. Then came allegations that she procured underage girls for her manager's sexual gratification. So the two went on the run.
fields.body:
She is the "Latin Madonna", the "Serpent in a Thong", a Mexican Marilyn Manson and a she-devil for the Catholic establishment. And now, in a case that is being seen throughout Latin America as a battle between cultures and moralities, she is accused of corrupting young girls.

Gloria de los Angeles Trevino Ruiz - or Gloria Trevi, as she is better known - spent her 30th birthday behind bars in Brazil last week, where she has been since her arrest on January 12. She had been on the run for more than three months, rumoured to be in Los Angeles, Santiago, Texas and Germany. This week she is facing extradition proceedings which could return her to Mexico, where she is due to stand trial.

Trevi's story starts more than 15 years ago, when a feisty 14-year-old from a middle-class Mexican family left home and started on her career as a performer. She could dance, sing, compose, drum and play the piano, and she soon set about showing that she could shock, too. In a country where performers still tended to be dutiful and conventional, the time was ripe for someone who was ready to kick over the traces.

She burst on the scene with an exotic stage persona - all torn fishnets, striptease and punky hair, with songs to match. She found a manager, Sergio Andrade, who, at a time when Madonna was conquering the world, quickly realised Trevi's potential. Andrade, the brother of a Mexican senator, was already a successful songwriter and had managed a number of other young women singers, although none had achieved the fame his new charge would attain.

Trevi's first three CDs sold more than 5m copies and she could pack stadiums with 20,000 fans, delighted to see and hear someone so naughty and dangerous. One album was entitled Mas Turbata Que Nunca (More Disturbed Than Ever), its subliminal message easily found by rolling the first two words together. No wonder she became known as La Atrenida - the insolent one.

Just as important as the medium she chose to reach her audience were the ideas she delivered through it: in a staunchly Catholic country, she spoke and sang about abortion, unwed motherhood, prostitution, drugs and politics. She became a symbol of fearless feminism, and both her teenage fans and many older, Mexican intellectuals admired her for her libertarian stance and her daring.

While her message was sometimes deadly serious, Trevi's performances were full-on rock: she interspersed her own material with that of Led Zeppelin and The Doors. The shows were sensational, whether she was beating out a rhythm with flaming drumsticks or pulling young men on to the stage and stripping them. As her fame and success on stage grew, she capitalised on her notoriety by posing nude for calendars - the last one showed her wearing nothing but a devil's forked tail - and as a naked version of Adelita, one of the heroines of the Mexican revolution. The Catholic hierarchy denounced her godlessness, which only added to her mystique.

In 1998, Andrade's young ex-wife, Aline Hernandez, published a book in which she claimed that Andrade lured her into a relationship when she was just 13. She married him at the age of 15. Hernandez portrayed Trevi and Andrade as sinister and manipulative. The book made waves, but its meatier allegations were dismissed as the product of Mexico's generally venomous showbusiness world. Then, gradually, the parents of other teenage girls who had also been part of Andrade's stable of young performers started to make the same allegations: that Trevi had helped to procure them for Andrade's sexual gratification.

Last November, after specific allegations made by the parents of one of the girls, Karina Yapor, the state of Chihuahua issued a wanted poster for Trevi and Andrade. Yapor's parents claimed that Andrade had seduced their daughter, who had gone to him for music lessons when she was 12. It was claimed that she had had a child by Andrade in Spain when she was 15 and the baby had been left in a Spanish orphanage. By the time the Mexican authorities went looking for them, Andrade and Trevi had slipped from view. He had apparently left Mexico more than two years ago; she had last been heard of giving an interview to a Miami-based television station in spring of last year.

Speculation on the streets and in the press was rife. Were the allegations simply part of an internal showbusiness feud? Was Trevi an innocent party? Would they ever return to Mexico? Then, just when it was rumoured that they were hiding out in the US, news came of their arrest in a Rio de Janeiro apartment one block from the Copacabana beach; the porter at their apartment building had thought they were just a bunch of "dirty hippies". Trevi has now been moved from jail in Rio to Brasilia, and the extradition proceedings could be completed this week.

In Mexico, Trevi's case is the subject of heated debate. Her mother appeared on television last week saying that her daughter was a "good girl" and that Andrade had always seemed like a "caballero" - a gentleman - to her. But elsewhere, the attacks were growing. One weekly magazine suggested Trevi and Andrade had been involved in black magic and had run what was essentially an "academy of Lolitas" in Cuernavaca.

Yapor is seen as the prosecution's key witness, but she has so far been supportive of Trevi and Andrade, saying initially that another man was the father of her baby. She has since changed the story, saying that the child was the result of a consensual relationship with Andrade. Last week, she refused to take a lie detector test requested by the prosecution.

Trevi, for her part, is clearly deter mined not to submit without a fight, and it seems that she will not take what might be the safer route of blaming Andrade for everything. The mug shots taken after her arrest show her with her trademark self-confident grin. She told Mexican journalists on the plane between Rio de Janeiro and Brasilia when she was being moved last week: "I am not going to play the victim. I support Sergio, I am with him." Andrade has taken the brunt of the public's outrage, but, judging from radio phone-in programmes, Mexicans are also angry with the girls' parents, who seem to have virtually signed over their daughters in the search for fame and fortune.

Feminist organisations in Chihuahua, the state that is pursuing the couple, have also pointed the finger at the attorney general's office, suggesting that the prosecution of Trevi and Andrade is a way of diverting attention from their inaction over the rape and murder of nearly 200 women in the border area of Juarez. "It is as if they want to show that they are concerned about the problems faced by women and sexual crime," said Irma Campos, a Chihuahua attorney and member of the women's group called March 8.

Mariana Martinez, an editor of the book written by Aline Hernandez that was the starting point for the scandal, said of the affair this week that "rebel lion is part of life, but the need to find a symbol for it can be manipulated so that it turns into the exact opposite. Trevi was similar to subcomandante Marcos [the leader of the Chiapas rebellion] in the way that she was an emblem in Mexico. In one way or another, Mexico needs heroes."

Guadalupe Loeza, the Mexican writer and cultural commentator, sees Trevi as a tragic victim three times over - of Andrade, of the star system and of the notoriously corrupt entertainment business. "Everyone knew about the kind of things that went on in Televisa [the television station that creates most Mexican stars]," said Loeza, "but no one said so openly. This is the first time the dirty linen is being washed in public. This is like a Pandora's box. There is now the space for lots of stories to come out. Trevi is a product of her time, of the disillusionment and the disappointment and the confusion of it."

Loeza said that it was clear why Trevi was so successful: "She was a seducer, she was not a fake. She appealed to everyone: eight-year-old girls who wanted to be like her, adolescents who thought they were her, adults who became fans of her calendars. I wrote at the time and I still believe that every Mexican woman has a Gloria Trevi inside her but is frightened to give it expression."

Other writers, such as Jorge Caballeros of the left-of-centre daily La Jornada, pay tribute to her for breaking taboos with her lyrics and for singing about politics: "She was a social and cultural phenomenon."

Last summer, the well-known talk-show host and comedian Paco Stanley was shot dead in broad daylight outside a Mexico City restaurant. Initially, the country mourned what appeared to be yet another random act of violence, but then it emerged that Stanley was a cocaine addict, and his sidekick on the show was alleged to have been behind the plot to kill him. The cynicism this case engendered about the entertainment industry has helped to fuel the charges against Trevi and Andrade. At the same time, there are many within the business who must know that if the dirty laundry is going to be washed, they will be hung out to dry along with Trevi and Andrade.

One of Trevi's hit CDs was entitled Why Am I Here? It's a question she may well be pondering in jail as she waits to see what the judicial process will do to her. She may also be wondering if it was inevitable that she would be punished for so openly flaunting the conventions of Mexican culture.
