As her fame and success on stage grew, she capitalised on her notoriety by posing nude for calendars - the last one showed her wearing nothing but a devil's forked tail - and as a naked version of Adelita, one of the heroines of the Mexican revolution. The Catholic hierarchy denounced her godlessness, which only added to her mystique. In 1998, Andrade's young ex-wife, Aline Hernandez, published a book in which she claimed that Andrade lured her into a relationship when she was just 13. She married him at the age of 15. Hernandez portrayed Trevi and Andrade as sinister and manipulative. The book made waves, but its meatier allegations were dismissed as the product of Mexico's generally venomous showbusiness world. Then, gradually, the parents of other teenage girls who had also been part of Andrade's stable of young performers started to make the same allegations: that Trevi had helped to procure them for Andrade's sexual gratification. Last November, after specific allegations made by the parents of one of the girls, Karina Yapor, the state of Chihuahua issued a wanted poster for Trevi and Andrade. Yapor's parents claimed that Andrade had seduced their daughter, who had gone to him for music lessons when she was 12. It was claimed that she had had a child by Andrade in Spain when she was 15 and the baby had been left in a Spanish orphanage. By the time the Mexican authorities went looking for them, Andrade and Trevi had slipped from view. He had apparently left Mexico more than two years ago; she had last been heard of giving an interview to a Miami-based television station in spring of last year. Speculation on the streets and in the press was rife. Were the allegations simply part of an internal showbusiness feud? Was Trevi an innocent party? Would they ever return to Mexico? Then, just when it was rumoured that they were hiding out in the US, news came of their arrest in a Rio de Janeiro apartment one block from the Copacabana beach; the porter at their apartment building had thought they were just a bunch of "dirty hippies". Trevi has now been moved from jail in Rio to Brasilia, and the extradition proceedings could be completed this week. In Mexico, Trevi's case is the subject of heated debate. Her mother appeared on television last week saying that her daughter was a "good girl" and that Andrade had always seemed like a "caballero" - a gentleman - to her. But elsewhere, the attacks were growing. One weekly magazine suggested Trevi and Andrade had been involved in black magic and had run what was essentially an "academy of Lolitas" in Cuernavaca. Yapor is seen as the prosecution's key witness, but she has so far been supportive of Trevi and Andrade, saying initially that another man was the father of her baby. She has since changed the story, saying that the child was the result of a consensual relationship with Andrade. Last week, she refused to take a lie detector test requested by the prosecution. Trevi, for her part, is clearly deter mined not to submit without a fight, and it seems that she will not take what might be the safer route of blaming Andrade for everything. The mug shots taken after her arrest show her with her trademark self-confident grin. She told Mexican journalists on the plane between Rio de Janeiro and Brasilia when she was being moved last week: "I am not going to play the victim. I support Sergio, I am with him." Andrade has taken the brunt of the public's outrage, but, judging from radio phone-in programmes, Mexicans are also angry with the girls' parents, who seem to have virtually signed over their daughters in the search for fame and fortune. Feminist organisations in Chihuahua, the state that is pursuing the couple, have also pointed the finger at the attorney general's office, suggesting that the prosecution of Trevi and Andrade is a way of diverting attention from their inaction over the rape and murder of nearly 200 women in the border area of Juarez. "It is as if they want to show that they are concerned about the problems faced by women and sexual crime," said Irma Campos, a Chihuahua attorney and member of the women's group called March 8. Mariana Martinez, an editor of the book written by Aline Hernandez that was the starting point for the scandal, said of the affair this week that "rebel lion is part of life, but the need to find a symbol for it can be manipulated so that it turns into the exact opposite. Trevi was similar to subcomandante Marcos [the leader of the Chiapas rebellion] in the way that she was an emblem in Mexico. In one way or another, Mexico needs heroes." Guadalupe Loeza, the Mexican writer and cultural commentator, sees Trevi as a tragic victim three times over - of Andrade, of the star system and of the notoriously corrupt entertainment business. "Everyone knew about the kind of things that went on in Televisa [the television station that creates most Mexican stars]," said Loeza, "but no one said so openly. This is the first time the dirty linen is being washed in public. This is like a Pandora's box. There is now the space for lots of stories to come out. Trevi is a product of her time, of the disillusionment and the disappointment and the confusion of it." Loeza said that it was clear why Trevi was so successful: "She was a seducer, she was not a fake. She appealed to everyone: eight-year-old girls who wanted to be like her, adolescents who thought they were her, adults who became fans of her calendars. I wrote at the time and I still believe that every Mexican woman has a Gloria Trevi inside her but is frightened to give it expression." Other writers, such as Jorge Caballeros of the left-of-centre daily La Jornada, pay tribute to her for breaking taboos with her lyrics and for singing about politics: "She was a social and cultural phenomenon." Last summer, the well-known talk-show host and comedian Paco Stanley was shot dead in broad daylight outside a Mexico City restaurant. Initially, the country mourned what appeared to be yet another random act of violence, but then it emerged that Stanley was a cocaine addict, and his sidekick on the show was alleged to have been behind the plot to kill him. The cynicism this case engendered about the entertainment industry has helped to fuel the charges against Trevi and Andrade. At the same time, there are many within the business who must know that if the dirty laundry is going to be washed, they will be hung out to dry along with Trevi and Andrade. One of Trevi's hit CDs was entitled Why Am I Here? It's a question she may well be pondering in jail as she waits to see what the judicial process will do to her. She may also be wondering if it was inevitable that she would be punished for so openly flaunting the conventions of Mexican culture.

fields.headline: No: 1584
fields.standfirst: Mouna Ayoub
fields.trailText: Mouna Ayoub
fields.body:
Age: 42.

Status: The saviour of couture.

I thought that was John Galliano. Darling, do you know nothing?

Alexander McQueen? Oh, I despair. They just draw the stuff.

Whereas . . . ? Whereas she buys it. A lot of it - $1m of it a year in fact.

Must be nice having 20 large ones a week to spend on frocks. You'd make the most of it too if you'd had her miserable life.

Which was? Meeting a fabulously wealthy Saudi engineer while waitressing in a cafe in Paris and moving to his mansion, yacht and private jet in Riyadh.

Golly, that does sound dreadful. You would hate it, too, if you liked dressing up as much as Ayoub. Her strict Muslim husband made her wear a floorlength traditional black abbaya and two veils. Once the novelty of teaming this with a Chanel belt wore off, she divorced him in 1996. And took £61m worth of jewellery with her.

What did he get? The five kids.

Poor woman. The least she could do was treat herself to an outfit or two. And the couture houses happily helped her into $100,000 numbers. There have been rumours Ayoub will get the Legion d'Honneur for services to the French economy - she's bought 150 suits from Chanel alone.

Bit flash, innit? Honestly, you make her sound extravagant. Besides, she's selling off much of her wardrobe in an auction at Christie's tomorrow to raise money for a children's charity.

Any bargains? Keep an eye out for the Versace evening suit with medallion motif decorated with classical and mythical scenes (£500-£800). Or there's always the understated Chanel sugar pink ensemble with a matching hat and bra (£250-300).

Well, mother did always say one's underwear should match. In that case, why not go the whole hog. This outfit also comes with co-ordinating sugar pink combat boots.

She says: "I have it. I can't hide it."

Does she try to? You try being inconspicuous with a 112-carat, $20m diamond on your finger.

Not to be confused with: Mona Lisa, Dr Magdi Yacoub, Imelda Marcos.

fields.headline: 'I'll only talk to you naked'
fields.trailText: Jon Henley in Paris on: Groping for the truth in a grubby affair |  A fairly fought mayoral race
fields.body:
A gloriously Gallic soap opera has divided le tout Paris. It has pitted man against woman, chauvinist against feminist, editorialist against commentator, philosopher against moralist. Acres of newsprint, hours of airtime have been devoted to it. And what everyone wants to know is, did Bruno Gaccio touch Sylvie Kerviel's breasts?

It's a tricky one. In Libération, Pierre Marcelle sat firmly on the fence, referring to "this obscure and tenebrous affair" about which "questions, lots of questions" should be asked. In l'Evenement, the philosopher Blandine Kriegel was reduced to quoting Montesquieu: "A republic," she said helfully, "presupposes virtue."

But let us begin at the beginning. What no one disputes is that one fine day a fortnight ago, Sylvie Kerviel, a journalist with Le Monde, published her interview with Bruno Gaccio, the senior writer on the popular French equivalent of Spitting Image, les Guignols.

According to Kerviel, the interview was brief. Gaccio, she wrote, said he hated talking about himself. He kissed her hand and inquired whether she liked pasta, because he had a restaurant in the south of France he would invite her to.

Asked what he found most interesting about the people he caricatured on the show, he replied: "The stains on their ties," and placed his index finger between her breasts. Later, he suggested he could "teach her a few positions she didn't know". He asked if she was married, and if so how many lovers she had.

Wise to the fact that this particular gambit from the Gallic school of male charm was unlikely to go unnoticed even in France, Gaccio's boss, Alain de Greef, moved swiftly to avert catastrophe. "I like Gaccio," he hurriedly told the next day's paper. "But he goes a bit far. In fact, he's an oik. He should never have behaved like that. But it was ironic."

Now it so happens there exists a brand-new organisation that has sworn to do something about the Frenchman's perennial penchant for below-the-belt blows in the battle of the sexes. Les Chiennes de Garde, or the Guard Bitches, are 471 well-known French females, including writers, directors, former ministers and a scary round-the-world yachtswoman.

They duly fired off a broadside the following day, accusing Gaccio of "gross macho harassment", denouncing De Greef for standing up for a subordinate rather than apologising to the victim, and threatening to "sink their fangs" into the pair of them.

Undaunted, De Greef issued a formal statement two days later, raising the stakes further: he denied the encounter had been anything like that described by Kerviel.

"This wasn't three minutes of sexual harrassment of a female journalist by an oafish humourist, but an hour and a quarter of journalistic harassment of a scripwriter who did not want to give an interview," he said. "Bruno Gaccio was rude, stu pid, ridiculous - and dumb enough to get trapped."

Le tout Paris adored it. Deontologically speaking, they wanted to know, was there such a thing as journalistic harassment? Could Ms Kerviel be accused of wearing what one commentator called a "metaphorical miniskirt"? The whole affair, another philosopher noted, was "bathed in shadows. Would that there were truly angels and demons. Alas, there are not."

The final instalment of the sorry saga came a couple of days ago. Gaccio himself emerged to tell a very different story. He had never given interviews and never would. But at Kerviel's insistence, he said, and I quote: "I don't mind talking about myself with you, but only naked, lying on animal skins and making love with a live trout."

And so on, and so on. The whole conversation, Gaccio said, was so Rabelaisian that no sane person would have taken offence. Rather than "a satyr lurking in the woods" he was, he claims, "a ridiculous schoolboy dancing naked on the table." But he did, he admitted, make the stain-on-tie gesture. And he admitted that he would not have sent a male journalist packing in the same way.

So there you have it. Filthy macho French male, or poor put-upon non-publicity seeker? Cher lecteur, you must make up your own mind. Suffice it to say that it is encouraging, in France, that this affair became an Affair. And that just occasionally, a word of apology may be better than all the philosophising in Paris.

Here comes Paris's Red Ken

It's official: Paris isn't as trendy as London, and even the French admit it. Jack Lang, flamboyant 60-year-old former culture minister, let slip as much last week when he said he'd be running for mayor.

"Compared to London, Berlin or Rome, Paris needs a new élan," Lang conceded. "My dream is to give back to Paris its premier place, and to make its inhabitants happier by transforming their daily lives. We have to support the Paris that's dynamic."

Lang, it has to be said, knows about dynamism. He's remembered by the French for helping push through some of François Mitterrand's grander projects - such as the Louvre pyramid - and for giving France its hugely popular national Fete de la Musique and an annual techno extravaganza. In some ways, Lang's candidacy echoes Ken Livingstone's: he represents a bygone age of socialism. So he's a long way from being the current Socialist PM's favourite person - but he's adored by the average Parisian. And Lang's opponent for the Socialist nomination is, funnily enough, a loyal if unflamboyant local party man.

But unlike Tony Blair, Lionel Jospin has promised not to get up to anything underhand: even if he privately favours the local candidate, Bertrand Dalanoe, the two leftist hopefuls will face a straight primary on March 30 at which all Paris party members will vote. Jospin will not interfere in his party's choice for one simple reason: though the French capital has swung leftwards, it has not been run by a Socialist since the Paris Commune uprising of 1871. Equally importantly, Paris city hall has always been a springboard to top national office: winning it would do no harm to Jospin's campaign for president in 2002.

Tainted by a string of corruption scandals, the centre-right incumbent, Jean Tiberi - who was chosen by Jacques Chirac as his successor when he left city hall to become president in 1995 - will almost certainly be forced out by his RPR party before the vote.

And assuming Lang does get the Socialist nomination, his likely opponent will be Philippe Seguin, a notable Gaullist heavyweight and former speaker of the French parliament. If those two square off, the race to put Paris back on the map will be every bit as nasty as London's has already become: one poll last week put support for the two grandees at 47% each

fields.headline: Don't call me an inventor
fields.standfirst: The man who brought us the bagless vacuum cleaner has a thing or two to get off his chest. Kitchen bins, for a start...
fields.trailText: The man who brought us the bagless vacuum cleaner has a thing or two to get off his chest. Kitchen bins, for a start...
fields.body:
Now, bins. Kitchen bins. There's some secret stuff going on at James Dyson's factory HQ in Malmesbury, Wiltshire. More revolutionary products in design on the tail (or the hose) of his mould-breaking bagless, see-through Dual Cyclone vacuum. So hush-hush that those involved have to sign a secrecy clause, have to promise not even to tell their spouse. Please tell me, I beg him, that it's kitchen bins.

"Oh no, yes, no they're awful," says Dyson, inventor, manufacturer, multi-millionaire. "Overfilling the bag, yes I know . It's taking the bag out that's the worst thing. Yes, and I hate the big ones." He has a quiet upper-class voice but his face is contorting in distaste. He wriggles about in his chair (Vitara by Antonio Citerio, £400), darting in and out of the checkerboard light thrown by the Venetian blinds behind him, dodging an Anglepoise light the size of a small robot by his ears. He is animated now. "I found quite a nice one, but it's £300. I found it in the Conran Shop and it's quite nice, but it's not perfect. It's cast iron - I got blue ones - and it's not that big, it's about that high and it has a very nice pedal and a stainless steel lid that comes up and then a galvanised bin that you lift out and it's got a very good seal around the top. Yes, it's a very good seal."

He's in a world of his own now. Loo flushes? I say. Not so sure about the stubbly ones down the corridor: time someone drew them to your attention? "Oh, the prison ones," he says. "They're from the prison catalogue. But actually, these ones aren't very good. I shouldn't say that in front of the architects. The architects sourced those. But I don't think they look very nice. I found one for our previous office that looked much better and worked better. This one, you rather lose your thumb in it don't you? These are German, aren't they?" Er, sorry, didn't notice . . . He's up and out of his chair and across the room and through another door. I can hear him shouting something. A German manufacturer's name, perhaps. "Yup, German," he says, striding back into the room. His secretary pops her head round the door, checking on the commotion perhaps. "Just talking about lavatory pushes," he says. "Oh right," she says, and goes back out again.

Dyson, 52 "and a half", owes his success to a permanent attention to detail, a constant edge of irritation. Little things make him cross. And big things make him even crosser. It was "a poxy little Hoover Junior" that had been angering, infuriating , him at home for years that set him thinking in 1978 about "the gigantic con" put upon us by the manufacturers that bags - "these bloody things" - were necessary.

He felt the same fury towards the humble wheelbarrow before his earlier invention of the Ballbarrow (over which he fell out with his sister; they still hardly speak). His autobiography, Against The Odds - which describes his 15-year battle for independence and success, with patents and licences and constant and continuing litigation and terrible debt - is littered with references to "complete bastards" and "pathetic" attitudes and other people's "apathy and chronic defensiveness" and "creative jealousy". Most of all, he's cross at Britain's "can't do" mentality. Last week, he sounded off on the radio about Eddie George's attitude to manufacturing. High interest rates, a strong pound as well as restrictive planning regulations, may well, he said, drive him and his production oversees. A long time in the wilderness, and you can tell he rather enjoys the attention.

"I'm very committed to Britain, or England, as we're now allowed to say. "But I am really worried because a lot of things are going seriously wrong. It's the most terrible place to make things at the moment. Our attitude to money is pretty Thatcherite. The man who has the money, earns the money, whereas in Japan where you pay less than 1% on money, it's not the City that gets rich, it's people who make things."

Dyson, a graduate of the Royal College of Art, and the son of a classics master, likes to think of himself and his 350 employees as people who make things. He refers to himself as an artist on a couple of occasions, as in "Deirdre [his wife, a rug designer] and I are both artists. She understands the creative impulse". He has become an emblem not just of the successful British entrepreneur (estimated wealth: £500m), but of English good taste. His Chelsea house (there are others in Wiltshire and Provence) is regularly featured in magazines devoted to interiors. He has three children, two sons and a daughter, Emily, who has just opened Couverture, a shop in London's King's Road pandering to one's desire for a £325 pair of slippers (a bit more than a bin).

He is laid-back in manner, he rolls his finger in the cleft of his chin when he's thinking, rubs his hand under his arm as if cashmere is a little too itchy for his liking (NB anything we can do about that?). He generally registers disagreement with a slight, fey laugh and he clearly likes his own way. He gets visibly annoyed twice during the interview - once when I ask whether the secret of a good invention is making something simpler, unlike, say, those machines for initialising golfballs which makes something simple more complicated.

"I"m not an inventor," he interrupts.

"Surely you . . ."

"No. No. No. An inventor is a boffin who has a brilliant idea. And there are 350 of us here working on things, to do something different, to make it better." But surely you're . . . "I hate the tag. I hate it," he continues. "It isn't a flash of brilliance, it's years of grind. People think, pfff, he's done that, he's struck lucky, but your invention has, in fact, come about by trying to do something that seemed impossible and perhaps slightly mad. I hate that word 'mad', strike that . . . Something that seems impossible and therefore a lot of people wouldn't attempt it, but you make it work . . . after a staggering amount of effort."

The other time he seems cross is when I say the Dyson design is trendy. "No, it's not." Yes it is. "It's not. It's not. It's not. It's not trendy. It works well. We earn our stripes the hard way. Trendy implies it's temporal. People say it works bloody well but it looks like a piece of shit. That to me is a great compliment."

Halfway through the interview the fire alarm starts pealing and 351 of us troop out to the muster station in the car park. Everybody is young. Everyone's in fleeces, apart from Dyson, who's in a pale purple Pashmina. Dyson has a Californian - or he'd say Japanese - vision for his company. There is pasta and salad in the cafe (he hates the word canteen). No suits and ties. Memos are banned. There is no recirculated air. (There were big scenes with the architects about this. "I said, 'I don't want any recirculated air.' They said, 'You have to.' I said, 'I'm not having it.' And I was getting phone calls saying, 'Be reasonable', and I just kept saying, 'I'm sorry, your sums don't add up, it will be cheaper without it, no ghastly, filters, smaller ducts, just fresh air which you have to cool or heat.' Two weeks later, they came back and said, 'You're right.'")

We're still standing in the car park when Dyson says: "This is where we lose 5,000 vacuum cleaners off the production lines. The lines stop and then it gets longer than the stoppage to get started again." His fine grey blond hair looks a little thinner in the outside air, his shoulders more angular. Is he insulated these days against failure? I ask.

"No," he says. "I've got everything tied up in this. Lots of things could go wrong. All our competitors are bringing out bagless vacuum cleaners. I feel the same fear as I always have - we're living by our wits. We are what bankers describe as a one-product company. And there are the ongoing legal suits with our competitors [over ads claiming that bags clog]. So one is embattled. It goes with the territory. webTitle: How France wins the race for growth

fields.headline: How France wins the race for growth
fields.trailText: France is emerging as mainland Europe's leading economy. Germany may be larger, at one-third of the region's output, but France, at 25%, has the best growth. Fourth-quarter French growth is driven by domestic demand; Germany's depends entirely on exports.
fields.body:
France is emerging as mainland Europe's leading economy. Germany may be larger, at one-third of the region's output, but France, at 25%, has the best growth. Fourth-quarter French growth is driven by domestic demand; Germany's depends entirely on exports.

The mainspring of French recovery is jobs. Jobs growth rose above 2% in 1999, faster than in the United States.

So why is the French economy so successful? After the follies of the Mitterrand experiment of 1981/82, France endured 15 years of non-stop deflation. Hoping to achieve stability by anchoring the economy to Germany's, the socialists were determined to halt the slide of the franc against the mark by 1987.

Growth came to an end with the world slowdown at the end of the decade. Then came the Bundesbank's purging of Mr Kohl's mistakes in the early 1990s and the Maastricht criteria - alias deflation - and the stability and growth pact.

No wonder voters changed government - with virtually no effect in dirigiste France - in each national assembly election: 1986, 1988, 1993 and 1997. Economic and monetary union cost Europe several million unemployed for some years, and much of that burden was borne by France.

Seen from the British perspective, France is a land of powerful trade unions, never happier than when bringing commerce to a halt with a blockade. But in fact labour's bargaining power has been pulverised. Since 1982, labour costs per employee have been lagging behind productivity by increasingly large margins.

Over the last year, for all the growth of GDP and jobs since 1997, pay per employee has grown just over 1.5%. This is a little above inflation, but modest at a time when unemployment has fallen to 10.6% from its earlier heights, not far above the supposed "structural" rate estimated at 10%.

The US is in the vanguard of productive advance and Eu rope has its work cut out to catch up, or so we imagine. But no: measured in equivalent purchasing power output per employee-hour in France and Germany is 10% higher than in the US.

The real problem in Europe is too few jobs. While France and Germany have close to full employment of "prime age males" - 25-54 years - their employment rates are far below US and British levels for women of all ages, youths and older males.

Out of the full labour force age group, 1998 employment ratios were 74% in the US and 72% in Britain, but only 64% in Germany and 59% in France.

After the purge of 1983-97 France could have years of pleasant surprises ahead. It gained a 20% labour cost advantage relative to Germany in the early 1990s and a lower in flation rate. Germany's reunification is no yet over, and neither is its dependence on older technology. So the euro could be weak in the long term, to France's advantage. Safety valves in the labour market include 2% of jobs being temporary without full rights, 4% in fixed-term contracts and 18% part-time.

Surely the 35-hour week will raise employment costs?

With employers required to pay the same for 35 hours as for 39, labour costs should go up by at least 10%. But again theoretical rigidity bends in practice. First, the average full-timer's year is 1,670 hours, only 4.5% more than the 1,600 allowed to 35 weekly hours in recognition of the seasonality of some work.

Second, rapid growth is generating big tax revenues: the 35-hour week pill is to be sweetened by a cut in social security contributions worth about 4% of salaries. More is likely in the future.

Third, to make the working- hour maxima practical, the government has agreed to the relaxation of restrictive practices governing hours and functions at work employers have been seeking for decades.

French labour could be making sacrifices for the token victory of a 35-hour week. But resulting flexibility could be much more important in sustaining jobs growth. Things are seldom as they seem, particularly in France.

 Charles Dumas is an analyst at Lombard Street Research

fields.headline: 'Dr Doom' poised to resign
fields.standfirst: P&D's Tony Dye considers his position after appalling returns for pension fund clients
fields.trailText: Tony Dye, the Phillips & Drew investment chief who has been predicting imminent stock market disaster for five years and as a result has produced appalling returns for his pension fund clients, is expected to depart this week.
fields.body:
Tony Dye, the Phillips & Drew investment chief who has been predicting imminent stock market disaster for five years and as a result has produced appalling returns for his pension fund clients, is expected to depart this week.

Mr Dye, who oversaw investments of £50bn at the fund manager for clients including ICI, Thames Water and many local authorities, is understood to be leaving after his managed balanced fund produce a return of just 2.75% in the fourth quarter, compared with a median return of 14.74%. Over the full year it produced 9.76%, compared with a median performance of more than 21%.

Mr Dye, dubbed Dr Doom, is due back from holiday this week. He is understood to have been considering his position for some time in hopes of a slump in the stock market.

P&D, formerly PDFM, could not be contacted yesterday but if Mr Dye quits it could prompt a clear-out of senior executives who have supported him at the fund management group.

There are suggestions that P&D - one of the City's most famous names - could be subsumed into its Swiss parent company UBS. There is also the possibility that disgruntled clients could launch legal action against the fund manager, claiming substantial damages for losing out as a result of a flawed investment policy.

Mr Dye - the City's leading Cassandra since 1995 when the FTSE stood at half its current level - said that shares in large British and American companies were overvalued and heading for big falls.

He switched £60bn belonging to 400 British pension funds out of big stocks and into "value investments" in search of higher growth that he believed the big corporates could deliver.

But the strategy backfired. He spurned drugs company and bank shares as among the most overvalued, and missed out on the huge share price gains they then experienced.

The increasing popularity of index-tracker funds, which buy and trade shares in direct proportion to their weighting on the stock market and now account for around one fifth of British share ownership, exacerbated his problems. Mr Dye's value shares have largely been ignored and failed to perform. At one time it seemed that almost every company in trouble had PDFM as a big shareholder.

The fund manager, which has also missed out on the recent technology and internet booms, has anchored the performance tables ever since 1996. But Mr Dye always maintained his strategy would eventually pay off, despite the defection of several big clients. Last year £8bn belonging to corporate and local authority pension funds was moved to other managers in a search for better performance.

In the drive to produce improved performance P&D has become more involved in the management of companies in which it has invested.

The fund manager, for instance, used its 22% of the Mirror group, to force through a merger between the Mirror and Trinity newspaper groups. When Mirror chief executive David Montgomery tried to block the deal P&D used its muscle to force him to resign. P&D has claimed the scalps of many other underperforming chief executives and even backed share raids on companies where it had big stakes in a bid to turn them around.

But its intervention has not always paid off. P&D, for example, backed the 1998 merger of Kwik-Save and Somerfield - where it held stakes in both. The merger has been one of the most unsuccessful ever attempted and the shares were among the worst performers of 1999.

fields.headline: Worm's Eye
fields.trailText: One of the quieter corners of the LSE was last week the scene of a small gathering the members of which attempted, in true Agatha Christie fashion, to discover what has happened to the missing 16 cents lopped off the value of the euro since its "successful" launch last year.
fields.body:
One of the quieter corners of the LSE was last week the scene of a small gathering the members of which attempted, in true Agatha Christie fashion, to discover what has happened to the missing 16 cents lopped off the value of the euro since its "successful" launch last year.

Actually it was 17 cents at the time but, in the intervening period, Euroland's currency has appreciated a little as was only to be expected. That said, the gathering rejected the obvious solution to the mystery - that currency's go up and down - having studied the claims made for it by the continent's leaders on the eve of its birth.

For those with very short memories, the euro was going to, if not replace the dollar, then at least force it to budge up and make room for a second anchor currency in the world system. No more would Europe be in the humiliating position of turning to Washington for the good things in life - whether strong money or military transport aircraft.

Now, Europe would be a super power in its own right.

The more astute among you may have spotted one or two flaws in this brilliant scheme. First, is there room in any system for more than one anchor currency? We tried it between the wars with the result that the economies of the anchor countries (Britain and the US) were plunged into depression.

Second, do combinations of countries become super powers simply by virtue of sharing one money? The British Empire was one such power that never operated a single currency whereas Brazil covers a vast area with one currency and shows no immediate sign of becoming a giant on the world stage.

One other huge currency area - which coincidentally chose a toponym for its bank notes, as have the Europeans - was Zaire. At the current rate of long-term decline, the euro will look rather more like this unlamented bathroom tissue funny money and rather less like the dollar.

All that said, the assembled protectives concluded that the missing 16 cents could be explained rather more simply. They represent the value that has been destroyed by the abolition of what had been a very successful market in currencies within the euro zone. In effect, they are the price that has been paid for losing the market efficiency of Europe's foreign exchanges.

Funnily enough we would all have benefited had the dollar taken a knock from the euro; this at least would have cooled down Wall Street's roaring asset boom. Just one benefit from the euro and they couldn't deliver even that.

webTitle: Europe unites behind German IMF bid

fields.headline: Europe unites behind German IMF bid
fields.trailText: European Union governments are today expected to bury their differences and rally around Germany's candidate for the top job at the International Monetary Fund.
fields.body:
European Union governments are today expected to bury their differences and rally around Germany's candidate for the top job at the International Monetary Fund.

With France and Britain having dropped their opposition to Caio Koch-Weser, EU finance ministers will be able to present a united front to the rest of the world when they meet in Brussels.

But it is still not clear that he will command enough support on the IMF board to succeed Michel Camdessus, who stepped down as managing director earlier this month.

The contest was thrown wide open last week when Japan nominated Eisuke Sakakibara, a former top finance ministry official, for the post which is traditionally filled by a European, and a group of African states put forward Stanley Fischer.

Mr Fischer, a naturalised American born in what is now Zambia, is the IMF's caretaker leader. Sources close to the discussions say that Mr Koch-Weser is unlikely to win the contest without support from the United States.

Yet the US treasury is thought to be lukewarm about his background in development rather than financial economics, and Wall Street is beginning to voice support for Mr Fischer.

"The markets welcome the fact that in Stanley Fischer, you now have a candidate who has experience in both the management and prevention of emerging market crises," said Mohamed El-Erian, a portfolio manager at the largest of the American bond fund managers, Pacific Investment Management.

With Europe certain to oppose an American being chosen for the IMF as well as the World Bank - which is headed by Jim Wolfensohn - some observers say Europe might eventually be forced to offer a more acceptable alternative to Mr Koch-Weser.

Andrew Crockett, a Briton who runs the Bank of International Settlements in Basle, is said to be favoured by some non-European IMF countries.

But Euroland governments would prefer one of their own nationals to take over from Mr Camdessus.

webTitle: US were ready to bail out Wilson

fields.headline: US were ready to bail out Wilson
fields.trailText: Harold Wilson appears to have been kept in the dark about a $3bn-plus rescue package that could have prevented the humiliating devaluation of sterling in November 1967, according to declassified papers from the US state department.
fields.body:
Harold Wilson appears to have been kept in the dark about a $3bn-plus rescue package that could have prevented the humiliating devaluation of sterling in November 1967, according to declassified papers from the US state department.

The move rocked Wilson's Labour government, undermining its credibility with backbench MPs and foreign governments. Wilson refused to devalue when he won the 1964 election, but three years later cheap imports were flooding into the country, exporters' goods were increasingly expensive and a balance of payments crisis loomed.

A memo marked: "Secret; sensitive" from White House special assistant, Walt Rostow, to President Lyndon Johnson on November 16 enthuses on the likelihood of central bankers chipping in to a huge fund to salvage the pound.

He wrote: "There is a general consensus on the need for an impressive package. The impression one gets is that the central bankers went to the brink and didn't like what they saw."

But Wilson, writing in his diary for November 15, commented that there were "no serious signs of a chequebook" from the Americans.

The diary note, from the Wilson family papers, is quoted in Ben Pimlott's 1992 biography of the late prime minister.

The then chancellor, James Callaghan, wrote in his memoirs that he believed devaluation to have been inevitable as from November 13, given the inadequacy of support offers from the US and the International Monetary Fund. Lord Callaghan stated that $2bn was on offer but that he and Bank of England governor Sir Leslie O'Brien, felt this would buy little more than a "breathing space".

Five months earlier, Callaghan had spoken of the need for a $3bn package - the figure Mr Rostow was mentioning to President Johnson two days before devaluation.

Why this last-minute package was not put to the British is not known. Washington DC was informed of the decision to devalue sterling from its post-war rate of $2.8 to $2.4 only late on the evening of Friday November 17.

Kenneth Morgan's biography of Lord Callaghan confirms that on November 13 the chancellor believed "the end of the road had been reached" and that President Johnson called an emergency cabinet meeting on Monday November 20 in which he told colleagues that sterling's devaluation "has the most serious consequences for the administration".

Another state department memorandum of November 13 warned the president that the consequences would include an attack on the dollar and the fact that "the gold market would come under very great pressure and might explode".

Wilson's assurance that the purchasing power of sterling at home had not been devalued backfired and the phrase "the pound in your pocket" was to haunt him for the rest of his political career.

Elsewhere in the State Department archive is material relating to the currency crisis of late 1968, in which Britain, America and other countries tried to persuade West Germany to revalue the mark.

On November 19 Johnson cabled Wilson with suggestions for a realignment of European currencies. Wilson sent two telegrams in reply which remain top secret and have not been declassified.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

Adult magazine publisher Richard Desmond is planning a £500m flotation of his Northern & Shell and Portland Investments businesses. Mr Desmond, an advertising salesman turned entrepreneur, is in talks with advisers about his plans, which also include online media operations.

The government is believed to have agreed to grant aid worth almost £540m to Airbus Industrie 's A3XX super jumbo plane project. The government aid for the project will not be formally announced until BAE Systems and EADS agree the terms to form a new Airbus Integrated Company, according to the newspaper.

Sunday Telegraph

John Taylor , chief executive of British Nuclear Fuels, will be ousted this week amid mounting concern over the future of the nuclear reprocessing group, says the newspaper. His departure follows an attack from the nuclear installations inspectorate accusing BNFL of "systematic management failures" allowing falsification of data for nuclear fuel destined for Japan. BNFL is said to have already chosen a successor, who is thought to come from outside the nuclear industry.

British Borneo is in talks with Centrica to sell its stake in the Elgin Franklin field in the North Sea in a deal which may be worth up to £200m. The newspaper said Centrica is emerging as one of the front runners to buy British Borneo's 8% stake in the field.

Mail on Sunday

BT is planning a shake-up involving more job cuts, spinning off divisions and possible board changes in response to dismal profits and falling shares.

Troubled group Marks & Spencer is planning to sell electrical goods in a major departure from its core clothing and grocery retailing business.

Carlsberg , one of the world's best known beer firms, is in talks with US group Anheuser-Busch , owner of Budweiser, which could lead to a £2bn takeover of the Danish firm.

Observer

Investment firm Knutsford is planning to launch a takeover bid on a retail group within the next three weeks. The newspaper said Knutsford has been looking at Storehouse , owner of BhS and Mothercare, which last Friday announced it had received several bid approaches. Knutsford, shortly to be headed by former Asda boss Archie Norman, denied last week that it is among Storehouse's predators.

Sunday Business

Powergen is this week expected to announce a takeover of LG&E Energy , a Kentucky-based utility, in a deal worth about £2bn. Investors have been waiting for Powergen to expand in the US since the breakdown of merger talks with Houston Industries two years ago. Analysts say that LG&E, is the right fit for Powergen in terms of size and region.

IoS

Creditors of Barings , the merchant bank brought to its knees by rogue trader Nick Leeson, are planning to launch legal action against the Bank of England for failing to properly supervise the institution.

Camelot , the National Lottery operator, is planning to slash its profits by half in a bid to secure its license for another seven years. The move is designed to see off the challenge from The People's Lottery, Sir Richard Branson's not-for-profit bid.

Online auction group eBay is expected to mount a £1bn bid to take over Sotheby's , the ailing auction house.

fields.headline: Durlacher joins £30m venture
fields.trailText: The man who created the Spice Girls has won £6m backing from technology boutique Durlacher to build a global pop website aimed at young music fans.
fields.body:
The man who created the Spice Girls has won £6m backing from technology boutique Durlacher to build a global pop website aimed at young music fans.

Simon Fuller, who also manages pop groups Eurythmics and S Club 7 (pictured above at last year's Party in the Park in London) has teamed up with music marketing specialist Robert Dodds to deliver pop to children aged between eight and 14 over new media platforms.

The venture, which launches and reveals its name later this year, has been valued at £30m, giving Durlacher a 20% stake. Mr Dodds, whose marketing firm Music Innovations counts Pepsi, MasterCard and Orange among its clients, said it will strike alliances with consumer brands keen to target the teen and pre-teen markets.

Unilever and Procter & Gamble have recently invested in websites aimed at tapping consumer spend among teenagers.

"Pop fans are traditionally a very poorly served market," Mr Dodds said. "We believe we can build a brand and service more comprehensive than anything they have previously experienced and one which parents will be happy to let their children use."

Geoffrey Chamberlain, chief executive of Durlacher Corporation, said: "Over the past 18 months Durlacher have reviewed many start-up pro posals within the music arena, but the quality of both the management and strategic thinking set this company apart from any other.

"This new venture demonstrates how the Durlacher model can be applied to help build leading consumer branded businesses, utilising old and new technologies."

fields.headline: Tata Tea pays £271m for Tetley
fields.standfirst: Purchase of global brand opens up opportunities for Indian producers
fields.trailText: Tetley, famous for its TV adverts featuring the Tetley tea folk, has been swallowed up by Tata Tea, the world's largest integrated tea company.
fields.body:
Tetley, famous for its TV adverts featuring the Tetley tea folk, has been swallowed up by Tata Tea, the world's largest integrated tea company.

The Indian company has paid £271m for the privately held Tetley, which makes Britain's most popular tea and the second largest global tea brand.

The deal concluded after months of negotiations, is being financed through a combination of equity and debt.

Tata Tea, part of India's largest business group Tata, said the existing Tetley management will continue to handle the day-to-day affairs of the company.

R.K. Krishna Kumar, vice-chairman of Tata Tea, said: "There are no implications on jobs at all." But he admitted there will be some changes in the board composition.

He said Tata and Tetley would remain separate entities for some time until the acquisition had stabilised.

Indian tea planters said the deal augured well for the local industry.

It puts an Indian firm on the global map for branded tea and will encourage others to scout for foreign brands, said R.S. Jhawar, chairman of the Indian Tea Association.

"For the first time, an Indian tea company has acquired a global brand. It opens a lot of opportunities for us," he said.

Darjeeling Planters Association chairman Ashok Lohia said Indian firms would be encouraged to think globally.

"Certainly it is an example for other tea companies. We need to think global," he said. "It is a great thing to happen. As an Indian tea planter, I feel delighted."

The acquisition excludes the American coffee business of Tetley, which was recently sold by the existing shareholders of Tetley separately.

Tata Tea has a 23% market share in India, behind Hindustan Lever, the Indian subsidiary of the Anglo-Dutch company Unilever, which has 44% of the market, Mr Kumar said.

The combined sales turn over of Tetley and Tata Tea was 29 billion rupees (£418m), he said.

"As we enter into new markets, these can increase very substantially," Mr Kumar said, although he gave no target.

"We [Tata Tea] are growing at 8% every year and we expect to accelerate that."

Tata Tea already had a five-year-old equal joint venture with Tetley in India and this would most probably be included in the international operations of Tata Tea, he said.

webTitle: Irn Bru set to take on Coke in US

fields.headline: Irn Bru set to take on Coke in US
fields.trailText: It is being billed as the David v Goliath clash of the soft beverage world. In one corner is a global giant, the planet's most popular drink and one of the most instantly recognisable brands of all time.
fields.body:
It is being billed as the David v Goliath clash of the soft beverage world. In one corner is a global giant, the planet's most popular drink and one of the most instantly recognisable brands of all time.

In the other is a bright orange, sweet, sticky concoction with a flavour described variously as liquid bubble gum or damp sheep fleece.

Undeterred by the fact that its appeal remains a mystery to most who were not raised on it from birth, Irn Bru, Scotland's unique "other national drink", is set to launch an ambitious attempt to cross the Atlantic and take on the multinational might of Coca-Cola in its own backyard.

AG Barr, the makers of the fabled hangover cure, confirmed yesterday that trials are under way in New York to establish whether the world's biggest but most discerning soft drink-buying public can find a place in their hearts and taste buds for a liquid whose secret principal ingredient is rumoured to be seaweed. The company hopes to open a US franchise operation.

Scotland's undying devotion to Irn Bru has made it one of the few places on earth where Coke is not the biggest selling soft drink. Last year, the Atlanta-based multinational appointed a special sales team north of the border to dislodge the home-grown upstart from its number one position.

The modern recipe for Coke may be unknown outside the company, but only two men know the full list of 32 flavourings which go into Irn Bru. Robin Barr, the company's chairman, and his cousin Michael, the transport and export director, personally mix the base syrup each week.

The sole written copy of the recipe is locked in a bank vault which will only be opened on production of the men's death certificates. Even the company's new managing director, Hugh McPherson - the first non-family member to hold the position - will not be told the ingredients until he has proved his trustworthiness.

fields.headline: Beyond the final frontier
fields.standfirst: At last someone has opened an internet cafe that's not just for geeks. The design of Nutopia, says  Jonathan Glancey, is as innovative as the technology it offers up on its sleek, streamlined terminals
fields.trailText: At last someone has opened an internet cafe that's not just for geeks. The design of Nutopia is as innovative as the technology it offers up on its sleek, streamlined terminals.
fields.body:
Ever since Stanley Kubrick released his magisterial 2001: A Space Odyssey, people have dreamed of inhabiting the film's supercool interiors. That was in 1968, when Nasa's own living spaces were about as glamorous as an electrician's workshop, but the movie sets still look good. They have influenced generations of designers from Tom Dixon and Marc Newson to Grant Mitchell, the New Zealander who has just put his stamp on London's newest internet cafe, the ethereally good-looking Nutopia.

Mitchell and his associates make the link explicit - the new cafe is, they say, "challenging the imagination of its competitors with interiors that steal from Kubrick's masterpiece". It also "aims to provide a space where technology meets creativity in an environment designed to appeal to a style-conscious clientele". That claim, loosely translated, means that a group of talented young computer and design buffs have created the first convincing "cybercafe", a space that aims to match the dream of computer technology.

Mitchell, 35, came to England from Auckland 15 years ago. He studied the piano from the age of five, but trained as a graphic designer before emigrating. He liked the idea of setting up some sort of work and meeting place where anyone could drop by, and was disappointed by the internet cafes that sprang up across Britain in the 90s. There was a mismatch, he thought, between what computers could do in terms of imagery, and the look and feel of internet cafes and offices that revolved around computers.

So Mitchell teamed up with George Philippakos (Nutopia's IT director) and Toula Philippakou (its operations manager) to create a corner of the capital in which those willing to pay £5 an hour can disappear into a computer-generated virtual world while inhabiting a workplace that is itself about as close to cyberspace as you can hope to find.

The Nutopia concept will doubtless be copied, but Mitchell and gang intend to keep several steps ahead of their rivals. What they have between them is that all too rare mix of passion, energy, imagination and technical know-how. "It's about imagining what we could do and could be," says Mitchell. "The name Nutopia comes from a statement made by John Lennon and Yoko Ono in 1973. We announce, they said, the birth of a conceptual country, Nutopia. It has no land, no boundaries or passports, only people". And this, more or less, is what Mitchell and co have set out to achieve in Covent Garden - a space where boundaries dissolve and it can be hard to tell what is real and what is unreal.

Karl Marx, after a few glasses of claret, might have liked working in Nutopia, for here, like nowhere else in London, all that's solid really does appear to melt into the air. By mixing old and new technologies - film projectors, slides, computer-generated imagery - Nutopia escapes the unthinking attachment to the new that distorts so much current thinking.

Low lighting levels, fish tanks, wires and cables hushed away are just some of the elements that help to make Nutopia such an airy and relaxing space to be in and work in. These, and the continually changing installations of furniture, fittings and artworks chosen by Mitchell and co. On display until the beginning of April are a light-emitting polycarbonate sofa by Ansel Thompson; a kinetic light sculpture made of three skipping ropes and a "chromastrobic" light by Paul Friedlander; and wall-mounted light panels by Jason Bruges that change as you move across or in front of them. These are inspired designs that connect the pop art world of the 60s with that of the 2000s and the promise of cyberspace.

The question that emerges and morphs in the brain after a mind-expanding visit to Nutopia is this: why, given the ability of computer programs to generate fantastic visions, are architects and designers incapable of realising such digital dreams in real space?

It's true that without computer modelling we would never have seen such brave and inventive buildings as Frank Gehry's Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao or Renzo Piano's Kansai International Airport. And yet, inside, neither building offers a breakaway sense of space. This is for one necessary reason: they are required to perform tasks - the display of artworks of many periods, the mass movement of people - that more fantastic configurations might only confuse. Except in the smoke-and-mirror games played in spaces like Nutopia, the cyberdream can so far only be seen on computer screens and in books.

Hybrid Space, a new book by Peter Zellner, a US architect who studied with Rem Koolhaas at Harvard, looks at the work of a dozen architectural practices worldwide. All are attempting to connect the real world with the virtual world, to exploit the computer's ability to create unexpected new forms through digital animation and complex algorithms, even to crossbreed biology and technology (very much a 60s dream; try not to think of Roger Dean's album covers for Yes). "Their researches," says Zellner, "are triggering a phase-shift in our perception and comprehension of space, materiality and time at the start of the new millennium."

Maybe. This is, of course, millennial and thus messianic thinking, although no less valuable for that. Many of the weird and wonderful spaces shown in the book are as unattainable, given existing building materials and technology, as the speed of light is for a spaceship, even the wonderful machines that moved so gracefully through 2001. That said, it is also true that Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, the great Prussian modernist, designed two remarkable glass skyscrapers between 1919 and 1921. These were to set the tone of many of the best office buildings of the 20th century, but at the time Mies conjured them, they were impossible to realise.

The mere fact that Zellner's architects are thinking about cyberspace is important. Architecture need not come to a full stop with bricks and mortar, steel and glass or even polycarbonates and neoprene. At the moment, however, we will have to make do with subtly theatrical spaces like Nutopia. This gives us the feel of what we might yet achieve as computer design comes of age and we begin to see how we might create buildings and interiors as ethereal and happily uncertain as a magic-lantern show. Or Mitchell's favourite interior, the Louis-XV-meets-supertech hotel room somewhere deep in hyperspace where Dr David Bowman, hero of 2001, arrives during the last reel of Kubrick's masterly exploration of future space.

It also "aims to provide a space where technology meets creativity in an environment designed to appeal to a style-conscious clientele". fields.headline: Slow down
fields.standfirst: The government wants a big cut in road deaths, but it has put the brake on the most obvious option - lowering national speed limits
fields.trailText: On Wednesday the government publishes its review of road safety and speed on the roads - daughters of John Prescott's transport white paper. This is the government's recipe for cutting deaths on the roads by 40% by 2010. In the same period it also wants to halve the number of children killed and seriously hurt.
fields.body:
On Wednesday the government publishes its review of road safety and speed on the roads - daughters of John Prescott's transport white paper. This is the government's recipe for cutting deaths on the roads by 40% by 2010. In the same period it also wants to halve the number of children killed and seriously hurt.

If the policy works it will still leave 1,700 people killed and around 3,000 children killed or seriously injured. That figure for deaths will compare well with most of our European neighbours, but poorly with our main road safety rival Sweden, which is putting in place policies which will aspire to zero road deaths. It will compare very badly with the safety standards expected in travel by rail and air.

The most controversial issue in the reviews has been whether to change national speed limits. A statistical analysis of the most dangerous and least dangerous roads led ministers to consider reducing the 30mph limit in towns and the 60mph limit on country roads, while raising the limit of 70mph on Britain's safest roads - the motorways. But lowering speed limits nationally was resisted by the motoring organisations at a time when the government was on the defensive over fuel taxation policies. And the increase in the upper limit was rejected by environment ministers because of the greatly increased contribution to the greenhouse effect from driving at high speeds.

Perhaps there could have been a trade-off. Say urban limits had been lowered to 25mph and motorway limits raised to 75 or 80mph. But even if that had squared the motoring lobby while improving safety, the opportunity has now passed, at least until limits are officially reviewed again.

Any immediate decisions on changes in speed limits have now been handed to local councils. They, following a direct intervention by the prime minister, will be instructed to reduce by 50% the number of children killed or seriously hurt. Britain's record for injuries to child pedestrians and cyclists is one of the worst in Europe. British children walk and cycle only a third as much as Dutch children, but face more than double the risk of death.

Councils have been given the power to reduce local speed limits where appropriate to 20mph to cut the risk faced by children near schools and on residential streets. Fine, but serious questions remain about whether the strategy can work without major funding from central government for a nationwide programme of traffic calming in residential areas, and without a clear policy for reducing the risk to cyclists and pedestrians on urban A and B roads where half of urban pedestrian and cycling deaths occur.

Ministers will be asked whether they have compromised on safety in order to promote mobility. What, for instance, will be the prime determinant of a slow-speed zone in a town - pedestrian safety or traffic density? If schools flank a major road at half-mile intervals, how should the school's ambit be defined? Should cars be forced to slow down past playing fields, shops and other facilities visited on foot? These are vital questions that still need clarification from government. Perhaps that will come later in guidance to local councils.

Another area where the government's policy appears unclear is in the enforcement of existing speed limits. The junior home office minister Charles Clarke told me in the autumn that the 30mph limit in built-up areas should be rigorously enforced on safety grounds... yet following pressure from the motoring lobby he was overruled by Downing Street.

The Association of Chief Police Officers confirmed recently that police will give motorists 10% leeway over the legal limit, plus an extra 2mph to allow for any discrepancies in speed-monitoring equipment. Safety experts argue that the leeway should not be given, as every one mile an hour increases the risk of an accident by 5%. The home secretary, Jack Straw, has yet to say whether he accepts these police guidelines on law enforcement.

In the summer, the home office is due to publish a wholesale review of sentencing for driving offences; ministers believe courts have been too lenient with dangerous drivers. But Jack Straw is reluctant to make traffic policing a core duty for police forces. A recent report by HM Inspectorate of Constabulary even described traffic policing as a Cinderella activity - the number of traffic officers has been halved in just over a decade. (The number of safety cameras, however, is set to increase with some councils being given the proceeds of speeding fines by the treasury for the sake of investment in enforcement.)

There is a democratic dimension missing from the road-safety review. No provision is being made to increase people's ability to demand enforcement of safe speeds on streets where they live. This may prove a critical flaw. Local campaigners are often told by police and councils that there needs to be a death on the road to lift it up the priority list for speed cameras or traffic calming.

But many initiatives in the review will be widely praised. Villagers will benefit from new 30mph speed limits (there is to be further discussion over reducing speeds on rural lanes). There will be be more Dutch-style "home zones" in which small residential streets are re-engineered at the behest of residents to remove the dominance of the car. The question here will be how far the government will meet what could amount to a massive demand for reworking local roads.

Wednesday's announcement will also feature a new panel to monitor progress towards the accident reduction targets. There will be consultation over how to improve training for young drivers - who are vulnerable to mistakes in the first few years of driving. It will raise the likelihood of greatly increased safety spending in the transport spending review due in the summer. And it will herald a new level of cooperation with the health and safety executive to bring business driving under similar rules that apply to workplaces. This might lead to a clampdown on the excesses of white van man.

The review is to be "target driven" but though deaths and injuries are confidently expected to fall, the government has abandoned hopes of cutting the number of accidents. They will rise as traffic increases.

Hit by a car at:

10mph nearly all children live

20mph one in 20 dies

30mph nearly half die

40mph 17 out of 20 die

 Roger Harrabin reports on transport for BBC Radio 4's Today

webTitle: Why Shearer is right to turn his back on England

fields.headline: Why Shearer is right to turn his back on England
fields.trailText: To some extent Shearer's decision to call it a day at international level has let Keegan off the hook. The critical voices that earlier this season queried Shearer's worth to the England side might have grown louder as the World Cup qualifiers got under way and another encounter with Germany approached.
fields.body:
The surprise that has greeted Alan Shearer's decision to retire from international football after the European championship confirms the wisdom of his timing. Clearly he never intended to fade away like just any old soldier.

At 29 he is leaving England while still relatively young. Gary Lineker was two years older when, with Japan in mind, he informed Graham Taylor that he would no longer be available for selection after the 1992 European championship.

At least there is less chance of Shearer departing amid the sort of controversy that attended Lineker's farewell performance in Stockholm, when Taylor substituted his captain before the end of a match which saw England beaten 2-1 and out of the tournament.

It is to be hoped that the retiring England captain will be able to leave the bridge in a more dignified manner. Kevin Keegan's team will probably not win Euro 2000 but if Shearer can lead them to respectability - the semi-finals, say - then his international career will have ended on a high note.

But for his last serious injury Shearer might even now be contemplating the next World Cup qualifiers. He recovered from torn cruciate ligaments at the end of 1992 to become one of the best England centre-forwards of his type since Nat Lofthouse, but the damage to ankle ligaments and fibula he suffered in a pre-season tournament in 1997 has probably shortened his international career by two years.

When he returned to the England side the goals were still coming but something of the old Shearer was missing. Crucially it was that half-yard of pace which makes a split-second's difference between a chance taken and a chance missed.

He has remained an outstanding striker for Newcastle United in the Premiership, once he was playing for the right manager and with the right partner, but for England he has not been the centre-forward who bulged the nets at Wembley in Euro 96.

Now he will concentrate on being an icon on Tyneside, probably with a view to learning and listening under Bobby Robson so that he can eventually become the Newcastle manager. There is a lot of football still left in him and when he eventually decides to pack up playing altogether it will again, barring further injuries, be at a moment of his own choosing.

To some extent Shearer's decision to call it a day at international level has let Keegan off the hook. The critical voices that earlier this season queried Shearer's worth to the England side might have grown louder as the World Cup qualifiers got under way and another encounter with Germany approached.

Shearer is facing a demanding enough European championship as it is. He was not at his best under Glenn Hoddle in the 1998 World Cup and his form deteriorated in the Euro 2000 qualifiers. Now he has to rouse himself against Portugal, Germany and Romania to avoid the accusation that he should have gone even sooner.

Knowing Shearer, he will do his utmost to go out with the fans pleading for him to stay on longer. He has not ruled out playing for England again in a crisis.

Keegan, however, must now begin the search for Shearer's successor sooner than he had planned. Like will not be replaced with like. Shearer is a completely different striker to Lineker, for example, although his rate of scoring - 28 goals in 57 appearances - bears comparison with Lineker's 48 in 80.

Injuries permitting, Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler will be high on the list to inherit Shearer's mantle. Kevin Phillips, Emile Heskey and, dare one say it, Andy Cole will also come into the reckoning. Of the younger pretenders, Michael Bridges and Carl Cort may eventually press their claims.

Will Shearer be the last of the present England squad to call it a day before the summer is out? After Euro 2000 David Seaman, Tony Adams or Paul Ince might decide enough is enough.

Either way, the England team will have to undergo some urgent renovations between the end of the European championship and the World Cup game against Germany in October. At least Keegan now knows where he has to start. And he could do worse than make Sol Campbell his next captain.

fields.headline: Nationwide Second Division
fields.trailText: Rovers return
fields.body:
Rovers return

Bristol Rovers returned to the top of the table with their 10th away win of the season, demolishing Oldham 4-1 at Boundary Park after striking thrice in the first 11 minutes.

Jamie Cureton, with his 18th and 19th of the season, and the Latvian Vitalijs Astafjevs made it an uphill task for Oldham before Andy Thomson added a fourth three minutes after half-time. Craig Dudley's 67th-minute effort was little consolation for the home side.

 Preston's match with Gillingham at Deepdale was delayed by an hour owing to a motorway accident but the wait was worth it for the travelling fans at least. Carl Asaba struck twice to knock North End off the top and boost the Gills' play-off hopes.

 While the match between two other play-off contenders at Wigan's JJB Stadium was overshadowed by crowd trouble, Stoke's 2-1 win was their first in five attempts. Scott Green put the hosts in front, Graham Kavanagh equalised before half-time and James O'Connor hit the winner 14 minutes from time.

 Millwall stole into third place ahead of Wigan with a 2-0 win at Cambridge, Paul Moody poaching both their goals. Burnley stayed in fifth, winning 2-1 at Colchester with Steve Davis notching both of theirs. Steve McGavin scored for the Essex side.

 Chesterfield ended a streak of four without a win, beating Reading 2-0 with goals from Stephen Payne and Ian Breckin.

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Brighton roll
fields.body:
Brighton roll

Brighton, eight games without a win, made up for it in style with a 7-1 victory at Chester's Deva Stadium, Bobby Zamora leading the way with a hat-trick against the league's bottom club.

Three goals in five second-half minutes knocked the stuffing out of Chester, Keith MacPherson, Paul Brooker and a Zamora penalty doing the damage before Darren Freeman and Paul Rogers finished things off. Luke Beckett was Chester's scorer.

 Rotherham's 17th clean sheet of the season and a goal from Paul Warne kept the Merry Millers on top of the table with a 1-0 win over Rochdale.

 Second-placed Swansea made it 13 matches unbeaten at home but a goalless draw against Hull leaves them only a point ahead of Darlington.

 The Quakers won 2-1 at Mansfield to extend their unbeaten run to six games. Marco Gabbiadini hit his 21st goal of the campaign in the 11th minute and Jesper Hjorth doubled the advantage after 78. Michael Boulding pulled one back for the Stags.

 Northampton moved into fifth place, Steven Howard's 50th-minute effort enough to give them a 1-0 win over Barnet, who had Warren Hackett sent off for foul and abusive language in the 31st minute and are now six games without an away success.

 Cheltenham undermined Peterborough's ambitions with goals from the on-loan Chris Freestone and a Jason Lee own-goal giving them a 2-1 win.

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: Rovers rally
fields.body:
Rovers rally

More than 18,000 were at Ewood Park to witness a dramatic Blackburn comeback, orchestrated by Keith Gillespie, a second-half substitute.

However, hopes of an instant return to the Premiership require more fuelling than a 2-1 home victory over a West Brom side who last won away four months ago. And the Rovers manager Tony Parkes admitted that despite the win, more needed to be done. "The crowd have become very subdued and now it's up to the team to lift the supporters," he said. "That's the stage we have reached now."

The introduction of Gillespie and Nathan Blake on the hour changed the game after Matt Carbon had put the visitors ahead after 13 minutes. The Irish winger scored his first of the season before setting up a 76th-minute winner for Christian Dailly.

 The Barnsley manager Dave Bassett criticised the referee Mick Fletcher after a 1-1 draw in which both sides had goals disallowed, Eric Tinkler equalising after Dean Holdsworth had scored from the spot. "I am not trying to slaughter the referee because sometimes these things happen in football and in the end I think a draw was a fair result," Bassett said.

Swindon's Sol Davis was sent off as fellow strugglers Crewe won with a Colin Cramb header at the County Ground. The Crewe manager Dario Gradi said: "They couldn't handle Rodney Jack's pace and it produced the goal and the sending off."

webTitle: Leicester's totem delivers in nick of time

fields.headline: Leicester's totem delivers in nick of time
fields.trailText: A few fire extinguishers might just go off in Matt Elliott's local this week. Having scored the goal which got Leicester here, the captain added two more headers to lift the trophy. Somehow his highly pregnant wife survived the excitement in the stands without going into labour.
fields.body:
A few fire extinguishers might just go off in Matt Elliott's local this week. Having scored the goal which got Leicester here, the captain added two more headers to lift the trophy. Somehow his highly pregnant wife survived the excitement in the stands without going into labour.

"I hope she hangs on for a couple more days," Elliott said afterwards, "because I want to celebrate." Any chance of the baby being called Wembley to remember dad's exploits? "It's where the child's conceived, isn't it?" the defender said. "Mind you, back alley doesn't sound too good."

By the end of his match-winning performance, Elliott looked like he had been dragged through a back alley. Mud on his balding head, blood down his left cheekbone, the 31-year-old deserved all the plaudits hurled at him.

Emergency centre-forward in the last round, centre-back here, he has done a huge amount to help Leicester back into Europe. "He was fabulous," said his manager Martin O'Neill. "He is priceless to us, like five or six others - colossal. He's a big-game player; I'm pleased he won a medal." When Leicester won this trophy in 1997 Elliott was cup-tied, having moved from Oxford United for £1.6m that season.

This time it was his wife Catherine who watched agonised in the stands. There was a worry Elliott might not be here if his fourth child, due yesterday, arrived before kick-off. Luckily for Leicester, following the Kanu and Babayaro line, Elliott Jr will be showing up late.

"We agreed if nothing happened before midnight on Saturday my wife would not tell me anything," Elliott said, "so I could remain reasonably relaxed. I kept my eye on her when there was a lull in the game and I had a little panic when I couldn't see her for 10 minutes or so. But at the end she was jiggling around with the best of them."

Elliott epitomises what O'Neill has achieved. Like several others at Leicester, Wembley has not always been his natural habitat. Epsom and Ewell, Torquay and Scunthorpe count among his former clubs. Here he dealt well with Dave Challinor's throws and, if he was partly culpable for David Kelly's equaliser, he more than made amends.

"I always thought we would win," O'Neill said. "I'm thrilled for the club and the players and, not being modest about it, I'm reasonably pleased for myself. This is our third final in four years, two of which we have won. For the size of our club we have done splendidly."

Having lost to a 10-man Tottenham last year, O'Neill was delighted to see off a 10-man Tranmere and thrilled to be congratulated by his former Nottingham Forest manager Brian Clough: "He pulled me aside to say well done. I'm so pleased he saw this."

The worry for Leicester fans is this will be the last they see of Emile Heskey; that Liverpool will make a move. "It will be a lot down to the lad himself," O'Neill said. "I will move heaven and earth to keep him."

John Aldridge, the Tranmere manager, was proud in defeat. He was involved in an argument with the Leicester bench after spotting one of their substitutes applauding Clint Hill's dismissal but said: "The players can go out of the stadium with their heads 6ft 5in high. With 10 men a lot of teams would have rolled over and died.

"We are disappointed with the way we conceded the goals, but it was a lot closer than people thought and I loved that. If we had drawn, I don't think anyone could have had any qualms."
