webTitle: From Wizard of the Dribble to wizard of the drivel, a pair of Diamond geezers

fields.headline: From Wizard of the Dribble to wizard of the drivel, a pair of Diamond geezers
fields.trailText: Match Of The Day's tribute to Sir Stan, a montage of shots of players observing one minute's silence at various Premiership grounds, was actually rather kind to modern footballers, demonstrating that even today's P-UIs know when it is time to act with a little solemnity.
fields.body:
'Bleedin' pissed-up idiots" was the first thing I heard when I switched on for Match Of The Day on Saturday. A little extreme, I thought, but since the week had been dominated by comparisons between Sir Stanley Matthews and the modern footballer, mostly favouring Sir Stan, my first thought was that here was another voice using the gentle knight's exemplary behaviour as a stick with which to beat today's, well, pissed-up idiots.

In fact I had caught the closing words of Muscle, a searing examination of the shady world of the nightclub bouncer and nothing at all to do with football, although there is every chance you will catch a couple of the Leeds United lads unwinding after a hard match.

Match Of The Day's tribute to Sir Stan, a montage of shots of players observing one minute's silence at various Premiership grounds, was actually rather kind to modern footballers, demonstrating that even today's P-UIs know when it is time to act with a little solemnity.

Overall, though, the endless tributes to Matthews erred uncomfortably on the side of reverence. Comparing him with present-day players proved about as useful as arguing over which taste nicer, apples or pears.

About the most revealing assessment of the Wizard of the Dribble came from the commendably down-to-earth Jimmy Armfield on Football Focus. He, unlike many of the talking heads rounded up in the cause of instant hagiography, shared a dressing room with Sir Stan - at Blackpool for seven years - and gave real insight into the great man's routine.

What may have helped give Matthews his edge, and certainly accounted for his longevity in the game, was the fact that he had a routine. In an era when footballers were happy to smoke away their afternoons in billiard halls before picking up pie and chips on the way home, he gave some thought to personal fitness and diet - which the young Armfield clearly found rather strange and fascinating.

The teetotal Stan was a great believer in the benefits of deep breathing, said Armfield, and was so weight- conscious he would starve himself for a full day if necessary, which nowadays is the kind of thing you expect from a footballer's wife rather than the player himself.

Sir Stan also persuaded Armfield of the wisdom of keeping his aggression in check. "If you lose control your game will go to pieces," he told the tyro defender. A shame he wasn't around when Gazza was learning the trade.

The lesson of keeping control has been well learned by Armfield. What makes him such a perceptive analyst on Radio 5 Live is that he manages to keep a sense of perspective about the game, invariably remaining cool amid the clamorous voices all around him.

My friend Dominik Diamond is from a slightly different broadcasting tradition to Armfield. The former England full-back, for instance, would be unlikely to suggest Victoria Adams had borrowed studs from David Beckham's boots to enhance the outline of her nipples when modelling. This was one of the less successful jokes on Diamond's show Diamond Sport, to which I was nevertheless grateful to turn as light relief from the valedictory atmosphere of so much of the football coverage last week. From the Wizard of the Dribble to the wizard of the drivel, in fact.

Diamond Sport was commended to me by the production company Bath Night, which makes it for the digital channel BBC Choice. Its production assistant wrote drawing my attention to the "quick wit" and "Scottish temperament" of "infamous funny man Dominik Diamond", most of which I would readily agree with - especially the bit about him being Scottish.

T he programme, though rather hit-and-miss, made me smile more than most of what I saw on TV last week. Diamond even raised a laugh from the increase in the TV licence, most of which he said would go to the BBC's digital output. As a result of the extra funds available, said the infamous funny man, next week's show would feature "live football - Manchester United versus the cast of Die Hard 2 - and guest presenters Desmond Lynam, Leonardo DiCaprio and Pamela Anderson."

The problem with Diamond Sport, "the show that takes the week of sport, laughs at it behind its back, takes its trousers down and then shows its bottom to the girls", is summed up by that tortuous introduction. If there were somebody around to do a little judicious editing, maybe throw out some of the more off-colour ideas, Diamond Sport would improve no end, but as it is produced, written and presented by Dominik Diamond (a veritable Orson Welles for the digital age), who is going to do it?

A little of Diamond's acid wit, however, would not go amiss on A Question Of Sport, the point of which I am afraid remains a mystery to me. Why is everybody falling about in paroxysms of mirth when nothing remotely funny is happening?

Last week's show was a football managers' special featuring John Aldridge, David O'Leary and the Smiths, Walter and Jim. The way Ally McCoist was carrying on you would have thought the guest list included Oscar Wilde, Noel Coward and Benny Hill. A producer friend once told me the secret of looking good on TV is to look pleased to be there, but you surely do not have to look that pleased.

fields.headline: Back to the European grindstone
fields.trailText: When Uefa announced that this season's Champions League would be expanded into what is almost a European League, it was hailed as a milestone. The impression persists, however, that instead it has become a millstone.
fields.body:
When Uefa announced that this season's Champions League would be expanded into what is almost a European League, it was hailed as a milestone. The impression persists, however, that instead it has become a millstone.

This month Europe's top clubs publicly declared themselves happy with the new format, which was specifically designed to meet their aims of making more millions while seeing off a potential breakaway.

But the evidence continues to suggest that this is one grind that has caused bluntness. During the first flurry of group games, club after European club watched domestic form collapse through tiredness and overwork.

It is worrying to think that the depreciation of domestic tournaments such as the FA and Worthington Cups should spread to the Premiership. Yet this week's resumption of the second tranche of Champions League group games heralds a March that truly can be called mad.

Beginning with the weekend just gone, Manchester United and Chelsea play two games a week for four weeks, alternating between Premiership and Europe, hotel and home, coach trips and air flights, the only r&r being the musical variety heard on personal-stereo headphones. And the price of success is to reach the quarter-finals, which begin two weeks after the final group game.

It will be of small consolation to both that their opening matches are against relatively out-of-form opposition (Chelsea take on Marseille in France tomorrow and United entertain Bordeaux the following evening); for on Saturday the first effects of this exhausting schedule were detected, in the distracted displays of Chelsea in overcoming Watford and United in drawing at Wimbledon.

This is unusual for Sir Alex Ferguson's team. United's domestic form held up surprisingly well while they qualified from their first-phase group late last year. But even Ferguson's seasoned campaigners are entering uncharted waters with this extra, expanded phase.

The effects on Chelsea of trying to perform twice a week were more worrying. While Gianluca Vialli's team impressed everyone in those earlier European matches, during two months of playing twice a week they picked up just 11 Premiership points from a possible 33 and slipped to 10th in the table.

Since returning to a once- a-week schedule they have gone 13 matches unbeaten, reached the FA Cup semi-final and climbed up to fifth in the league. So it must be with some trepidation that Chelsea climb back aboard the European treadmill, aware no doubt of the irony that their Premiership target of finishing in a Champions League place could be scuppered by their participation in that very tournament.

The intense demands of twice-a-week football could also, of course, have a lasting effect on United's hopes of retaining the title. Ferguson has already hinted that his impressive squad resources will be utilised against Bordeaux.

But there is another concern about this growing continental drift: that the clubs and Uefa are not listening to the customers, the very people who are helping finance this expansion via their increased use of the turnstile and television set.

Domestic rivalry tends to burn much brighter in the hearts of supporters than international enmities, no matter the scope for xenophobia. One could bet that United fans would rather not play Bordeaux if it increased their chances of beating Liverpool on Saturday. For their part Chelsea supporters would no doubt forego a game against foreign opposition if it helped their team put one over on, say, Spurs or Leeds.

The powers that be should take all this into consideration. But given that the money does the talking here, they almost certainly will not. Instead, the top clubs will grow richer and the top players will grow tired. And, if we are not careful, the supporters will become indifferent.

fields.headline: Wallace leads the rampage
fields.trailText: Dundee 1 - 7 Rangers
fields.body:
Rangers last night won the kind of game that gives professional football a bad name. They conquered so easily at Dundee that it should attract the attention of those agencies specialising in people in distress. Mercifully, Steven Tweed's late own-goal in the second half was all they added after creating mayhem in the first. But it still made the total seven; far too many.

They wasted no time in getting started. Dundee, whose league position is increasingly perilous, could have done without losing a goal inside 75 seconds. But far worse was to happen before the end of the half because, by the time they reached the sanctuary of the dressing room, they were 6-1 down after suffering the kind of humiliation that tends to cost managers their jobs.

Rod Wallace had claimed a hat-trick and his team-mates had added three more. Those who believe that Rangers should go off and play somewhere else will feel vindicated.

In fairness, most of the goals were memorable. The first, scored after a through-ball from Giovanni van Bronckhorst, was slipped into the net by Wallace, shrugging off a tackle by Tweed.

There were then 20 minutes to wait until the second arrived from an Andrei Kanchel skis corner that Tony Vidmar headed home with the defence unable to match his leap.

Rangers had already done enough to claim the points but there was a glimmer of hope for Dundee when they pulled a goal back in the 27th minute. Willie Falconer headed back a corner for Tweed to finish.

But, four goals in 15 minutes transformed the match and underlined the gap between the haves and the have-nots that blights the Scottish Premier League.

First, Rozental fashioned a move involving Van Bronckhorst to place the ball in front of Wallace for a third goal. A couple of minutes later, Stephan Klos simply kicked the ball 80 yards to allow the same striker to flick the ball over the head of Rab Douglas, who seemed to be as disillusioned as his own supporters.

All this time, Jörg Albertz had been practising his thunderballs and in the 38th minute he struck one from the outside the penalty area to give Rangers a fifth that they hardly needed.

But there was a genuine sense of occasion in the 45th minute when Wallace held up the ball to allow Rozental to score with a simple shot on his first start after returning to the club following a two-year fight against serious injury.

webTitle: Roving Robinson finds time to score

fields.headline: Roving Robinson finds time to score
fields.trailText: Charlton 1 - 0 Sheff United
fields.body:
John Robinson must be wondering whether he is coming or going. Nine days ago he was in Bolton where he missed the chance that would have kept Charlton in the FA Cup. On Wednesday night it was Doha, scoring the only goal for Wales against Qatar.

On Saturday it was south-east London and the only goal again, to help Charlton extend their lead at the top to the current seven points. His priority now is not so much the title as a few nights with his feet up.

"I got back early Thursday about eight o'clock," he said. "We had been up since half nine the night before and they're three hours ahead so I've been waking up at a ridiculous time each morning. The main benefit was we weren't away today because there would have been a lot more travelling." Oh, the glamour of a professional footballer's life.

By the 90th minute, when he was substituted and left the field to a standing ovation, Robinson looked completely shattered - but then so did most of his team-mates. Charlton were made to battle from first to last by a resurgent Sheffield United who had lost only one of their 12 league games under Neil Warnock.

At times the intensity was too much for Warnock, who thought Robinson should have been sent off when he fended off Michael Brown in the 60th minute and the United player went down clutching his face. "I didn't really catch him. There's no way in a million years I'd go out to elbow anyone, and even Browny said I didn't catch him, hardly," said Robinson.

The Welshman had scored by then, an astute volley at the back post two minutes into the second half, and Charlton were on the way to a 10th consecutive league victory.

"I don't care what league you're in, that's a fantastic record but we know it can turn round in two matches," Robinson said. "We know what we've got to do and we'll just keep plugging along. The pressure's on the other sides because they're playing catch-up."

"We said today, 'Let's come and have a look at the best side in the league and see how far we've got to go'," said Warnock. "We've learned a lot from Charlton if we want to get to the very top. They're head and shoulders the best side in the division."

webTitle: Rae lands himself up to the elbows in trouble

fields.headline: Rae lands himself up to the elbows in trouble
fields.trailText: Sunderland 1 - 1 Derby
fields.byline: David Hopps at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
The first consequence of the post-match brawl between Alex Rae and Darryl Powell should be compulsory hearing tests. When two gruffly spoken managers try to rouse their struggling sides, anyone could mistakenly imagine that the cry had gone out for a fight at the end of the tunnel.

The next consequence should be more severe. If referees cannot maintain order - and ever since Andy d'Urso's pusillanimous retreat from Manchester United's pack that impression is unavoidable - then the Football Association must impose discipline as best it can. The FA has already said it will examine video evidence.

Earlier Rae had wildly elbowed Powell in the face and the referee Alan Wiley missed the obvious. When Powell recovered, three team-mates and the physio stopped him striding off in retribution. Rae, with the warped mentality of a second-rate enforcer, hung around not to apologise but to foul-mouth him.

Powell had 20 minutes - 25 if you count stoppage time - to compose himself. Wiley, perhaps suspecting his blunder, beseeched him at length not to retaliate. One mistimed challenge on Rae minutes later was kindly exonerated.

For Powell then to confront Rae in the tunnel provided further evidence that Premiership egos are out of control. Powell was dragged away by stewards and Derby teammates. If Derby's manager Jim Smith is not seriously considering stripping Powell of the Derby captaincy, he should be.

"I heard some noise in the tunnel," Smith said. "When I came out my players were dragging Darryl Powell into the dressing room."

Sunderland's manager Peter Reid also impressed for his honesty. "I have spoken to Alex about the elbow and he will be dealt with internally," he said. "It has happened to some of my players ... It is up to all of us to stamp this kind of thing out."

The match itself was largely displeasing. Derby benefited from Malcolm Christie's effervescence after half-time and he deservedly put them ahead. Rae equalised two minutes later, squeezing Michael Gray's cross in at the near post. Boos rang out on the whistle.

webTitle: New Yorke doubt as Giggs steals the show

fields.headline: New Yorke doubt as Giggs steals the show
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 2 - 2 Man United
fields.body:
For the second time in two weeks a row threatens to undermine United's build-up to one of their most important Premiership games of the season.

After the pre-Leeds dust-up involving David Beckham, United's chances of winning next Saturday's crucial meeting with Liverpool are being hampered by a row over Dwight Yorke.

On Saturday Sir Alex Ferguson said he was expecting the striker's return from Gold Cup duty with Trinidad and Tobago today, perhaps to face Bordeaux in the Champions League on Wednesday but definitely to play against Liverpool, who are looking to cut their gap with United to seven points.

But now Trinidad and Tobago have asked United to release Yorke to play in a World Cup qualifier against the Dutch Antilles on the same day. If Ferguson refuses, Trinidad and Tobago could make Fifa force the player's release.

It is just another problem United's manager could do without after watching his team put in a stuttering performance that encouraged only Gérard Houllier.

In the absence of Yorke, plus the suspended Roy Keane and Paul Scholes, the Premiership leaders twice had to come from behind to take a point, while feeling grateful that second-placed Leeds could only draw at Middlesbrough.

Sam Hammam may have sold up at Wimbledon but their players have not sold out. For here was a fighting performance in the best underdog tradition of the Crazy Gang, even if their goalkeeper Neil Sullivan was forced to rescue them with a series of excellent saves.

For the second time in four days Beckham was taken off the right wing and handed the central midfield role he reportedly covets but which he has yet to pull off.

As it turned out, the star of United's show was the pin-up Beckham replaced, Ryan Giggs. Before Becks-mania swept the land, it was the Welshman's new car, love life and fashion sense that the media doted on. But Giggs got left in the wings - forgotten by the papers and left to plough a private furrow up and down the left flank.

On Saturday's evidence, however, he is once again in touch with the higher levels of skill and confidence that catapulted him to fame in the first place and resurfaced briefly with that one-man goal in last season's FA Cup semi-final replay against Arsenal.

The contrast in Ferguson's post-match appraisal of the two players said it all. On Giggs: "Ryan is in great form at the moment. He was just marvellous today." On Beckham: "David did all right, fine."

Giggs set up both goals as United hauled themselves back into the game after Wimbledon took a first-minute lead when the impressive Andreas Lund set up Jason Euell for a soft shot past Mark Bosnich.

United equalised on the half-hour when a delicious Giggs pass picked out Jordi Cruyff's clever run and the Dutchman finished impeccably.

Wimbledon restored their lead on 62 minutes, capitalising on a series of errors before Carl Cort headed in.

But when, 10 minutes from time, Beckham cleared a Wimbledon corner, Giggs embarked on a speedy run the length of the pitch before cleverly setting up Andy Cole for his 19th goal of the season.

fields.headline: Mowbray stars at both ends
fields.trailText: Birmingham City 1 - 1 Ipswich Town
fields.body:
Two of the division's most in-form teams were unable to separate themselves here yesterday but this was no stalemate.

An Ipswich side comfortable on the ball and rich in ability to make it do the work was counterbalanced by some skilful and resolute defending from an unfamiliar City back three to provide an intriguing contest.

That the City manager Trevor Francis should abandon his customary 4-4-2 formation to go like-for-like with Town's 3-5-2 line-up shows how highly he regards George Burley's team.

He did the same last season and was rewarded by a 1-0 victory. This time, though, he was happy with a draw. In contrast, some City supporters will not be.

They felt victory would put the Blues firmly in the hunt for an automatic promotion place rather than a play-off one. But Francis was quick to correct them. "We're still on course for an automatic place," he said. "That is, if Charlton, Ipswich and Manchester City each lose 10 games.

"An automatic place was not on even if we had won. As it is I'm very pleased my team has drawn with a very good side. The point has lifted us up to fifth place and the teams I'm concerned about are the ones near or below us: Huddersfield, Wolves, Fulham and Blackburn. To be in fifth place after the illness and injuries we've had to deal with is a fantastic achievement."

Yet for almost half-an-hour Blues were on course to close the gap on their Suffolk rivals to seven points. Ipswich's veteran defender Tony Mowbray proved an unlikely City hero when his diving header, worthy of the best striker, diverted Simon Charlton's cross past a helpless Richard Wright.

Jamie Clapham's searing left-foot drive from distance threatened to restore parity but the ball rebounded to safety off Ian Bennett's right-hand post.

However, with seconds of the half remaining Ipswich scored the goal their enterprise deserved when Mowbray, atoning for his earlier blunder, headed Wayne Brown's free-kick across goal for David Johnson to volley home.

Town felt they should have had a penalty when David Holdsworth appeared to foul Marcus Stewart after the break. Had he been penalised it would have spoiled a fine display but the appeal was turned down.

It should not have mattered as Johnson had a golden chance to give Ipswich victory six minutes from time. Set up by a pinpoint rightwing cross from John McGreal, Johnson's header packed power but lacked direction, leaving them with only a point.

"The thought of coming away with a point before kick-off would have been a disaster," Burley said. "But with hindsight this is always a diffi cult place to come to and, even though we were well in control by the end, I'm not too disappointed.

"The draw has lifted us into second place and, if we can maintain the consistency that has now seen us go 18 games without defeat, there's no reason we cannot stay there."

fields.headline: Elliott wins a double-header
fields.trailText: Leicester City 2 - 1 Tranmere Rovers
fields.body:
The hard work Leicester City put into their set-pieces won them the Worthington Cup in worthy style yesterday. Matt Elliott headed in twice from Steve Guppy's corners to take the League Cup, in its various guises, to Filbert Street for a third time with a second success in four seasons.

Tranmere Rovers were famous for the three minutes it took Leicester to regain the lead after David Kelly had brought the scores level with just under a quarter-of-an-hour remaining, and they also hit the bar in stoppage-time. The fact that John Aldridge's side rallied so strongly after Clint Hill, one of their centre-backs, had been sent off lent an heroic aura to the Nationwide First Division team's narrow defeat.

This was one of the tournament's more eventful denouements. As well as being the first Wembley cup final to feature a lineswoman, Wendy Thoms, it also saw two referees. The unlucky Alan Wilkie ended his whistling career on a stretcher after pulling a calf muscle shortly before the hour.

His replacement, Phil Richards, produced Hill's red card, the Tranmere player's fourth of the season, within seven minutes of taking over. While there was little doubt about the correctness of the decision, Hill having fouled Emile Heskey to deny the England striker a clear run at goal, it was also true that Heskey had gathered Neil Lennon's pass from an offside decision.

Either way the loss of a man inspired Tranmere to their most effective football of the game. For, while the neatness of their approach, often stemming from the imaginative passes of Alan Mahon, had promised them something in the first 20 minutes, they failed to take the chances on offer.

Leicester took a little time to find a similar rhythm. Eventually, however, their knack of combining some half-decent football from the middle of the Premiership with an ability to mix it inherent in born survivors won them the day.

Elliott, moreover, was a fitting match-winner. He more than anyone has typified the refusal of Martin O'Neill's team to be distracted by events off the field at Filbert Street this season: Balkan wars in the boardroom, a clutch of players and officials facing FA charges on ticket offences from last season's Worthington final and Stan Collymore's way with fire extinguishers.

Bought for a song from Oxford United, Elliott has turned out to be the complete footballer for Leicester, equally at home in defence or attack and a ready-made emergency forward when injuries deprived O'Neill of his first-choice strikers Heskey and Tony Cottee.

Tranmere were as worried by Heskey's speed and aggression as Argentina had been four days earlier and it eventually cost them the services of Hill who, having been cautioned for a foul on Stefan Oakes at the start, might have gone two minutes before half-time after bringing down the England player near the left-hand corner of the penalty area. Yet the partnership of Heskey and Cottee worked only in patches, although a precise centre from Cottee late in the first half merited more than Heskey's wayward header over the bar.

Against that Tranmere, playing with David Kelly as a lone striker who enjoyed only sporadic support from Andy Parkinson, lacked a presence in the goalmouth for much of the match. And the vaunted throw-ins of Dave Challinor, for all their distance, offered little threat to Leicester's tall defenders.

Yet the narrowness of the offside decision which denied Scott Taylor a goal, from Mahon's through-pass just before the quarter-hour, was an indication of how Leicester might be beaten. In the 18th minute Mahon was again the provider as Taylor, this time onside, bore down on Tim Flowers with the defence outwitted. But Taylor shot over the bar and this soon began to appear the pivotal moment.

After 29 minutes, following Guppy's corner, Elliott evaded Challinor to produce a header which struck the underside of the bar, hit Murphy on the way down and bounced over the goalline.

Leicester began to indulge themselves in some fancy patterns, a rare sight. But, when Guppy and Heskey set up Muzzy Izzet with a clear chance 10 minutes into the second half, the midfielder stumbled over the ball and eventually shot wide as a tackle came in. The departure of Hill might have reduced the seriousness of the miss but in the 77th minute Gary Jones nodded down Gareth Roberts's long free-kick and Kelly drove a fine shot past Flowers from a fine angle. The Wirral end of Wembley roared anew but Leicester thrive on these situations. Three minutes later another corner from Guppy found Elliott using his strength to beat Challinor once more and nod the ball down inside the near post.

At the last Taylor headed against the Leicester bar from Kelly's centre - enough to send Tranmere and their followers home with thoughts of what might have been. But Leicester had purged memories of a doleful defeat by Tottenham in last season's final while demonstrating that they could be enterprising as well as merely industrious.

webTitle: Dutch master makes most of leap year

fields.headline: Dutch master makes most of leap year
fields.trailText: Arsenal 3 - 1 Southampton
fields.body:
It was one small leap by Dennis Bergkamp, one giant step for mankind at Highbury. Rising to meet Silvinho's cross in the 36th minute, the Dutchman ended an amazing sequence which suggests Arsenal should ask John Charles whether he has any old boots lying around.

By nodding in the Brazilian's first-time ball, Bergkamp became the first Arsenal player this season to head a goal from open play. The last time a Gunners striker had achieved such a feat was in October 1998. That was also Bergkamp, against Dynamo Kiev. Little danger of headaches here.

"It is a weak point," Arsène Wenger said, surprising given the talent of Marc Overmars and the unerring way Bergkamp took his chance. "It showed how beautiful a goal can be with a good cross and a good header."

The sort of beauty the Arsenal manager sees every morning, presumably. "In training," he replied, "we always have the ball on the ground." Nwankwo Kanu, 6ft 4in, scores with his bonce as regularly as Juninho. His team's three other headed goals this term - by Patrick Vieira and Gilles Grimandi - have come from set pieces.

That figure might have been greater but for the recent absence of Tony Adams. His return after almost two months out was as important to Arsenal's improved performance as Bergkamp's rekindled form. "They're special players," Wenger said. "The team has a better balance as well."

It is a balance of spirit as well as skill. Adams, Wenger explained, gives the side confidence and desire. After two defeats the Frenchman saw this as a test of his players' determination to succeed. There was as much chance of Adams failing that as there was of Sam Hammam booking a holiday to the fjords on Saturday.

"I think the team have missed their captain," Adams insisted. "When he is not out there, standards can sometimes drop... We should be up there challenging the best and being one of the best, not some kind of mid-table team."

Arsenal's relative failure this season has affected their fans, many of whom seemed to think the silent tribute to Sir Stanley Matthews lasted 90 minutes. But with the side approaching full strength a Champions League place looks likely. Kanu did everything but score on his return, Overmars appeared as a substitute and Freddie Ljungberg was lively.

"Obviously we have to look at the Champions League and finish in the top three," Bergkamp said. "But it's very important we show in the next few months what Arsenal will do next season."

Southampton must wish they could look beyond May. They were unlucky that Dean Richards had to limp through the second half because all three substitutes were on. But, after a bright opening, they could have conceded six. Wenger, le professeur, had too much for Glenn Hoddle, his former pupil at Monaco.

It is hard to imagine Southampton going down, with a four-point cushion and a game in hand. They passed neatly at times but had little in the way of a final pass.

Bergkamp showed them how, releasing Ljungberg to open the scoring before heading in No2. Although Richards pulled a goal back with a header from a corner, Ljungberg settled matters with a cross which drifted in after Vieira had failed - surprise, surprise - to get a head to it.

webTitle: City high rollers are given Royle let-off

fields.headline: City high rollers are given Royle let-off
fields.trailText: Man City 1 - 1 Walsall
fields.body:
Walsall probably had more than just the Manchester City fans cursing at the end of 90 minutes, given the number of fixed-odds coupons they ruined with this result.

Apparently there had been only five takers on Inverness Caledonian Thistle triumphing at Celtic Park this month. Those brave enough to back Walsall must have been viewed before kick-off with as much pity as those canny souls. And here likewise, without question, the Black Country side deserved all three points.

At first sight this was a home banker. High-flying City surely had too much class against a side begged, borrowed and scraped together, and with the prospect of putting pressure on Ipswich as the second-placed side prepared to meet Birmingham yesterday, motivation should not have been a problem.

But these favourites were Manchester City, a club who tend to put their supporters through all manner of torture. And that really was the story of this 90 minutes.

Prompted by Mark Kennedy, the home side began brightly. But Walsall grew wise to them and soon caused problems of their own, hitting City on the counter and gaining more possession, so that it came as little surprise when Pedro Matias, picked up for nothing from Macclesfield, defeated the City goalkeeper Nicky Weaver with a deflected shot to give Walsall the lead.

Despite City's double half-time substitutions, Tony Grant for Kevin Horlock and Robert Taylor for Paul Dickov, little changed and it took a controversial 71st-minute goal from Shaun Goater to equalise. And still Weaver needed to produce a last-minute fingertip save from Michalis Vlachos.

The City manager Joe Royle started and ended his post-match musings with an apology. "I felt like booing myself at half-time," he said. "There was not enough perspiration and no inspiration." Fitting, really, given that this was an apology of a performance.

webTitle: Cadete has instant effect on Bradford's survival instincts

fields.headline: Cadete has instant effect on Bradford's survival instincts
fields.trailText: Bradford 1 - 1 Aston Villa
fields.body:
Arrival of new striker stirs optimism in Bradford. Sound familiar? In September Bruno Rodriguez was hailed as the man to save City's season; now it is Jorge Cadete.

Gamble one was a spectacular failure. Rodriguez returned to Paris St-Germain one month into an eight-month loan deal after criticising the club and city. Gamble two must succeed. If the Portuguese can galvanise Bradford's season as he transformed their performance against Aston Villa on Saturday, the manager Paul Jewell will not be humiliated again.

Within seconds of Cadete's entrance on 75 minutes David Wetherall's effort was clawed round a post by Peter Enckelman and from the resulting corner Dean Windass headed home to draw Bradford level. Then, with eight minutes remaining, Cadete rose above Gareth Southgate only for his header to be palmed on to the bar. It was an inspired and inspiring substitution by Jewell.

However, Cadete will be eased in gently. He has not started for Benfica all season but an 18-month spell at Celtic, which yielded 38 goals in 49 appearances and ended in May 1997, will stand him in good stead to cope with the pace of the Premiership.

Motivation ought not to be a problem for the 31-year-old forward either. He hopes to make the Portuguese squad for Euro 2000 and, with England their opening opponents, what better way to enhance his chances of selection than by shining in the Premiership?

Bradford need some illuminating, although they are by no means down and out. Unbeaten at home since mid-October, they are in the relegation zone on goal difference alone. But their return of six points from away games needs to be improved if they are to survive.

John Gregory could teach them a thing or two about that. Villa's pre-Christmas slump heaped pressure on the manager but he now has a place in Europe, be it through the FA Cup or the League, in his sights. Villa have lost only once in 17 games but Gregory is desperate for something to show for his troubles. He is close to signing PSV's Belgian striker Luc Nilis to help the cause.

"We have had some major problems on and off the pitch in the past two years and it has taken a while to get the squad I want together," he said. "I think we're just ahead of schedule at the moment. But I need to win something. Expectations here are high but that's what I want."

Paul Merson's revival has inspired Villa's surge and he gave them a deserved lead on Saturday. They should have been out of sight by half-time. Eventually they were relieved to secure a point after Cadete's timely intervention.

fields.headline: Branch diddles fractious Forest
fields.trailText: So much for sportsmanship as epitomised by Sir Stanley Matthews. Within minutes of a perfectly observed one minute's silence in his memory, the Wolves striker Ade Akinbiyi, a man built like a prize fighter, decided to behave like one. Although his butt that floored Tony Vaughan was more Tysonesque than Marquis of Queensberry, likewise Vaughan's slap in the face that had provoked Akinbiyi was more befitting a boudoir brawl than 12 three-minute rounds
fields.body:
So much for sportsmanship as epitomised by Sir Stanley Matthews. Within minutes of a perfectly observed one minute's silence in his memory, the Wolves striker Ade Akinbiyi, a man built like a prize fighter, decided to behave like one. Although his butt that floored Tony Vaughan was more Tysonesque than Marquis of Queensberry, likewise Vaughan's slap in the face that had provoked Akinbiyi was more befitting a boudoir brawl than 12 three-minute rounds

Nevertheless Steve Lodge had little option but to send both men packing and he brandished five yellow cards - all to Forest - before he signed off the first half with another red one to give David Prutton second use of the soap in the visitors' dressing room. Prutton's exit, after a second caution, meant that for the third time this season Forest finished a game with nine men.

Refreshingly the manager David Platt admitted there was a problem with discipline. "It's something I should have put right and I haven't," he said.

It was also clear he felt the hosts should have redressed the balance after Michael Branch scored the third goal having intercepted Dave Beasant's weakly hit attempt to find touch so that an injured Wolves player could receive treatment.

But whereas the Wolves manager Colin Lee was forthright in his condemnation of Akinbiyi's conduct and vehement in his defence of Branch, he seemed to have been less forceful in getting the message across amid the furore provoked by Branch's goal.

"We tried to speak to the referee and the fourth official about giving a goal back," he said.

Yet although the players in this game appeared happy to take the law into their own hands to settle scores, Wolves were not prepared to do just that to right a wrong. They were three goals to the good, courtesy of Branch's controversial strike and less contentious ones from Ludo Pollet and Darren Bazeley, so what would it have cost them? More importantly, Sir Stanley would definitely have approved.

webTitle: Ten man Juventus keep their bearings at the top

fields.headline: Ten man Juventus keep their bearings at the top
fields.trailText: Juventus maintained their advantage over Lazio at the top of the Campionato after beating Roma at the Stadio Delle Alpi 2-1 last night.
fields.body:
Juventus maintained their advantage over Lazio at the top of the Campionato after beating Roma at the Stadio Delle Alpi 2-1 last night.

Carlo Ancelotti's side took an early lead through an Edgar Davids volley from outside the box but Marco Delvecchio cancelled that out with a delightful off-balance touch which diverted Vicenzo Montella's angled lob across the face of the goal past hapless Juve keeper Edwin Van der Sar.

Reduced to ten men for the best part of the match, after Paolo Montero was sent off midway through the first half for diverting the ball with his hand while Francesco Totti was running away with the goal at his mercy, Juventus held their nerve and ground out a terrific result. Roma who await Leeds on Thursday for the first leg of their Uefa Cup tie failed to capitalise on their numerical advantage

They were dealt an early blow right at the start of the second half when goalkeeper Francesco Antognioli misjudged Alessandro Birindeli's cross after a deflection on Aldair. The ball bounced just off the line but Pipo Inzaghi was there to tap it in to a rapturous welcome from the Siniora's bench who leapt in the air as one. Inzaghi and Alex Del Piero had chances to put the match beyond Roma's reach but a late flourish for the visitors saw Vicenzo Montella miss a great chance when he dwelt on the ball with only Van der Sar to beat.

Fabio Capello must surely have conceded any title hopes for Roma as they are now eight points behind pace setters Juve.

Lazio beat Udinese 2-1 on Saturday and kept in touch with Juve but are still four points behind the leaders in second place. Paolo Negro and Marcello Salas had given them a firm grip on the proceedings before Thomas Locatelli grabbed a late consolation for the visitors at the Stadio Olympico.

Milan lost ground on Juventus when they were held 0-0 at struggling Cagliari. A victory in Sardinia would have carried the defending champions on to 47 points, level with Juventus. But after a bright opening 25 minutes Milan's attacking threat fizzled out and Alberto Zaccheroni's side were fortunate to escape with a point.

Milan failed to produce a shot on goal in the second half whereas Cagliari, motivated by the midfield pairing of the Uruguayan Fabian O'Neill and Tiziano De Patre, created 10 clear chances over the 90 minutes. The draw left Milan third, two points behind Juve and one behind Lazio, who beat Udinese 2-1 on Saturday.

Internazionale went to fourth, a point ahead of Leeds's Uefa Cup opponents Roma, after their comfortable 3-0 victory over Venezia, although their striker Christian Vieri limped off after apparently pulling a thigh muscle.

Reggina continued their admirable first season in Serie A with a 2-1 win over Lecce. Torino drew 1-1 at Bari to remain above the relegation zone, and the games between Bologna and Piacenza and Perugia and Verona ended goalless.

Fiorentina shocked the Parma faithful on Saturday pulling off a major upset by crashing Alberto Malesani's side 4-0. Only last week the Viola had lost to Roma by the same scoreline but they came back with a vengeance at Parma's Ennio Tardini stadium. Abel Balbo's first half strike was soon followed a Rui Costa brace and Predrag Mijiatovic rounded off late one.

webTitle: Shearer's parting shot hits the mark

fields.headline: Shearer's parting shot hits the mark
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 0 - 2 Newcastle
fields.body:
Alan Shearer's timing was immaculate. Three minutes from the end of the game that prefaced his "big announcement", he scored a goal that in years to come will remind Kevin Keegan and England's supporters what they are missing. According to the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson, Shearer's control of a Robert Lee pass and low shot beyond Pavel Srnicek were "the hallmark of a great finisher".

Such a familiar Shearer epithet will, from July, be heard no longer in the national context, in order that he may give Newcastle his best for the rest of his playing days. Despite not even turning 30 until August, he will be at home with the kids when England begin their qualifying route to the 2002 World Cup.

"I want everyone to understand I am not walking away from a challenge; I am hugely patriotic and my time as England captain has made me incredibly proud," he said. "However, I realise if I want to give Newcastle value for money in the remaining four years of my contract, I need to pace myself a bit more than I am able to do at the moment.

"I would like to play, if selected, in Euro 2000 and then bow out so that the manager has time to plan effectively for the 2002 World Cup. I am not saying I would never play for England again; if there was an injury crisis or real need for me to help out, I would always be honoured to answer the call.

"However, football is about planning for the future and hopefully my decision today will help England become even more successful in the coming years."

For Keegan, the England coach who made true the dreams of the Tyneside community with his £15m signing of Shearer while in charge at St James' Park, it is a major and unexpected blow. A "very sad" Keegan said that he had tried to change his captain's mind but that "everyone should respect his decision; I certainly do.

"What makes Alan Shearer special is that he is his own man," Keegan added. "I'm happy for him because it's what he wants. His England career speaks for itself; a total of 28 goals in 57 games for his country has been a tremendous achievement and, who knows, the best could yet be to come at Euro 2000."

Shearer spoke to both Keegan and Robson before making the announcement. "In my opinion he could have gone on at international level for perhaps another two seasons," Robson said, "but he wants to come out of it at the very top when people remember him as a great international player, and I applaud him for that."

Other observers suggested different influencing factors. "I don't think there's been a top-class striker with his record who has had so many doubters," said the television pundit Alan Hansen. "Once your own supporters - and I'm talking about England supporters - start doubting you then you've got a problem. He's looked at that and thought, 'I'm going to go at the top'."

At Hillsborough on Saturday night all the words came from Newcastle, Wednesday's manager Danny Wilson declining to perform for the media after recent newspaper stories. Or perhaps he did not want to risk further embarrassment from the Wednesday press steward who introduced the Newcastle manager as "Bryan Robson".

This slip of the tongue was symptomatic of the Wednesday malaise: on and off the field they cannot help putting their foot in it.

A minute after Peter Atherton's error had gifted Kevin Gallacher the chance to nudge Newcastle ahead, Gerald Sibon faced an open goal but shot so tamely that Shay Given was able to reach up and palm the ball away off the bar. Atherton later miskicked in front of his goalkeeper; Des Walker fell over and almost let in Kieron Dyer.

It was sad to see Wednesday fumbling in the dark as their Premiership life ebbed away. Shearer, naturally, was conviction itself as he drilled home the second goal.

fields.headline: Harley motors into contention
fields.trailText: Fast, direct and executed by an Englishman: it was a goal that Graham Taylor had to admire even if it was a devastating counter-blow to the heart of a Watford side still pumping with pride and energy.
fields.body:
Fast, direct and executed by an Englishman: it was a goal that Graham Taylor had to admire even if it was a devastating counter-blow to the heart of a Watford side still pumping with pride and energy.

Both Chelsea goals came from the Taylor manual rather than the Gianluca Vialli version but the unconvincing hosts were grateful for any return on their labours. Chelsea had done little to suggest the classic counter-attack and Jon Harley's imperious headed winner, a passage of excellence they may need to match against Marseille tomorrow night.

The reward for 20-year-old Harley, who has so impressively exploited injury to Graeme le Saux and the extended absence of Celestine Babayaro, could be a first start in the Champions League in the Stade Vélodrome.

There is much more to Harley's game, though, than the pitch-long sprint that enabled him to score his first Chelsea goal after 65 minutes. The confident Kent youngster, converted from midfield, has shown a composure well beyond his years in adapting to being a left-back in a Premiership team of so many talents.

Already, after only 19 senior appearances, Harley is being touted as the answer to one of England's chronic problems. Vialli lends qualified support to that belief: "He's probably one of the best left-sided offensive players in England. He's got to work on his defensive game but he has not been playing in that position for long. And let's see how the boy responds to more pressure."

Taylor readily acknowledged the quality of Chelsea's winner, even if he saw it as yet another sucker punch, stemming from a Watford corner. Harley's header, high past Alec Chamberlain's left hand, climaxed a superb volleyed pass from Didier Deschamps and Dan Petrescu's inviting cross.

webTitle: Barmby sings again with Hammers off message

fields.headline: Barmby sings again with Hammers off message
fields.trailText: Not only the referee missed Paolo di Canio. So did West Ham, who also had Frank Lampard suspended and a keeper, Sasa Ilic, who arrived as a stopgap on Friday and stopped little. Nick Barmby's first and third goals were gifts.
fields.body:
Not only the referee missed Paolo di Canio. So did West Ham, who also had Frank Lampard suspended and a keeper, Sasa Ilic, who arrived as a stopgap on Friday and stopped little. Nick Barmby's first and third goals were gifts.

If the FA had not banned expressions of satisfaction from referees, Paul Alcock, pushed over last time he met Di Canio, might have punched the air when he received the home team sheet. If the victim support reps had not dispersed when they found they had been brought under false pretences, they might have helped Harry Redknapp and Ilic.

The West Ham manager was sharper than his team: "We were woeful up front, overrun in midfield and defensively all over the place." He added in mitigation: "Nine have been away on international duty; I've not seen 'em all week" - as if they had come back speaking in foreign tongues, their programming scrambled.

Redknapp was harsh about Joe Cole: "He's a little boy with a lot to learn." The rest did not hint at his "outstanding talent". In the first half they had lots of ball but no clue. In the second they lost the ball, too. The attack had clearly been issued with SA80s, so the Everton keeper Thomas Myhre made his own excitement flapping at crosses. In defence the sweeper Rio Ferdinand was strangely right of a back three.

Stuart Pearce, back from a broken leg, was far more comfortable and dynamic on the left. On a day when Sir Stanley Matthews was remembered no one was booked and Pearce and Richard Gough, both 38 in April, seemed bent on showing they could be playing at 50.

Everton, genuinely upset by international action in injury to Francis Jeffers, recognised West Ham were a shambles and did little for the cause of Don Hutchison, dropped for thinking he is worth more than the club do, with an irresistible second-half display. Europe is not beyond them.

Mark Pembridge, back from Qatar with Wales, passed with colours; Joe-Max Moore scored his sixth goal in seven games; and Barmby, at 26, is threatening again to fulfil the talent hailed as outstanding at 18. His second goal was a gem of vision, running and execution.

As Frank Dobson, a West Ham supporter, knows, the answer lies in the rigging. Not even Tony Blair could fix this one for his man.

webTitle: Armstrong seals predictable victory to Beach II

fields.headline: Armstrong seals predictable victory to Beach II
fields.trailText: Coventry 0 - 1 Tottenham
fields.body:
Gordon Strachan had seen this would happen. The Coventry manager had predicted the game would be settled from a set piece and, given that nothing much has gone right for Coventry lately, he feared that his team would be the one to concede it. "I knew what was coming," he said.

But the goal was still something of a surprise, because it was Tottenham's first for nearly seven hours and because Coventry were undone by the most basic of lapses, but mostly because the scorer was Chris Armstrong.

Darren Anderton swung a corner over and there was Armstrong running into the space in the Coventry area that Colin Hendry has been bought to command. Magnus Hedman somehow allowed the ball to squirm under him.

It was Armstrong's sixth goal this season and maybe his last for the club. He appears to have been written off by manager and fans, his confidence is low and Les Ferdinand and Steffen Iversen are almost ready to resume. And George Graham is looking for a new striker.

"I think the defence is good," the Spurs manager said. "Midfield is OK." The attack is much more of a worry. "We can't score."

Strachan should be so lucky. This week he is taking the squad to La Manga, where the fire-extinguishing arrangements will be the least of his worries. The club have booked 20 places, but cannot fill them. When Noel Whelan limped off he became the club's 11th injured first-team player.

They still have a superabundance of playmakers, but even the pitch has turned against them. Strachan described it as "sandy, bobbly, horrible... you have to play the percentages. Turn them, chase them, wait for the first mistake. We were warned and we didn't take heed."

When the pitch is a beach and midfield is a minefield, trust Graham to deliver. "I knew it wasn't going to be a classic," he said. And that's how he likes it: 1-0 to the Tottenham.

fields.headline: Anelka proves the Real deal
fields.standfirst:
Real Madrid 3 - 0 Barcelona 0
Roberto Carlos 5, Anelka 23, Morientes 53
fields.trailText: Nicolas Anelka got off the mark for Real Madrid at last when he pounced on a rebound from the Barcelona keeper Francesc Arnau. The £22m Frenchman was roundly applauded by the 80,000 fans present when substituted 10 minutes before the end.
fields.body:
Nicolas Anelka got off the mark for Real Madrid at last when he pounced on a rebound from the Barcelona keeper Francesc Arnau. The £22m Frenchman was roundly applauded by the 80,000 fans present when substituted 10 minutes before the end.

Real's crushing victory over Barcelona in the Bernabeu stadium saw them overtake the Catalans for the first time this season and put them six points behind the leaders Deportivo La Coruna. Deportivo, who play Arsenal at Highbury in the Uefa Cup on Thursday, beat Real Mallorca 2-1 at home.

Barca recovered briefly from a chaotic start and upped the pace towards the end of the first half - a free-kick from Rivaldo grazed a post - but when Fernando Morientes slammed in a third in the 53rd minute the Catalans simply gave up the ghost.

After Real's poorest start to the season since 1973 forced them to sack their coach John Toshack in November, they are understandably euphoric at this turn-around in fortunes - and secretly amazed. The caretaker coach Vicente del Bosque has taken the side from being dangerously close to the relegation zone to beating their arch-rivals Barcelona for the first time since 1996, all in the space of three months.

The Barcelona coach Louis van Gaal blamed everything from his players to the referee but insisted that his playing strategy could not be faulted.

"My system makes no mistakes: the players follow it or they don't," the daily El Pais quoted him as saying.

He insisted that the first two goals were down to refereeing mistakes. He then blamed his goalkeeper for "not stopping [Roberto Carlos's] free-kick" and his players for clamouring for handball before the second goal while the ball was in play.

webTitle: Agreement in tatters, Adams tells Sinn Fein

fields.headline: Agreement in tatters, Adams tells Sinn Fein
fields.standfirst:
Republicans looking to build up electoral support

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Gerry Adams issued a clear signal yesterday that there was no prospect of the IRA agreeing to disarm when he warned that the Good Friday agreement was now "in tatters".
fields.body:
Gerry Adams issued a clear signal yesterday that there was no prospect of the IRA agreeing to disarm when he warned that the Good Friday agreement was now "in tatters".

At a special conference in Dublin, Mr Adams said that republicans were looking to a new phase in which they would build up their electoral support to make it easier to resist unionist demands.

"If the Good Friday agreement is lost because the British government caved into unionist demands, one thing is certain," the Sinn Fein president said. "At some point in the future, a new agreement will be negotiated.

"We have to ensure that Sinn Fein is there in a better position to negotiate a better agreement than the one which is now in tatters."

Mr Adams told a Sinn Fein conference in Dublin it was the "comparative weakness" of nationalists against the strength of unionism that allowed Peter Mandelson to suspend the new political institutions in Belfast two weeks ago.

"We should also recall that during the negotiations leading to the Good Friday agreement, that if Sinn Fein had been a stronger player, the progressive elements of that agreement would have been much stronger," he said.

Mr Adams' remarks made clear that the Sinn Fein leadership has lost any hope of reviving the Good Friday agreement on the government's terms.

Peter Mandelson, who reimposed direct rule earlier this month, has made clear that he will only reverse his decision if the IRA give a clear commitment that it will begin to disarm.

Mr Adams made clear that this was an impossible demand. "If the British government, with all of its military firepower and muscle, could not get an IRA surrender in 30 years of war, then unionist leaders or British ministers cannot expect a Sinn Fein leadership to do it for them," he said.

The current political vacuum must be closed, Mr Adams warned.

"Otherwise, there is the possibility that all of the good work of recent years could be frittered away."

Mr Mandelson attempted to take heart from Mr Adams' speech, saying that he was glad to hear the Sinn Fein leadership reiterate its commitment to the political path.

"I'm glad that the republican movement is concentrating on electoral politics and not the use of guns," he said.

But the Northern Ireland secretary insisted that demands for weapons to be put beyond use had to be met.

"I want Sinn Fein to come back to the table, talk with their partners in the process and find a way forward," Mr Mandelson said.

Ken Maginnis, the Ulster Unionist security spokesman, underlined the gulf between his party and Sinn Fein when he reiterated his demand for decommissioning. But he also called on the Irish government and the SDLP to do more to achieve disarmament.

"That is the first area where defining decisions have to be made and it is on that basis the UUP believes it will be able to do business," he said.

Mr Maginnis also deplored Sinn Fein's call for a return to street protests.

"It is designed to manipulate, in a callous way, all those who have genuine republican aspirations and is the antithesis of what Ulster Unionists, the SDLP and the two governments have worked to achieve," he said.

webTitle: Britain donates £2.2m aid as Mozambique flood waters rise

fields.headline: Britain donates £2.2m aid as Mozambique flood waters rise
fields.standfirst: More about the floods in Mozambique
fields.trailText: The British government today announced a £500,000 aid package for Mozambique as the country's water department warned that the flooding which has left thousands of people stranded would get worse in the next few days.
fields.body:
The British government today announced a £500,000 aid package for Mozambique as the country's water department warned that the flooding which has left thousands of people stranded would get worse in the next few days.

With the Limpopo river continuing to rise, just five helicopters continued to try to save as many people as possible stuck in trees and on rooftops in southern and central Mozambique.

On Sunday, a 2m high wall of water submerged Chokwe, a town of 40,000 people about 125 miles north of the capital Maputo. On Monday, villages 25 miles farther downstream flooded, said Michele Quintaglie, spokeswoman for the UN world food programme.

"There will be thousands of people left behind tonight. These people will be on their own to get through the night," Ms Quintaglie said, adding that it appeared many of the thousands left in the Chokwe area overnight had survived.

The five rescue helicopters currently deployed are not able to rescue people in all the flooded areas. One helicopter crew member described how a woman threw her baby at a full helicopter as it lifted off. He caught the child by its arm, saving it from certain death, but it was unclear whether its mother survived.

Around 200 deaths have been confirmed as a result of the flooding so far, but officials believe the final toll is likely to be far higher.

In a statement to the House of Commons this afternoon, international development secretary Clare Short confirmed the new £500,000 package and said that British aid for the stricken region now totalled £2.2 million.

The financial support is being channelled through the UN, Unicef, Oxfam and other charities. Ms Short also confirmed that two humanitarian specialists had been sent to the region to help co-ordinate the aid effort.

"We stand by ready to provide further assistance," she said.

The German, Dutch and Norwegian governments also pledged to donate unspecified amounts to the rescue effort.

The swollen Limpopo river will continue to rise in the nearest days, Mozambique's water department said. The Save river was also expected to continue rising.

A World Food Programme report said 55,000 people needed to be evacuated from the southern Gaza province and 30,000 from the Save river valley.

The national disaster management centre said the situation was critical at Xai-Xai, the capital of Gaza, downstream from Chokwe. Roads on both sides of the town of about 130,000 people have been washed away, and it has run out of fuel and has no power.

Meanwhile, more water was heading downstream into Mozambique's Cahora Bassa Dam from its western neighbour, Zimbabwe, which released billions of gallons from its overflowing Kariba Dam yesterday. The Mozambican water department said this did not pose an immediate threat.

In Zimbabwe, which has also been hit by tropical storms, president Robert Mugabe came under attack for concentrating resources on the Congo war instead of deploying adequate troops and helicopters to help rescue victims of a tropical cyclone.

The opposition and official sources in the civil protection division said the government's disaster management programme has been hit seriously by a severe shortage of fuel and helicopters.

The civil protection division said helicopters were still trying to rescue hundreds of people marooned in Manicaland and Chiredzi on the border with Mozambique.

"We have one helicopter [in our area] where we could have done with 10," said one source. "...it's fairly obvious the planes are... in the Congo. Otherwise there is no reason why they would not have been permissioned for such an important task."

fields.headline: Pet passports
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about travelling pets on the net...
fields.trailText: 1. Dogs made history today when they entered Britain with passports.
fields.body:
1. Dogs made history today when they entered Britain with passports.

2. Five-year-old pug Frodo Baggins (pictured) was the first pet from France to legally rest his paws at the foot of the white cliffs of Dover for over a century.

3. Under the new travel plans cats and dogs win passports if they are microchipped (for identification), blood tested, vaccinated against rabies and frisked for ticks.

4. Until today, the alternative was an unpopular six months in quarantine.

5. It's still not free rein for our four-legged friends: pets are restricted to 25 countries until the pilot scheme ends and can only travel on a handful of routes.

6. When the pilot ends rodents such as guinea pigs, rabbits, mice and rats will be accepted. Who knows how the burghers of Dover will react?

7. Animals have been coming to these islands for thousands of years - the rabbit was introduced by the Norman French after 1066.

8. 8000 years ago the two sides of the channel were linked by a land bridge, which is why Britain does not have a distinct island ecology.

9. And then there are always the bats - rabies-carrying specimens have been found on this side of the sea.

10. Dogs are good swimmers but regular travellers may wish to invest in a life jacket.

webTitle: Reindeer Games misses season of goodwill

fields.headline: Reindeer Games misses season of goodwill
fields.trailText: American box-office charts put Ben Affleck's belated new thriller at number three
fields.body:
Ben Affleck's new film Reindeer Games definitely seems to have missed the season of goodwill. Despite featuring an explicit cabin romp between the Hollywood hunk and ex-supermodel Charlize Theron, the high-energy Christmas crime caper, directed by veteran director, John Frankenheimer, has failed to woo both audiences and critics.

The noir-style thriller was originally scheduled for a Christmas Day release but because the holiday field was too crowded the distributor, Dimension Films, decided to pull it. No doubt it has been ruing the decision ever since. It briefly retitled the film, Deceptions but the impetus was lost and, despite the hype, the absence of strong critical reviews placed the film at number three in this weekend's American box office chart. Peter Howell in the Toronto Star called the film, "Ho. Ho. Hokum," while "distressingly unfunny," was the verdict of Jack Mathews in the New York Daily News, and Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times suggested, "just a nudge, and the movie would fall over into self-parody, and maybe work better."

It was up to the slightly less glamorous partnership of Bruce Willis and Matthew Perry to deliver the presents. Their mob farce, The Whole Nine Yards retained its position at the top of the box office tree for the second weekend in a row. In second place was Snow Day, a pre-teen comedy about a group of kids who sabotage a snow plow to make sure their high school remains closed.

Claiming the final two spots in the top five were Meg Ryan's latest offering Hanging Up at number 4, and the sci-fi thriller Pitch Black at number 5. The The Tigger Movie bounced in at number six, with Michael Douglas's Wonder Boys just behind at number seven. Bringing up the rear was Scream 3 at number eight, and Oscar hopefuls American Beauty and The Cider House Rules at number nine and ten respectively.

webTitle: Time to voyage on the three Cs

fields.headline: Time to voyage on the three Cs
fields.trailText: There is a new holy trinity for the new millennium - a new mantra on every aspirant cyber squillionaire's lips. In order to succeed, you have to rise early and chant it for several hours. Let's practice. Repeat after me: "Content, community, commerce; content, community, commerce . . . "
fields.byline: Simon Waldman, head of Guardian Unlimited
fields.body:
There is a new holy trinity for the new millennium - a new mantra on every aspirant cyber squillionaire's lips. In order to succeed, you have to rise early and chant it for several hours. Let's practice. Repeat after me: "Content, community, commerce; content, community, commerce . . . "

Get these three working together online and before you know it, you too will be the envy of your friends, family and former colleagues. It has worked for AOL, it has worked for Yahoo!, it has worked for Amazon - so, yes, it's about time you got it to work for you.

Now, although many people are uttering the three Cs as if it was as important and innovative a concept as "E=MC2", the more sceptical among you will have noticed that there is very little that is new about it.

The best of traditional media, whether newspapers, magazines, TV or radio, have after all been based on building communities around content and making money from them - primarily by getting those communities to pay for the content or by selling advertising.

Online we still have the advertising model, but the real difference is that the revenue has shifted from the entrance point (the cover price) to the exit - what people go on to buy from your site.

For example, NME, the paper, costs £1.15 at the news-stand. Inside it, they tell you what music to buy and based on this information, you might go off to Our Price, where you will buy the CD.

If the CD is any good, you will buy another copy of NME and go back to Our Price again and so on until everyone makes money except you - all your money has been spent on CDs.

At NME.com, however, you read for free. But after reading a review and deciding you want to buy the CD, you simply click on the buy it button and, via Yalplay, you buy it and NME takes a slice. The distance between recommendation and retail, between content and commerce has almost disappeared.

The same is true at Amazon - although it comes from the other direction. What was once simply a shop now hires journalists to write reviews of books and CDs - as well as getting users to write their own reviews.

Now, in some ways this is good. There are few things more annoy ing than reading that something is fantastic and then not being able to get your hands on it in the shops. The convenience of reading about it and buying it immediately is an excellent service to readers.

But all this convenience comes at a price. How much can we trust the reviews on a website where success is judged by the number of units sold through it? Where is the editorial independence?

Anyone who can string a sentence together (and a fair few who can't) is currently being chased by various online retailers to provide their "content". One Amazon journalist told me recently their role was to "accentuate the positive", which is a slightly chilling term. That said, their reviews are pretty balanced. Scouring other sites shows considerably less neutrality.

From other sites come reports of journalists lured by the offer of stunning share options and promises of editorial independence only to find themselves beaten up by the commercial team and forced into writing sales puffs.

At the same time, there is a danger that this debate gets a little too precious. It has been standard practice for years in newspapers for readers to be able to buy a book or record that has been reviewed, but few can really suggest that the integrity of those pages have suffered because of it. Much of what is happening on the net is a natural and comfortable extension of this.

And, quite frankly, it is rather naive to work in an e-commerce outlet, plan to earn a fortune from share options and think that you will never be part of actually selling anything. The answer here is not about what journalists are prepared (or forced) to do, but about the trust that is placed in their words by consumers.

What people expect from a review or recommendation depends heavily on context. Consumers expect a certain amount of selling from Amazon but expect a newspaper or, say, the NME to be more selective.

That doesn't mean that Amazon staff are entitled to behave like a bunch of barrow boys flogging bad fruit while a newspaper should refrain from promoting anything for fear of losing its dignity. The difference is much more subtle, and the trick for all involved is about finding the limits.

For many media owners, commercial success on the net will come from some form of e-commerce. If they fail to exploit this to the full, they will find themselves in trouble. But if they push things too far, and betray readers' trust, they will be in even more trouble.

Trust, you see, is the most precious commodity on the net. It is frighteningly difficult to gain, and just as frighteningly easy to lose. And once you have lost it, it is all but impossible to get it back.

webTitle: Theres life in the television dog yet

fields.headline: Theres life in the television dog yet
fields.trailText: In the internet-crazed world we now inhabit, there are still some delightful reminders of old-fashioned television reality. Following a visit to America which has gone dot.com dotty, it was reassuring to come home to the news that television make-over programmes were being blamed for a spate of church paving thefts in Cornwall.
fields.body:
In the internet-crazed world we now inhabit, there are still some delightful reminders of old-fashioned television reality. Following a visit to America which has gone dot.com dotty, it was reassuring to come home to the news that television make-over programmes were being blamed for a spate of church paving thefts in Cornwall.

Borrowing techniques from the media monitoring units of the political parties, the Diocese of Truro said, "Slate slab is very much in demand. It's been featured in five out of 15 programmes we have watched."

Far away from the circus atmosphere of the giant NATPE sales market in New Orleans, which included an appearance by the US pin-up Cindy Margolis, recently awarded the dubious honour of being "the most downloaded woman in the world," this story showed that even in the new world of the web, mainstream television is far from dead.

For years pundits have been predicting the demise of the US networks but the corpses have been displaying disturbing signs of life. After a couple of years of creative barrenness, a raft of popular new programmes led by drama like The West Wing has steadied audience erosion. The power of well-made narrative, something the web cannot match, is exactly why drama has also been at the heart of ITV's success in this country.

Another ITV success story, Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, has, just like here, spearheaded an upsurge in network television. Drawing huge audiences, it has exemplified the pulling power of national television, reaching a scale of audiences other media can only envy.

No doubt American television will try to over-cook Millionaire's goose. Rival networks have rushed out copycat shows, including one aptly titled Greed, as well as the ill-fated Who Wants to Marry a Multi-Millionaire? None the less, the arrival of successful new shows has coincided with a dynamic advertising market.

Ironically, rather than killing off old media, dot.com companies are making traditional television rich via their marketing expenditure. In London, more than 30 start-up web companies now advertise regularly. So far 2000 has been a boom year for commercial TV ad revenue. In the US, network economics are stronger than for the last five years for the same reason.

Even better news came from Zenith Media USA's recent report on how the internet affected primetime US network television. Surprisingly, the viewing in wired-up households was only slightly lower than by non-web users, and ratings for teen shows like Dawson's Creek were over 10% higher in wired homes. Chat rooms have created an electronic school playground for teen programmes.

As Zenith's Helen Katz concluded: "The internet will not kill TV, especially network TV." The word "especially" is a comforting one for all owners of network television on both sides of the Atlantic.

Of course, some caution is necessary. This is a transitional phase, and once they have used network ad time to establish their brands and extract what the Americans call "wallet share" from e-commerce, dot.com companies will grow into dosh.com companies and start to squeeze TV audiences harder.

Yet, as the owners of the "sticky" content which websites need to retain users, traditional media companies - many of which (including Pearson, Reuters, United and BSkyB) have recently announced gigantic, £150m-plus investments in internet services - are well placed for future convergence. Even the Time Warner/AOL merger can be interpreted not as an astonishing victory for a 10-year-old new media company, but old media shrewdly safeguarding its future. All the photos of a confident Steve Case of AOL with an avuncular arm around a nervous-looking Gerald Levin of Time Warner do not tell the full story.

I t was Levin who dominated the announcement press conference. It is Levin who will be chief executive of the new venture. It is Time Warner who will contribute 80% of the joint companies' revenues. It was AOL who desperately needed access to Time Warner's cable pipes for their survival. As US internet guru Michael Wolff put it, "The dog continues to wag the tail".

With a few exceptions, some of the bigger dogs have been slow to see the world changing. Even Rupert Murdoch, with his intuitive sense of the next step, was initially sceptical about the internet. Now they are making up for lost time.

Established media owners with access to both content and cross-promotion have the all-important ability in a fragmenting media economy to bark, bite and wag their tails all at the same time. With German shepherd dogs and French poodles scratching at the door, British broadcasters will have to do exactly that.
