fields.headline: Ulterior motives behind born-again Kenmania
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The years pass, the pariah politician changes his act a little and the media discover he is their kind of man after all. Step forward Ken Livingstone, Red Ken of memories past, erstwhile danger to democracy, scourge of the Tory party, emperor of loony leftism and favoured target of newspapers left and right.
fields.body:
The years pass, the pariah politician changes his act a little and the media discover he is their kind of man after all. Step forward Ken Livingstone, Red Ken of memories past, erstwhile danger to democracy, scourge of the Tory party, emperor of loony leftism and favoured target of newspapers left and right.

Suddenly though, Ken is all the rage with his former tormentors. Any enemy of Tony Blair's is a friend of papers now, and their concern that they might be robbed of Ken playing fast and loose with New Labour as London's mayor has been extraordinary to behold.

The message behind the London Evening Standard's splash headline on Monday could not be more obvious: "Go for it, Ken, says London". At no time during Livingstone's days as Greater London Council leader would he have been granted such a positive endorsement from that paper.

Any poll in his favour would have been buried. This poll result, which did indeed show Livingstone as favourite to win should he stand as mayor, was anything but a fair and impartial report.

The results, said the article, were "bleak" for Blair. But turning to the inside for details of the poll, what did we discover? If Livingstone doesn't stand then Dobson would win the mayoralty by a mile.

The clear implication of the Standard's presentation is: this newspaper wants Ken to run as an independent, not because they want him as mayor, but because they wish to screw Labour.

Standard editor Max Hastings is on record as a Livingstone detractor, but he is playing a cynical political game, and fooling his readers into the bargain. If Livingstone were to win, the paper would attack him mercilessly.

On the same day, two Standard columnists also backed Livingstone. Simon Jenkins - who has shown no love for leftwing politics in the past - thundered: "Stand, Ken - and deliver us from this rotten system." AN Wilson could not contain his delight at the turn of events. "Chaos reigns," he wrote. It's "a big bodyblow to bossyboots Blair".

The Standard was far from alone in its ecstatic greeting for Livingstone's narrow loss. The Daily Mail's Monday front page was headlined: "Red Ken: it was theft". When did that paper ever show such sympathy for a Livingstone defeat?

On Tuesday, the Times latched on to the Standard result too: "Poll beckons Livingstone to take the plunge".

But this joy wasn't confined to rightwing organs. The Daily Express, somewhat maverick, but generally pro-Labour in its present incarnation, devoted its leader to a plea for Livingstone to stand as an independent because "he would do democracy a service".

Its senior columnist, Andrew Marr, who is evidently read fairly regularly by Tony Blair, also offered encouragement to Livingstone. "Let Ken stand," he said, "but let him get beaten." This overlooks the damage that will be done to Labour if he did so.

Similarly, the Independent, having pointed out that "on policy" he was wrong in his GLC days and "mostly wrong now" urged: "It would be right for him to stand as an independent in order to give the voters the chance to make the wrong choice".

Even ITN got caught up in this spirit, if somewhat unwittingly. In its Wednesday evening bulletin, it carried a report which said that Livingstone was not speaking but filmed him all the same, making a call. Livingstone was heard to say that he was inundated with letters (urging him to stand) and therefore needed to take on extra staff to cope.

In other words, the media are pushing with all their might for their old foe to stand.

So what's happening here? Why the conversion? It would appear to be a conjunction of three separate interests, two of which are avowedly political. Mischief-making Tory papers want Livingstone as a candidate, and possibly as mayor, because they hope to foment a split in the Labour party and therefore to undermine Blair.

The liberal papers, with the exception of the Mirror, which has been loyal to Blair, want to give Blair a bloody nose because they believe the electoral college system was fundamentally undemocratic. In mid-term, they feel they can attack Blair's so-called control freakery with impunity.

Politics aside though, we come to the third - and main - reason, which is purely journalistic. With Livingstone out of the race, the "story" vanishes. There will be little interest, in Jenkins's winning phrase, between "an ageing carthorse, Mr Dobson, and an ageing stallion, Steve Norris".

Livingstone is the grit in the oyster. If he stands, papers will have loads of material for the next six weeks and, if he were to win, for years ahead. Imagine the endless headlines with "row", "storm" and "fury"

fields.headline: Consternation, Consecration and Congratulations
fields.trailText: BENCH WARFARE
fields.body:
BENCH WARFARE

'When one's centre-back is sent off for a crazed lunge on the opposition's centre-forward in a major cup final, one is permitted to display a smidgen of emotion. But do remember it is not considered good form to amble over to the opposing bench and start administering slaps.' That sage advice can be found in Granny Fiver's Guide To Modern Wembley Etiquette (published 1923). It's a tome John Aldridge would have done well to read, because after Clint Hill was sent off in yesterday's Worthington Cup final, the Tranmere boss is alleged to have taken to task Leicester substitute Theo Zagorakis, who was sitting on the Foxy bench busy applauding Hill's dismissal. Aldo could face FA censure for his trouble.

Tranny defender Hill was sent packing after sending Emile Heskey crashing to the floor when he was clear on goal. Zagorakis considered the referee's verdict a most pleasant outcome and clapped accordingly, at which point Aldo is alleged to have slapped him one right in front of onlooking FA officials. "We will be awaiting the match official's report before deciding what action - if any - needs to be taken over this matter," said FA automaton Steve Double, carefully positioning a misconduct charge over Aldo's head using a special moral pulley.

Whether Aldo actually did get fisty or not is unclear at present, although a clue to what happened may be found in the following admission. "I wasn't happy with the reaction from Leicester's bench to the sending-off, especially that of one player. fields.headline: Driving miss crazy
fields.standfirst: Lucy Cross  thought she'd found the perfect man - until they went for spin in his car. And the problem wasn't that he drove too fast
fields.trailText: Lucy Cross thought she'd found the perfect man - until they went for spin in his car. And the problem wasn't that he drove too fast
fields.body:
I regard myself a modern woman, a feminist even. I've read all the right books and take strong positions on women's role in society.

I applaud the birth of New Man with his developed sensitivity, his ability to cry and be open about his feelings and his celebration of women's equality. But something happened recently with a guy I started dating which makes me think that all my feminist beliefs aren't worth the tin that my badges are printed on.

Patrick was attractive to me because he had the soul of a poet. He knew all the names of butterflies, cried spontaneously when seeing something beautiful like a flower opening and he could cook really complicated things. But as our relationship progressed I found myself getting a bit stuck on something.

He was all these wonderful things but I felt occasionally that his sensitivity was verging on the little-girlish. I wanted some affirmation of his masculine side and thought that perhaps if we took a trip in his car that speeding along the motorway might allow me to see him in a different light. So I suggested a weekend trip to the country. He thought it would be lovely. "Can we go in your car?" He looked a bit crestfallen. I felt disappointed, and it showed. He looked at his fingernails. "Alright then."

His battered Datsun Sunny wasn't much to look at. I strapped myself in and waited for the tug of acceleration, praying that this would inject a bit of testosterone into our wilting relationship. We stopped and started in the London traffic but finally broke free onto the M40. This was his chance to shine.

We were in the slow lane behind a lorry. I could feel myself leaning forward in my seat. He put his indicator on and did lots of looking but seemed reluctant to overtake. I couldn't speak. It was worse than I imagined. He finally broke out from behind the lorry into the middle lane but once we nudged in front, the car squealing like a pig, he nipped back into the slow lane - tongue poking out a bit with concentration, like a little boy reading a book. Hopeless.

Later that day, sipping beer in a pub by the river, I told him that I just didn't think it was working. He asked for a reason. How could I explain that his inability to own the road, to overtake and win in the motorway competition turned me off? I mumbled something about insurmountable differences and suggested he dropped me at the train station and I'd return to London on public transport.

Shocked by my need for a man who could overtake, I reflected on past relationships and found, to my surprise that I had been in love with several men who couldn't drive at all.

Martin Amis said "Poets don't drive", and my predilection for poets has proved this to be true in many cases. These are the men who shun all responsibilities and take pride in their inability to stay sober enough to even have a driving lesson. Their appeal is in the fact that they have shunned peer pressure and distanced themselves from the key car-buying demographic, finding status in places beyond the material. I find these men as attractive as those who burn across asphalt, busting the rev counter.

So my conclusion is that men who are ambivalent about driving are not attractive to me. And it's not just me.

I did a survey of my girl friends and asked how they would feel if they were on a date with a guy and were stuck in a slow lane behind a lorry and the man driving the car wasn't keen to overtake. One friend said "Urgh. How irritating. I'd wonder what was wrong with him." Another went further and said that she'd get out at the next service station and hitch a lift home. These women would consider themselves feminists but are suffering from this same syndrome as me.

At this point I should confess that I am an ambivalent driver. Technically, I can drive, but put me on a motorway and I freeze. I consider myself pretty able to cope in difficult situations - show me a fuse box, ask me to light a fire or install some software and I can do it. But on the motorway I'm a little girl, squeezing my eyes shut rather than facing oncoming hazards, sticking in the slow lane and blocking people's exits.

If I get stuck behind a horse box I will sit it out until it's time to leave the motorway rather than overtake.

This is an attempt at a Darwinian justification for my (and my friends) attraction to boy racers - that I need a man to do the thing I can't really do. But given that my girl friends are confident drivers I think I would probably just say that women like guys who are into and can handle powerful vehicles.

A few weeks after the trip to the countryside I received an email from Patrick telling me that he'd like to drive across asphalt at a hundred miles an hour with me, naked. Yeah, right.

 Names have been changed to protect the ambivalent driver

fields.headline: Here's how we saved £5,000
fields.standfirst: Everyone knows it's cheaper to buy a new car abroad - but how do you do it?
fields.trailText: Everyone knows it's cheaper to buy a new car abroad - but how do you do it? Martin Whitlock and his family found out
fields.body:
Until this moment I have never owned a brand new car. It always seemed a curious way of tearing up one's money - listening for the thud of the 25% drop in its value as you drove it out of the showroom door.

But when it came to replacing our ageing Volvo, fuel consumption was a driving issue and newness therefore of the essence. We'd been eyeing up the Peugeot 406 diesel; but a recent estate model would be £15,000 or so and an older one wouldn't have the new, ultra-efficient, HDi engine.

Might an import be the answer? A friend of mine had tried. She wanted an Audi A3 but had been told, quite wrongly, that it was unavailable on the continent in right-hand drive. By the time she'd discovered the truth of the matter she had already taken delivery of a UK showroom model.

I was determined to do better and turned for guidance to the EU's car price website. This compares tax-free prices in each member country and gives an index figure for each car. For the Peugeot 406 the index is 128.8% in the UK, compared with 100% in Holland and 115% in Belgium. But the clear winner is Denmark, at 77.8% - or 40% off the UK price.

Not that the Danes themselves are winners. When you add back Danish tax their cars are among the most expensive around. But the rock-bottom manufacturers' prices required to compensate means that every bargain-hunter in Europe is beating a path to their dealers' doors. Jonas, who sold us our car, was far too polite to admit that he was doing us a favour. But he didn't need us the way we needed him. He had been a struggle to find. I started by choosing batch of the larger dealers from the Peugeot Denmark website and faxing our requirements.

Result: silence. I called the Peugeot hotline number given in the EU website, which turned out to be customer services in Coventry. It seemed a cheek to be asking them how to circumvent their own outrageous prices. They were polite, but scarcely chummy and offered me the number of the Peugeot importer in Denmark.

The importer told me to contact a dealer. "But the dealers won't speak to me," I returned.

Then, a week later, came a message containing the phone number of one of the dealers I had already tried. I dialled it anyway, but the salesman who answered was adamant. "We don't do UK cars," he told me. "But," I protested, "the importer said . . ." A muffled conversation at the other end and then, suddenly, I was speaking to Jonas and the way ahead was clear.

But what to order? We had wanted an LX family estate, with optional rear electric windows. The UK price was £17,495 after dealer's discount. But equipment levels vary widely across Europe, and in Denmark we assumed we would be limited to a Danish model, although supplied with imperial speedometer and right-hand drive.

We had spent hours poring over the model details from the Peugeot Denmark web site, guessing at the meaning of the Danish words for such things as vanity mirror and parcel shelf. Eventually we settled on the ST. In practice, Peugeot were not about to build an Anglo-Danish hybrid, so Jonas completed the circle by matching the ST back to a UK model. The equivalent he plumped for was the GTX, two levels up from the LX, list price £20,470.

The order form was on my desk within hours. The price, tax free, was 122,340 krone - a bit over £10,000 at current rates. It included a whopping 10,000 krone for "documentation", but we were pleased to pay. The deposit requested was a reasonable 25%.

With the run-up to Christmas and the millennium we put the car to the back of our minds. Then, in January, the call came. It was four months since we had placed the order.

We had to organise in a hurry. Insurance was a problem. Our broker couldn't find cover that would operate before the car was registered in the UK. So I rang round and got it from Direct Line. The Go website was offering flights to Copenhagen for £40. To get them you had to collect vouchers from a newspaper we didn't read. We had already missed the relevant days; could my brother be relied upon not to have thrown away his back numbers? Fortunately, he could.

Six in the morning on the day of departure. Travelling light, we left the pushchair at home and set out on foot for the station. A bad moment to remind ourselves how slowly the children walk. We missed the train but made it to the check-in at Stansted with six minutes to spare.

In Copenhagen the Tivoli Gardens was closed so we went to the zoo. The next day we called on Jonas. It took him a moment or two to negotiate our bankers' draft, but he had the invoice, temporary Danish registration and the all-important manufacturers' certificate of conformity ready on his desk. We had 24 hours to leave the country.

Only the certificate of conformity bothered us. The left/right- hand drive and metric/imperial speedometer options had not been ticked. Jonas could not read the French and shrugged. We decided to hope for the best.

We drove through the night, entertaining ourselves with the trip computer and the rain-sensitive windscreen wipers while trying to interpret the Danish instruction manual. Despite getting hopelessly lost in Holland we ended up in Dover at nine the next morning, green but triumphant after a choppy crossing, elated to hear the thud of our new car increasing in value as we drove it on to British soil.

Registration was simple, or would have been if the certificate of confor mity had not been rejected. I called Peugeot in Coventry. Our certificate was only valid in certain countries - a case of EU harmonisation that was not quite harmonious. They agreed to issue a new one. Meanwhile an English manual cost £6 from a Peugeot main dealer. No question asked.

Now we are registered and legal, with tax disc and smart new V reg. number plates, awaiting only the last piece in the jigsaw: a bill from customs and excise for 17.5% that will bring the purchase price to about £12,000. Add £500 as the cost of collection and the saving is a clear £5,000 compared with the car we originally wanted; nearer £7,000 compared with the higher specification car we actually drove away.

Checklist

 Start with the EU website at http://europa.eu.int/comm/ dg04/aid/en/car.htm - go from there to the six-monthly price report. If your car isn't featured try the nearest base model. Find the cheapest country for your car. Check the hotline number for the manufacturer in case you get stuck.

 Find the dealers on the car maker's website for your chosen country. There are generally links to these on the manufacturer's main website.

 Telephone if you can - faxes and emails can be ignored.

If it's Holland or Scandinavia, you can assume without arrogance that they will speak English.

 When selecting a model explain that you want the UK equivalent. Non-standard features can affect the second-hand value of the car.

 Don't be frightened because its abroad. Sending a deposit to a large overseas car dealer is less risky that giving it to a dodgy middle-man in the UK.

 Remember to ask for the certificate of conformity and temporary registration, and be sure to get a receipted invoice.

 Take a bank draft when you get the car. Make sure it is insured for the drive home.

 Don't be put off by the paperwork. Get the information pack on importing a vehicle from DVLA (01792 772134). Take the registration and VAT forms it contains to a vehicle registration office with the invoice, certificate of conformity, insurance and a cheque for the tax disc plus a fee of £25. The VAT form will be sent to customs and excise who will send you a bill.

 Once home, the car is not legal until it has a UK tax and plates.

 If there's a problem with the certificate of conformity, contact the manufacturer's UK office.
fields.bodyText: Until this moment I have never owned a brand new car. It always seemed a curious way of tearing up one's money - listening for the thud of the 25% drop in its value as you drove it out of the showroom door. But when it came to replacing our ageing Volvo, fuel consumption was a driving issue and newness therefore of the essence. We'd been eyeing up the Peugeot 406 diesel; but a recent estate model would be £15,000 or so and an older one wouldn't have the new, ultra-efficient, HDi engine. Might an import be the answer? A friend of mine had tried. She wanted an Audi A3 but had been told, quite wrongly, that it was unavailable on the continent in right-hand drive. By the time she'd discovered the truth of the matter she had already taken delivery of a UK showroom model. I was determined to do better and turned for guidance to the EU's car price website. This compares tax-free prices in each member country and gives an index figure for each car. For the Peugeot 406 the index is 128.8% in the UK, compared with 100% in Holland and 115% in Belgium. But the clear winner is Denmark, at 77.8% - or 40% off the UK price. Not that the Danes themselves are winners. When you add back Danish tax their cars are among the most expensive around. But the rock-bottom manufacturers' prices required to compensate means that every bargain-hunter in Europe is beating a path to their dealers' doors. Jonas, who sold us our car, was far too polite to admit that he was doing us a favour. But he didn't need us the way we needed him. He had been a struggle to find. I started by choosing batch of the larger dealers from the Peugeot Denmark website and faxing our requirements. Result: silence. I called the Peugeot hotline number given in the EU website, which turned out to be customer services in Coventry. It seemed a cheek to be asking them how to circumvent their own outrageous prices. They were polite, but scarcely chummy and offered me the number of the Peugeot importer in Denmark. The importer told me to contact a dealer. "But the dealers won't speak to me," I returned. Then, a week later, came a message containing the phone number of one of the dealers I had already tried. I dialled it anyway, but the salesman who answered was adamant. "We don't do UK cars," he told me. "But," I protested, "the importer said . . ." A muffled conversation at the other end and then, suddenly, I was speaking to Jonas and the way ahead was clear. But what to order? We had wanted an LX family estate, with optional rear electric windows. The UK price was £17,495 after dealer's discount. But equipment levels vary widely across Europe, and in Denmark we assumed we would be limited to a Danish model, although supplied with imperial speedometer and right-hand drive. We had spent hours poring over the model details from the Peugeot Denmark web site, guessing at the meaning of the Danish words for such things as vanity mirror and parcel shelf. Eventually we settled on the ST. In practice, Peugeot were not about to build an Anglo-Danish hybrid, so Jonas completed the circle by matching the ST back to a UK model. The equivalent he plumped for was the GTX, two levels up from the LX, list price £20,470. The order form was on my desk within hours. The price, tax free, was 122,340 krone - a bit over £10,000 at current rates. It included a whopping 10,000 krone for "documentation", but we were pleased to pay. The deposit requested was a reasonable 25%. With the run-up to Christmas and the millennium we put the car to the back of our minds. Then, in January, the call came. It was four months since we had placed the order. We had to organise in a hurry. Insurance was a problem. Our broker couldn't find cover that would operate before the car was registered in the UK. So I rang round and got it from Direct Line. The Go website was offering flights to Copenhagen for £40. To get them you had to collect vouchers from a newspaper we didn't read. We had already missed the relevant days; could my brother be relied upon not to have thrown away his back numbers? Fortunately, he could. Six in the morning on the day of departure. Travelling light, we left the pushchair at home and set out on foot for the station. A bad moment to remind ourselves how slowly the children walk. We missed the train but made it to the check-in at Stansted with six minutes to spare. In Copenhagen the Tivoli Gardens was closed so we went to the zoo. The next day we called on Jonas. It took him a moment or two to negotiate our bankers' draft, but he had the invoice, temporary Danish registration and the all-important manufacturers' certificate of conformity ready on his desk. We had 24 hours to leave the country. Only the certificate of conformity bothered us. The left/right- hand drive and metric/imperial speedometer options had not been ticked. Jonas could not read the French and shrugged. We decided to hope for the best. We drove through the night, entertaining ourselves with the trip computer and the rain-sensitive windscreen wipers while trying to interpret the Danish instruction manual. Despite getting hopelessly lost in Holland we ended up in Dover at nine the next morning, green but triumphant after a choppy crossing, elated to hear the thud of our new car increasing in value as we drove it on to British soil. Registration was simple, or would have been if the certificate of confor mity had not been rejected. I called Peugeot in Coventry. Our certificate was only valid in certain countries - a case of EU harmonisation that was not quite harmonious. They agreed to issue a new one. Meanwhile an English manual cost £6 from a Peugeot main dealer. No question asked. Now we are registered and legal, with tax disc and smart new V reg. number plates, awaiting only the last piece in the jigsaw: a bill from customs and excise for 17.5% that will bring the purchase price to about £12,000. Add £500 as the cost of collection and the saving is a clear £5,000 compared with the car we originally wanted; nearer £7,000 compared with the higher specification car we actually drove away. Checklist  Start with the EU website at http://europa.eu.int/comm/ dg04/aid/en/car.htm - go from there to the six-monthly price report. If your car isn't featured try the nearest base model. Find the cheapest country for your car. Check the hotline number for the manufacturer in case you get stuck.  Find the dealers on the car maker's website for your chosen country. There are generally links to these on the manufacturer's main website.  Telephone if you can - faxes and emails can be ignored. If it's Holland or Scandinavia, you can assume without arrogance that they will speak English.  When selecting a model explain that you want the UK equivalent. Non-standard features can affect the second-hand value of the car.  Don't be frightened because its abroad. Sending a deposit to a large overseas car dealer is less risky that giving it to a dodgy middle-man in the UK.  Remember to ask for the certificate of conformity and temporary registration, and be sure to get a receipted invoice.  Take a bank draft when you get the car. Make sure it is insured for the drive home.  Don't be put off by the paperwork. Get the information pack on importing a vehicle from DVLA (01792 772134). Take the registration and VAT forms it contains to a vehicle registration office with the invoice, certificate of conformity, insurance and a cheque for the tax disc plus a fee of £25. The VAT form will be sent to customs and excise who will send you a bill.  Once home, the car is not legal until it has a UK tax and plates.  If there's a problem with the certificate of conformity, contact the manufacturer's UK office.

webTitle: Me and my motor: Iain Lee

fields.headline: Me and my motor: Iain Lee
fields.trailText: What car do you drive?
fields.body:
What car do you drive?

A Ford Fiesta. It's a man's car. Or at least it was until I bought it from him. It's a classic K-reg 1.1, in eggshell blue. The boot doesn't lock, and the stereo's held on with chewing gum, but aside from those two minor points it's absolutely rubbish.

What does that say about you?

I need a new car.

What do you like best about it?

The fact that it's a car. Beyond that it has nothing whatsoever in its favour. Except perhaps the colour: an exquisite lapis lazuli. It makes me cry to look at it. For all sorts of reasons.

Why did you buy it?

I needed to get to Milton Keynes in a hurry, and there were no buses.

What kind of driver are you?

I drive the way that I make love. Slowly, carefully and with a hammer under my seat.

Have you ever crashed?

I once drove into the back of another car at low speed. I apologised and it was all OK. I can't really remember what she looked like. I've dined out on that story, I can tell you.

What do you use your car for?

Driving mainly. Though sometimes, if I'm in the mood, I'll sit quietly at the wheel, with the engine ticking over, just enjoying the noise of the 1.1, the smell of the petrol fumes, and then at the last moment I'll get up and open the garage door. I'd do it more often but it does tend to give me a headache.

What's in the glove compartment?

It's more of a ledge than a compartment. It's got a Gary Glitter tape in it, and a leaflet about a Cornish monkey sanctuary. I went to Cornwall once. I visited a Monkey Sanctuary. It was brilliant. I picked up a leaflet. Can't remember where I put it though. Probably knocking about in a glove compartment somewhere. Or on a ledge-like equivalent.

What music do you listen to on the road?

Glitter.

What would be your dream car?

A Ford Fiesta. Flame red. P-reg. Maybe even a 1.3. Man! I'd eat those 1.1 K-regs for breakfast! Probably never happen though. Still, a guy can dream.

 Iain Lee presents the 11 O'clock Show on Channel 4

fields.headline: The greening of Tony
fields.standfirst:
Blair's change of heart on GM is welcome

GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The green activists who have worked so hard for this moment hail it as Tony Blair's biggest u-turn since becoming prime minister. We can argue about that, but there is no doubt that Mr Blair's shift on genetically modified food represents a dramatic change of heart.
fields.body:
The green activists who have worked so hard for this moment hail it as Tony Blair's biggest u-turn since becoming prime minister. We can argue about that, but there is no doubt that Mr Blair's shift on genetically modified food represents a dramatic change of heart. One year ago the PM was urging us to "resist the tyranny of pressure groups", insisting that GM foods were perfectly safe and that if he was happy to eat them, then so should we. Yesterday Mr Blair declared almost the reverse position: "There's no doubt that there is potential for harm, both in terms of human safety and in the diversity of our environment, from GM foods and crops." This represents a significant journey by the PM, in terms of both policy and politics.

First the substance of the move. As an early campaigner on this once-ignored question, we welcome Mr Blair's sudden conversion to a cause he once dismissed as mere hysteria. For Mr Blair seemed to make up his mind hurriedly on GM foods. Soon after taking office, he was persuaded that Britain could be a world leader in biotechnology and that we should not make the frequent mistake of our past - letting our domination of a new technology slip away. Appealing, too, was the ethical dimension: the hard-sell for GM claimed this innovation would cure world hunger at a stroke, using science to feed the third world. Labour's new friends in big business were keen. For our young, outward-looking, modernising premier, GM food must have seemed a technology made in his own image. The fact that, as David Hencke and Rob Evans reveal on our news pages today, President Clinton was lobbying heavily for GM cannot have hurt.

So it is no wonder that, when the backlash came, Mr Blair and his team were first surprised then airily dismissive. For them this was yet another case of the future against the past, with the greens and consumer activists mere Luddites determined to stand in the way of progress. On GM foods, we were part of the legendary forces of conservatism. But the behind-the-scenes perseverance of the pressure groups and the (often underestimated) environment minister Michael Meacher seems to have turned things around. The argument that there is at least a risk to pressing ahead with such untried technology, whose long-term impact on our environment can only be guessed at, has clearly prevailed. Perhaps now Mr Blair will act on his article in the Independent on Sunday yesterday, and accept that the right approach to GM is proper testing and labelling before any of these new products or crops are foisted on the public.

So much for the policy. The politics of this u-turn are also significant. Mr Blair appears to have timed his reverse for today's opening of the OECD conference on GM food in Edinburgh. He will have been warned that the gathering threatened to become "another Seattle", with anti-GM activists dominating proceedings. Fearful of the PR disaster that would have ensued, the prime minister clearly calculated that it was better to have red faces in the government before the conference than red paint thrown at the government once it started.

We hope that this is the start of a change, that Tony Blair will be less dismissive of sincere concerns voiced in future. Maybe he will hesitate before waving aside a future public outcry the way he brushed off anxiety over GM food, as a "flash in the pan". Perhaps Mr Blair will realise that he does not always know the public mind better than it knows itself - and that sometimes the ability to lead is also the ability to listen.

webTitle: How US put pressure on Blair over GM food

fields.headline: How US put pressure on Blair over GM food
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: President Clinton was briefed to put intensive pressure on Tony Blair to open up Britain and Europe to US genetically modified food and crops during private talks at the Downing Street summit in 1998, papers released to the Guardian revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
President Clinton was briefed to put intensive pressure on Tony Blair to open up Britain and Europe to US genetically modified food and crops during private talks at the Downing Street summit in 1998, papers released to the Guardian revealed yesterday.

And within 24 hours of US protests, Britain had acted to modify proposals to try to open the way for more GM food being sold in Britain and the rest of the European Union.

The approach, which was never made public, was timed for three separate meetings - two in Downing Street's state dining room, and at Dunbar Court in the foreign office, at the EU summit on May 18.

Documents released to the Guardian under the US freedom of information act reveal President Clinton was briefed to warn Mr Blair - who then held the EU presidency - that "the EU's slow and non-transparent approval process for genetically modified organisms has cost US exporters hundreds of millions in lost sales."

It goes on: "In the spirit of increased US-EU regulatory cooperation, we urge the EU to take immediate action to ensure that these products receive a timely review."

Papers for the meeting show the same complaints were put to President Jacques Santer, then head of the European Commission, and Sir Leon Brittan, then EU foreign affairs commissioner.

The papers show more detailed complaints were put to Margaret Beckett, then trade secretary, and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, by William Daley, the US trade secretary, and Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, at meetings in the foreign office and Downing Street that morning.

Participating in the talks were the co-chairmen of the Transatlantic Business Dialogue - a lobbying organisation - Lodewijk de Vink, chief executive of Warner-Lambert (now Time-Warner), the US in ternational media company, and Juergen Schrempp, chief executive of Daimler-Benz, the car makers, who back deregulation of European-US trade.

The papers show that not only did the US attack the EU over the slow approval of GM crops but it criticised the labelling of GM foods.

The brief reads: "Differences among member states over labelling have been an impediment to reforming the approval process. We will be watching the commission's efforts to implement its new guidelines for labelling and we hope the EU can now move quickly to complete review of the products in the pipeline.

"That said, the US sees no reason to label a product simply because it has been genetically engineered. Mandatory labelling of GMOs should be based on sound science."

The next day the Financial Times reported that the UK presidency had brought forward proposals to scrap plans for labelling food saying "it may contain GM ingredients" which had created an impasse with national governments. The UK government - in line with US policy - proposed to limit the products that could be labelled as containing US soya bean derivatives.

Downing Street denied any American pressure.

Last night the Guardian's disclosure was welcomed by Tony Juniper, Friends of the Earth campaigner on GM food. He said: " The government has repeatedly denied in private and public that the US has ever raised or tried to put pressure on the government over GM food. These previously secret briefing papers suggest the opposite occurred."

The papers also show that neither John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, who had overall responsibility for the environment, nor Michael Meacher, the environment minister in charge of GM crops, were invited to these discussions.

The briefing papers will be banned under home secretary Jack Straw's freedom of information bill until 2029.

fields.headline: Are these photos racist?
fields.standfirst: This week South Africa's newspapers are in the dock. The charge? Racism. The evidence? Pictures and articles which an investigation says show Africa in a poor light. Chris McGreal on a row that is splitting the nation
fields.trailText: This week South Africa's newspapers are in the dock. The charge? Racism. The evidence? Pictures and articles which an investigation says show Africa in a poor light. Chris McGreal on a row that is splitting the nation
fields.body:
On Wednesday, South Africa's human rights commissioners will gather in Johannesburg in the hope, rather than the expectation, of interrogating the country's editors on alleged racism in their news coverage.

The commission has summonsed more than 30 journalists with threats of up to six months in prison if they refuse to comply. Those summonsed include Richard Lambert, editor of the Financial Times, Victor Mallett, South Africa correspondent of the Financial Times, and John Witherow, editor of the Sunday Times. Some are determined not to show up, saying the subpoenas fly in the face of constitutional guarantees of press freedom besides any concern about the planned conduct of the hearings. Editors are presumed guilty and open to interrogation on just about anything the commissioners care to ask.

A group of black editors, while criticising the "ill-advised" approach, says it will cooperate with the probe because the greater crime is the racism still rife in South Africa's press.

The human rights commission launched its investigation a year ago after the Black Lawyers Association accused a leading anti-apartheid newspaper - the Mail and Guardian - of unfairly targeting black professionals in corruption stories. The BLA said that over a six-month period the paper, in which the Guardian Media Group has a majority stake, printed three times as many stories about corrupt black people as white people.

The paper questioned the figures, and pointed out that with black people now dominating government, they were likely to account for a higher number of corruption cases. The BLA made similar accusations of "subliminal racism" against the Johannesburg Sunday Times.

The human rights commission took the complaint as an opportunity to launch an inquiry into racism in the entire news media. It began with a 200-page report that amounts to the case for the prosecution at this week's hearings. The commission says the report provides "prima facie" evidence of media racism and that the press should be held to account. A series of images (reproduced, right) became the centre of heated debate.

The report's author, Claudia Braude, throws mainstream South African journalism under apartheid into damning context. She highlights the profits-driven policy of collaboration with white governments. "Newsrooms were infiltrated by spies, and intelligence and military agents who helped to control the shaping of the apartheid mind. This is a story that has only barely begun to be told. It nonetheless has major implications for the credibility of the contemporary mass media industry," the report says.

The South African press is still dominated by white people whose preferences and prejudices influence the choice of news stories and how they are portrayed. The industry only has itself to blame for a shortage of black reporters and editors. Most newspapers never bothered to start targeted training schemes until it was evident apartheid had run its course.

But further scrutiny of the report brought howls of derision. It was dismissed as a collection of unsubstantiated allegations, even absurdities in places. Braude failed to scrutinise the allegations for accuracy but still used them to bolster her premise that coverage of almost every story - from crime and politics to war and business - is infused with "subliminal racism". Critics, even those sympathetic with the need for inquiry into racism in the press, pointed out that in her efforts to prove racism across the board, Braude allowed herself to be dragged into a number of indefensible positions. In so doing, she let those with real transgressions to defend off the hook.

Interestingly, in its pursuit of the white-dominated press the human rights commission chose Braude, a white woman, to write the report and the Media Monitoring Project, a white-run organisation, to provide the statistical interpretation.

Few of the editors who have been summonsed to appear are clear about exactly what they will be asked to account for. But the human rights commission's report gives them a fair idea. It is divided into three parts:

'White Supremacist Narratives of South Africa in Transition'

Braude opens her analysis with more than a dozen pages on anti-Semitism in Die Afrikaner, an obscure Afrikaner nationalist newspaper which persistently denies the Holocaust and favours theories about a Jewish masterplan to bring about a new world order. The report also delves into Radio Pretoria, a once-banned station that has made no secret of its pro-apartheid leanings with its perpetual rantings about humans being like plants divided into sub-groups that should not cross-pollinate. Radio Pretoria broadcasts predictable diatribes against affirmative action, land reform and other measures to right past wrongs.

The report concludes: "Both Die Afrikaner and Radio Pretoria repre sent South Africa in a state of decline as a direct consequence of transition to non-racial, democratic rule, and particularly of black governance." Although neither organisation reaches much beyond a narrow and bigoted audience, they are used as the basis of an examination of the mainstream press in the second part of the report.

'Racialisation of news in mainstream coverage of contemporary South Africa'

In her examination of the mainstream media, Braude looks at one week of news coverage in June 1999. Stories of doctors complaining about overcrowded hospitals, a threat from rabid dogs and fresh budget cuts are all deemed racist because they portray black government in a negative light.

The analysis for which the report was most widely derided leaps out. It focuses on an editorial in The Citizen, a Johannesburg daily, which criticises the standard of rubbish collection. Braude sees it as evidence of a "deep-seated racialised anxiety about dirt".

"The psychosexual racist logic arises from the phallic obsessions, Oedipal projections and anal-sadistic orientations in European cultures which endow non-European (especially African) men and women with sexual prowess; view non-Europeans as either cruel, revengeful fathers, frivolous, carefree children, or passive, long-suffering mothers; and identify non-Europeans (especially black people) with dirt, odious smells and faeces," the report says.

The Johannesburg Star called it "psycho babble". Others noted that many of the complaints about rubbish collection come from the townships, which are still badly served compared to the formerly whites-only suburbs.

And then there was the seemingly innocuous picture of two birds sitting on a rubbish bin that appeared on the front page of The Star under the headline, Trash for Two. One of the birds is a maribou stork. The commission concluded that the bin symbolised the decay of Johannesburg under black rule and the birds a fear of Africans flooding in. "As such, the photograph integrates anxieties about decaying urban infrastructure with fears of incursions from Africa," it says. Except, as the caption says, the picture was taken in Uganda not Johannesburg.

But it is the report's analysis of political coverage which is most telling. The commission was clearly disturbed at the numerous articles which probed President Thabo Mbeki's style of politics, often portrayed as centralised and secretive.

The Mail and Guardian was taken to task over an article entitled "Can Thabo be a good Machiavelli?". Braude concluded that this, and similar articles in other papers, was aimed at portraying Mbeki as "another power-hungry soon-to-be African dictator". Others saw it as examining the president's exercise of power in much the way Tony Blair's style of politics has been similarly scrutinised.

The report dedicates much space to stories on Mbhazima "Sam" Shilowa, just installed as the African National Congress premier of the country's richest province, Guateng. The Star had a story about Shilowa's annual "state of the province" address under the headline "Shilowa outlines Guateng master plan". It is accompanied by a photograph of the premier on a TV screen. The commission concluded that the story and picture were designed to invoke a "fear of black dictatorship".

"The spectre of Orwellian control evoked by the photograph is underscored by the word 'master plan' in the headline," it said.

The third part of the report is an analysis by the Media Monitoring Project. It sets out dozens of propositions - black lives are unimportant, African society is primitive and Africa is ridden with disaster, disease and violence - and then judges to what extent news stories reinforce these racial stereotypes.

fields.bodyText: On Wednesday, South Africa's human rights commissioners will gather in Johannesburg in the hope, rather than the expectation, of interrogating the country's editors on alleged racism in their news coverage. The commission has summonsed more than 30 journalists with threats of up to six months in prison if they refuse to comply. Those summonsed include Richard Lambert, editor of the Financial Times, Victor Mallett, South Africa correspondent of the Financial Times, and John Witherow, editor of the Sunday Times. Some are determined not to show up, saying the subpoenas fly in the face of constitutional guarantees of press freedom besides any concern about the planned conduct of the hearings. Editors are presumed guilty and open to interrogation on just about anything the commissioners care to ask. A group of black editors, while criticising the "ill-advised" approach, says it will cooperate with the probe because the greater crime is the racism still rife in South Africa's press. The human rights commission launched its investigation a year ago after the Black Lawyers Association accused a leading anti-apartheid newspaper - the Mail and Guardian - of unfairly targeting black professionals in corruption stories. The BLA said that over a six-month period the paper, in which the Guardian Media Group has a majority stake, printed three times as many stories about corrupt black people as white people. The paper questioned the figures, and pointed out that with black people now dominating government, they were likely to account for a higher number of corruption cases. The BLA made similar accusations of "subliminal racism" against the Johannesburg Sunday Times. The human rights commission took the complaint as an opportunity to launch an inquiry into racism in the entire news media. It began with a 200-page report that amounts to the case for the prosecution at this week's hearings. The commission says the report provides "prima facie" evidence of media racism and that the press should be held to account. A series of images (reproduced, right) became the centre of heated debate. The report's author, Claudia Braude, throws mainstream South African journalism under apartheid into damning context. She highlights the profits-driven policy of collaboration with white governments. "Newsrooms were infiltrated by spies, and intelligence and military agents who helped to control the shaping of the apartheid mind. This is a story that has only barely begun to be told. It nonetheless has major implications for the credibility of the contemporary mass media industry," the report says. The South African press is still dominated by white people whose preferences and prejudices influence the choice of news stories and how they are portrayed. The industry only has itself to blame for a shortage of black reporters and editors. Most newspapers never bothered to start targeted training schemes until it was evident apartheid had run its course. But further scrutiny of the report brought howls of derision. It was dismissed as a collection of unsubstantiated allegations, even absurdities in places. Braude failed to scrutinise the allegations for accuracy but still used them to bolster her premise that coverage of almost every story - from crime and politics to war and business - is infused with "subliminal racism". Critics, even those sympathetic with the need for inquiry into racism in the press, pointed out that in her efforts to prove racism across the board, Braude allowed herself to be dragged into a number of indefensible positions. In so doing, she let those with real transgressions to defend off the hook. Interestingly, in its pursuit of the white-dominated press the human rights commission chose Braude, a white woman, to write the report and the Media Monitoring Project, a white-run organisation, to provide the statistical interpretation. Few of the editors who have been summonsed to appear are clear about exactly what they will be asked to account for. But the human rights commission's report gives them a fair idea. It is divided into three parts: 'White Supremacist Narratives of South Africa in Transition' Braude opens her analysis with more than a dozen pages on anti-Semitism in Die Afrikaner, an obscure Afrikaner nationalist newspaper which persistently denies the Holocaust and favours theories about a Jewish masterplan to bring about a new world order. The report also delves into Radio Pretoria, a once-banned station that has made no secret of its pro-apartheid leanings with its perpetual rantings about humans being like plants divided into sub-groups that should not cross-pollinate. Radio Pretoria broadcasts predictable diatribes against affirmative action, land reform and other measures to right past wrongs. The report concludes: "Both Die Afrikaner and Radio Pretoria repre sent South Africa in a state of decline as a direct consequence of transition to non-racial, democratic rule, and particularly of black governance." Although neither organisation reaches much beyond a narrow and bigoted audience, they are used as the basis of an examination of the mainstream press in the second part of the report. 'Racialisation of news in mainstream coverage of contemporary South Africa' In her examination of the mainstream media, Braude looks at one week of news coverage in June 1999. Stories of doctors complaining about overcrowded hospitals, a threat from rabid dogs and fresh budget cuts are all deemed racist because they portray black government in a negative light. The analysis for which the report was most widely derided leaps out. It focuses on an editorial in The Citizen, a Johannesburg daily, which criticises the standard of rubbish collection. Braude sees it as evidence of a "deep-seated racialised anxiety about dirt". "The psychosexual racist logic arises from the phallic obsessions, Oedipal projections and anal-sadistic orientations in European cultures which endow non-European (especially African) men and women with sexual prowess; view non-Europeans as either cruel, revengeful fathers, frivolous, carefree children, or passive, long-suffering mothers; and identify non-Europeans (especially black people) with dirt, odious smells and faeces," the report says. The Johannesburg Star called it "psycho babble". Others noted that many of the complaints about rubbish collection come from the townships, which are still badly served compared to the formerly whites-only suburbs. And then there was the seemingly innocuous picture of two birds sitting on a rubbish bin that appeared on the front page of The Star under the headline, Trash for Two. One of the birds is a maribou stork. The commission concluded that the bin symbolised the decay of Johannesburg under black rule and the birds a fear of Africans flooding in. "As such, the photograph integrates anxieties about decaying urban infrastructure with fears of incursions from Africa," it says. Except, as the caption says, the picture was taken in Uganda not Johannesburg. But it is the report's analysis of political coverage which is most telling. The commission was clearly disturbed at the numerous articles which probed President Thabo Mbeki's style of politics, often portrayed as centralised and secretive. webTitle: Is it right to put the media on trial? No

fields.headline: Is it right to put the media on trial? No
fields.trailText: I call on the editors to defy the subpoenas served on them by the Human Rights Commission en bloc. By appearing before the HRC, they will give credence to a discredited organisation that has failed to carry out its mandate effectively since its inception in 1995.
fields.byline: Rhoda Kadalie, former member of the HRC
fields.body:
I call on the editors to defy the subpoenas served on them by the Human Rights Commission en bloc. By appearing before the HRC, they will give credence to a discredited organisation that has failed to carry out its mandate effectively since its inception in 1995.

These subpoenas are a gross violation of freedom of expression and an attempt to prescribe to the press what they should be thinking and writing. Where are the voices of academics, NGOs and civil society in condemning the erosion of civil liberties by an institution that should be robust in defending them? The public has a moral duty to be vigilant of these watchdog institutions as they cannot be entrusted to be the gatekeepers of the fundamental rights of all South Africans.

Nobody is denying that racism exists and that it rears its head in the media in various ways.[But] is this obsession with race not perhaps a ploy to divert attention from its own inefficacy in dealing with the myriad of human rights violations in our country? Should we as taxpayers not insist that it attend to many of the other rights in the Bill of Rights?

Instead, the commission dabbles with witch-hunts in its desperation to foist its dwindling power on an unsuspecting public. The list of incomplete tasks is endless and should remind the HRC to get its own house in order first. The heavy-handed tactics are an apt demonstration that when search and seizure powers are conferred upon incompetent and beleaguered individuals, the consequences might be too ghastly to contemplate!

fields.headline: Is it right to put the media on trial? Yes
fields.trailText: South Africa is recovering from apartheid, the worst type of racism and abuse of human rights. Our national parliament created the Human Rights Commission to safeguard the rights of all South Africans, and to ensure that people are not discriminated against or abused because of race, religion, creed or culture. Government ministers, church leaders, generals, school principals and so on appear before the commission as soon as a complaint is laid.
fields.body:
South Africa is recovering from apartheid, the worst type of racism and abuse of human rights. Our national parliament created the Human Rights Commission to safeguard the rights of all South Africans, and to ensure that people are not discriminated against or abused because of race, religion, creed or culture. Government ministers, church leaders, generals, school principals and so on appear before the commission as soon as a complaint is laid.

The media have praised the HRC. But, when their turn comes, they duck and dive. Must we talk of media freedom at the expense of South Africa's black majority? What was the liberation struggle about? Are certain people and institutions going to be above the law? Are the summonses by the HRC a threat to press freedom, as the media say?

Statements such as "threat to press freedom" or "interference with editorial independence" are not one-size-fits-all tenets of faith. Every journalist, for instance, has a moral obligation not to disclose the identity of his informant, if this whistleblower is exposing corruption in the government service. But we cannot say the same of a journalist who writes a story in which it is clear he knows the identity of the racist who killed five blacks in a Pretoria bus a few weeks ago. Surely, the public good is served if this journalist discloses his source.

Who makes this judgment? The editor whose job it is to make such calls. Are we asking for too much when we say the media must uphold the dignity of the people it purports to serve? This means it must help expunge the racism that has plagued our country and it must also subject itself to this process.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst:
Frank Dobson

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Interview with Frank Dobson, Labour's candidate for London mayor.
fields.body:
Newspapers: Most days I read the [London] Evening Standard, Saturdays the FT. I hardly read papers. I like Ian Aitken and I've always rated Andrew Marr.

Magazines: The one I buy regularly is Time Out - to find what's on at the pictures or at the Barbican, concerts, things like that. Nothing else, really.

Books: My all-time favourite is A House for Mr Biswas by VS Naipaul. I read quite a lot of detective stories, at the moment - there's not much to beat Raymond Chandler. And two books by Alan Furst about Paris during the Occupation. Also, Lisa Jardine's Worldy Goods, about the Renaissance. I normally try and give my brain a run-out on holiday. So last time I went to Amsterdam, I took the Roger Scruton book on Spinoza.

Film: The last two I've seen were American Beauty, which was quite good but not as good as it was cracked up to be, and East is East, which was better than it was cracked up to be. I like Mike Leigh films and, of course, Richard Curtis.

Television: My life is so irregular that I couldn't claim there's anything I regularly watch. The two things I've recently enjoyed were Longitude and the two-parter about Conan Doyle. There's lots of rubbish on television.

Radio: Radio 4 for about an hour in the morning. 5 Live as well - their current affairs coverage is in some ways better. They're not so up themselves as Radio 4.

Ads: Some of the car ads trying to sell cars to women are quite fun because they are wonderful mockeries of the macho male motorist. But my real ambition - obviously not on TV ads - is to see the first major tobacco companies saying: "Follow the maker's instructions, become an addict, and die."

Multimedia: When I'm not in an office I'm a technology-free zone.

fields.headline: The mayor makers
fields.standfirst:
The government is spending £4m convincing Londoners that the election for mayor is important. But will it work? Alex Benady reveals the strategy while Roy Greenslade says that Ken Livingstone should beware media gifts

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The government is spending £4m convincing Londoners that the election for mayor is important. But will it work? Alex Benady reveals the strategy while Roy Greenslade says that Ken Livingstone should beware media gifts
fields.body:
It seems that Labour's road to the London mayoral elections has been paved with banana skins. Frank Dobson's controversial selection as mayoral candidate was swiftly followed last week by a slap-down from the House of Lords over whether candidates should have free mailings.

But there could be further humiliation in store. All other pratfalls not-withstanding, political analysts agree that a poor or indifferent turnout for the elections on May 4 will be another severe embarrassment for the government and its flagship policy of devolution, no matter who is elected.

With this very much in mind, the government is spending £4m on a blanket advertising campaign, one of its most sophisticated to date, aimed at explaining the complexities of London's new electoral system and persuading apathetic Londoners to vote. The budget may not sound much by the multi-million pound standards of modern business, but the fact that the entire amount will be spent in London, most of it within 10 weeks, means that its distinctive orange asterisk logo will be almost impossible to miss. If the media schedule hits its targets, the average Londoner will be exposed to the campaign in one or other of its many forms at least 50 times in the coming weeks.

The first wave, the so-called "responsibilities" phase of the campaign, broke last week as 1,700 posters went up all over the capital bearing the headline "It's the biggest job in London. You choose who gets it". The line will also be carried on the back of bus and tube tickets. "The idea is to explain exactly what the mayor does and how he can affect individual lives," explains Jo Cave, account director at the campaign's advertising agency WCRS.

The message will be reinforced by radio and press adverts, tube posters and a TV commercial (revealed here for the first time) directed by Selby at Godman films, which breaks this Wednesday. The 30-second films shows scenes of London life with the ubiquitous orange asterisk highlighting the mayor's responsibilities such as transport and policing.

Phase two of the campaign will use the local press to explain the mechanics of the mayoral election process, how to vote and key electoral innovations. The final assault on the capital's consciousness will begin five days before "E day" - as the government commandeers every advertising vehicle available. Five 10-second TV films, press and radio ads as well as buses, beer mats and airships will announce the countdown to the election. There will also be a door drop to every London household detailing the mayor's responsibilities and telling people how and where to vote.

It may sound a little over the top, but the approach was determined by fears that Londoners, some of whom have voted no fewer than five times in the past three years, may be suffering "election fatigue". "Londoners have been called to vote so often recently, another direct call to vote wouldn't be heard," Cave said. "People don't vote for a community or for an idea. They want to know what the impact will be on their individual lives. So we are addressing them as the mayor's employers in an attempt to make them feel empowered."

The question is, do campaigns like this work? Evidence from previous campaigns is mixed. The government regularly runs programmes encouraging people to register to vote, but the spends tend to be so tiny - £0.5m over the entire country - that effects are negligible, or indiscernible.

There have been similar efforts to encourage greater participation in US presidential elections, but turnout is still around 55%. The government spent £2m in Scotland and £2m in Wales promoting the elections, but even the first flush of enthusiasm for their own parliaments failed to produce turnouts anywhere near those for a general election. The problem is that the power of advertising is quite limited. "Advertising is best at raising awareness," says Roger Mortimer, senior political analyst at market research firm MORI. "The vast majority of people know this election is happening, so to have any effect, it will have to change attitudes, to convince people that the election matters."

But that is a much harder task. Even if it did succeed, how could we tell, asks Patrick Dunleavy, professor of government at the London School of Economics. "Campaigns like these can work if all the other switches are facing in the right direction," he says. "But advertising is a comparatively minor factor in the mix. The commitment of government and the major parties [markedly lacking in last year's European elections] and quality of the field, will affect turn out far more." This, he says, creates a tension between Labour as the government and Labour as a political party. "Ironically the best chance of a good turnout is if Ken Livingstone stands. If he doesn't, there will be much less public interest."

The refusal to let mayoral candidates have the one-off mail shot customary in parliamentary elections illustrates just how the government can act to keep interest low. Much of the debate about such campaigns tends to centre on their technical merits and party political manoeuvrings. But there are those who believe that they can serve a fundamental role in the political enfranchisement of minorities and their enlistment into mainstream society.

Operation Black Vote was established in 1996 to sell politics to the black community and encourage participation in the electoral process. "About 27% of black people aren't registered to vote, compared to 6% of white people," says Simon Wooley, the campaign's co-founder. He says campaigns to persuade people to vote can work and are important, especially where whole groups don't participate. He points to a test campaign in the London borough of Southwark where a mailing to 50,000 black people increased registration by 7%.

Wooley, who has a background in the industry, says that advertising is exactly the right way to address the problem of voter apathy. "You have to sell politics to a justifiably cynical community," he argues.

He supports the orange asterisk campaign in principle, but says it has missed a trick. The first mistake he says was to target the entire population. Like universal benefits, it's a waste of money. "The middle classes don't need to be told that the election is happening. The campaign should be far more heavily targeted towards minorities." But he also says that the idea that such campaigns can work in isolation is wrong. "Campaigns in a vacuum don't work. We need to demystify the democratic process, and without an ongoing programme that just can't happen."

He points to a test campaign in the London borough of Southwark where a mailing to 50,000 black people increased registration by 7%. Wooley, who has a background in the industry, says that advertising is exactly the right way to address the problem of voter apathy. "You have to sell politics to a justifiably cynical community," he argues. He supports the orange asterisk campaign in principle, but says it has missed a trick. The first mistake he says was to target the entire population. Like universal benefits, it's a waste of money. "The middle classes don't need to be told that the election is happening. The campaign should be far more heavily targeted towards minorities." But he also says that the idea that such campaigns can work in isolation is wrong. "Campaigns in a vacuum don't work. We need to demystify the democratic process, and without an ongoing programme that just can't happen."

fields.headline: Buddy, can you spare £200m?
fields.standfirst:
Last week Chris Smith demanded that BBC1 becomes 'the flagship' for the corporation. John Dugdale reveals why the channel is not living up to any of our expectations.

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Last week Chris Smith demanded that BBC1 becomes 'the flagship' for the corporation. John Dugdale reveals why the channel is not living up to any of our expectations
fields.body:
If you're sceptical about the BBC's desperate need for the £200m per annum hike in licence-fee income that culture secretary Chris Smith announced last week - stipulating that much of it must help to "re-establish BBC1 as the corporation's flagship" - just compare the peak-time line-ups for the current week (February 26 - March 3) on ITV and BBC1, paying particular attention to repeats.

On the commercial channel, recycling is limited to the laughably-titled New I've Been Framed; on the public-service network, in contrast, the schedule is padded out with "narrative" (same week) repeats of Muscle, Goodness Gracious Me, A Question of Sport, It's Only TV But I Like It, The Peter Principle, Playing the Field and My Hero.

And that's not all - there are also re-runs of The Royle Family and They Think It's All Over, plus (as if UK Gold didn't exist) yet another chance to view whiskery episodes of Dad's Army, One Foot in the Grave, Men Behaving Badly and Only Fools And Horses. With the BBC's Kick The Habit campaign getting under way next week, Dr Smith's treatment may at least help to cure Mr Salmon of west London of his addiction to replaying old comedies.

Or take the big sports events so far this year: the likely Six Nations decider between England and France, the England vs Argentina football friendly, the resumed Champions League and the FA Cup quarter-finals were all broadcast by Sky, ITV, or some combination of the two, leaving BBC1 forced to make do with less crucial rugby internationals and Fifa's torpid club tournament in Brazil. Buddy, can you spare £200m?

Further wounds were inflicted a fortnight ago by Royal Television Society research indicating that ITV broadcast 66 of the 100 most-watched programmes last year, including all the top 10. Broadcast magazine's ratings analyst, William Phillips, who compiled the chart, argued: "Take away EastEnders and a handful of specials, and little remains to justify the corporation's pretensions as a convenor of the whole nation for shared amusement."

The BBC response was predictable. "We don't judge ourselves purely by numbers, we have different barometers of our success. We aim to give all licence fee payers a nourishing schedule filled with quality and diversity." This follows the argument advanced by the director of television, Alan Yentob, when campaigning for the director-general post, that the BBC should not be fixated on ratings if its programmes were innovative, educational or of high quality.

Echoing this mantra, BBC1 controller Peter Salmon chose "Quality, range, diversity" as his slogan for the winter season, but he also struck a more personal note by speaking of "programmes which push back the boundaries of ambition", presumably referring to Castaway 2000 and last week's Child Of Our Time. This is a recurring theme ("unless you can be ambitious on BBC1, what's the point?"), and his willingness to gamble has resulted, again and again, in glory co-existing with disaster.

Last winter's successes, including the return of Parky, were overshadowed by the catastrophic results of Salmon's signing of Vanessa; this winter's successes, such as Paul Abbott's Clocking Off, have similarly won less press coverage than the Castaway 2000 fiasco or the gaffe-strewn live millennium spectacular. Welcoming Victoria Wood back to BBC1 has been offset by the seeming insanity of signing Hale & Pace, the bold coup of switching The Royle Family from BBC2 to BBC1 by the equally daring blunder of putting Mrs Merton And Malcolm straight onto BBC1.

Last autumn - with Warriors, Walking with Dinosaurs, and Wives and Daughters - was his most impressive season so far, marred only by the high-profile embarrassment of French and Saunders' Let Them Eat Cake. But of its successes only The Royle Family is a returning series, highlighting his biggest headache: a lack of "banker" shows in drama, comedy and entertainment. By the end of May he will have totted up 1,000 days in the job, but the Casualty spin-off Holby City and Dinnerladies are the only new, BBC1-originated series in these genres with audiences averaging above 9m.

Salmon inherited a number of shows nearing the end of their natural lives, and has done all that could be asked of a controller - hiring top talent - in his efforts to replace them. Reeves and Mortimer, Bazal and Ginger, for example, have all been called up to little avail to stop the rot on Saturday nights.

He has been unlucky in trying to fill the gaps left by Men Behaving Badly, Birds of a Feather and Goodnight Sweetheart: neither Marks & Gran nor Simon Nye have so far provided him with another stonker, and two John Sullivan sitcoms have disappointed. In drama, similarly, Lucy Gannon has produced strong finite works but not another Soldier Soldier or Peak Practice, and Kay Mellor (Playing the Field) and Mike Bullen (Sunburn) have added to a long list of BBC1 semi-hits rather than delivering the kind of ratings their ITV shows get.

Equally unfortunately, Salmon's period as controller has coincided with ITV's transformation into a ruthless ratings machine, increasing its share targets each year and so pushing BBC1 consistently below 30%, slumping to 26% in its nadir last year. Key defeats have been inflicted - on Christmas day, on Saturday nights, in the head-to-head between SM TV: Live and Live & Kicking.

Just as troublingly, however, David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, has combined this relentless frontal offensive with sneakily contesting the BBC's claim to a uniquely "rich mix", to a monopoly of "quality and diversity" - a strategy clearest in drama. If you add up their respective (non-soap, first-run) primetime drama offerings this week, BBC1 has six totalling five hours 10 minutes, compared to ITV's seven totalling seven hours. The latter figure was even higher in previous weeks, when it played two-hour whodunnits on Saturday night.

Nor are these all cops 'n' docs shows - ITV is closing the gap in costume adaptations, and such series as Four Fathers, Last Train, At Home With The Braithwaites and Reach For The Moon are far from being formulaic genre pieces. The Death Of Stephen Lawrence and Lost For Words were last year's best single plays.

Tellingly, BBC programming is now divided in its seasonal and weekly press packs into "highlights" - led in the current season by Castaway 2000, Clocking Off, Kick the Habit and the forthcoming remake of Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased) - and the unloved, under-promoted remainder. Funding flows towards prestige projects such as Walking With Dinosaurs or Vanity Fair, designed to win Bafta awards and impress governors and MPs.

Surrounded by mediocrity and re-run reminders of past glories, these peaks belie an overall picture in which ITV is on top in drama, entertainment and sport, has countered BBC1's (now less decisive) ascendancy in sitcom by developing comedy dramas, and is on level-pegging in popular factual output since the waning of the docu-soap fad.

The BBC's sole clear-cut area of supremacy is in anything which involves informing or coaching the public, a broad spectrum stretching from Walking with Dinosaurs and televising literary classics to consumer programmes and leisure shows such as Ground Force and Changing Rooms.

And, luckily, this aptitude for providing spoonfuls of entertainment to help the medicine of information go down coincides with the government's conception of the key function of broadcasting. Tony Blair identifies his priorities as "education, education, education"; Greg Dyke declares in a Spectator lecture that education will be at the heart of his BBC; Chris Smith specifies that, besides boosting BBC1, the extra licence-fee income must go towards the corporation's "commitment to education".

Smith's statement left it unclear how he defines "education programmes", and whether he expects more of them in peak on BBC1 and BBC2. But - even if the only formal requirement is for more money to go to dedicated niche services and off-peak schools/adult-learning zones - one can readily imagine controllers and producers, sensing the way the wind is blowing, getting still more enthusiastic about television's new-found mission to teach. The empires of the BBC's science and education departments, which already include such series as Animal Hospital, will grab more of the schedule. Getting educated by stealth will be increasingly hard to avoid if you're watching the BBC.

It's vital, however, that beefing up BBC1 is kept separate from all this homework for the viewer. With 78 years of Reithian experience behind it, the BBC is confident in the role of teacher, good-humouredly bossy in its campaigns or beat-the-criminals series, making lessons fun in its dinosaur soap or in Robert Winston's science epics.

But it's perhaps no coincidence that a period when - governed by John Birt's "mission to inform" - it's been at its most pedagogic has seen it surrender countless sports rights and lose the knack of making frivolous, fictional programmes which are not the least bit worthy or instructive. Programmes which politicians rarely see or understand.

So every penny possible from Smith's £200m hand-out should go towards sitcoms, sport, and dramas which are neither adapted from A-level texts nor set in schools. Otherwise, BBC1 risks turning into what Radio 4 has already become - a brilliant sixth-form college, but incapable of coming up with anything new which is not designed to improve its audience.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: * As William Hague desperately tried to keep the interest of the assembled hacks at the What the Papers Say awards on Friday - a notoriously difficult job - the restless audience was actually much more fascinated by the gossip sweeping the tables. Associated Newspapers, it appears, has made an approach to the deputy editor of the Sun, Rebekah Wade. Wade would bring Paul Dacre a much needed female sensibility to the upper executive eschelons at Associated. How about making her the editor of the limp Mail on Sunday which could do with an injection of Wade chutzpah?

Associated Newspapers, it appears, has made an approach to the deputy editor of the Sun, Rebekah Wade.
