*Ooooh, the tension, the tension. Condé Nast has finally agreed the arrival date for Mandi Norwood, the Cosmo editor who is going to New York to edit Si Newhouse's Mademoiselle magazine - it's all happening in two weeks.

The Condé Nast luvvy machine has been in overdrive, securing Norwood elegant living accommodation on fashionable E69th Street. She will be expected to use the palatial pad to entertain and impress the New York glitterati - just as is expected of Vogue's Anna Wintour, Vanity Fair's Graydon Cater and Architectural Digest's Paige Ruse who all have awesome homes courtesy of the Newhouse empire.

*Daily Mail, page 12, February 25: "A curse on this cult of celebrity." Ray Connolly attacks the supine press for indulging in a constant stream of dull, celebrity PR-driven stories which have replaced coverage of real heroes such as Sir Stanley Matthews who didn't need such crass exposure to make their mark.

*Daily Mail, pages 1, 50, 51, February 25: Titanic star Kate Winslett is expecting a baby.

*Daily Mail, page 3, "Seductive" Samantha Janus, the leading lady at the centre of three bitter divorce battles.

*Daily Mail, Page 11, Jennifer Lopez wears same dress as Gerri Halliwell shock.

fields.headline: Trust the little blighters
fields.trailText: "Don't forget the Fruit Gums, Mum" - a brutal appeal to kids' pester power, or an unforgettable campaign that made Fruit Gums a favourite in many homes? You take your pick. Well, the issue is back again - and this time with a vengeance.
fields.body:
"Don't forget the Fruit Gums, Mum" - a brutal appeal to kids' pester power, or an unforgettable campaign that made Fruit Gums a favourite in many homes? You take your pick. Well, the issue is back again - and this time with a vengeance.

A recent conference on toys and games highlighted, again, the issue of television advertising to children and the threat of a Europe-wide ban when Sweden takes up presidency of the European Union next year. When Sweden announced its presidential agenda, extending its own ban on television advertising to children throughout Europe was high on its list. I understand that it's dropped down their batting order since then, and most commentators believe their chances of imposing the ban are slim. This is good news because, like most bans, it would be ineffective and counter-productive.

The reason for the ban in Sweden is because their government accepted research stating that most children could not recognise the difference between advertisements and programmes until they were 10 years old. They then added two years for luck, and imposed a ban on television ads aimed at the under-12s. The deputy director of the Swedish ministry of culture added for good measure that television advertising leaves children "vulnerable to abuse and deception by adults".

All the evidence in this country shows that children's advertising literacy develops from the age of four and that by the age of seven or eight they have developed a good understanding of the purpose and intent of advertising. The Independent Television Commission, scrutinising the rules governing toy advertising, concluded that "as a result of exposure to media technology of all kinds, the children were quick to assimilate and interpret what they were shown".

Beyond this, there is a series of reasons why a ban would be inappropriate for the UK. First, the quality of children's television. Swedish children's television is dominated by cheap American cartoons (many of which, by the way, are linked to merchandising). A ban on children's advertising here would have a catastrophic effect on the funding of commercial children's television programming.

If advertising revenue were taken away from ITV, children's programmes would be removed, reduced to low-cost shows from elsewhere, or could even become available as subscription only.

Next, the accusation that pester power is purely the result of television advertising. Nonsense. All the studies from Sweden that I have seen show there is no less pester power for toys there than here. The major sources are toy catalogues and playground competitiveness.

Even here, somebody told me last year, the Argos catalogue have more impact on children in the UK than all the television advertising put together. And let's not forget the international marketing phenomenon of movies like Toy Story 2.

Next, cost. Swedish toys are up to 40% more expensive than in the rest of the EU. This higher cost is the result of limited competition. Competition always brings down prices and benefits the consumer. Advertising is an essential component of a competitive marketplace.

Of course, any focus group of parents asked if they would like to see less advertising aimed at children would probably say yes. But the same group asked if they would like to see less advertising but that, as a consequence, toys would be more expensive would say no.

What we should be paying attention to, and what we in this country do pay attention to, is how best to self-regulate advertising, to make sure that vulnerable audiences aren't exploited. Advertising agencies comply with tough rules about what we can and cannot do. The regulations pay special regard to the child audience and contain provisions to ensure that children are not exposed to inappropriate commercial messages or influence.

O f course, elements of merchandising are excessive and irritating for parents. But advertising helps children to discriminate and to grow up. And, just like adults, they know, or they soon learn, that they can't automatically have what they see advertised. All of us face a range of marketing influences around which we make our choices. Children are going to be joining a commercial world. They have to learn to cope with and interpret the marketing influences that surround them.

The issue of television advertising to children will also surely be raised at the International Advertising Association congress in June. Archbishop Foley, representing the Vatican, will give his views on the power of advertising and spell out why he thinks it should be limited. I'm looking forward to hearing what he says, and giving the counter argument.

Advertising does not exist in a vacuum; it doesn't exist for its own sake, like art or religion. It's a commercial activity. If you don't like the ads, you don't have to buy the goods. Ultimate power rests with the consumer. Trying to ring-fence advertising in the way proposed is futile and would be counter-productive.

fields.headline: You're safe - for now
fields.standfirst:
Yesterday's papers were full of it (again) - the Mirror share mess which refuses to go away. Roy Greenslade reports on the board's response to the latest twists

More about the Mirror share deal scandal
fields.trailText: Another week passes in the Mirror's City Slickers scandal and there is no sign that the rest of the media will stop gnawing at the bone. The dogs have got their teeth into editor Piers Morgan and they won't let go. The biter is being bitten and joy is unconfined.
fields.body:
Another week passes in the Mirror's City Slickers scandal and there is no sign that the rest of the media will stop gnawing at the bone. The dogs have got their teeth into editor Piers Morgan and they won't let go. The biter is being bitten and joy is unconfined.

Every day a story appears, usually mentioning "a new twist" which, it is argued, will surely result in Morgan's resignation. On Wednesday I was called by BBC's Radio 5 Live and asked to "stay by a phone" because they were sure Morgan was going any minute. I said I doubted it. A couple of hours later someone called from BBC News 24 to put me "on standby." "We've heard Morgan will go tonight," the woman said breathlessly. No, I replied, that won't happen.

Even experienced print journalists were retailing rumours that the Trinity Mirror management was about to axe the editor, if somewhat reluctantly, following the latest set of revelations. "He's history," a friend told me. "Did you see yesterday's Times?"

Well, I read the Times, the Guardian, the London Evening Standard, the Daily Express, Private Eye, the Spectator, Punch, Press Gazette and, of course, the Sun. All carried reports which, to quote one, put "embattled" Morgan "under fresh pressure." I also saw yesterday's Sunday Business, Sunday Times, Observer and Mail on Sunday, all of which called Morgan's word into question.

Mirrorgate, as the Sun has dubbed it, certainly has legs. It is more than three weeks since we first heard about Morgan having bought £20,000 of shares in Viglen Technology the day before his paper tipped them.

Last week's headlines looked bad for Morgan and the confident forecasts of his doom certainly suggested he was bound to go. But where was the killer fact among the new crop of revelations - the smoking gun of Watergate fame - which would convince the Trinity Mirror board to change its mind?

It has been evidently unmoved by the fact that Morgan also bought shares in two other companies, Wiggins and Corporate Executive Search, which featured in the Slickers column. These deals had been investigated as part of the internal inquiry which cleared Morgan of misbehaviour. Following that inquiry I spoke separately to three board members, and to Morgan, and was assured that they could not find a correlation between Morgan's share-buying activities and tipping by the Slickers.

I could not imagine the directors, knowing them as well as I do, would lie to me. Nor, indeed, could they afford to lie because of the independent stock exchange inquiry, which has access to tapes of Morgan's conversations with his broker. If it finds him guilty, then it would call into question the board's probity. In the circumstances, and even allowing for their desire to keep Morgan on board, I accepted their word.

I also realised that once the Slickers - Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell -were sacked they were unlikely to keep quiet and, no matter how loyal they had been to Morgan in previous weeks, that tie was bound to loosen.

They have an axe to grind. Leaving aside the sense of humiliation at being fired in the public spotlight, they have a practical (and financial) reason to tell the world they have been treated unfairly. In order to press their claim for compensation, it is important for them to show that the editor and his senior staff were aware of their activities in buying shares and tipping them and that this was part of the Mirror culture.

According to the Express, Bhoyrul and Hipwell "are understood to have potentially damaging emails and computer print-outs which cast new light on the affair." The Guardian said that Bhoyrul's lawyers are "in possession of an email" which contradicts Morgan's version of events. Yesterday's papers, adding detail to that claim, alleged that Bhoyrul disputed Morgan's original explanation of the timing of his Viglen purchase: he bought them later than he originally said and the Slickers filed their story earlier.

This could well be true, but I understand that the board are convinced it doesn't materially alter their view that Morgan's purchase was a coincidence. As for computer records, Trinity Mirror must have checked them already and decided there is no problem.

But the affair remains a grotesque embarrassment, for Trinity and for Morgan. A critical leader in the trade magazine Press Gazette, which reflects the views of many veteran journalists including former senior Daily Mirror staff who abhor the concept of share-buying, was toned down before publication.

It has undoubtedly damaged the paper's reputation, if not among its own readers, then definitely among the chattering classes. It has become a routine joke among the journalistic community. Mirror reporters are tired of being asked whether they have any share tips. At the What the Papers Say awards last Friday, Tory leader William Hague opened his address with a remark about the affair, though it was greeted by only polite laughter.

Despite everything that's happened, the majority of the Mirror's staff are eager for Morgan to stay. I bumped into a young Mirror reporter at a function last week who said she and her colleagues were praying that the editor would keep his job. "He's irreplacable," she said.

webTitle: Wars, famine and lions - how the west views the world

fields.headline: Wars, famine and lions - how the west views the world
fields.standfirst: The past decade has seen a shocking reduction in coverage of world events. As a report takes TV companies to task,  John Vidal  asks why we are ignoring our neighbours
fields.trailText: The past decade has seen a shocking reduction in coverage of world events. As a report takes TV companies to task, John Vidal asks why we are ignoring our neighbours
fields.body:
Ten years ago, I travelled to Sudan to cover the food shortages. There in Khartoum were television crews from three British channels making very diverse programmes. Africa, it seemed, was on the map and this was reflected in documentaries, news reports and debates.

Back in Britain, the nightly TV news was dominated by the seismic political changes taking place in eastern Europe and Russia. Channel 4's Dispatches programme was airing remarkable documentaries about Tibet and the Balkans, there were peak-time programmes on the BBC about life in China and Uganda, and it wasn't hard to find major TV exposés of international factory farming and ecological injustices. In short, there was a real sense of a wider world.

It was not to last. Even as TV foreign coverage was developing a loyal audience of millions, the great hype in London media circles was how the proposed new Broadcasting Act would provide viewers with more "choice". The politicians and heads of most TV channels were arguing strongly that freeing ITV from many of its public service commitments would usher in a new era of "diversity". Only a few Cassandras warned that the competitive rush for audiences would turn British TV inward, ignoring the rest of the world.

The Cassandras have been proved correct. We almost certainly know less about what is happening in the world today than we did 10 years ago. TV hardly gives us a clue what is happening in most parts of the world, the social and economic forces shaping people's lives, how other cultures think, or are responding on political or personal levels to some of the greatest scientific, ecological, cultural and societal changes in world history.

Even as business and politics has globalised, and as more people than ever are travelling abroad, so British TV - the prime source of information about the 5bn people living in the developing world - has become more insular, shallower, more opinionated, narrower, consumer-led, less intelligent and more self-obsessed. Our world map is massively diminishing even as our ignorance is increasing.

The proof comes from a major study commissioned for Britain's leading international aid, development and environment charities. It shows how British terrestrial TV, despite having an extra channel, has wilfully abandoned coverage of the developing world in the past decade. The decline in the quantity and quality of coverage has been stark and dramatic: the total number of hours of factual programming on developing countries has declined by 50%; ITV has dropped its coverage by 74%; BBC2 by more than a third, Channel 4 by 56%. BBC 1 is increas ingly obsessed with soft wildlife and travel programmes and Channel 5, says the report, has commissioned almost nothing from non-western countries since it was set up.

The quality of coverage has shifted considerably, too, says the report done by the Third World and Environment Broadcasting Project (3WE) which was set up in 1989 by groups including Oxfam, Action Aid, the WWF, Save the Children, Voluntary Service Overseas, Christian Aid and the RSPB. At the start of the decade, a large number of factual programmes about developing countries were about human rights, the environment and development subjects - they accounted for 30% of the output. These have almost entirely been replaced by travel and wildlife programmes which, argues the report "do not offer complete portraits of the developing world".

Moreover, those few current affairs reports, international documentaries, and arts, culture and religious analysis programmes still being made are now mostly broadcast at the margins of the schedules - late night or very early in the morning. The vast majority of factual shows about poorer countries shown at peak times are now celebrity-led programmes about travel or wildlife.

These two areas have, the report suggests, become the bastion of TV's coverage from developing countries. Are they supposed to be of use to people trying to understand what is happening in the lives of 80% of the world's population? Presumably yes, as together these two categories now make up almost 60% of all programming about poor countries.

This dismal picture, says the report, acidly, begs an analysis of TV's public service value: "A disproportionate number of these types of programmes consist of either footage of animals without a broader social context or celebrities visiting resorts. Holiday-type travel programmes figure more heavily than adventure travel programmes." BBC2 and C4 are both criticised here. The figures suggest a complete reversal of programming policies by channels once regarded as the flagships for minority interest and overseas coverage but which are now widely regarded as obsessed with sex and controversy. Channel 4, notes the report, broadcast more factual programmes on developing countries at the start of the decade than BBC1 and BBC2 combined. Today this trend is reversed and C4, despite having no higher overall share of the audience slice, is now showing 100 fewer hours a year while boasting of being more diverse than ever.

The report also notes that ecological programming, a major theme of the channel's overseas factual programming in 1989, is now "virtually extinct with little effort to innovate in this area". When it did offer four hours of prime time TV to rubbish global environmentalism - in 1997's Against Nature - it was castigated by the ITC for misrepresentation. The programmes were widely attacked for being nonsensical and ignorant.

It gets worse. News programmes rely to an increasing extent on reporting disaster and conflict. Overseas current affairs coverage has declined by 38% to just 12 hours a year across all five channels. But it is religious, cultural and arts programmes which have been the hardest hit. Where these categories made up 20% of all overseas factual programming 10 years ago, today they barely exist, with just 21 hours a year across all channels. "This is a very significant reduction in an important area of programming which helps augment multicultural awareness within the UK," says the report. "In the name of choice, it appears that the British viewer is now treated to a greater amount of travel and wildlife programming with a serious diminution in other categories. There is room for much greater production innovation."

So what is happening? The report's author, Jennie Stone, says that there are many factors responsible for the dwindling level of international factual programming in the past decade. She cites diminishing budgets, the advent of new technology which allows images to be quickly and cheaply transmitted but which results in less in-depth analysis, and a changing production culture with staff more likely to move across programme genres, with less overall commitment.

She also suggests that TV has moved rapidly to invest in online and internet services with international filming being one of the first areas to have its budgets cut. Her report attacks the oft-repeated excuse that the British public is just not interested in factual programming from poor countries. "This is inadequate," she says, citing dozens of programmes over the years that have reached huge audiences.

The report concludes by calling for a reversal of most of the trends: "TV remains the primary medium through which the British public is informed about the developing world. Increasing global links are the fabric of our societies and Britain stands in a unique international position at the heart of the UN, the EU, Nato, the Group of 8, the Commonwealth and many other influential global bodies. We believe broadcasters have a key responsibility towards coverage of these links."

fields.headline: Government welcomes nuclear chief's resignation
fields.standfirst: More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText:
The government today welcomed the resignation of John Taylor,
the chief executive of British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL), after damning criticism of safety lapses at the
Sellafield reprocessing plant.
fields.body:
The government today welcomed the resignation of John Taylor,
the chief executive of British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL), after damning criticism of safety lapses at the
Sellafield reprocessing plant.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said: "I welcome John
Taylor's decision to resign. In the circumstances it was the
appropriate course of action. We can now look forward to a fresh
start at BNFL under a new chief executive."

Mr Taylor, who is expected to receive a £300,000 payoff, is the first of several heads expected to roll after
employees of the state-run firm were accused of falsifying
safety data at the plant, putting at risk contracts in Japan and
Germany. The health and safety executive issued a highly
critical report on the running of Sellafield and the nuclear
installations inspectorate accused BNFL of "systematic
management failures". BNFL admitted the lapses but insisted that
safety was never threatened.

BNFL dismissed five employees after the inspectorate found that
the company's mixed oxide (Mox) fuel plant at
Sellafield, in Cumbria, had provided false quality control measurements for
reprocessed fuel exported to Japan.

The Japanese have demanded BNFL take back the plutonium
consignments, and the government has conceded the row is a
setback to its privatisation plans. Germany's PreussenElektra
says it will seek damages from BNFL after having to shut down
one of its nuclear plants temporarily when it received false
documents accompanying Mox fuel supplies. An American campaign group is also trying to block BNFL's plans to
build a nuclear waste incinerator near Yellowstone
national park.

BNFL is expected to officially announce Mr Taylor's resignation tomorrow. Also expected to go is Chris Loughlin, who is in charge of the £1.8bn
Thorp reprocessing plant and Mox plant.

Mr Taylor was expected to take charge of government plans to sell
49% of BNFL, which employs 2,000 people. The sell-off had already been
postponed until after the election because of the bad safety
report.
fields.bodyText: The government today welcomed the resignation of John Taylor, the chief executive of British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL), after damning criticism of safety lapses at the Sellafield reprocessing plant. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said: "I welcome John Taylor's decision to resign. In the circumstances it was the appropriate course of action. We can now look forward to a fresh start at BNFL under a new chief executive." Mr Taylor, who is expected to receive a £300,000 payoff, is the first of several heads expected to roll after employees of the state-run firm were accused of falsifying safety data at the plant, putting at risk contracts in Japan and Germany. The health and safety executive issued a highly critical report on the running of Sellafield and the nuclear installations inspectorate accused BNFL of "systematic management failures". BNFL admitted the lapses but insisted that safety was never threatened. BNFL dismissed five employees after the inspectorate found that the company's mixed oxide (Mox) fuel plant at Sellafield, in Cumbria, had provided false quality control measurements for reprocessed fuel exported to Japan. The Japanese have demanded BNFL take back the plutonium consignments, and the government has conceded the row is a setback to its privatisation plans. Germany's PreussenElektra says it will seek damages from BNFL after having to shut down one of its nuclear plants temporarily when it received false documents accompanying Mox fuel supplies. An American campaign group is also trying to block BNFL's plans to build a nuclear waste incinerator near Yellowstone national park. BNFL is expected to officially announce Mr Taylor's resignation tomorrow. Also expected to go is Chris Loughlin, who is in charge of the £1.8bn Thorp reprocessing plant and Mox plant. Mr Taylor was expected to take charge of government plans to sell 49% of BNFL, which employs 2,000 people. The sell-off had already been postponed until after the election because of the bad safety report.

fields.headline: The first scalp at BNFL
fields.standfirst:
Westminster Correspondent David Hencke traces the legacy of cover-ups at the nationalised nuclear power firm
More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText: John Taylor's resignation as chief executive of British Nuclear Fuels is the first scalp for politicians and environmentalists long suspicious that the firm has been involved in safety cover-ups for decades.
fields.body:
John Taylor's resignation as chief executive of British Nuclear Fuels is the first scalp for politicians and environmentalists long suspicious that the firm has been involved in safety cover-ups for decades.

Despite attempts by groups such as Greenpeace, Friends of the Earth and the Campaign for Freedom of Information to find out what goes on behind closed doors at Sellafield, the nationalised company has always pleaded commercial secrecy to avoid telling the public what happens there. The Health and Safety Commission, which is supposed to protect the public, has been happy to go along with this code of silence.

Ironically it has taken the non-nuclear Japanese government to expose this particular scandal by proving that BNFL falsified plutonium fuel safety data on nuclear fuel exported there. Faced with proof of "systematic management failures" in a report from the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate and with a £12bn order book for reprocessed fuel from the Thorp plant at risk, the chief executive was, for once, left with little choice.

The news could not be worse for chancellor Gordon Brown and trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, who are hoping to float off part of BNFL to raise money for future tax cuts. No one is going to be very interested in the sale if the company's commercial future is not bright. It has been difficult enough to sell the reprocessed fuel - known as mox - without all this flaring up.

For workers in one of the more depressed part of the United Kingdom this is bad news indeed. With high unemployment around Workington, Whitehaven and along the coast to Barrow in Furness, Sellafield is a major employer and provides some of best paid, most hi-tech jobs available.

The workers can probably rely on former cabinet minister Jack Cunningham, the MP for Copeland, to take up their cause. A staunch supporter of the chemical and nuclear industries, Mr Cunningham is likely to use his close links with the government to press for action. Some support can also be expected from other Labour MPs in the area, notably the social services minister, John Hutton, who represents Barrow, and Dale Campbell Savours, Labour MP for Workington. The latter, however, is well known for his "zero tolerance" over cover ups - whether in MI5 or among colleagues who fail to declare their business interests to parliament - so he will need convincing.

In the meantime Mr Byers will seek to restore public confidence by proving that he can act tough. More heads could roll before the week is out in a desperate attempt to show the company is back on track. It is worth remembering, however, that BNFL's difficulties are entirely self-inflicted.

fields.headline: The office zodiac
fields.standfirst: Instead of star signs, what's your business sign?
fields.trailText: 28 February: Instead of star signs, what's your business sign?
fields.body:
Marketing: You are ambitious yet stupid. You chose a marketing degree to avoid having to study in college, concentrating instead on drinking and socializing which is pretty much what your job responsibilities are now. Least compatible with sales.
Sales: Laziest of all signs, often referred to as "marketing without a degree." You are also self centered and paranoid. Unless someone calls you and begs you to take their money, you like to avoid contact with customers so you can "concentrate on the big picture." You seek admiration for your golf game throughout your life.
Technology: Unable to control anything in your personal life, you are instead content to completely control everything that happens at your workplace. Often even you don't understand what you are saying but who can tell. It is written that Geeks shall inherit the Earth.

webTitle: English novelist wins case against Verona university

fields.headline: English novelist wins case against Verona university
fields.trailText: The English writer Tim Parks has won an epic legal battle against the Italian university whose discrimination inspired his controversial novel Europa.
fields.body:
The English writer Tim Parks has won an epic legal battle against the Italian university whose discrimination inspired his controversial novel Europa.

The University of Verona faces possible criminal prosecution for financial irregularities after being ordered to pay up to £500,000 in salary arrears to Mr Parks and five other foreign lecturers.

A Bologna court has ruled in favour of the lecturers after a 13-year legal odyssey in Italian and European courts, sparked by a cut in wages, employment rights and sackings.

Europa was short-listed for the 1997 Booker prize for its account of the misadventures of a dysfunctional, sexually predatory group of foreign-trained university lecturers travelling in a bus from Italy to Strasbourg to petition the European parliament for the rights that their Italian colleagues enjoyed.

Mr Parks, 45, hailed the ending of a "senseless" saga that pitted the former employees against the university in a venomous, draining test of will.

However, more than 1,000 other foreign lecturers, known as lettori , remain embroiled in similar legal actions against Italian universities.

The Bologna verdict upheld a decision by Italy's highest appeals court, which found that foreign lecturers were entitled to the same pay as colleagues with Italian degrees. From the late 1980s, 20 universities, including Verona's, slowly downgraded the pay and conditions of the foreign lecturers, culmi nating in mass sackings three years ago.

Mr Parks left before he was sacked, but is believed to be owed almost £100,000 in entitlements. Verona has also been ordered to pay costs, which lawyers will this week calculate.

Potentially even graver for Verona was the decision of the magistrate, Cristina Astraldi de Zorzi, to recommend an inquiry into 10 areas of its finances. A leaked copy of her report alleged that there were inconsistencies in income and spending records, as well as the drawing up of contracts Mario Marigo, Verona's dean at the time, has denied this.

David Petrie, the Scottish president of Italy's association of lettori , said the ruling would help those lecturers with pending cases. "It will have a big impact," he said.

Most of Mr Parks's former colleagues have been unable to find new jobs in Italy. Paul Hyde, who taught English history and literature, said he was relieved by the latest ruling, but doubted he would see his estimated £100,000 soon.

"I hear that the university is nearly broke. It has spent so much on legal fees I'd be surprised if there is all that much left," he said. "It's been a torturous process; it's beyond credibility. Universities here are not institutions for education, they are power bases for other purposes. You couldn't make it up."

Overcrowding, underfunding, nepotistic appointments and corrupt exam practices are blamed for Italy having one of the lowest proportion of graduates in Europe, at 8.1%.

fields.trailText: Opta Soccer Robbie Fowler will join Leeds in the wake of Emile Heskey's signing for Liverpool - the Anfield club are said to be making an official £10m bid for the Leicester player.
fields.body:
Opta Soccer Robbie Fowler will join Leeds in the wake of Emile Heskey's signing for Liverpool - the Anfield club are said to be making an official £10m bid for the Leicester player.

Middlesbrough have made an approach to Arsenal regarding Stephen Hughes. The 23-year-old midfielder, who would cost £3m, does not figure in Arsene Wenger's plans and would be prepared to join Boro for the promise of first team football.

Tottenham are interested in Bordeaux striker Lilian Laslandes and Wimbledon front-man John Hartson.

Thomas Helveg, AC Milan's mifielder and right wing back, is a target for Chelsea and Tottenham.

Manchester United are set to make an £3.6m offer for Feyenoord's Polish international goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek. If the bid fails, expect Alex Ferguson to turn his attentions to Wimbledon's Neil Sullivan.

Daily Star Tony Adams will follow Alan Shearer into international retirement after Euro 2000.

webTitle: Neighbours fear that, after Chechnya, they are next

fields.headline: Neighbours fear that, after Chechnya, they are next
fields.standfirst:
Kremlin troops are pounding Chechen rebels nearby. The west is making stern noises. Georgia is very nervous

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Kremlin troops are pounding Chechen rebels nearby. The west is making stern noises. Georgia is very nervous
fields.body:
More than 10,000ft up in the forbidding, snowbound Caucasus mountains where southern Chechnya presses against Georgia, a high-risk confrontation is being played out between Russian paratroopers, Georgian border guards, and Chechen guerrillas.

For the several thousand Chechen guerrillas involved, it's a fight for sheer winter survival against the firepower and manpower deployed by the Kremlin; for the Russians, it's a no-holds-barred chance to destroy the Chechen resistance; for the Georgian border guards, the frontline keeps the Chechen war from invading their country.

A spillover into Georgia would threaten the young post-Soviet country's fragile independence and territorial integrity, worsen its tense relations with Moscow and trigger diplomatic and strategic dilemmas that could reach far beyond the Caucasus.

The Russians are angry, the guerrillas are desperate, the Georgians are alarmed, and the US is frightened that Georgia will be dragged into the Chechen conflict, said a western diplomat in Tbilisi. "You have all the ingredients for an explosive situation."

"The Russians", a senior Georgian official said, "want to move the conflict into Georgia".

Bowing to months of pressure from Moscow, the Georgian president, Eduard Shevardnadze, who was the Soviet Union's last foreign minister, ordered the 50-mile border with Chechnya and Russia sealed last week - an impossible task.

It is extremely inhospitable territory, with only one road at the crossing point of Shatili, the route linking Tbilisi with the destroyed Chechen capital, Grozny. But there are almost three dozen other footpaths across a frontier that cannot be comprehensively patrolled.

The Russians constantly contend that the Chechens are ferrying men, arms and supplies over the mountains, and they accuse Georgia of harbouring guerrilla training camps. Tbilisi dismisses this as nonsense, provocation and an example of Moscow seeking pretexts for a possible intervention.

Mr Shevardnadze, who has led Georgia for seven years and expects to be re-elected for another five in April, has so far resisted Russian demands to station troops on the Georgian side of the border. But Russian troops already stationed at four bases inside Georgia outnumber the Georgian army.

Last November, the Russians agreed to close two of the bases by next year, but Tbilisi is not holding its breath - the air is thick with mistrust.

"We can't see how these bases are needed," said a Georgian official. "But the Russians are not serious [about closing them]." The Chechen war is now concentrated 10 miles from the border of Georgia, a small but strategically vital country of 5.5m.

Nine unarmed monitors from the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe have been warily watch ing the standoff at the Shatili crossing point since taking up their posts 10 days ago.

"The situation is tense but stable," said a source, adding that any unauthorised movement across the border was "immediately destroyed" by the Russians.

The monitors can hear the constant bombing and shelling from the Russian onslaught on Chechen rebel redoubts. Seeking to advance up the Argun valley to take the last rebel stronghold of Shatoi, the Russians have thousands of guerrillas hemmed in, their backs to the Georgian border and Russian paratroopers.

The Kremlin claimed yesterday that its troops had thwarted an attempt by the Chechen rebels to break out across the border into Georgia - precisely the scenario the Georgians fear. But as spring nears and the fighters become more mobile, there is little doubt they will be heading for Georgia.

There is already a native Chechen community of 5,000 living compactly in the Georgian mountains. It has been swollen by 7,000 refugees from the war.

"You have a base, you have a guerrilla movement and you have a porous border," says the senior western official. "It's a Palestinian situation. And another big bone of contention for Georgia."

Mr Shevardnadze, 77, appears to be about the only thing preventing the small, feuding country from drifting towards its own implosion.

Georgia has yet to recover from two separatist wars by the regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia in the past eight years.

There are 300,000 refugees from Abkhazia living in Georgia - two-thirds of the population from the breakaway region, which remains a no-go area for Georgians. The country's ancient infrastructure is groaning under the growing strain; Tbilisi is subject to power cuts every day.

And with the economy a mess, almost every Georgian family depends on a remittance of equalling about £60 a month from the half-million Georgians working in Russia. But employing his leverage, Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, is stepping up threats to impose a visa regime on Georgians in or travelling to Russia.

Georgia is also central to US plans to exploit the oil and gas riches of the Caspian basin, and Mr Shevardnadze talks optimistically of Georgia joining Nato. Officials from the region, Russia, the US and Turkey are expected in Tbilisi within weeks to discuss plans for a Caucasus "stability pact", modelled on western policy in the Balkans.

The idea was mooted in Tbilisi two weeks ago by President Suleyman Demirel of Turkey, Georgia's southern neighbour, and Russia's traditional rival for influence in the Caucasus.

Moscow is sceptical, seeing Turkey as a proxy for US scheming in the region.

However, Mr Putin is sending an envoy to Ankara today with a message for President Demirel. "The western countries now support Georgia actively," Mr Putin said.

In Tbilisi last week, Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, stressed western support for Georgia's "three Is: independence, integrity [territorial], and integration into euro-Atlantic structures".

All three factors, Tbilisi fears, are being tested at the mountain border.

webTitle: Mowlam denies Blair U-turn on GM foods

fields.headline: Mowlam denies Blair U-turn on GM foods
fields.standfirst: The OECD conference online
fields.trailText: The cabinet office minister, Mo Mowlam, told a conference on the safety of genetically modified foods today that the government's position on GM crops was unchanged, despite an apparent U-turn by the prime minister, Tony Blair, yesterday.
fields.body:
The cabinet office minister, Mo Mowlam, told a conference on the safety of genetically modified foods today that the government's position on GM crops was unchanged, despite an apparent U-turn by the prime minister, Tony Blair, yesterday.

"Our position has remained consistent," she told delegates at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) summit in Edinburgh. In an article in the Independent on Sunday, Mr Blair had said there was "no doubt that there is potential for harm". Ms Mowlam said: "What we have always said is that there are potential harmful effects. There is always an element of risk.

"What is important in this issue is that the public have knowledge of the risks. We hope that by labelling and the research being done that that will be the case."

The summit, which is being paid for by the government, is chaired by Sir John Krebs, who is also chairman of the new Food Standards Agency.

Experts on GM technology, as well as pressure groups such as Friends of the Earth and Greenpeace, hope the conference will tackle the environmental implications of GM crops as well as dietary concerns.

Sir John said he did not expect consensus in the three-day talks, but wanted to hear a diversity of views. "It is the first attempt to draw together people from around the world in an inclusive debate about genetically modified food," he said.

He added that debate on GM foods had become fragmented and needed to focus on the scientific evidence. Ms Mowlam backed this view and said the OECD had worked hard to get every view included.

"There is about one-third for and one-third who are anti-GM," she said. "I hope we have done our best to make sure all views are represented."

Later in the morning, the conference heard a call for biotechnology companies to ban so-called "terminator" crops.

Surman Sahai, president of the Indian Gene Campaign, told delegates that these crops cannot reproduce, forcing farmers to buy new seed every year and thereby discriminating against third world farmers.

She added that GM firms such as Monsanto had to end a culture of secrecy surrounding the use of genetically modified crops in poorer countries. "One of the problems in India is that field tests were not transparent," she said. "The farmers in the region were not told what was happening."

A lack of openness would mean a backlash against GM crops which Ms Sahai said offered some solutions to the food problems of less-developed countries. "Those of us in the developing world cannot understand sterile technologies," she said, referring to the inability of these seeds to reproduce.

"If it is going to threaten our self-reliance in food production, if our self-reliance in agriculture is threatened, it is clear we will not accept these technologies."

In another development, Friends of the Earth said that the Welsh assembly was considering blocking the sale of the first GM seed in the UK.

On Wednesday, the rural affairs committee will debate whether to place the seed, developed by Aventis (formerly AgrEvo) on the national list, the first regulatory hurdle before seeds can be grown commercially.

FoE biotechnology campaigner Pete Riley said: "The government's decision to devolve decision-making powers to the Welsh assembly could scupper plans to commercialise GM crops."

fields.headline: Passport pets enter UK
fields.trailText: A five-year-old pug dog has become the                                                                    first animal to enter Britain using a pet                                                                    passport.
fields.body:
A five-year-old pug dog has become the first animal to enter Britain using a pet passport.

Frodo Baggins travelled from Calais in France to Dover on a cross-channel ferry with owner Helen de Borchgrave, of London, to take advantage of the relaxation in Britain's century-old quarantine regulations.

After passing without incident through immigration checks at the French port with a passport, the black dog boarded a P&O Stena Line ferry in the French port with his owner and arrived in Dover as the first animal to use the new pet passport scheme.

Ms de Borchgrave said: "He is a very happy dog. Frodo loved the Continent and will be going back soon. Its great that I don't have to leave him behind anymore."

Meanwhile three Labradors, Amber, Bodie and Chester, are expected to arrive at Dover within hours by hovercraft. Then, the first train carrying pets is due to arrive at Folkestone via the channel tunnel.

Claude the basset hound and Ximo the Rhodesian ridgeback will be among a band of pets travelling by rail under the new scheme.

Ms de Borchgrave said the pet passports scheme will allow her to avoid the heartbreak of leaving her dog behind when she travels for work.

She spends four or five months a year in Europe for her work as an oil painting and fine art restorer, and as an art lecturer.

Ms de Borchgrave said in the past she has been forced to leave her dog with friends, as she would not put him in quarantine.

"He has never been able to travel with me before, as I think quarantine is cruel. Rather than lose him for six months I have left him behind in the past."

Cats and dogs are the only ones to benefit from the one-year pilot scheme, which is set to be extended if there is no rabies outbreak.

Under the scheme, animals from 22 countries in western Europe will be able to skip quarantine if their owners can prove they are free from the disease. Next year it is expected to be extended to the United States, Canada and the Caribbean. Qualifying pets must also be treated against ticks and tapeworms and must not have strayed from the qualifying European zone in the past six months. Rabies, once the subject of major health campaigns, has grown far rarer and there has not been a scare since 1975 when a Sussex woman was bitten by a bat. Mainland Europe reports fewer than 10 cases of human rabies a year.

Claude the basset hound and Ximo the Rhodesian ridgeback will be among a band of pets travelling by rail under the new scheme. Ms de Borchgrave said the pet passports scheme will allow her to avoid the heartbreak of leaving her dog behind when she travels for work. She spends four or five months a year in Europe for her work as an oil painting and fine art restorer, and as an art lecturer. Ms de Borchgrave said in the past she has been forced to leave her dog with friends, as she would not put him in quarantine. "He has never been able to travel with me before, as I think quarantine is cruel. Rather than lose him for six months I have left him behind in the past." Cats and dogs are the only ones to benefit from the one-year pilot scheme, which is set to be extended if there is no rabies outbreak. Under the scheme, animals from 22 countries in western Europe will be able to skip quarantine if their owners can prove they are free from the disease. Next year it is expected to be extended to the United States, Canada and the Caribbean. Qualifying pets must also be treated against ticks and tapeworms and must not have strayed from the qualifying European zone in the past six months. Rabies, once the subject of major health campaigns, has grown far rarer and there has not been a scare since 1975 when a Sussex woman was bitten by a bat. Mainland Europe reports fewer than 10 cases of human rabies a year.

fields.headline: Genetically modified foods
fields.standfirst: Prime minister Tony Blair has acknowledged "legitimate public  concern" about GM foods.  Mark Tran traces the change in government attitude.
fields.trailText:
How did the prime minister announce the new line?
In an article in the Independent on Sunday. He wrote: "There's no doubt that there is potential for harm, both in terms of human safety and in the diversity of our environment, from GM foods and crops." A year ago, Mr Blair was urging people to "resist the tyranny of pressure groups" amid public alarm over research showing that rats fed GM potatoes suffered damage to their vital organs and weakened immune systems. Ministers rallied around Mr Blair. John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and other ministers signed a letter laying down the party line on GM foods. It said: "We are confident that the GM products currently on sale are safe."
fields.body:
How did the prime minister announce the new line?
In an article in the Independent on Sunday. He wrote: "There's no doubt that there is potential for harm, both in terms of human safety and in the diversity of our environment, from GM foods and crops." A year ago, Mr Blair was urging people to "resist the tyranny of pressure groups" amid public alarm over research showing that rats fed GM potatoes suffered damage to their vital organs and weakened immune systems. Ministers rallied around Mr Blair. John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and other ministers signed a letter laying down the party line on GM foods. It said: "We are confident that the GM products currently on sale are safe."

Has the government admitted the U-turn?
No, Downing Street insists policy has not changed. Cabinet office minister Mo Mowlam today said that government policy has remained consistent. But environmental groups who have been critical of GM foods think the government has changed tack. "At long last, Mr Blair is listening to the public who have made it perfectly clear that they don't want GM food on their plates," said Charles Secrett, executive director of Friends of the Earth.

Why has the government changed its tune?
The government has come under huge public pressure, with papers from the Guardian to the Mail voicing concern on the issue. Supermarkets, farmers and biotech companies have all backed away from GM foods. The world's biggest producers of genetically modified crops are planning to sharply reduce their planting this year. Farmers in the US, Canada and Argentina are expected to reduce plantings of GM crops by 20% to 25%, according to Worldwatch, the US environmental group. The reductions are being attributed to concern among farmers that their produce will not sell. Iceland, the British supermarket, banned GM food from its own-label products and found an increase in sales. Other supermarkets followed.

What happened to Monsanto, the US biotech giant?
The firm decided to change its name because it had become synonymous with GM foods. The beleaguered American biotech company is merging with the US-Swiss drugs group Pharmacia & Upjohn to form a $50bn corporation known as Pharmacia. Only an autonomous agricultural subsidiary will continue to use the Monsanto name.

What about allegations that the US put pressure on the government to support GM foods?
Environmental groups have been particularly vocal in accusing Mr Blair of bowing to US pressure to allow testing of GM crops. In the latest incident of arm-twisting, the Guardian reports that President Bill Clinton put pressure on Mr Blair to open up Britain and Europe to American GM foods during private talks at the Downing Street summit of 1998. Within 24 hours, Britain had acted to modify proposals to try and open the way for more GM food to be sold in Britain and the rest of the EU.

Has GM crop-testing stopped in the UK?
No. The government has resisted pressure to declare a moratorium on GM crop trials and the latest tests are due to start Wednesday. But the biotechnology industry is having trouble finding enough farmers to take part.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Bad news for Grisham fans, Bertolucci to sponsor Critics' Week, and, on the casting couch, Penelope Cruz, Will Smith, Alfred Molina, Rachael Leigh Cook, Helena Bonham Carter, and Lynn Redgrave
fields.body:
 Some bad news for John Grisham fans, some good news for the rest of us. The best-selling writer has stated in a lecture at Baylor University in Waco, Texas that he has no further plans to adapt any of his novels into films because Hollywood doesn't have the book's best interest at heart. Grisham has reportedly called The Chamber a "horrible adaptation".

 Bernardo Bertolucci has agreed to become the first sponsor of the International Critics' Week (May 11-19) at this year's Cannes Film Festival. The director will also host a workshop in which he will debate film issues with selected Critics' Week directors. Bertolucci's film, Before the Revolution, which made his name in the Critics' Week in 1964, will be screened again at this year's festival.

Casting Couch

 Penelope Cruz who wowed audiences with her performance in the highly-acclaimed All About My Mother is to join Nic Cage in an adaptation of the best-selling world war two romance, Captain Corelli's Mandolin. Cruz will play Pelagia, the Greek girl who is torn between two men in this John Madden-directed epic set during the Italian occupation of the Greek island of Cephalonia. Shooting starts on May 22 in Greece.

 Will Smith is in talks to play the lead in Phone Booth. Not as Superman, but as man who answers a random call in a phone booth and ends up the target of a sniper. No director is attached, but that should quickly change once Smith climbs aboard.

 British star made big in Hollywood, Alfred Molina, is to star with Johnny Depp and Juliette Binoche in Chocolat, a romantic comedy directed by Cider House Rules helmer, Lasse Hallstrom. Molina will play the Comte de Reynaud, a highly-strung nobleman and leader of a small town whose control over the populace is compromised by their patronage of a chocolate shop opened by a woman (Binoche).

 Rachael Leigh Cook has signed to star in a love triangle called Conspiracy. Cook will play the object of two men's complicated affections. Jay Lowi will direct and shooting is scheduled for May.

 Helena Bonham Carter will co-star with Steve Martin and Kevin Bacon in a black comedy called Novocaine. She will play Martin's patient who pulls his comfortable dentist's life into a spiral when she seduces him. No director is yet attached but shooting is scheduled to begin in the spring.

 Lynn Redgrave and Richard Harris are in negotiations to star in My Kingdom, an indie tale of power, ambition and greed in a contemporary Liverpool family, scripted by Don Boyd and The Guardian's Nick Davies. Harris will play a gangland leader who finds himself embroiled in a family struggle with his daughters when a tragic event causes him to relinquish control over his underworld kingdom. Production is set to begin in May.

fields.headline: Battle over Blair Witch town
fields.trailText: The inhabitants of Burkittsville, Maryland, where The Blair Witch Project was shot, have said they do not want the film crew back again
fields.body:
The inhabitants of Burkittsville, Maryland, where The Blair Witch Project was shot, have said they do not want the film crew back again.

At a meeting with the sequel's director Joe Berlinger, an ex-councilman, Sam Brown, declared that the sleepy hamlet - population less than 200 - had been "raped" by unwanted fans who had vandalised gravestones and stolen town property as souvenirs in the wake of the phenomenally successful indie sleeper. Brown, along with other residents, claimed that the sequel would turn the townsfolk into "prostitutes" and demanded that the producers think again. He seems to have succeeded in getting what he wants. According to Michael Styer, director of the Maryland Film Office, the Blair Witch 2 producers wanted to feature the town, but a "minority of citizens made it clear they would be 'inhospitable' to the project."

The whole episode is proving rather embarrassing for the townês mayor. Joyce Brown is keen for Berlinger to film in Burkittsville but it is her husband, the aforementioned Sam, who is behind the "broomsticks out" campaign. She says she has faxed a letter and left numerous messages for the producers at Blair Redux Productions, Inc. regretting her failure for not having stopped the town meeting, but her apologies donêt seem to have cut much ice with the battle-weary producers. In an interview with USA Today Styer says, "Since limited shooting was scheduled for the town and the scenes were generic enough to be duplicated elsewhere in Maryland, it was decided by [the filmmakers] that it was not worth spending any more time trying to make it in Burkittsville."

When they do find a location for the top-secret sequel, director Berlinger, famous for his award-winning documentaries, Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hill and Brother's Keeper, hopes to start filming straightaway in time for a Halloween release this year. A planned prequel by original co-directors Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez should be ready for summer 2001.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
 Jon Katz (who last week provoked a big online debate with an article on the future of the press). An extract is published below www.slashdot.org

Are newspapers over? At this moment in media history, they have never been more pressed to define themselves, or done a worse job. All over the information spectrum, media audiences are fragmented, drawn to the timeliness, convenience and immediacy of cable news, and the net and the web.

The challenge for newspapers isn't technological. It's creative. They don't tell us things we don't know. They don't offer us good writing or strong opinion. They don't even have good comics any more. And their coverage of technology generally sucks. And profoundly so. They still don't recognise that the net is not a sex story or a business story but the biggest story of our time.

In recent years, newspapers have remained graphically impaired. They seem oblivious to the graphic revolution that has swept magazines and is spreading through the web. Papers continue to cover new media technologies and popular culture poorly, alienating young and future audiences. They have ceded good writing to magazines, publishing and websites.

Papers seem seem almost stupefyingly oblivious to the fact that they aren't in the breaking news business anymore. As the net and web spawn ferocious and idiosyncratic commentary, democratising opinion all over the country, newspapers cling to stuffy and elitist op-ed pages, where opinion is generally confined to a "left" and "right" and voice usually given to elite cliques of pundits, academics, authors and chief executives.

Technology is spawning a host of significant issues of relevance to almost everyone. How many of these stories make their way to the front pages of newspapers? Few, and then rarely. Newspapers are the scolds of the Digital Age, shrieking and clucking about a changing world (the net, the web, movies, TV shows, rap, hip-hop, kids today) like Temperance Ladies wandering into a bar.

Newspapers are also struggling to evolve definitions of culture, leisure time, recreation and amusement. Opera, classical music, hard cover books, art museums are one kind of culture. But there are new kinds - elaborate and creative gaming and video cultures, creative coding, the booming business of web architecture and design, proliferating weblogs , vast messaging systems and services like AIM and ICQ, collaborative global information-and-software sharing movements like Linux.

Few newspaper readers have even heard about these new kinds of culture. No wonder kids - especially geek and nerd kids - have abandoned papers in droves.

fields.headline: Picking the name out of a hat
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we talk to a county cricketer about what he's been up to in the close season. This week Northamptonshire wicketkeeper David Ripley takes the hotseat
fields.trailText: David Ripley, 33, is Northamptonshire's wicketkeeper. He made his debut in 1984 and 13 years later was voted Northants's Player of the Year, taking 30 catches, 6 stumpings and averaging 42. In each of the last two seasons, he has helped a team-mate to a triple-century - he put on 401 for the sixth wicket with Mal Loye (322*) against Glamorgan in 1998, and 293 for the seventh wicket with David Sales (303*) against Essex in 1999. In his spare time he enjoys a pint of bitter.
fields.body:
David Ripley, 33, is Northamptonshire's wicketkeeper. He made his debut in 1984 and 13 years later was voted Northants's Player of the Year, taking 30 catches, 6 stumpings and averaging 42. In each of the last two seasons, he has helped a team-mate to a triple-century - he put on 401 for the sixth wicket with Mal Loye (322*) against Glamorgan in 1998, and 293 for the seventh wicket with David Sales (303*) against Essex in 1999. In his spare time he enjoys a pint of bitter.

"During the winter I am the cricket development officer for Northants. I had been doing the job fairly informally for a while, but I've been official for the last two years. Neil Foster was the development officer here before me, and when he left, the job was split in two - I work with the grass roots while David Capel is more on the excellence side. David is full-time and I'll be joining him once my playing years are up. I've been on one-year contracts for a while; I'm just playing it by ear each season.

My job is to get as wide a range of people as possible playing and enjoying cricket, and to try and bring them up to a level where they fall within David's remit. It is a wide brief. I've gone into lots of schools and we've done a lot to raise the profile of ladies' cricket. Some of my most enjoyable sessions have been the two or three I've done with disability schools. It is a learning process - I am very confident about delivering the cricket coaching but other things, like grants and funding, are a bit alien.

One of my favourite parts of the job is working with new coaches. Lots of Northants players have qualified - Tony Penberthy, Toby Bailey, Jason Brown and David Sales. Rob Bailey has been helping us out a bit too, even though he is moving to Derbyshire.

I wish it was only a five-days-a-week job. I have two boys - Joe, ten, and George, five, and another due on March 3. It would be nice to spend a bit more time with them. We did manage to get away, though, in October to the Canary Islands. We haven't thought of a name yet for the baby: we're clashing a bit so I think we might just end up picking the name out of a hat.

I spend a bit of my spare time watching Leeds United. I try to catch a game whenever I go up to visit my parents, who still live in Leeds. I also love rugby, and Northampton County Cricket Club has got a good rapport with Northampton Rugby Club. Matt Dawson, the England captain, and Ian McGeechan [the Lions coach] have spoken to us about drills and communication skills. We really enjoyed it.

We're on seven-month contracts now at Northants, so we report back on March 1. We go on a pre-season tour to Grenada a few weeks later, playing Grenada, the Windward Isles and a West Indies Masters XI. I'm looking forward to it - I last went to the West Indies with Young England in 1984-85."

David Ripley was talking to Tanya Aldred.

fields.headline: Portillo softens euro opposition
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo yesterday softened his opposition to the European single currency when he denied that he was a "never man" who would rule out British membership under all circumstances.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo yesterday softened his opposition to the European single currency when he denied that he was a "never man" who would rule out British membership under all circumstances.

In a move which will be seized upon by Labour, the shadow chancellor said that the Conservatives had to keep open the option of joining the euro because they could not predict what would happen in the future.

"We are allowing for the possibility that someone can come up with solutions to problems [with the euro]," Mr Portillo told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost. "I wouldn't say I'm a never man. We can't see forever and a day."

Mr Portillo, who since his appointment as shadow chancellor has made a habit of reversing key Tory economic policies, insisted that he stood by William Hague's pledge to oppose the euro for the lifetime of the next parliament.

"We will look at what happens in the course of the next parliament," he said. "We'll be prepared to be convinced [though] I've no idea whether we will be."

Mr Portillo signalled that he is moving away from his earlier belief that the single currency should be opposed in principle. This is likely to fuel speculation that he is once again at odds with Mr Hague.

At the launch of his Keep the Pound campaign earlier this month, the Tory leader indicated that he could never envisage joining the euro because European interest rates would be "nearly always wrong for us".

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will today step up the government's attacks on the Tories' euroscepticism when he throws his weight behind Britain in Europe's campaign, Out of Europe Out of Work.

The Tories have reacted angrily to the campaign, saying that the pro-Europeans have created a false impression that Mr Hague wants to withdraw from the European Union.

However, John Redwood, the former shadow cabinet minister, said yesterday that staunch opponents of the EU should feel at home in the Conservative party.

Mr Redwood told GMTV: "William Hague needs to draw a coalition of voters together, those who want to pull out of the EU altogether and those who wish to stay in for the trade and the friendship but not all of the other things that are on offer."

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will today step up the government's attacks on the Tories' euroscepticism when he throws his weight behind Britain in Europe's campaign, Out of Europe Out of Work. The Tories have reacted angrily to the campaign, saying that the pro-Europeans have created a false impression that Mr Hague wants to withdraw from the European Union. However, John Redwood, the former shadow cabinet minister, said yesterday that staunch opponents of the EU should feel at home in the Conservative party. Mr Redwood told GMTV: "William Hague needs to draw a coalition of voters together, those who want to pull out of the EU altogether and those who wish to stay in for the trade and the friendship but not all of the other things that are on offer."

fields.headline: The best prison guard scene
fields.standfirst: The Greenmile
fields.trailText: The Greenmile
fields.body:
Death Row custodians Paul Edgecomb (Tom Hanks), Dean Stanton (Barry Pepper) and Brutus Howell (David Morse) stand anxiously in the former's office. Suddenly Howell points to the corner of the room.

"Right there."

A mouse scuttles out from under a locked iron door and heads right for them. Stanton looks bemused.

"It ain't normal for a mouse to come up on people this way. Maybe it's rabid."

Edgecomb's brow furrows.

"Could be."

"The big mouse expert", Howell scoffs. "You see him foaming at the mouth, mouse man?"

Stanton peers at the rodent.

"I don't see its mouth at all."

Howell produces a biscuit.

"Oh no", Stanton exclaims. "We'll be hip-deep in mice..."

"I want to see what it'll do."

He places the biscuit on the floor. The mouse runs up, happily gnaws through it, then retreats back under the door.

"He's going in the damn restraint room. And you just know he's chewing the padding out of the walls..."

"Alright", Edgecomb sighs. "Let's go and get the damn mouse."

See also: Face/Off, Kiss Of The Spider Woman, Porridge

Don't see also: Sleepers

webTitle: Extra £120m to woo nurses to NHS

fields.headline: Extra £120m to woo nurses to NHS
fields.trailText: The government is to spend an extra £120m on training nurses and midwives as part of a radical overhaul of pay and work structures in the health service.
fields.body:
The government is to spend an extra £120m on training nurses and midwives as part of a radical overhaul of pay and work structures in the health service.

One thousand additional nursing and midwife training places will be created as part of a massive recruitment drive for all staff in the NHS, health secretary Alan Milburn said today.

Figures released today showed that the total number of nurses working in the NHS increased by 4,500 to 304,560 last year. Mr Milburn, one of the government's most ardent modernisers, said: "No one should doubt my determination to sweep away the structures that stand in the way of modernisation that patient care demands."

An overhaul of the NHS is one of the government's top priorities after a series of critical reports detailing the shortage of beds and high level of infections from hospital stays. Public opinion polls repeatedly show that voters are dissatisfied with the state of the NHS, especially delays in treatment. Prime minister Tony Blair recently pledged to spend more money on the NHS although his handlers later downgraded that promise to an "aspiration".

"Modernising the workforce, modernising ways of working, modernising training and education, modernising pay and employment. These are the key steps we are taking towards a new health service and a new care system," Mr Milburn said.

The health secretary said he planned to expand the number of nurses, doctors and consultants and create a national pay framework. New standards also would be introduced later this year to judge every NHS body on job flexibility offered to staff, including family-friendly practices and modernised training.

"It is time to free the managers and clinicians that want to modernise services locally from the structures that have impeded change nationally," Mr Milburn said.

But Liam Fox, the opposition spokesman on health, dismissed Mr Milburn's statement. "The real problem in nursing lies not in recruitment but in retention," he said. "The government needs to address the problems of inflexible shift patterns, low staff morale and an ever-increasing burden of paperwork, which is resulting in nurses being used as clerks rather than doing what they set out to do, namely caring for patients."

fields.headline: Nuclear chief likely to quit
fields.standfirst: More about the British nuclear industry
fields.trailText: John Taylor, the chief executive of the troubled British Nuclear Fuels company is expected to resign on Tuesday,      nine days after a devastating report from the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate     attacking management failures at every level in the company.
fields.body:
John Taylor, the chief executive of the troubled British Nuclear Fuels company is expected to resign on Tuesday, nine days after a devastating report from the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate attacking management failures at every level in the company.

Mr Taylor, was in Japan at the time the report was published, and appeared in no mood to resign but the pressure from ministers for changes appeared to have forced his hand. He is expected to get a pay off of £300,000.

The chairman, Hugh Collom, appointed only last October had been given two months to reorganise the company by the government but the strength of the inspectorate's criticism took ministers by surprise.

Laurence Williams, the NII chief inspector said "Its no use sacking a few production workers. Responsibility must start at the top."

He was referring to the fact that five workers at the plutonium and uranium mixed oxide fuel plant (mox) had been dismissed for falsifying documents on fuel destined for Japan. Since then it has emerged that more documents covering fuel sent to Germany was also falsified further damaging the company's reputation.

Also expected to go is Chris Loughlin, in charge of both the giant £1.8 billion Thorp reprocessing plant and the MOX plant. There will be a shake up of the whole management structure at Sellafield and it would be a surprise if more heads did not roll.

Mr Taylor, who came from the oil giant Exxon, had a good reputation but the nuclear inspectors criticised the company for putting business considerations before safety. They said the standard of safety at the giant Sellafield works in Cumbria was "only just tolerable."

If widespread management changes were not implemented in two months the inspectorate said they would move to close the money making reprocessing works to force the company's hand.

Mr Taylor had been expected to mastermind the government's plan to sell off 49 per cent of the state owned BNFL company which employs 20,000 people.

It had already been postponed until after the election because of the adverse safety report. Now it may never happen since the company has lost so much business in last few weeks.

fields.headline: Faking it
fields.standfirst: Paris shows its diversity
fields.trailText: The fashion circus moved to Paris yesterday for the final leg of the month-long     calendar of autumn/winter 2000 shows, which run until next Saturday.
fields.body:
The fashion circus moved to Paris yesterday for the final leg of the month-long calendar of autumn/winter 2000 shows, which run until next Saturday.

An increasingly tight schedule meant that many Britons had flown straight from Milan after Giorgio Armani's presentation on Saturday evening.

While Milan is generally regarded as the city where next season's big trends are thrown up, Paris is at the true heart of fashion. The home of classic labels like Chanel, Dior and Lacroix, the eight-day schedule is an inspiring mix of tradition and innovation that plays host to a breadth of talent no other city can equal.

Yohji Yamamoto presented a collection of loose, unstructured clothes that are wrapped around the body to create a voluminous silhouette. The collection had an Eskimo feel and used a mix of real hides and fake fur. Long suede dresses came with raw edges and overly long arms, while padded coats had straggly fake fur collars. There were also faded paisley pattern skirts and high-necked jackets which came with gently quilted sleeves. Few of these outlandish pieces will make it to the shop floor, but they expressed Yamamoto's abstract vision and proved how diverse Paris fashion can be.

Hermes, by contrast, is a label in the traditional mode with a heritage going back to 1837, when Thierry Hermes started making leather goods. Yesterday's show had an equestrian feel, although there were no clothes to frighten the horses. The Hermes woman is one who epitomises discreet elegance: clothes are super-expensive but only advertise this through their luxurious quality rather than with any obvious branding. Suede wraparound skirts, loose-fitting fur gilets and thick cashmere polo necks were all worn with flat leather riding boots, in a colour palate of cream, grey and black. Since Belgian designer Martin Margiela took over at the helm, Hermes has found favour with a younger crowd, who regard his subtly monogrammed trainer as the pinnacle of designer street chic. At around £290, it is unlikely to have the mass appeal of Nike or Reebok, which is why it is so desirable.

webTitle: Boy blown from 250ft cliff in gale survives fall

fields.headline: Boy blown from 250ft cliff in gale survives fall
fields.trailText: An 11-year-old boy survived yesterday after he was blown over the edge of a 250ft     cliff during a gale.
fields.body:
An 11-year-old boy survived yesterday after he was blown over the edge of a 250ft cliff during a gale.

The boy, who was last night being treated for serious back injuries, had been walking with his parents on Boulby cliff near Skinningrove, Cleveland. Inspector Peter Gdaniec, of Cleveland police, said: "He is still being assessed, but this looks like an amazing escape."

The boy, who is from Middlesbrough but has not been named, was taken to Middlesbrough general hospital by helicopter. He was later transferred to South Cleveland hospital. His injuries are not thought to be life-threatening.

Mark Vickery, the RAF helicopter's winchman, said he was surprised that the boy had survived. He added: "He had told his parents that he did not want to walk any more so his dad gave him the car keys and said they would see him back at the car. They turned around moments later and he had disappeared."

fields.headline: De Silva shines again
fields.trailText: Aravinda de Silva celebrated his return to the Sri Lankan side with his 18th Test century yesterday as the visitors compiled a decisive lead over Pakistan on the second day of the first match in Rawalpindi.
fields.body:
Aravinda de Silva celebrated his return to the Sri Lankan side with his 18th Test century yesterday as the visitors compiled a decisive lead over Pakistan on the second day of the first match in Rawalpindi.

Sri Lanka closed at 290 for eight, 108 runs ahead, after the old firm of De Silva and the former captain Arjuna Ranatunga - who both missed Sri Lanka's most recent series against Zimbabwe - added 129 for the fifth wicket.

The 34-year-old De Silva was in an unusually stoic mood, taking 246 balls to reach his century. He was well supported by Mahela Jayawardene, who scored a quickfire 42 from 52 balls, and Ranatunga, whose patient 49 ended when he inside-edged Abdur Razzaq on to his stumps.

Razzaq trapped Romesh Kaluwitharana leg-before with his next delivery, but Pakistan - fresh from a 3-0 series whitewash by Australia - had already lost the initiative. They received more bad news with the revelation that Wasim Akram, who bowled only 13 deliveries before suffering a groin injury, was likely to miss the rest of the three-Test series.

De Silva eventually fell to Saqlain Mushtaq shortly before the close, his chanceless 112 spanning 354 minutes and including 12 boundaries.

 India have appointed Sourav Ganguly captain for next month's one-day series with South Africa, after Sachin Tendulkar's resignation. South Africa hung on to win the first Test in Bombay on Saturday by four wickets, Jacques Kallis and Mark Boucher guiding them past the victory target of 163 after they at one stage slumped to 128 for six.

Mohammad Azharuddin and Sadagopan Ramesh have been brought in for the second Test, which starts on Thursday.

 The Australian captain Steve Waugh has vowed to extend his side's world record of 13 one-day wins on the trot, after Adam Gilchrist's blistering 128 from 98 balls in Christchurch gave them a 3-0 series lead over New Zealand.
