fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Boeing strike goes on
fields.body:
Boeing strike goes on

Striking engineers at aircraft maker Boeing said they would extend their 19-day dispute after the company refused to add to its pay offer.

Three days of talks with a top federal mediator failed to produce a new contract for the second-largest union at Boeing, the Society of Professional Engineering Employees, leaving some 18,000 engineers and technical workers on the picket line indefinitely.

Unions demand fair treatment

Campaigners hope that a special court of appeal hearing into compensation this week will lead to an increase in damages for workplace injuries and illness.

Five judges will consider recommendations from the Law Commission to raise damages in personal injury cases. If the court follows the commission's recommendations, damages will be increased to bring awards into line with inflation.

£100m order for Rolls-Royce

Rolls-Royce looks set to win a £100m order to supply British Midland with engines for its recently ordered Airbus Industrie A330-200s this week. It is expected to announce the deal, along with a 15% rise in pre-tax profits to about £361m, on Thursday.

Windows CE to get upgrade

Microsoft confirmed yesterday at the Cebit fair in Germany that it will launch an upgraded version of its Windows CE software on June 30.

webTitle: Brown tells jobless to fill vacancies

fields.headline: Brown tells jobless to fill vacancies
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is to revive memories of Norman Tebbit's "get on your bike" advice when he tells the unemployed tomorrow that they should take up some of the 1m vacant jobs in Britain.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is to revive memories of Norman Tebbit's "get on your bike" advice when he tells the unemployed tomorrow that they should take up some of the 1m vacant jobs in Britain.

As part of his drive to achieve full employment, the chancellor will publish a treasury study which shows that there are many job vacancies even in areas of high unemployment. A source close to Mr Brown said last night: "At a time when there are 1m vacancies in the economy, and when those vacancies are near places of unemployment, those who could work should work."

The source said that Mr Brown wanted to make clear to the 1.1m people claiming unemployment benefit that help in the future will be provided to "businesses in the poorest areas and not more benefit offices".

The chancellor will demonstrate his concern about possible abuse of unemployment benefit when he tours deprived areas of the country over the next fortnight in the company of the Labour peer Lord Grabiner who is studying ways of clamping down on the black economy. Mr Brown is to visit London, Sunderland, the West Midlands and Liverpool.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, underlined the government's thinking yesterday when he said that ministers expected the unemployed to do more to find work. "In every region of the country there are vacancies running into tens of thousands and we want people who are not in work at the moment to take these jobs," he told GMTV.

However, Mr Byers indicated that next month's budget would aim to provide help for businesses in deprived areas. The chancellor is expected to expand the enterprise management incentive scheme to help smaller businesses. He is also expected to increase the number of managers and employees who will be able to benefit from up to £100,000 in tax-free shares.

Mr Byers said: "There are some regions of the country which clearly are not getting the benefits of the economic prosperity that we're seeing. What we need is an active government policy to make sure that those regions are given more opportunities and that we encourage people to get into jobs which are there."

Mr Byers said: "There are some regions of the country which clearly are not getting the benefits of the economic prosperity that we're seeing. What we need is an active government policy to make sure that those regions are given more opportunities and that we encourage people to get into jobs which are there."

fields.headline: University challenge
fields.standfirst: You don't need a degree to serve a burger. And PAs with BAs are also squandering their talents, says a new report.  Esther Addley disagrees.
fields.trailText: You don't need a degree to serve a burger. And PAs with BAs are also squandering their talents, says a new report. Esther Addley disagrees.
fields.body:
'What do you say when you meet an English graduate?" runs the old joke. "Hamburger and fries, please." It's hardly a witticism of which Oscar Wilde would be proud, but that hasn't stopped generations of maths and science students (not known for their Wildeian wit) retelling it with glee. An arts degree, according to those with more technical skills, prepares you only for a life of menial service jobs. You might be able to throw together a lovely sentence but you're not much qualified for anything else.

A report published last week gives the joke a new punchline: "Ask them to take a memo." Almost a third of workers are overqualified for their jobs, says a study by the centre for economic performance, many of whom have arts degrees. But instead of wasting their qualifications flipping burgers at McDonald's, today's over-educated youth have found a new way to squander their talents. Over-education, says the report, "means exactly what it says - people with more educational qualifications than they need to do their job." And the example the report chooses? Secretaries with degrees. "The graduate secretary will not need any of the skills acquired on a degree course." Working as a PA is a booby-prize job, the report suggests, for graduates who can't find work anywhere else.

These are striking conclusions, not least because they run contrary to the industry consensus on graduate secretaries - that they are more plentiful, more valued and more challenged than ever before. A quarter of administrative and office support staff now hold degrees, and recruitment professionals are keen to assure graduates that this is because the secretarial role has changed beyond recognition, and so is able to attract and retain not only the school-leaver but the president of the university debating society.

But the role of the secretary has always retained a lingering stigma: that those who can, do a "proper" job, those who can't become an admin worker. So does this research finally prove that graduates are wasting three years' education by becoming secretaries?

Emphatically not, say recruitment agencies. "This report implies an outdated view of what a secretary does," says Sarah El Doori of Office Angels. Well of course, as a secretarial employer she would say that. The report even has a name for this kind of thing - "qualifications inflation". This means that companies artificially inflate the skills a particular role demands to attract a better calibre of candidate. "As more people acquire A-levels and degrees, employers narrow the field of candidates by increasing entry requirements. Even if the nature of the job is unchanged, where previously employers might have asked for an A-level as a minimum, they might now ask for a degree." Oh dear. Bad news indeed if you are looking for more from your job than just a bit of cash to pay off the student loan.

But the authors of the report are anxious to qualify their findings, and taking the data at face value, as some press reports have chosen to, is misleading. It is obvious that the diversity of roles within the "secretarial" sector is staggering - ranging from office juniors who sort the post to senior PAs who manage their bosses' workload. Few of these positions demand a detailed knowledge of the later plays of Aphra Behn, or the ability to parse a paragraph. Yet secretarial candidates and recruiters will testify that three years spent learning how to think laterally, act individually and drink liberally are rarely if ever wasted.

Third-level education has boomed in the past two decades - more than a third of school leavers now go on to college - and it is absurd to imagine they can all become doctors and lawyers and do the kind of jobs their grandparents assumed were suitable for "graduates". Lots of them don't want to, either. They want to get a foothold in the media, or work for a charity, or (whisper it) they may even want to become a well-paid administrative professional. Many so-called secretaries have as much responsibility today as would have been carried by middle management a generation ago. Some of them even have maths and science degrees.

fields.headline: Office art
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Few people are lucky enough to have an attractive workplace. One man plans to change that by encouraging British firms to think more imaginatively about their environments. Inspired by New York, where corporate art is a serious and colourful business, Ben Austin has set up a company to persuade British firms to act as patrons to emerging artists.
fields.body:
Few people are lucky enough to have an attractive workplace. One man plans to change that by encouraging British firms to think more imaginatively about their environments. Inspired by New York, where corporate art is a serious and colourful business, Ben Austin has set up a company to persuade British firms to act as patrons to emerging artists.

Corporate art policies are not unknown here. A floor of the BBC's Broadcasting House is decorated with large canvases by students of the London institute. The paintings are for sale, so the Beeb enjoys a lively environment at no expense to the licence-payer, and the artists have the chance to sell to staff and visitors. And City recruitment consultancy Joslin Rowe has long been a patron of abstract painter John Hoyland, whose work decorates its premises.

With a colleague trained at Sotheby's, Austin offers a curating service to advise businesses on looking after any art they already have. But his main purpose is a "bespoke service", commissioning artists to create new work for specific spaces, preferably working from scratch with architects and interior designers.

Unsurprisingly, artists have not been difficult to source. "There has been a deluge," says Austin, who is himself something of an artist, "although not a very good one". He goes talent-spotting at degree shows, guided by "whatever I happen to like". Corporate art, he says, must be accessible and appealing, and "not too controversial". Which is not to say that corporate is necessarily small-minded. Nor is it all image, an aesthetic package to flesh out the corporate typeface and mission statement. Austin describes business patronage as a way for "small and medium companies to give something to the community."

The government seems to agree - from next year there are plans to reward such schemes with tax concessions

webTitle: Budget expected to hold capital gains tax surprises

fields.headline: Budget expected to hold capital gains tax surprises
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's commitment to enterprise will be underscored by radical changes to the capital gains tax regime in next month's Budget, which could go beyond plans already floated.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's commitment to enterprise will be underscored by radical changes to the capital gains tax regime in next month's Budget, which could go beyond plans already floated.

The chancellor believes the move could unleash a wave of venture capital to help small business, especially dot.com firms, realise their potential.

In his pre-Budget report in November, Mr Brown said he was planning to increase the incentives for enterprise by cutting the qualifying period for reduced CGT on business assets from 10 years to five.

But after lengthy consultations with the venture capital industry, he is now understood to be considering shortening the so-called business assets taper to four years.

In an increasingly fast moving economy, Mr Brown believes a shorter qualifying period for the lower 10% CGT rate is more in tune with the time it takes to get a new business up and running.

In a further development which will benefit the fast-growing hi-tech sector, the chancellor is also poised to announce a widening of the scope of CGT incentives by reducing the percentage thresholds for qualifying business asset shareholdings.

Investors now have to own 25% of the equity of a new company to take advantage of the system, a high hurdle which many are reluctant to clear. Full-time employees must own 5% of the equity to qualify for reduced CGT.

To make the system less restrictive, Mr Brown is thinking of cutting both limits to stim ulate investment in hi-tech firms and encourage quality staff to go and work for them.

As part of the build-up to the Budget on March 22, Mr Brown will go on a national tour this week, taking in employment black spots in east London, Sunderland, Sandwell and Liverpool. Treasury sources said the emphasis of the tour would be on promoting enterprise in these areas to lower unemployment.

The treasury is expected to publish research highlighting the fact that the level of vacancies are almost as high as the number of people claiming unemployment benefit.

Initiatives launched by the government to help deprived communities include enterprise management scholarships, which provide subsidised places at business schools for budding entrepreneurs.

fields.headline: I really want to know
fields.standfirst: Lifehouse/Pete Townshend Sadler's Wells ***
fields.trailText: Pete Townshend at Sadler's Wells? The ex-Who star's venue for this performance of the 30-years-in-the-making rock opera Lifehouse was, like its recent broadcast on Radio 3, no accident. Townshend now wishes his work to be measured by classical standards.
fields.body:
Pete Townshend at Sadler's Wells? The ex-Who star's venue for this performance of the 30-years-in-the-making rock opera Lifehouse was, like its recent broadcast on Radio 3, no accident. Townshend now wishes his work to be measured by classical standards.

Here, Who favourites were interposed between orchestral compositions. Behind Townshend wigging out on Who Are You?, the London Chamber Orchestra sat, tapping their feet. In the crowd goatee mixed with mullet as he struggled to define a mature context for an adolescent artform.

Townshend has revived Lifehouse - positing a dystopian millennium whose fragmented society communicates by computer - to place The Who's finest songs "in their original context". But there's little, save Townshend's explanatory links, to generate a sense of "concept". A narrative arc is fleetingly perceptible in the interplay of ballad and rock, orchestra and psychedelia. Elsewhere, one waits for the hits - and it's a bonus to hear them sung by the man who wrote every word.

Lifehouse's guiding ideal is the search for music's transcendence - "the simple secret of the note in us all", according to the deeply hippie Pure and Easy, its defining track. Townshend's enduring curiosity about what makes music tick is admirable - even if the frustrating truth may be that its transcendent moments are essentially arbitrary. There were thrilling peaks but as the gig dragged on beyond three hours, nothing he conjured could rival what should have been its grand finale: in the keyboard refrain of Won't Get Fooled Again.


***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: No permanent solution
fields.standfirst:
Should agencies be paid a hefty fee when their temps are taken on full time? Bill Saunders on how changing an obscure law could shake up the job market.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Should agencies be paid a hefty fee when their temps are taken on full time? Bill Saunders on how changing an obscure law could shake up the job market.
fields.body:
Last week, after intense lobbying from the recruitment industry, the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) announced it was stepping back from its declared intent to abolish outright the secretarial temp-to-perm fee.

This may seem a dull procedural nicety, but the heated debate over temp-to-perm fees threatened to have a significant impact on the secretarial job market. Traditionally it has been the custom that when someone who has been working as a temp is taken on as a full-time employee, the hiring company pays a fee to the agency that originally supplied him or her. These fees are an important source of revenue for the agencies, which have recruited and placed the staff. So when last year the DTI announced its intention to abolish the practice as part of its long-overdue plans to overhaul the legislation governing the recruitment industry, it sparked enormous protest.

The government's rethink on the issue represents a significant success on the part of the lobbying agencies. And indeed the industry's ruling body, the recruitment and employment confederation, has welcomed the decision. But behind the scenes one leading recruitment consultant, who was deeply involved with negotiations on behalf of her own and several other agencies, would only go as far as to say that she felt "reasonably encouraged" by the move. This is because, despite months of uncertainty over whether the legislation would be introduced in the first place, the issue has still not been fully resolved to everyone's satisfaction.

The alternative proposed by the DTI is that if an agency wants to charge a fee, a "waiting period" can be agreed before a temp becomes permanent, during which time the agency receives its temp fee as normal. At the end of the period the temp will be able to transfer freely to the employer's full-time staff. But the department has yet to indicate how long a waiting period it will consider reasonable.

The DTI has argued that insisting on a fee when a temp is taken on full-time deters employers from transferring temporary workers to permanent status, and that in some instances employers have dismissed temps rather than pay the fee. The employment agencies' were sceptical that this occurs on a large scale, and pointed to the example of Belgium, where similar legislation resulted in agencies folding and the survivors cutting back on temps' benefits, such as training.

The managing director of one London secretarial consultancy claims that many of her clients have promised to continue to pay the fee regardless of how the law is finally resolved. Certainly the current system facilitates an efficient form of recruiting for both employer and employee. And, argues the industry, it is a more just one, too. Temps who might be unfairly, but quite legally, discriminated against in applying for permanent positions at least have a chance to get their foot in the door and prove themselves.

The industry considers the fee its due. It argues that the cost of finding, interviewing and training temps is one that it should be able to recoup. Temps are its main asset, it argues, so why should it part with them for nothing, or go to the trouble of recruiting and training them if they will be continually poached?

But as some temps will testify, employers can be unwilling to play ball. Karen Howard, a PA who started work at a PR company three months ago, says she has been left in limbo because her manager is reluctant to pay the agency fee. "My boss took me on with every intention of giving me a permanent job, but she has delayed over giving me a contract because of the fee involved."

Howard got the job after her agency faxed through her CV on spec. "My boss has a small business with a really tight cash flow, and her argument is that it is a bit much for the agency to expect £3,000 for faxing through my CV. I have sympathy with her, but working without a contract when you know the firm might go bust at any point puts me in a precarious position." Her experience of a less than scrupulous manager underlines how important it is for temps that lingering uncertainty is resolved.

Certainly there are good arguments on both sides, and the DTI's attempt to find a compromise to satisfy everyone has required some subtle arbitration. Perhaps the best that can be said, yet again, is that both temps and agencies must wait to see how this new compromise will work in practice.

webTitle: Take up your sick bed and work

fields.headline: Take up your sick bed and work
fields.standfirst:
Absenteeism is costing the nation's businesses £10bn a year. As a result, some companies are taking a greater interest when their employees call in ill. Kate Hilpern reports.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Unless you happen to work for a pharmacist, it's a safe bet that your boss will be delighted to see the end of the flu epidemic. After fielding countless sniffling phonecalls from staff croaking that they really, honestly, can't make it in to the office, employers are looking forward to having a full complement of staff once again.
fields.body:
Unless you happen to work for a pharmacist, it's a safe bet that your boss will be delighted to see the end of the flu epidemic. After fielding countless sniffling phonecalls from staff croaking that they really, honestly, can't make it in to the office, employers are looking forward to having a full complement of staff once again.

They shouldn't get excited too soon, however. Latest reports reveal that absenteeism is now one of the biggest problems facing the British workplace - whether or not we're at the height of the flu season. In a study by Gee Publishing, 40% of the 311 companies polled said that absence levels had risen during the previous three years, and one in five said absence was a major problem. In response, many companies are putting in place new and often controversial measures to persuade their employees to come to work.

It's not difficult to see why employers are concerned about staff taking sickies. The financial consequences are severe - absenteeism can cost a company 3% of its payroll, a national total of more than £10bn a year, according to the CBI. To persuade staff to make that little bit more effort to get into work, the Institute of Personnel and Development (IPD) has found that many employers are making sweeping changes in their procedure for employees calling in sick, as well as in the content of their return-to-work interviews. Some organisations are even providing a figure for the number of "acceptable" days' absence, which raises the rather alarming prospect of workers having to drag themselves out of their wheelchairs once they have exceeded their monthly backache quota.

Richard Stafford, a business psychologist specialising in human resources policies, insists that quotas don't work like that. "It's simply a case of monitoring patterns of absence so that it is brought to employers' attention if, say, an employee is off sick for eight occasional Mondays in four months. In turn, they can take this up with the member of staff. It is a very successful method of preventing unnecessary absence." Such surveys have turned up the entirely unsurprising evidence that most "sickies" are taken on a Monday after a long weekend overindulging, or to cover a pre-planned long weekend break.

"We decided to be proactive about absence because we only have 200 staff and so it has a major impact on day-to-day business," says Deirdre Devereux, administrator services manager at Marsden Building Society. This involved the company taking the radical step of paying staff not to be ill. Workers with a full attendance during the year now receive a £100 bonus.

This form of inducement is catching on. Absence levels at some Tesco stores had reached 11% when the company started dangling the promise of bonuses before staff tempted to take time off. But more important, according to Keith Luxton, group human resources manager, was understanding why people were taking time off in the first place, and developing better ways to deal with absenteeism as it happens.

"When someone phones in sick, do they speak to someone trained in managing absence? When they return to work, are they interviewed about what was wrong with them, whether they are well enough to be back at work and if there is anything the company can do to prevent it happening again?" he asks. "In an attempt to address these issues, we organised workshops on absence and how to manage it. The result is that absence has halved in some stores."

Companies that have been most successful in tackling these questions are the ones that have considered the role of support staff and not just managers, according to Angela Baron, employee resourcing adviser at the IPD. "It's very often the PA or secretary who takes the calls from staff who aren't coming in, who fills out the relevant forms on their return, and who monitors the total number of days they take off," she explains.

When it comes to taking a sneaky day off, Baron has found that support staff are often seen as a "soft touch". Sheepish hungover workers hoping not to have to explain themselves to their boss ask to speak to the secretary instead. "If the secretary is clued up on managing sickness, the member of staff might think twice about making the call," says Baron.

These techniques, however, are not without their sceptics. Dr Martyn Dyer-Smith, principal psychologist at the university of Northumbria at Carlisle and specialist in absence, is one of them. He believes the fact that about 38% of companies now have absence monitoring systems in place may be counter-productive. "The point should not be getting staff to take as few days off as possible. The point should be getting them to be as productive as possible. Monitoring dehumanises the workforce, and the systems that companies are putting in place as a result of the monitoring seem to be based on fear and bribery, whereas any attempt to make staff want to be at work should first and foremost find out why they are not."

Tesco, of course, would claim that's exactly what its back-to-work interviews strive to achieve. But Dyer-Smith claims a deeper exploration is required into the very culture of the organisation. Certain sectors and companies, for example, are more prone to absence than others. Larger companies of more than 1,000 employees average 10 days absence per employee a year, a level almost twice that of smaller companies, while the public sector reports 10.4 days of absence compared with 6.2 days in the businesses services sector. Dyer-Smith believes the reasons are down to company culture.

"The larger the company, the more likely it is that its employees feel anonymous - a very common reason for absence. As for the differences between public and private sector, these are closely associated with national attitudes. People are happy to cheat the taxman but not their neighbour, and will steal public property but not their neighbour's property. It's as if they believe 'public' means 'not belonging to anyone'. No wonder, then, that they feel less guilty about taking sick days."

Introducing flexible working is, according to Dr Joan Harvey, the best way of decreasing absenteeism. Harvey is a chartered psychologist at the university of Newcastle-Upon-Tyne and research specialist in absenteeism. "If you have a hangover, you don't feel as if you need to take the whole day off," she explains. "You can simply come in a couple of hours late and it's acceptable. Everybody feels respected and everybody wins."

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: After decades of battling for equality, women are still earning less than men, according to recent government figures which show that, on average, women still earn only around 81p for every £1 that men earn.
fields.byline: Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine
fields.body:
 UNFAIR PAY

After decades of battling for equality, women are still earning less than men, according to recent government figures which show that, on average, women still earn only around 81p for every £1 that men earn.

The picture is even worse for female part-time workers, who bring home 60% of men's full-time hourly rate. This will be one of the key issues on the agenda at the TUC women's conference in March, where a new report "Fair Pay for Women Now!" will be launched. See www.tuc.org.uk for more information.

 ONLINE NANNIES

Having trouble organising your childcare? A new website from Top Notch Nannies has information about nannies, maternity nurses, babysitters and other childcare professionals. The site offers an interactive section where parents can get advice on childcare provision, and you can even apply for a nanny online. See www.topnotchnannies.com

 DOCUMENT DISPOSAL

A rap on the knuckles from manufacturer Rexel, which says that we are too careless with sensitive documents, putting them in the bin rather than disposing of them safely. Only a quarter of firms with a turnover of more than £1m are satisfied that their business disposes of confidential material safely, says the company. To help firms, Rexel has produced a free booklet, Secrets and Shredders. For a copy, email your details, quoting the reference "shredder booklet", to businessmachines@acco-uk.co.uk

 PEN PINCHING

How many times a day do you make a trip to the stationery cupboard having discovered that all the pens have vanished from your desk? Office supplier OfficeSMART has studied the phenomenon of disappearing desktop items, polling companies around the UK to discover which objects are most favoured by lightfingered colleagues. Unsurprisingly, pens came top of the list, followed by staplers, hole punches and scissors. The company even enlisted a behavioural psychologist to identify the type of person most likely to run off with your ruler and pinch your Post-It notes. Better keep a sharp eye on your colleagues!

 THE LONGEST DAY

The long hours culture is still alive and well, according to Tricia Jackson, author of Career Development, the latest good practice guide from the Institute of Personnel and Development. "Employees seem to be working longer hours, with unwanted additional responsibilities, under more pressure to achieve stringent targets," says Jackson. The book is available at £9.99 from the IPD, tel 020 8263 3387.

fields.headline: Rapid rebuttal
fields.standfirst: How to cope with office gossip
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: How to cope with office gossip
fields.body:
Office gossip can be vicious, hurtful, and extremely entertaining. Spreading malicious rumours used to take guile and planning but even that skill has now been made virtually effort-free, thanks to the internet.

E-mailing sleaze stories means you reach the maximum audience for the minimum trouble. Using someone else's e-mail address to send them from will provide the perfect cover, and that way you can get two victims at one time, watching the fur fly as the subject of the gossip confronts the address owner.

Being the victim is a whole heap less funny, though. Whether the rumours circulating about you are true or not is borderline irrelevant. What matters is the damage they can cause in terms of reputation, embarrassment and/or career.

Quashing the stories Office gossip brings out a tendency to over-react and the more shocking the rumours the more knee-jerk the reaction. Bide your time. Accept the fact that the first three revenge tactics you consider will be overwhelmingly stupid.

Imagine, for instance, someone is spreading gossip that you are having an affair with the boss. Spontaneous solutions will probably include any or all of the following:  Shoot the messenger. An intense and overriding hatred for the person who brought the rumour to your attention, resulting in a falling-out of epic proportions.

 Confront the perpetrator in public. This will provide great spectator sport for the rest of the workforce, who are probably bored out of their skulls and happy to watch a bit of blood-letting. Expecting a confession is a bit ripe, though. Instead of the cry 'It's a fair cop, guv!', guarantee you will be met by a blank stare and the comment 'That wasn't me.', at which point you are essentially stuffed unless you have the entire conversation down on tape.  Talk to the boss. But remember to brace yourself for the look of distaste that will cross his or her face. Telling him or her that there are rumours the pair of you are at it like rabbits will only bring on one of two responses: a) Flickering distrust in case you are saying this in the hope that he or she may recognise your potential as a couple and making a pass, or: b) The green light to make a pass him or herself.

 Make a public denial. The more you think about this idea the better it sounds. You see yourself picking a small space in the middle of the open-plan office, and then clearing your throat to attract pin-drop attention from your colleagues before letting rip in a voice laden with sarcasm and venom: 'It has been brought to my attention that I am having a torrid affair with Nigel Waterbottom. This has come as a complete surprise to both of us because I am happily married and also well aware - as are you all - of Nigel's little personal hygiene problem....' etc.

This tactic is laden with problems, though, the biggest being that you will inadvertently be spreading your own rumour. Count on it that not everyone will have been aware of your alleged liaison until you mouthed off. Remember Tara Palmer-Tompkinson's denial in the press that there was anything going on between her and Prince William? Or last Sunday's tabloid comment from Will MacDonald: 'I shared a hotel room with Chris Evans...but not a bed'. But had anyone even got wind of this gossip before these two denials?

Gossip survival  Stay cool. Everyone will be interested in your first response to the rumours, as this will make or break them. Ranting, shouting or fierce denials may be viewed as signs of guilt. Look surprised or amused and then signal disinterest.

 Do not change your behaviour. If you have a friendly relationship with the person you are supposed to be having the affair with then carry on as norm. Ignoring or avoiding them will look suspicious.

 As will suddenly referring to your real partner more than usual. Only instigate smoochy office phone calls to him or her if that is normal behaviour.

 Do not retaliate. Getting into a fight with pigs only ensures you get all dirty, too.

 Remember the motto the royals use in similar circumstances: "Never explain, never complain".

fields.headline: Pru joins Equitable's predators
fields.trailText: The Prudential is among a number of insurers considering making a bid for the troubled Equitable Life - a mutual which has 600,000 members who could qualify for a windfall payout if a takeover were to succeed.
fields.body:
The Prudential is among a number of insurers considering making a bid for the troubled Equitable Life - a mutual which has 600,000 members who could qualify for a windfall payout if a takeover were to succeed.

Prudential is understood to have asked American investment bank Morgan Stanley to advise on the possibility of a bid - which could top £4bn.

Other insurers thought to be interested in Equitable include French-owned Sun Life & Provincial and Standard Life, which is facing a chal lenge to its mutual status too from policyholders eager to force the insurer to hand out its reserves. European insurers such as Germany's Allianz and Dutch insurer Aegon are also likely suitors.

Equitable insists that demutualisation is not on the agenda, but the insurer may be forced into a change of heart if it loses an appeal to the House of Lords in the summer.

When rates were high in the 1980s Equitable promised high, guaranteed annuity rates to 90,000 pension investors. But when rates fell, the society cut rates and investors took Equitable to court.

Last September the high court upheld Equitable's action but last month, the court of appeal ruled that it should honour its guarantees. The society is now appealing to the law lords.

But analysts have calculated that if the society loses it could face a £1.5bn bill and be forced to put itself up for sale in order to meet its obligations.

The bad publicity associated with the legal action is already affecting the society; Equitable's new business levels have been badly hit.

Yesterday a spokesman for the Pru refused to comment on the speculation about Eq uitable Life. But it is understood that the company believes Equitable offers an opportunity which cannot be ignored. Despite the legal furore Equitable is still a leading pensions brand. It has very low costs - partially as a result of paying far lower commissions to salesmen.

The Pru, which bought rival mutual Scottish Amicable three years ago, would be ready to move in on the society as soon as the House of Lords case is over. As a mutual, a hostile bid would mean going directly to the society's 600,000 members, a potentially very expensive exercise.

fields.headline: Labours of love
fields.standfirst: Michael Pennington discovered a passion for Shakespeare in his teens. He talks to  Michael Billlington about his life with the bard.
fields.trailText: Michael Pennington reckons he could have been Britain's richest teenager. Back in the 50s, ITV presented a quiz-show called Double Your Money, the Who Wants to Be a Millionaire of its day. One contestant chose Shakespeare as his special subject, but flunked the final question on Measure for Measure that would have netted him £64,000.
fields.body:
Michael Pennington reckons he could have been Britain's richest teenager. Back in the 50s, ITV presented a quiz-show called Double Your Money, the Who Wants to Be a Millionaire of its day. One contestant chose Shakespeare as his special subject, but flunked the final question on Measure for Measure that would have netted him £64,000.

The 14-year-old Pennington, having got all the previous questions right, was on the edge of his sofa yelling the answer at the screen. "What a misspent youth," he now says, "having an encyclopedic knowledge of Shakespeare!" As my eyes shoot up, he admits, "No, I'm not being quite sincere, am I?"

He sure isn't. Shakespeare, for much of Pennington's working life, has been his mission and his meal-ticket. He has played Hamlet - one of the best I've seen - for the RSC, along with Berowne, Hector and both Angelo and the Duke in Measure for Measure. With Michael Bogdanov, he founded and ran the piratical English Shakespeare Company in the 80s.

Currently he's polishing up his Stratford Timon of Athens for a Barbican opening on Wednesday, while correcting the proofs for his wise, witty book Twelfth Night: A User's Guide, to be published in April. He's the nearest equivalent to Granville-Barker in our own day: an actor-scholar who brings to Shakespeare a wealth of practical experience.

For Pennington, playing Timon is the accidental fulfilment of a dream: he took over after Alan Bates pulled out with a chest illness. "One night last summer," he says, "I was going to see a friend in Phantom of the Opera. Just before going in, I checked my phone for messages and found one from Greg Doran, the Stratford director, who was remarkably cool, asking if I was in the country. I found he was offering me Timon, with three weeks to go before the first preview! Within 36 hours I was in rehearsal.

"To me it's incredibly sentimental because I was in the 1965 Stratford production with Scofield. I had a line and a half, watched Scofield from the wings every night and thought, 'I'd love to do this one day when I'm grown up'. Little did I know that the next Timon on the main Stratford stage, 34 years later, would be me."

Timon is one of Shakespeare's oddest heroes: a spendthrift who, when times turn hard and his chums desert him, transforms into a railing misanthrope. Watching Timon of Athens, said theatre critic Tynan of Mayfair, is "like going to some scandalously sophisticated party at which, halfway through, the host falls down drunk and begins to rave from under the piano". But Pennington, with his excavating intelligence, thinks there's infinitely more to the play than that.

"On first sight," he says, "it's the story of a man who goes on an extraordinary journey from Camelot to Cardboard City. But I think there is a positive idealism in him that makes him a major Shakespearean figure. He's a champagne socialist who believes that if you're lucky enough to be born rich you must share it. There's a genuine public spiritedness about him which is slightly absurd. What's interesting is the way that turns into its opposite.

"We're playing it Jacobean but, in a curious way, it reminds me of the 60s. One of the most potent images of that period is the face of the mass-killer, Charles Manson, coming out at you like Jim Morrison, who was a cultural hero. I see the play as an extension of that idea: a study of what happens when idealism goes sour. Except that in the end Timon achieves a provisional salvation. He faces down his demons and there's a sort of exhilarating peace about the conclusion that seems to me completely Shakespearean. Like Richard II, Timon reconstructs his personality to become a human being."

Pennington's love-affair with Shakespeare - he compares it to a marriage, in that you have periods of acrimony and fatigue but you keep coming back - dates from childhood. He was taken by his parents - his father was a Chancery lawyer - to see an Old Vic Macbeth and, on coming home, instantly started to act out the play. By 15 he had seen virtually the entire canon. But Pennington's missionary Bardic zeal is combined with an awareness that Shakespeare, like Homer, occasionally nodded.

Both qualities come out in his book on Twelfth Night, which is studded with self-critical accounts of the productions he has directed for the ESC and for companies in Tokyo and Chicago. Pennington writes movingly of Shakespeare's "transforming power": he cites the example of a high-security prisoner playing Caliban in an ESC workshop, "his poetry a tangible defiance of the fact that he couldn't see over a wall a few feet away". He also writes, with crucifying accuracy, about Shakespeare's tendency to hammer home a gag and about the plot-delaying procrastination of the sadistic scene in Twelfth Night where Feste taunts the imprisoned Malvolio. Only a true lover, you feel, could write so unsparingly about his mistress's faults.

Oddly, for a man so variously talented, Pennington has no further plans to direct or write. He loves acting, has Antony, Lear and Prospero in his sights and wouldn't mind a crack at Ibsen, Strindberg and more Eduardo de Filippo: he did Filumena for the Peter Hall Company and was mortified when it closed. He gets a bit pissed off at being told he should direct: it is, he says, "rather like an electrician being proposed a carpentry course". And, having written four books, including a practical guide to Hamlet, he feels that's it. "All I do in these books," he says, "is tap into the energy of the play. The Hamlet book was relatively easy to write because the play has such narrative pulse. Twelfth Night was more difficult because it's elusive, impressionistic, and it's hard to find the play's moral register. At one point I was in despair but I hope I've now cracked it."

My own hope is that he can be forced back to his word-processor: he's too good a writer to waste. As an actor, he's also a rare example of a vanishing breed: the predominantly classical performer who can make old texts live in the present. He's done his share of telly and the odd movie but his natural stamping-ground is the classical stage where lung capacity has to be matched to psychological penetration. In Timon, if Stratford is anything to go by, he not only restores a neglected play but seems to be gearing himself up to play a most uncivil Lear. Just as well he wasn't a schoolboy millionaire quiz-kid after all.

Shakespeare, for much of Pennington's working life, has been his mission and his meal-ticket. With Michael Bogdanov, he founded and ran the piratical English Shakespeare Company in the 80s. Currently he's polishing up his Stratford Timon of Athens for a Barbican opening on Wednesday, while correcting the proofs for his wise, witty book Twelfth Night: A User's Guide, to be published in April. He's the nearest equivalent to Granville-Barker in our own day: an actor-scholar who brings to Shakespeare a wealth of practical experience. For Pennington, playing Timon is the accidental fulfilment of a dream: he took over after Alan Bates pulled out with a chest illness. "One night last summer," he says, "I was going to see a friend in Phantom of the Opera. Just before going in, I checked my phone for messages and found one from Greg Doran, the Stratford director, who was remarkably cool, asking if I was in the country. I found he was offering me Timon, with three weeks to go before the first preview! Within 36 hours I was in rehearsal. "To me it's incredibly sentimental because I was in the 1965 Stratford production with Scofield. I had a line and a half, watched Scofield from the wings every night and thought, 'I'd love to do this one day when I'm grown up'. Little did I know that the next Timon on the main Stratford stage, 34 years later, would be me." Timon is one of Shakespeare's oddest heroes: a spendthrift who, when times turn hard and his chums desert him, transforms into a railing misanthrope. Watching Timon of Athens, said theatre critic Tynan of Mayfair, is "like going to some scandalously sophisticated party at which, halfway through, the host falls down drunk and begins to rave from under the piano". But Pennington, with his excavating intelligence, thinks there's infinitely more to the play than that. "On first sight," he says, "it's the story of a man who goes on an extraordinary journey from Camelot to Cardboard City. But I think there is a positive idealism in him that makes him a major Shakespearean figure. He's a champagne socialist who believes that if you're lucky enough to be born rich you must share it. There's a genuine public spiritedness about him which is slightly absurd. What's interesting is the way that turns into its opposite. "We're playing it Jacobean but, in a curious way, it reminds me of the 60s. One of the most potent images of that period is the face of the mass-killer, Charles Manson, coming out at you like Jim Morrison, who was a cultural hero. I see the play as an extension of that idea: a study of what happens when idealism goes sour. Except that in the end Timon achieves a provisional salvation. He faces down his demons and there's a sort of exhilarating peace about the conclusion that seems to me completely Shakespearean. Like Richard II, Timon reconstructs his personality to become a human being." Pennington's love-affair with Shakespeare - he compares it to a marriage, in that you have periods of acrimony and fatigue but you keep coming back - dates from childhood. He was taken by his parents - his father was a Chancery lawyer - to see an Old Vic Macbeth and, on coming home, instantly started to act out the play. By 15 he had seen virtually the entire canon. But Pennington's missionary Bardic zeal is combined with an awareness that Shakespeare, like Homer, occasionally nodded. Both qualities come out in his book on Twelfth Night, which is studded with self-critical accounts of the productions he has directed for the ESC and for companies in Tokyo and Chicago. Pennington writes movingly of Shakespeare's "transforming power": he cites the example of a high-security prisoner playing Caliban in an ESC workshop, "his poetry a tangible defiance of the fact that he couldn't see over a wall a few feet away". He also writes, with crucifying accuracy, about Shakespeare's tendency to hammer home a gag and about the plot-delaying procrastination of the sadistic scene in Twelfth Night where Feste taunts the imprisoned Malvolio. Only a true lover, you feel, could write so unsparingly about his mistress's faults. Oddly, for a man so variously talented, Pennington has no further plans to direct or write. He loves acting, has Antony, Lear and Prospero in his sights and wouldn't mind a crack at Ibsen, Strindberg and more Eduardo de Filippo: he did Filumena for the Peter Hall Company and was mortified when it closed. He gets a bit pissed off at being told he should direct: it is, he says, "rather like an electrician being proposed a carpentry course". And, having written four books, including a practical guide to Hamlet, he feels that's it. "All I do in these books," he says, "is tap into the energy of the play. The Hamlet book was relatively easy to write because the play has such narrative pulse. Twelfth Night was more difficult because it's elusive, impressionistic, and it's hard to find the play's moral register. At one point I was in despair but I hope I've now cracked it." My own hope is that he can be forced back to his word-processor: he's too good a writer to waste. As an actor, he's also a rare example of a vanishing breed: the predominantly classical performer who can make old texts live in the present. He's done his share of telly and the odd movie but his natural stamping-ground is the classical stage where lung capacity has to be matched to psychological penetration. In Timon, if Stratford is anything to go by, he not only restores a neglected play but seems to be gearing himself up to play a most uncivil Lear. Just as well he wasn't a schoolboy millionaire quiz-kid after all.

fields.headline: Electric and Current
fields.standfirst: Wire Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: Few bands have survived the process of reforming and kept their original allure. But Wire are old hands at this game, having already reconvened for a period during the late-80s, a partially successful experiment that dissipated amidst those perennial musical/personal differences. This first performance in 10 years vindicates their decision to return yet again. Wire's clipped, impressionistic art-pop was inspired by punk but always more ambiguous, this was hardly a greatest hits-fest. It didn't need to be: playing a set of songs written for the most part over 20 years ago, Wire still possess more currency than most groups half their age. Opening with the title track from their debut album "Pink Flag", they embrace material from the first two periods of their history, plus a new composition, "Art of Persistence", which happily straddles both.

Opening with the title track from their debut album "Pink Flag", they embrace material from the first two periods of their history, plus a new composition, "Art of Persistence", which happily straddles both.

The presence of Robert Gotobed is vital. A great minimalist drummers, Gotobed was marginalised from the '80s Wire as the group became more in thrall to synthesised instruments and computerised methods of recording. Tonight, however, Wire are synthetic-free, but utterly modern, a testimony to the prescience of their core sound. The appearance of dancer Michael Clark around a disquieting rendition of "Heartbeat" proves Wire are as disinclined as ever to conform.

fields.headline: Schubert Ensemble
fields.standfirst:
***
Purcell Room, London
fields.trailText: With a line-up identical to that of Schubert's Trout Quintet - piano and four strings including double bass - the Schubert Ensemble inevitably spends most of its time exploring 19th-century chamber music. But it has a valiant history of performing new works too, and this Purcell Room appearance was turned into a showcase.
fields.body:
With a line-up identical to that of Schubert's Trout Quintet - piano and four strings including double bass - the Schubert Ensemble inevitably spends most of its time exploring 19th-century chamber music. But it has a valiant history of performing new works too, and this Purcell Room appearance was turned into a showcase of seven of the scores (from a grand total of more than 25) it has commissioned, ranging from a Michael Berkeley piece of 1985 to two premieres of works by composers still in their early 20s.

Berkeley's tightly structured From the Savage Messiah, a homage to the French sculptor Gaudier-Brzeska, is a fierce, impressive piece, extracting far more from the prescribed instrumentation than the salon niceties that some of the other composers in the programme produced. Graham Fitkin's MacGuffin was like comfort food - bland, doughy and of low nutritional value - while Piers Hellawell's The Building of Curves masked its commonplaces in over-written textures and redundant figuration. At least both Howard Skempton's tiny Spadesbourne Suite and Martin Butler's American Rounds set out unashamedly to ingratiate themselves, and did so in a modest and accomplished way.

The brand-new works could hardly have been more different. Undoings, by the Oxford undergraduate Lee Dunleavy, was a nicely imagined essay in texture, its silence-punctuated gestures owing quite bit to the example of Wolfgang Rihm; for someone whose research interest is Brian Ferneyhough, Dunleavy's music is surprisingly visceral in its impact. But Edward Rushton's L'An Mil, a vision of the turning of the last millennium rather than the recent one, set out from a very different stylistic position, with string and piano figuration that unmistakably echoed Debussy and Ravel; the way that Rushton tied the threads of his piece together to make a perfectly balanced whole, though, revealed a genuinely contemporary sense of form.
